HEADLINE: Alternatives to CD's

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Low interest rates have left many bank customers scrambling to find safe investments that pay higher returns than savings accounts. A higher return means taking increased risks, and savers should know what the risks are before they take their money out of certificates of deposit, savings accounts or bank money-market accounts and thus give up Federal deposit insurance protection. Here are some alternative investments and their risks.
 
Alternative Risk 

Money funds Like bank money-market accounts, but they pay dividends, not interest, and are fairly safe, with principal guaranteed by the sponsor, usually a brokerage. No money fund has ever failed.
 
Common stocks: Risk lies in selecting stocks that are not overpriced and thus are likely to increase in value.
 
Bonds: Debt issued by companies and governments. The safest are United States Treasury bonds; they pay the lowest returns, but are exempt from state and local taxes. Before buying a state, local or corporate bond, check the issuer's credit rating in Standard & Poor's or Moody's Investors Service.
 
Mutual funds: They invest in products like stocks, bonds and mortgages, and sell shares in their portfolios. Share prices can go down and investors can lose money. Some funds specialize in growth stocks, in blue-chip stocks, in stocks that offer relatively steady returns, or in other types of business.
 
(Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla.)

PEACE SUMMIT AT U.N.
Proclaiming renewed hopes for a safer world, leaders of the 15 nations on the United Nations Security Council met jointly and said they would devote their energies to preserving peace. They asked the new Secretary General to draft proposals to make the U.N. a potent peacemaker in trouble spots worldwide. 1

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Filing is Made By T.W.A.

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Trying to avoid the fate of competitors that have been forced to liquidate, Trans World Airlines Inc. made an unusual Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing yesterday that is likely to rid it of $1 billion of debt and give it a good chance to survive.
T.W.A. will continue to fly while it operates under court protection, and its passengers are not expected to notice any changes in service. T.W.A. said that all previously issued tickets and frequent-flier miles would be honored and that all existing flights would continue. The bankruptcy filing does not entail any layoffs or cutbacks. 
 The filing, made in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., resembles a so-called prepackaged bankruptcy in that the airline enters the proceedings with agreements in place from its creditors to reduce its debt and cut its interest expenses by $160 million.
 
Owned by Icahn
 The bankruptcy filing had been expected since July, when the airline's chairman, Carl C. Icahn, averted a showdown with creditors that could have resulted in the seizure of many of its planes. The filing opens a new chapter in the history of an airline that once spanned the globe and had Howard Hughes as its major stockholder.
T.W.A. has not been a public company . since 1988, when Mr. Icahn took it private in a leveraged buyout. At the time, he took out $469 million in cash for himself while adding greatly to the company's debt.
By last year Mr. Icahn had become disillusioned with the airline, which suffered huge losses during the Persian Gulf crisis, when fuel prices doubled and the number of passengers plunged. To raise cash, he sold off the airline's prized London routes.
T.W.A. follows several other American airlines into bankruptcy court in recent years, including two that are still flying, Continental and America West, and three that have been or are being liquidated: Eastern, Pan Am and Midway.
Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, said that while the filing would enable T.W.A. to get through the next year, which is expected to be a difficult one for the industry, the airline's long-term prospects remained in doubt.
"He's not out of the woods yet," said Mr. Murphy, who was at a news conference held by Mr. Icahn and his top managers at the St. Regis Hotel in midtown Manhattan. Mr. Murphy noted that T.W.A.'s fleet of 194 planes was one of the industry's oldest, averaging about 16 years. The industry average is about 10.5 years.
Mark Buckstein, the head counsel for T.W.A., estimated that the carrier should emerge from under Chapter 11 in about six months.
T.W.A. was unable to complete all the papers and agreements in time for a formal prepackaged bankruptcy deal. A delay would have pushed the filing into April, analysts said, when traffic picks up and a move into bankruptcy court might have hurt bookings.
 
Creditors Go Along
 Most bankruptcy filings result in the company's management and creditors haggling, sometimes for months or years, over how much each side will give up in reaching a plan to reorganize the bankrupt company and emerge from court protection.
But Mr. Icahn was able to persuade all of T.W.A.'s main groups of creditors to go along with his plan, stressing that weakening the airline more could leave bondholders with little. He enticed them with a plan to go after business travelers with lower fares and he also agreed to help build up T.W.A.'s cash with about $35 million of his own money.
Mr. Icahn has portrayed himself as an industry maverick who, instead of ordering new planes and loading his company with additional debt, held back and now has all the old planes he needs at low lease rates.
The airline's filing is different from those made by carriers like Pan Am, which was close to running out of cash when it filed for protection last January and ended up being liquidated.
Wilbur Ross, the lawyer who represented bondholders in the negotiations with T.W.A.'s management, said the carrier had $500 million in cash and would have an additional $300 million once it completed the sale of several international routes and its Travel Channel, a cable television service with news and features about travel. It will also arrange $200 million of "debtor in possession financing" with various banks. Lenders of such financing are first in line to be repaid.
 
Cash From Other Unit
 Mr. Icahn said he was prepared to dip into the funds of his other companies, chiefly ACF Industries, a leasing and rail transportation company, to put up the $200 million in financing. That move is a fairly safe bet for him, since he would be paid off first in the event that T.W.A. is eventually liquidated.
T.W.A. also said it had completed an agreement with its largest union, the machinists, making it likely that it will have labor peace with those workers until at least 1995.
In return for wage increases of 18 to 20 percent over the next two and a half years, the airline won changes in work rules to improve productivity and will receive some concessions on its health-care costs. A protracted strike by machinists played a role in forcing Eastern to liquidate early in 1991.
Mr. Icahn has prided himself in not having ordered many new planes, since he has been able to get older planes at leases of up to 70 percent less than a year before, cutting his operating costs.
But Mr. Murphy said that many of the planes would not be able to meet coming Federal noise standards and would have to be retired or have their engines modified at considerable cost. The agreement leaves T.W.A. bondholders with big losses, with the total debt of $1.7 billion to be cut by $1 billion. Under the agreement, bondholders holding 15 percent notes agreed to have the amount owed lowered to $215 million, from $231.4 million, at an interest rate of 8 3/4 percent.
The holders of $334 million in 16 and 17 percent bonds will give up $105 million in return for 35 percent of an issue of new common stock, while the remaining $229 million of bonds will pay an interest rate of 8 percent. These holders, however, were able to have their bonds backed by collateral, including planes and engines.
 
The Biggest Risk
 The holders of $607 million in 12 percent bonds will take the biggest risk, since they agreed to take common stock, the value of which will depend on how well the airline can leave its troubles behind.
The largest T.W.A. creditors are Chemical Banking; Fleet National Bank of Providence, R.I., and Worldspan L.P. of Atlanta.
Mr. Icahn and his managers said they had hoped to file a prepackaged bankruptcy under which a company can emerge from court quickly, having agreed in advance on a reorganization plan. Mr. Ross said that the negotiations were delayed by discussions over what planes and engines would serve as collateral.
Mr. Icahn said that the carrier would concentrate on attracting business travelers with lower fares. He also disclosed that the airline would acquire 40 used McDonnell Douglas DC-9's to improve service at Kennedy International Airport, from which the airline operates most of its international flights. Its main domestic hub is at St. Louis.
Domestic flights to Kennedy are now used mostly to bring passengers from around the country to connect with international flights. Mr. Icahn hopes that by increasing the frequency of domestic flights from points like St. Louis, and by lowering fares, that business flyers will begin using the airline to fly to New York.
He also said he would run the risk of a proxy fight in a year if the five nonmanagement members of the Trans World board wanted to put up an alternative slate to replace the six managment directors. He said the company would pay the outside members to wage the proxy fight if they chose to do so.
Mr. Icahn will also end up owning from 15 to 40 percent of the common stock, since he is a major holder of the 12 percent bonds.
He said that he lost money on the bonds. "T.W.A. bonds are the worst investment I made in a decade," he said, smiling.
Mr. Icahn gained control of T.W.A. in 1985 in a bitter fight for control with Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation. With major concessions and good will from its unions, the carrier did well for a few years. It even acquired Ozark Airlines to strenghten its St. Louis hub.
Mr. Icahn and his staff also proved adept at switching planes to domestic service and to the Caribbean at a time when terrorist attacks caused a sharp drop in international travel.
After selling the London routes last year, Mr. Icahn sought to sell the airline, but found no takers. Since then he has worked to lower debt and expenses in the hope that T.W.A. could struggle along until an economic recovery might spur interest from other airlines.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT AT THE U.N.;
WORLD LEADERS, AT THE U.N., PLEDGE TO EXPAND ITS ROLE TO ACHIEVE A LASTING PEACE

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Proclaiming that the cold war's end has raised hopes for a safer, more equitable and humane world, leaders of the 15 countries on the United Nations Security Council pledged today to strengthen the United Nations and play a larger role in its peacekeeping operations.
President Bush, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and other leaders, who were attending the first meeting of the Security Council at the head-of-Government level, asked the new United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Ghali, to make proposals this summer for strengthening the United Nations' capacity for resolving escalating disputes before they turn violent. They also asked for proposals on expanding the organization's ability to preserve peace in trouble spots across the globe. 
 The Council declaration said the spread of democracy and respect for human rights would play a critical role in making the world a safer place in the post-cold-war era. And they called for firm new steps to halt the spread of weapons of mass destruction as well as for cuts in all nations' arsenals. [Text of the declaration and excerpts from speeches, pages 4 and 5.]
 
Day of Lofty Speeches
 The Council's daylong meeting here brought together President Bush, Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of France, Britain and China -- the permanent Security Council members with a special responsibility for preserving peace under the Charter.
Also attending the summit meeting were the Government leaders of Japan, Austria, Belgium, India, Morocco, Venezuela, Ecuador and Cape Verde and the Foreign Ministers of Hungary and Zimbabwe. They are serving two-year terms on the Council.
It was a day of lofty public speeches in which the Council's members acknowledged that the cold war's demise had freed the United Nations from the political paralysis that has hindered it for most of its 46 years of existence. The meeting also underscored the new era of Russian-American cooperation -- highlighted by Mr. Yeltsin's calling the Western countries his allies.
The leaders also met among themselves, and more or less ignored the swell of different protesters in the streets.
President Bush, Prime Minister John Major of Britain and several other leaders praised the role the United Nations played in driving Iraq out of Kuwait last year, destroying President Saddam Hussein's nuclear weapons and bringing Libya to account for the bombing of two airliners.
But no concrete decisions were made on strengthening the organization's activities or on dealing with its deepening financial difficulties. Member states currently owe more than $800 million in unpaid dues.
The summit declaration said, "The members of the Security Council consider that their meeting is a timely recognition of the fact that there are new favorable international circumstances under which the Security Council has begun to fulfill more effectively its primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security."
Today's high-level meeting, and the declaration it adopted, came at the suggestion of Britain's Government, which is this month's president of the Council. It has been suggested that a principal reason was Prime Minister Major's desire to enhance his stature before elections expected later this year.
Today's meeting, held around the horseshoe table in the Security Council's chamber, provided an opportunity for many bilateral contacts, including President Yeltsin's first meeting with the Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa. And it allowed the Chinese to break out of the ostracism imposed by most of the world since Beijing cracked down on the democracy movement in 1989.
 
'Common Ground' Sought
 President Bush set the tone for many speeches today when he told the meeting, "We meet at a moment of new beginning for this institution and, really, for every member nation." He added that "the collapse of imperial communism and the end of the cold war breathe new life into the United Nations."
"It's an exciting opportunity for our United Nations and we must not allow it to slip away," he said. "Right now across the globe the United Nations is working day and night in the cause of peace."
The President called for agreement on a worldwide ban on chemical weapons by the end of the year and said he would continue "the search for common ground" on mutual arms reductions when he meets with the Russian leader on Saturday.
President Yeltsin, who was making his first appearance here since Russia took over the defunct Soviet Union's position at the United Nations, gave a similarly emphatic commitment to peace, cooperation and disarmament.
"Perhaps for the first time ever, there is now a real chance to put an end to despotism and to dismantle the totalitarian order, whatever shape it may take," he told other Security Council members.
Saying Russia now "considers the United States and the West not as mere partners but rather as allies," President Yeltsin called for further disarmament measures, including deep cuts in strategic and tactical nuclear weapons, limiting and eventually eliminating nuclear testing, cuts in conventional armaments and the creation of a global anti-missile shield to be developed cooperatively with the United States.
President Yeltsin also stressed his Government's commitment to political freedom and human rights, saying the last 10 political prisoners were freed a few days ago.
"There are no more prisoners of conscience in free Russia," he told the Council.
Afterward, President Yeltsin told a news conference that his plan for a global anti-missile shield would protect countries against accidental or unauthorized missile launchings and encourage nuclear disarmament. It would also provide work for Russia's nuclear and other military scientists and stop them from "drifting abroad" and spreading dangerous technologies.
 
Arms Moved to Russia
 Mr. Yeltsin said that all land-based tactical nuclear weapons have now been withdrawn to Russia from Kazakhstan and Belarus and that evacuation of those weapons from Ukraine would be completed by July. The weapons will be stored and eventually destroyed, he said.
Mr. Yeltsin also announced that his Government would recognize the breakaway former Yugoslav republics of Croatia and Slovenia at the end of next week and said that action would help resolve the civil war there.
The declaration is particularly tough on countries violating the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty by selling machinery and information on making atomic weapons, saying the Council will take "appropriate measures" against them.
Prime Minister Major told a closing news conference that this means the Security Council is ready to use its considerable enforcement powers against countries spreading nuclear weaponry.
The declaration also breaks new ground by saying that "non-military sources of instability in the economic, social, humanitarian and ecological fields" can also become threats to peace and security and thus merit the Council's attention.
The idea of holding such a meeting to take stock of the United Nations' future in a world freed of east-west tension was first suggested last year by President Francois Mitterrand of France.
Several leaders made practical suggestions for strengthening the United Nations peacemaking and peacekeeping capacity.
President Mitterrand went furthest, saying France stands ready to provide the Council with 1,000 soldiers for peacekeeping duties within 48 hours and to double that number within a week.
But he also called for activation of the Military Staff Committee, a long moribund group of senior officers that is supposed to advise the Security Council on the use of troops put at its disposal but which never found a role for itself in cold-war days.
Chancellor Franz Vranitzky of Austria called on the United Nations to deploy peacekeeping forces in tense areas before fighting starts and without necessarily getting the agreement of both sides. Prime Minister Wilfried Martens of Belgium suggested creating an emergency peacekeeping reserve fund to finance the early stages of such operations.
But some countries also aired pet grievances about the way the Security Council works now that it is becoming more influential in world affairs. Japan, Venezuela, India and Zimbabwe all said that the Council was unrepresentative of the present-day world.
Prime Minister Li Peng of China stressed his country's traditional belief that outside organizations' criticism of the way governments treat their citizens constitutes interference in their internal affairs.
And India, which has exploded a nuclear device, entered a reservation over the Council's strong stand against the spread of nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction.

HEADLINE: Senate, Heeding Consumers' Ire, Votes to Limit Cable TV Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Defying both the politically powerful cable-television industry and the Bush Administration, the Senate handed a victory to the broadcast industry today by voting to impose local and Federal regulation on cable rates and telling cable companies to pay for broadcasters' programming.
Spurred by consumer complaints of rising charges and poor service from cable operators, the Senate adopted legislation that would require the Federal Communications Commission to establish national guidelines for basic cable-television rates. The F.C.C. would then regulate rates itself or allow local authorities to do so provided they followed the national guidelines. Most of the cable industry's rates were deregulated in 1984. 
 The Senate bill would also for the first time allow local television stations, some of them owned by ABC, CBS and NBC, to begin collecting fees from the cable industry for the retransmission of the stations' signals, a big setback for that industry.
 
Bipartisan Support
 The Senators voted 73 to 18 for the bill today, with a majority from both parties supporting the new regulation.
The House has consistently been more enthusiastic than the Senate in recent years about regulating the cable industry. Similar legislation is pending in the House as leaders have waited to see whether the Senate, which blocked a cable-regulation bill in 1990, was willing to change its position.
The Bush Administration threatened on Monday to veto the Senate version, contending that recently proposed legislation to allow telephone companies into the cable industry would create enough competition to hold down cable-television rates and improve service.
Consumer groups backed today's bill because it would control rates and force cable-television programmers to sell their own channels, like CNN and ESPN, at "reasonable" rates to all cable-and satellite-television companies. About 3.6 million mostly rural families in the United States rely on home satellite dishes, often because they cannot hook up to cable.
 
Warning by Cable Operators
 The average rate charged to cable subscribers climbed 61 percent nationwide from 1986 to 1990, with rates doubling and tripling in some cities. But the cable industry says that because the number of available cable channels was also increasing during this period, the rate per channel was rising by only slightly more than the inflation rate.
The cable industry contends that consumers will actually be hurt if the extra fees paid to broadcasters are high enough to push up monthly cable rates. If regulators set rates too low, the cable industry has warned that it may be forced to spend less money to develop new or better programs.
"This so-called consumer protection bill, designed for the benefit of the conventional broadcasting industry, would force cable subscribers' dollars to go to support CBS and NBC, at the expense of cable channels like Discovery and CNN," said James P. Mooney, the president and chief executive of the National Cable Television Association.
The besieged broadcast industry, which has lost a seventh of its market share to the cable industry in six years, could collect as much as $3 billion in annual fees for the retransmission rights under the legislation voted today.
"The Senate has taken a giant leap toward insuring the long-term viability of universal, free, over-the-air television service," said Edward O. Fritts, the president and chief executive of the National Association of Broadcasters.
Consumer advocates say the new fees to broadcasters will not be high enough to prevent cable rates from falling with regulation, although no one actually knows what the broadcast retransmission fees will be.
Cable companies would be allowed to refuse to retransmit the signal of any broadcast station whose fee they found exorbitant, so the fee per subscriber cannot be predicted. But as much as three-quarters of the cable industry's viewers mainly watch retransmitted broadcasts.
Cable companies would be forced to transmit those broadcast signals that are given to them without charge.
Representative Jim Cooper, a Tennessee Democrat who is a member of the Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance, said that because of the lopsided majority in the Senate today, he expected the House to pass broad cable-regulation legislation within two months. "That's an extremely strong vote, that's way beyond a veto-proof majority, and I think that will accelerate House passage of a very strong bill," he said.
Two years ago the House passed by a unanimous voice vote a bill that would have authorized the F.C.C. to regulate virtually all basic cable-television service plans, while local governments could petition for F.C.C. regulation of the next more expensive tier if rates became unreasonable. The basic plans would only have included local broadcast stations and public service channels.
Another bill pending in the House is nearly identical to the Senate bill, but it excludes retransmission payments from cable companies to broadcasters. The bill was introduced by Representative Dennis E. Eckart, Democrat of Ohio, who has also sponsored a separate bill calling for such retransmission payments.
 
F.C.C. Sets Definitions
 Congress barred local rate regulation in 1984 except where there was no "effective competition" from broadcast stations. The F.C.C. initially ruled that effective competition existed in any city with three or more broadcast stations, a decision that left 97 percent of the industry free of government price restrictions.
But effective Oct. 25 last year, the F.C.C. tightened its standard to six or more broadcast stations, a ruling that authorized rate regulations for two-thirds of the nation's cable systems and a third of the nation's cable subscribers. Local rate regulation has been limited, however, to basic service plans that must include local broadcast stations and public service channels but little else.
In response to the F.C.C.'s action and the threat of Congressional legislation, some cable systems have taken popular channels like CNN and ESPN out of their basic plans and offered them as premium services.
 
If Complaints Are Lodged
 Today's Senate bill would authorize rate regulation for almost all of the nation's cable systems. Basic service plans would be regulated immediately, while the F.C.C. would be given the authority to regulate more expensive service plans if it receives complaints of unreasonable rate increases.
The Senate bill would also address the dwindling variety in basic service plans by prescribing regulation for the next more expensive service plan in any city where the basic service plan attracts less than 30 percent of all cable subscribers.
Critics of the F.C.C. have suggested that it will draft a weak set of regulatory guidelines if the Senate bill is signed into law. But the Federal agency's decision to tighten its definition of effective competition has also demonstrated the staff's alarm at rising cable rates.
The Motion Picture Association of America opposed today's legislation because it made no provision for Hollywood to receive part of the retransmission fees. But the powerful lobby of movie producers has traditionally had more influence in the House than the Senate.
Underlying the entire debate over cable-television legislation today was a division over whether regulation or competition would be the best way to protect consumers from abusive pricing and service in the cable industry.

HEADLINE: Bleak Economy Shatters Job Security in Banking

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Mark Hollowell was 17 years old and just out of high school when an Arizona bank took him on as a mail clerk. Banks were clean and respectable places, with nice benefits, nice hours, nice people and above all, job security. In time, he became an assistant vice president earning $35,000 a year.
Today, at 32, Mr. Hollowell is one of tens of thousands of American bank employees who have lost their jobs over the last two years. His wife, Tammie, has a $32,000-a-year job as a systems analyst that keeps their family afloat, but her own prospects are dimming. She, too, works for a bank, Valley National, which has laid off 1,000 people since the late 1980's.
 
Worse Before It's Better
 "Can you believe?" Mr. Hollowell said. "We both got into this thinking we were set for life." 
 The recession that has been the most brutal in memory for white-collar workers has been especially jolting for bank employees, who had reason to expect they had been hired until they reached retirement age. Once a staid and strait-laced business with courthouse-like buildings that were quiet as churches, banking hurtled into a decade of easy lending, giveaway credit cards, 24-hour automatic teller machines and branches as ubiquitous as the gas stations they have come to mimic.
The overstaffing and overexpansion of the 80's brought on thousands of layoffs when the recession hit. The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics found that 22,000 jobs, from chief executives to tellers, were lost in commercial banks nationwide last year, falling to 1.5 million. In savings institutions, 27,000 jobs were cut, to 331,000. Many of those layoffs were in New York City, the nation's banking capital, which lost about 7,000 commercial and savings bank jobs, dropping to 150,000.
And for banking, the turmoil is likely to continue well after the recession ends. The Federal Government's sales and closings of floundering savings institutions, more than 500 to date, are far from over. And more mergers of giant banks, like the pending combination of Bank of America of San Francisco and Security Pacific of Los Angeles, spell 100,000 more layoffs this year in commercial banks alone, predicts Towers Perrin, a management consulting firm.
The upheaval in banking is a stark example of the contraction and metamorphosis invading much of the American workplace, pushed along by the recession. Below the top management ranks, temporary and part-time workers with negligible benefits are displacing full-time workers with generous benefits. And even for full-timers, an old understanding is evaporating: the idea that dedicated work will be rewarded with a career-long job and regular promotions.
Lorraine Broshears, 42, profited from the changes in the 80's that let women move out of the teller cage and back office. In Phoenix, she ran the 23-branch northern division of Pima Savings and Loan with a staff of 113. She earned $49,000 a year, which with the salary of her husband, Ed, a pilot for America West, gave her an easy life. But the airline has been ailing and is operating under protection of bankruptcy court, and the Bank of America has taken over Pima and shut it down. "All of a sudden you're given two weeks' notice and you're gone," Mrs. Broshears said.
 
Go-Getters, and Takers
 Mrs. Broshears relished banking's hustle and bustle. To be sure, in the 80's, the industry bred self-dealing gunslingers like Charles H. Keating Jr., whose headquarters were in Phoenix, and the competitive fervor of the times blinded banks' judgment in making loans. But Mrs. Broshears said it also produced a smarter and better business, with banking employees getting out of their offices to corral deposits and make loans.
"Careers depend on making sales," she said. "That's something 20 years ago you never saw." She disagrees with laid-off bank workers who think consumers have lost something in the new style of banking. But like them she condemns shoot-from-the-hip personnel policies. "Corporations won't find that dedication they would years ago," she said. "That's the consequence -- the disillusionment of the work force. Why be loyal when it won't be reciprocated?"
Among states, banking in Arizona has taken a colossal beating, the result of frenzied lending to underqualified customers for houses, offices and shopping malls and the subsequent collapse of real estate values. Harold Feeney, the state's new superintendent of banking, says only one small savings and loan institution survives of the 12 based in the state in the mid-1980's, while the number of commercial banks has shrunk to 37 from 50.
Of 26,000 bank employees four years ago, nearly one in five had lost their jobs through last June, the last date for which the state employment service has data. The figure is certainly higher now: the state unemployment rate leaped to 8.6 percent in December, from 7.1 percent in November and 4.5 percent in April.
 
Help-Not-Wanted Ads
 One of the few help-wanted ads for banking employees these days is an offer by Citibank's Arizona subsidiary for a collection agent to track down consumers who have stopped payments on the mortgages and personal loans that it made so freely in the 80's. Personnel offices of surviving banks are so swamped with job seekers that one has been running an advertisement that says, "M& I Thunderbird Bank has no current openings and is not accepting applications at this time."
Executives of banks that have been letting people go say they have little choice. They have to push down costs to survive in a less regulated world of competitors that includes banks from out of state, mutual funds, insurance companies and stockbrokers. "Business does not walk in the door," said Robert W. Wahlstrom, senior vice president and head of human resources at Valley National, the state's biggest bank. "It is no longer a placid, laid-back environment."
In earlier recessions, employment officials here say, people could still find jobs as tellers or lending officers. "Banking was always an industry you would recommend to someone who wanted a career change," said Richard Polito, manager of Arizona's job placement and training service in downtown Phoenix. "It was a safety net occupation. It was recession-proof."
Every Tuesday, an organization of unemployed executives known as Azpen, for Arizona Professional Employees Network, gathers at a Mennonite church in the affluent northern part of Phoenix. Many were bankers or had jobs tied to banking.
More than 200 people, mostly aged 35 to 60, most in coats and ties and twice the usual number, showed up at the meeting on Jan. 21. They heard lectures from fellow members on building self-esteem and on networking to help one another find jobs.
One job seeker attending that day was Mike Miller, 49, laid off as a branch administrator for M& I Thunderbird. "I was caught in a rif, a reduction in force," he said. "The section I was in was decimated. They moved the things we were doing to other areas of the bank." Mr. Miller took a part-time job helping the Federal Government review loans of banks it was taking over, but that work dried up.
"Banking used to be fun," he said. "You knew your customer. It's like working in a factory now."
Richard Nosky, who recruits executives for Arizona companies, used to have to look far out of state to find officers for the state's booming banks. Now he says he has a file of dozens of banking executives who earned $60,000 to more than $200,000 a year and who are looking for work.
In Mr. Nosky's files is J. Michael Materie, 53, whose credentials suggest that he is better equipped than most bankers for the current environment. Regulators would recruit him to stabilize sinking savings and loans so they could be sold. He earned $220,000 a year fixing up one that was taken over by the Bank of America, and the Government let him go without a severance check.
 
Giving It Up
 Mr. Materie has sold his Mercedes and kept his Chevrolet Blazer. He thinks he and his wife, Helen, who does not work outside the home, can get along until he starts collecting a pension in about 10 years. But what he wants more than a salary is a top management job, and not necessarily in banking. "I'd most like to be running a company," he said. "I think I was good at it. I've been a senior vice president or higher in everything I've done since 1975."
Some people here have given up on banks. Last November Gail Stapleton, 36 and single, accepted a voluntary layoff from Valley National after 14 years there, most as a personal banker. "I wanted to work for a bank," she said. "I loved math. And I loved people. What could be better than banking?" But in the 80's, Valley National turned up pressure on personal bankers, giving them loan quotas to meet. Ms. Stapleton has gone back to school and is pondering a career in the arts -- working in a gallery or designing fabric.
To avert layoffs of solid performers in future recessions, Mr. Wahlstrom said, Valley National is forming a core of 6,500 permanent employees, 500 fewer than now on the payroll. Part-time and temporary workers would take the heat of recessions, Mr. Wahlstrom said. Already, he said, several hundred of Valley National's 1,300 tellers are part-timers. "You can no longer afford to carry a person who is partially productive," he said.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Clears Way for Return of Haitians

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Supreme Court cleared the way tonight for the repatriation of thousands of Haitians even while a Federal appeals court was deciding the legality of the policy.
In reaching its order, the High Court voted 6 to 3 to grant the Justice Department's motion to stay a Federal court's injunction against the forcible return of Haitians who fled their country after its first democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was ousted in a coup in September. 
 The ruling gives the Administration the authority to start repatriating the Haitians, 9,000 of whom are being held at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba, even though the issue is still being argued before the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, said a senior Justice Department official who insisted on anonymity.
 
One Ruling Withdrawn
 "As a practical matter, it means the Government is free to begin the forced return of Haitians until the 11th Circuit's decision," said Ira Kurzban, a Miami lawyer representing the Haitian Refugee Center.
The High Court's order simply said that the injunction issued by a Federal judge in Miami "is stayed pending disposition of the case" by the appeals court.
Earlier today, the appeals court said it had erroneously announced that it ruled in favor of the Government. The court later withdrew the order, saying it was a clerical error.
After the announcement favoring the Government, Attorney General William Barr immediately said the Government had clear authority to repatriate the Haitians. Another Government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the process could begin "in the very near future."
 
Thousands Have Fled
 The United States and the Organization of American States have refused to recognize the army-supported regime that replaced Father Aristide, and responded by imposing a harsh economic embargo on Haiti to press for his return.
More than 14,000 Haitians have fled the Caribbean nation since the coup, but the United States says the that the Haitians are fleeing poverty, not political repression, and therefore are not entitled to political asylum.
An increase in the number of Haitians fleeing by boat in recent weeks and the deteriorating political climate in Haiti have apparently convinced the Administration that hopes for a political solution in Haiti have all but disappeared, and the Administration is having to consider a whole new range of policy options.
 The United States Ambassador to Haiti, Alvin P. Adams, Jr., was recalled this week to discuss policy options after a political meeting called by the Prime Minister-designate, Rene Theodore, was stormed by plainclothes policemen. Washington strongly condemned the Haitian military Government.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Senate handed a victory to the broadcast industry, defying both the Administration and the politically powerful cable-television industry by voting to impose local and Federal regulation on cable rates and telling cable companies to pay for broadcasters' programming. Spurred by consumer complaints of rising charges and poor service, the Senate voted 73 to 18 for the bill, which requires the F.C.C. to establish national guidelines for basic cable-television rates. [Page 1.] How Senators voted. [46.] 
 The Government index devised to forecast the economy fell 0.3 percent in December, its second straight decline. The leading indicators now stand at the lowest level since June. [35.]
Sales of new homes tumbled 6.6 percent in December, the Government said, wiping out nearly all of November's gains and dragging down the year's total to the lowest level in nine years. [35.]
Prices paid to farmers for raw products were unchanged from December to January, the Agriculture Department said. [46.]
Treasury Secretary Brady tried to convince the captains of American industry that a recovery was on its way. The surprise was that his audience needed little convincing. [35.] The White House stepped up efforts to give political momentum to Bush's economic proposals. [8.]
The Administration will delay a proposal to eliminate tax benefits for Americans who buy annuities. The shift came after insurance executives expressed concern and insurers' stocks plunged. [35.]
Members of a Senate subcommittee criticized the S.E.C. for not forcing companies to clarify how they pay top executives. [39.]
The recession has been especially jolting for bank employees, who had expected to have jobs until retirement. [1.]
 
Companies
Trans World Airlines made an unusual type of bankruptcy filing, having previously won agreements from most of its creditors to reduce its debt by $1 billion. The filing is an attempt to avoid the fate of competitors that have been forced to liquidate, and it gives the airline a good chance to survive. [1.]
As Macy's enters bankruptcy, Bloomingdale's is emerging from it with a new top merchant and a new attitude. [35.]
Aetna plans to withdraw from the Massachusetts auto-insurance market, where it has experienced heavy losses. [37.]
Child World will close 26 stores and three distribution centers and take a $20 million charge for its fourth quarter. [37.]
 
International
Boris N. Yeltsin made his debut on the stage of international summit talks. In his drive to bring a free market to his new Russia, he put aside time for just one sortie outside the Security Council -- a private dinner at the Federal Reserve Bank. [5.]
 
Markets
A late blue-chip selloff caused the Dow Jones industrials to drop 21.47, to 3,223.39. The Dow was off 9.39 for the week. [38.]
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in light trading, a bounce that most traders said represented a slight correction to big declines earlier in the week. [38.]
The dollar was mixed in New York and lower overseas amid fears of central bank intervention against it. [44.] Precious metals futures advanced on the Commodity Exchange. [44.]

Gilbert P. Hyatt is a familiar name to executives of companies like Matsushita, Sony and NEC. Although they refuse to talk about it, they have agreed to pay him huge royalties on virtually every electronic appliance they sell in the U.S. Patents. [35.]
If offered early retirement, one should first evaluate the package. A series of important choices follows. Your Money. [36.]

HEADLINE: SUMMIT AT THE U.N.;
Yeltsin, on Summit's Stage, Stresses His Russian Identity

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 31

 BODY:
As heir to the Soviet Union's Security Council seat, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia made his debut today on the stage of international summit talks, heading off comparisons with Mikhail S. Gorbachev by portraying himself as a man from a different country.
From the moment his IL-62 jet touched down at Kennedy Airport on Thursday night with the word Russia emblazoned across its side, Mr. Yeltsin made it clear that he represented a nation rising from the debris of the former Soviet state. 
 His was "free Russia," a Russia that had "just shaken off the yoke of Communism," a Russia he said had a "new Russian foreign policy" and wanted to be a full ally of the United States.
In his efforts to bring a free market to this new Russia, Mr. Yeltsin took time for just one sortie outside the meeting of 15 leaders of Security Council countries at the United Nations -- a private dinner at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, with about 80 executives from government, business and banking. Those present included the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan; the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Gerald E. Corrigan, and the Secretary of the Treasury,Nicholas F. Brady.
As Vitaly Churkin, a spokesman for the Russian Foreign Ministry, said Mr. Yeltsin wanted to "cover three elements" in the United States: the Bush Administration, Congress and New York business.
Mr. Yeltsin's proclamation of the new Russia and the appeal to American business leaders went hand in hand, aides said, as both were aimed at dispelling old doubts about Soviet intentions and presenting instead a Russia that was democratic and committed to free markets.
"He's presenting Russia as a new phenomenon in international life," Mr. Churkin said. "There has been a qualitative change. Now that we're fully regarded as fully part of the democratic world, we would like to build our relations with other countries belonging to that world as friends and maybe as allies."
President Yeltsin portrayed his present economic-reform efforts as simply a continuation of the battle against Communism and the failed coup in August by Soviet hard-liners.
He said that among the major steps to a free market would be a presidential decree "granting concessions, along with a law on mineral resources that in particular will create great opportunities for attracting foreign capital and technologies into the raw-materials sector."
He also raised the possibility of unspecified most-favored-nation treatment for trading partners and concessions for individual and possibly group enterprises, as well as the creation of "joint corporations" in automobile manufacturing, energy production, farming and highway construction.
 
Mentions Technology Transfer
 In return, Mr. Yeltsin asked for "reciprocity" and noted that there were now American limits on the transfer of technology.
He also called for an early agreement between Russia and the United States on the protection of investments and mentioned the possibility of a Russian-American international insurance fund for private investments, in which other nations could take part.
Those pledges were aimed at businessmen and bankers in private -- people invited to the meeting like John F. McGillicuddy, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chemical Banking Corporation, and Walter V. Shipley, Chemical's president and chief operating officer, as well as William R. Rhodes, a vice chairman of Citicorp.
The Russian economy also came up in Mr. Yeltsin's meeting with the Chinese Prime Minister, Li Peng, which focused heavily on economic cooperation between China and the republics that form the new Commonwealth of Independent States.
But in his United Nations speech, Mr. Yeltsin's only passing references to the economy were a phrase blaming the Communists for creating an "economy mutilated by ideological diktat and built contrary to all common sense" and a pledge that Russia was "to embark upon a most difficult economic reform."
 
No Begging, However . . .
 This past July, after Mr. Gorbachev sought financial support for the Soviet Union at the meeting of leaders of seven large industrial democracies in London, he said pointedly that the President of a great power should not go around asking for handouts.
Mr. Yeltsin and his aides remembered those words. "Yeltsin will not ask" for Western money, one adviser Dmitri Volkogonov said, though he added that such scruples did not prevent lesser figures in the Russian Government from doing so. Still, Mr. Yeltsin seemed exasperated that the industrial democracies had not yet provided Russia with assistance like a fund to stabilize the ruble.
"We've been talking about this for seven months and unfortunately, so far, nothing has been done," he said at a news conference. "And that's very dnagerous. Today, Russia is facing the last opportunity to defend democracy and the entire world has noticed.
If the effort fails, he said, "once again there will be mass repression, once again we'll have the arms race and the world will be put into a completely new orbit."
He added that he expected the ruble to become a floating, convertible currency by 1993.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Boutros Ghali of Egypt, center, the United Nations Secretary General, addressing the first summit meeting yesterday of the Security Council. Among the government leaders with him were, at left, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and, at right, Prime Minister John Major of Britain. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2568 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT AT THE U.N.;
Excerpts From Speeches by Leaders of Permanent Members of U.N. Council

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from speeches delivered today at a Security Council summit meeting by leaders of the Council's five permanent member nations. Translations were provided by the Russian, Chinese and French missions.
 
BORIS N. YELTSIN
President of Russia
 This summit meeting of the Security Council, the first of its kind on the political Olympus of the contemporary world, is a historic and unprecedented event. The end of the 20th century is a time of great promise and new anxieties. The never-ending search for truth and an insight into what the future has in store for humanity seems to be getting its second wind. 
 Perhaps for the first time ever there is now a real chance to put an end to despotism and to dismantle the totalitarian order whatever shape it may take.
I trust that after all the unthinkable tragedies and tremendous losses that it has suffered, mankind will reject this legacy. It will not allow the 21st century to bring new suffering and deprivations to our children and grandchildren.
The process of profound change is already under way in various spheres of life and above all in the economy.
 
Problem for All Humanity
 It is a problem that concerns not just individual nations or states, but the entire humanity. After all, an economy mutilated by ideological diktat and built contrary to all common sense forms the principal material basis of totalitarianism.
A profound awareness of this causal relationship has led the Russian leadership to embark upon a most difficult economic reform. We have taken that risk in a country where an all-out war was waged against economic interests for many decades.
I am grateful to the world community for its support of our efforts and for the understanding that not only the future of the people of Russia, but also that of the entire planet, largely depends on whether or not the reforms are successful. I am also grateful to Russians for their courage and patience. They should take a great deal of credit for the fact that the world community is breaking with its totalitarian past.
Democracy is one of the major assets of human civilization. All times and all countries have known people who stood up to defend it without sparing themselves. The people of Russia defended democracy near the walls of our Moscow White House.
 
Democratic Guarantees
 Now we must accomplish the most difficult task, that is, the creation of legal, political and socioeconomic guarantees to make democratic changes irreversible.
All of us carry a huge burden of mutual mistrust. It is no secret that a most profound abyss has separated the two states that until recently were referred to as the superpowers. This abyss must be bridged. That is the wish of our nations and the will of the Presidents of the United States of America and the Russian federation.
The new political situation in the world makes it possible not only to advance new original ideas but also to make even the most ambitious of them practicable. Our proposals have been outlined in our messages to the United Nations Secretary General, Mr. Boutros-Ghali, and the U.S. President, Mr. George Bush.
Russia believes that the time has come to considerably reduce the presence of means of destruction on our planet. I am convinced that together we are capable of making the principle of minimum defense sufficiency a fundamental law of existence of contemporary states.
 
Real Opportunities
 Today there are real opportunities for:
*Implementing deep cuts in strategic offensive arms and tactical nuclear weapons;
*Resolutely moving towards significant limitations on nuclear testing and even towards its complete cessation;
*Making ABM defenses less complicated and costly and eliminating anti-satellite systems;
*Considerably reducing conventional armaments and armed forces;
*Ensuring practical implementation of international agreements on the prohibition of chemical and bacteriological weapons;
*Enhancing the reliability of barriers to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
 
Problem of Arms Experts
 The problem of experts engaged in the development and production of such weapons, including nuclear physicists, has lately become a top priority. No county has the right to use its talents for political gains at the expense of international security. Russia is fully aware of its own responsibility and is taking steps to provide social security to such experts.
At the same time we support the idea of establishing international centers that could coordinate appropriate research and support the most promising areas of work.
I think the time has come to consider creating a global system for protection of the world community. It could be based on a reorientation of the U.S. Strategic Defense Initiative to make use of high technologies developed in Russia's defense complex.
We are ready to actively participate in building and putting in place a pan-European collective defense system, in particular in the Vienna talks and in the upcoming post-Helsinki II talks on security and cooperation in Europe.
Russia considers the United States and the West not as mere partners but rather as allies. It is a basis prerequisite for, I would say, a revolution in peaceful cooperation among civilized nations.
We reject any subordination of foreign policy to pure ideology or ideological doctrines. Our principles are clear and simple: supremacy of democracy, human rights and freedoms, legal and moral standards.

 	 	 		. . .	 	A few days ago the 10 remaining political prisoners were granted pardon by a decree of the President of the Russian federation. There are no more prisoners of conscience in free Russia.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We will make use of the effective role of the United Nations and the Security Council and take part in the search for lasting solutions to the Yugoslav and Afghan problems and for a normalization of the situation in the Near and Middle East and in Cambodia and in other regions.
I believe that we need a special quick-response mechanism to insure peace and stability. Upon a decision of the Security Council it could be expeditiously activated in areas of crisis.
We are prepared to become practically involved in United Nations peacekeeping operations and contribute to their logistical support.
My country firmly supports steps aimed at asserting the rule of law throughout the world. It is necessary to enhance the prestige of the International Court of Justice as an effective instrument of peaceful settlement of international disputes.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
GEORGE BUSH
President of the United States
 We meet at a moment of new beginnings for this institution and really for every member nation.
And for most of its history, the United Nations was caught in a cold war crossfire. And I think back to my days here, in the early '70s, as a permanent representative, of the way then polemics displaced peacekeeping. And long before I came onto the scene and long after I left, the U.N. was all too often paralyzed by cruel ideological divisions and the struggle to contain Soviet expansion.
And today all that's changed. In the collapse of imperial Communism and the end of the cold war breathe new life into the United Nations. And it was just one year ago that the world saw this new, invigorated United Nations in action, as this Council stood fast against aggression and stood for the sacred principles enshrined in the U.N. Charter.
And now it's time to step forward again, make the internal reforms, accelerate the revitalization, accept the responsibilities necessary for a vigorous and effective United Nations.

 	 	 		. . .	 	It's an exciting opportunity for our United Nations, and we must not allow it to slip away. Right now, across the globe the U.N. is working night and day in the cause of peace. And never before in its four decades have the U.N.'s blue helmets and blue berets been so engaged in the noble work of peacekeeping, even to the extent of building the foundation for free elections. And never before has the United Nations been so ready and so compelled to step up to the task of peacemaking, both to resolve hot wars and to conduct that forward-looking mission known as preventive diplomacy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Democracy, human rights, the rule of law, these are the building blocks of peace and freedom. And in the lives of millions of men and women around the world, its import is simple. It can mean the difference between war and peace, healing and hatred, and where there is fear and despair it really can mean hope.

 	 	 		. . .	 	In my first address here to the United Nations as President, I challenged the Soviet Union to eliminate chemical weapons, and called on every nation to join us in this crusade.. . . What greater cause for this great body -- to make certain the world has seen the last of these terrible weapons. And so let us vow to make this year the year all nations at long last join to ban this scourge.
There is much more to do regarding weapons of mass destruction.
 
Anti-Nuclear Steps
 Just three days ago, in my State of the Union message here, I announced the steps, far-reaching unilateral steps that we will take to reduce our nuclear arsenal, and these steps affect each element in our strategic triad -- the land, the sea and the air.
In addition to these unilateral steps, we are prepared to move forward on mutual arms reduction. I noted his constructive comments here today; and tomorrow, in my meeting with President Yeltsin, we will continue the search for common ground on this vitally important issue. He responded with some very serious proposals just the other day.
Our triumph in the gulf is testament to the U.N.'s mission -- that security is a shared responsibility. And today, this institution spearheads a quarantine against the outlaw regime of Saddam Hussein. It is the strong belief of my country that we must keep sanctions in place and take the following steps to preserve our common security.
We must continue to focus on Iraq's capability to build or maintain weapons of mass destruction. And we must make clear to the world and, most important, to the people of Iraq that no normalization is possible so long as Saddam Hussein remains there, remains in power.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Two weeks ago, this Council, in unity, sent a very strong message to Libya. And let me repeat today Resolution 731, passed unanimously by this body, by the Security Council, calls on Libya to comply fully with the requests of three states on this Council. And I would just like to use this meeting today to call on Libya to heed the call of the Security Council of the United Nations.
 
LI PENG
Prime Minister of China
 Human rights and fundamental freedoms of the entire mankind should be universally respected. Human rights covers many aspects. They include not only civil and political rights, but also economic, social and cultural rights. As far as the large numbers of developing countries are concerned, the rights to independence, subsistence and development are of paramount importance.
In essence, the issue of human rights falls within the sovereignty of each country. A country's human rights situation should not be judged in total disregard of its history and national conditions. It is neither appropriate nor workable to demand that all countries measure up to the human rights criteria or models of one or a small number of countries.
China values human rights and stands ready to engage in discussion and cooperation with other countries on an equal footing on the question of human rights -- on the basis of mutual understanding, mutual respect, and seeking consensus while reserving differences. However, it is opposed to interference in the internal affairs of other countries using the human rights issue as an excuse.
 
JOHN MAJOR
Prime Minister of Britain
 I hope this meeting will set in hand work to strengthen the United Nations.
New ideas focus on new opportunities in preventive diplomacy and in peacemaking and peacekeeping. By preventive diplomacy we mean action to avert, or at least to contain, crisis. Let us exploit the unrealized potential of the U.N. Charter.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The Secretary General should take the initiative boldly in drawing potential conflict to the attention of the Security Council. In the past he has been hobbled by the political rivalry between member states, often reflected most sharply in the Council.
In the future, the Council must be prepared to act before tension becomes conflict. The Secretary General deserves an assurance of our good faith in his judgment. This meeting can give him that assurance.. . .
Peacemaking and peacekeeping should run in parallel. Demand is not likely to decrease; we should like to enhance the U.N.'s ability to respond. We recognize the load placed on the organization and the skills and experience of its staff. But we want the U.N. to be able to carry out its mission even more effectively. That is why we propose that the Council should invite the Secretary General to give his ideas on how this might be done.
The report might look at the U.N.'s role in identifying and dealing with causes of instability and potential crisis, as well as the contribution to be made by regional bodies in helping the work of the Council.
 
FRANCOIS MITTERRAND
President of France
 This collective security will be very quickly jeopardized unless we can establish modern conditions for it. Past experience has not been convincing. Nothing is possible without the determination of states, and especially the major powers, to reject the law of the jungle, the 'might is right' principle. This determination is enshrined in the United Nations Charter. This Charter was blocked for a long time and yet now it is usable in all its provisions, which we have to apply immediately.. . .
I would like to inform you that a country such as France is ready to make available to the United Nations Secretary General a contingent of 1,000 men for peacekeeping operations, at any time and on 48 hours' notice. The number could be doubled within a week. This deployment would clearly mean activating the military staff committee which is provided for by the Charter.
Secondly, we have to develop preventive diplomacy. This is essential. The members of the Security Council must undertake systematically to provide the Secretary General with information on international security and give him a mandate to enter into regular contact with his counterparts, leaders of regional organizations.. . .
Lastly, we should also make use, as much as necessary, of new forums to address the specific needs on relations between disarmament and development. Suggestions have been made, such as those by Germany, and they are good ones.
This is why France is recommending the establishment of regional funds for conversion which would promote the transfer of research and military development to nonmilitary production -- initially for the benefit of new states, republics which have an urgent need; also for the benefit of certain states which are heirs to the former Soviet Union and also of many other countries, in the Middle East among others.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 35; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 880 words

HEADLINE: Administration Delays Plan To End Annuity Tax Benefit

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Bush Administration backed down tonight and said it would delay a proposal to eliminate the tax benefits enjoyed by the hundreds of thousands of customers who each year buy annuities.
The action came after top life-insurance executives expressed concern over the proposal and after insurance industry stocks fell in trading today, with Aetna Life and Casualty down $2.50 a share, to $41.50, and Cigna losing $1.125 a share, to $54. 
 As proposed, the bill sent to Congress by the Administration would have been effective Saturday, raising the likelihood that annuity sales would dry up immediately. But the Treasury said late today that it would revise the proposal to make it effective only after it was approved by Congress. A tax provision often takes effect the day the bill is introduced, which can be many months before it is actually passed by the Congress and signed by the President.
The Treasury decision is likely to lead to a surge in annuity sales, as buyers rush to get tax advantages that could soon be lost.
Some two-thirds of the life insurers' business is now devoted to annuities. Those sales would likely fall off sharply if the President's proposal ending the tax-deferred status of annuity earnings became law.
Meanwhile, executives of top Wall Street brokerage firms expressed opposition to the President's proposal that would tax the unrealized gains that brokerage firms often enjoy on their inventory of securities.
Although annuities have long been sold as a form of insurance against living too long -- beyond one's ability to pay for retirement -- in recent years annuities have become a popular vehicle for accumulating savings tax-free. Some people use annuity proceeds to supplement retirement income late in life, paying for everyday expenses, but others have viewed annuities as akin to bank certificates of deposit on which they can earn interest tax-free.
It is the latter use that the Government is trying to curtail. Under the budget plan that President Bush detailed in his State of the Union Message this week, the interest earned on annuities that lacked a significant "life contingency" would be taxed, just as the interest on bank C.D.'s is taxed.
In other words, if an annuity were designed so that the annuity customer or the customer's heirs were guaranteed a minimum payout regardless of when the customer died, the Government would take the position that the annuity was really a savings vehicle that deserved to be taxed.
At the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, Ted Athanassiades, a senior executive vice president, estimated that 90 percent of the annuities that the Met sold would not meet the Government's test for having a life contingency. Mr. Athanassiades argued that nevertheless the vast majority of annuity buyers did purchase their contract to supplement retirement savings and that the President's proposal would punish the majority in order to thwart a minority who viewed annuities as tax dodges.
"This is a great vehicle for long-term savings -- maybe because of the tax-deferred status," Mr. Athanassiades said. "Yet, the way the Government wants to require life contingencies, it would make the product unsalable."
 
Insurer Calls Proposal Unfair
 At Aetna, another major seller of annuity contracts, Tom West, a senior vice president, said the President's proposal was unfair for two reasons. For one thing, he said, it would require purchasers of annuities to decide when they bought their contracts (rather than at retirement) whether they wanted a payout with a life contingency.
"When people buy annuities, they don't know whether they will be married when they begin receiving their annuity, whether their spouse will be alive, or what their financial or health condition will be," Mr. West said. "And in any case, people should know that if they do die early their estate will get a refund of the unspent amount."
But at Indiana University, Prof. Joseph Belth, the editor of a prominent life insurance industry newsletter, the Insurance Forum, said that "in terms of pure tax theory, you could make an argument for what the Treasury is doing." He continued, "Their argument would be that as long as there is not a substantial insurance element to an annuity, it should not be treated as insurance for tax purposes."
He said that not even the American Council of Life Insurance, the industry's Washington-based trade group, questioned the tax logic of the President's proposal. Instead, Richard Schweiker, the former Senator from Pennsylvania who is now the council's president, focused on the possibility that the proposal would slow savings in the economy.
A similar theme was voiced by the Securities Industry Association, a Wall Street trade group, which argued that requiring brokers to pay taxes based on the increased value of securities they hold in inventory would weaken the industry's competitiveness versus foreign brokers and could actually draw capital out of Wall Street at a time when the public is concerned about the strength of financial institutions of all types.
"We are the only industry that is being asked to take things that are in inventory and treat them as sold," said a Merrill Lynch spokesman, speaking on condition that he not be identified.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT AT THE U.N.;
Security Council Summit Declaration: 'New Risks for Stability and Security'

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Following is the text of the declaration issued at the Security Council summit meeting here today:
The Security Council met at the headquarters of the United Nations in New York on Jan. 31, 1992, for the first time at the level of heads of state and government. The members of the Council considered, within the framework of their commitment to the United Nations Charter, "the responsibility of the Security Council in the maintenance of international peace and security." 
 The members of the Security Council consider that their meeting is a timely recognition of the fact that there are new favorable international circumstances under which the Security Council has begun to fulfill more effectively its primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security.
This meeting takes place at a time of momentous change. The ending of the cold war has raised hopes for a safer, more equitable and more humane world. Rapid progress has been made in many regions of the world toward democracy and responsive forms of government, as well as toward achieving the purposes set out in the Charter. The completion of the dismantling of apartheid in South Africa would constitute a major contribution to these purposes and positive trends, including to the encouragement of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.
 
Liberation of Kuwait
 Last year, under the authority of the United Nations, the international community succeeded in enabling Kuwait to regain its sovereignty and territorial integrity, which it had lost as a result of Iraqi aggression. The resolutions adopted by the Security Council remain essential to the restoration of peace and stability in the region and must be fully implemented. At the same time the members of the Council are concerned by the humanitarian situation of the innocent civilian population of Iraq.
The members of the Council support the Middle East peace process, facilitated by the Russian Federation and the United States, and hope that it will be brought to a successful conclusion on the basis of Council resolutions 242 (1967) and 338 (1973).
They welcome the role the United Nations has been able to play under the Charter in progress toward settling longstanding regional disputes, and will work for further progress toward their resolution. They applaud the valuable contribution being made by United Nations peacekeeping forces now operating in Asia, Africa, Latin America and Europe.
The members of the Council note that United Nations peacekeeping tasks have increased and broadened considerably in recent years. Election monitoring, human-rights verification and the repatriation of refugees have in the settlement of some regional conflicts, at the request or with the agreement of the parties concerned, been integral parts of the Security Council's effort to maintain international peace and security. They welcome these developments.
The members of the Council also recognize that change, however welcome, has brought new risks for stability and security. Some of the most acute problems result from changes to state structures. The members of the Council will encourage all efforts to help achieve peace, stability and cooperation during these changes.
 
New Challenges to U.N.
 The international community therefore faces new challenges in the search for peace. All member states expect the United Nations to play a central role at this crucial stage. The members of the Council stress the importance of strengthening and improving the United Nations to increase its effectiveness. They are determined to assume fully their responsibilities with the United Nations Organization in the framework of the Charter.
The absence of war and military conflicts amongst states does not in itself insure international peace and security. The non-military sources of instability in the economic, social, humanitarian and ecological fields have become threats to peace and security. The United Nations membership as a whole needs to give the highest priority to the solution of these matters.
The members of the Council pledge their commitment to international law and to the United Nations Charter. All disputes between states should be peacefully resolved in accordance with the provisions of the Charter.
The members of the Council reaffirm their commitment to the collective security system of the Charter to deal with threats to peace and to reverse acts of aggression.
The members of the Council express their deep concern over acts of international terrorism and emphasize the need for the international community to deal effectively with all such acts.
To strengthen the effectiveness of these commitments, and in order that the Security Council should have the means to discharge its primary responsibility under the Charter for the maintenance of international peace and security, the members of the Council have decided on the following approach.
They invite the Secretary General to prepare, for circulation to the members of the United Nations by July 1, 1992, his analysis and recommendations on ways of strengthening and making more efficient within the framework and provisions of the Charter the capacity of the United Nations for preventive diplomacy, for peacemaking and for peacekeeping.
The Secretary General's analysis and recommendations could cover the role of the United Nations in identifying potential crises and areas of instability as well as the contribution to be made by regional organizations in accordance with Chapter VIII of the United Nations Charter in helping the work of the Council. They could also cover the need for adequate resources, both material and financial. The Secretary General might draw on lessons learned in recent United Nations peacekeeping missions to recommend ways of making more effective Secretariat planning and operations. He could also consider how greater use might be made of his good offices, and of his other functions under the United Nations Charter.
The members of the Council, while fully conscious of the responsibilites of other organs of the United Nations in the fields of disarmament, arms control and nonproliferation, reaffirm the crucial contribution which progress in these areas can make to the maintenance of international peace and security. They express their commitment to take concrete steps to enhance the effectiveness of the United Nations in these areas.
 
Arms-Control Issues
 The members of the Council underline the need for all member states to fulfill their obligations in relation to arms control and disarmament; to prevent the proliferation in all its aspects of all weapons of mass destructions; to avoid excessive and destabilizing accumulations and transfers of arms, and to resolve peacefully in accordance with the Charter any problems concerning these matters threatening or disrupting the maintenance of regional and global stability. They emphasize the importance of the early ratification and implementation by the states concerned of all international and regional arms-control arrangements, especially the Start and C.F.E. treaties.
The proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction constitutes a threat to international peace and security. The members of the Council commit themselves to working to prevent the spread of technology related to the research for or production of such weapons and to take appropriate action to that end.
On nuclear proliferation, they note the importance of the decision of many countries to adhere to the nonproliferation treaty and emphasize the integral role in the implementation of that treaty of fully effective I.A.E.A. safeguards, as well as the importance of effective export controls. The members of the Council will take appropriate measures in the case of any violations notified to them by the I.A.E.A.
On chemical weapons, they support the efforts of the Geneva conference with a view to reaching agreement on the conclusion, by the end of 1992, of a universal convention, including a verification regime, to prohibit chemical weapons.
 
Monitoring Arms Transfers
 On conventional armaments, they note the General Assembly's vote in favor of a United Nations register of arms transfers as a first step, and in this connection recognize the importance of all states providing all the information called for in the General Assembly's resolution.
In conclusion the members of the Security Council affirm their determination to build on the initiative of their meeting in order to secure positive advances in promoting international peace and security. They agree that the United Nations Secretary General has a crucial role to play. The members of the Council express their deep appreciation to the outgoing Secretary General, His Excellency Mr. Javier Perez de Cuellar, for his outstanding contribution to the work of the United Nations, culminating in the signature of the El Salvador peace agreement. They welcome the new Secretary Gcapeneral, His Excellency Dr. Boutros Ghali, and note with satisfaction his intention to strengthen and improve the functioning of the United Nations. They pledge their full support to him, and undertake to work closely with him and his staff in fulfillment of their shared objectives, including a more efficient and effective United Nations system.
The members of the Council agree that the world now has the best chance of achieving international peace and security since the foundation of the United Nations. They undertake to work, in their own efforts and in close cooperation with other United Nations member states to achieve this, as well as to address urgently all the other problems, in particular those of economic and social development, requiring the collective response of the international community. They recognize that peace and prosperity are indivisible and that lasting peace and stability require effective international cooperation for the eradication of poverty and the promotion of a better life for all in larger freedom.
