HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Debate;
Bush's Economic Programs Are Target of 5 Democrats

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The five major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination assailed President Bush's economic recovery program tonight and offered alternative visions in a nationally televised debate that revolved as much around policy as personal swipes.
Tonight's debate reflected the pragmatic, meat-and-potatoes tone of this campaign as candidates aim their appeals at the hard-hit voters of New Hampshire, whose Feb. 18 primary is just a little more than two weeks away. The economy dominated, beginning with the candidates' biting response to President Bush's State of the Union Message Tuesday night. 
 Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska characterized the President's speech as "all hat and no cowboy." Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas said Mr. Bush did not seem to understand "the magnitude" of the nation's economic plight. "They just don't get it," he said. And Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa said Mr. Bush was promising simply "more of the same."
But there was some aggressive intramural jockeying among the candidates. Mr. Kerrey tried to present Mr. Clinton as a candidate who tried to be all things to all people, on issues from the Congressional raise to health care.
"At least tell the American people what you're for, what you're prepared to stand up and fight for," Mr. Kerrey said, asserting that Mr. Clinton attacked the Congressional raise in advertising after praising it in a private conversation. Mr. Clinton denied that.
Mr. Harkin tried to cast his rivals as being too close to the Republicans in their tax policies, particularly on the issue of capital gains. The Senator from Iowa, who presents himself as the most faithful Democrat in the race, asserted that support for a cut in the tax on capital gains, "however you slice it, favors the rich."
Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who supports such a cut if it is devised to enoucrage investment, noted that his rivals had treated him far more gently when they considered him less of a threat. "I've moved up in the polls and now I'm Darth Vadar," said the former Senator, who is second in many of the New Hampshire polls.
Mr. Clinton seemed to relish a return to the issues tonight, in his first major debate appearance since a supermarket tabloid published accusations that he had a 12-year sexual affair with an Arkansas state worker and sometime singer. Mr. Clinton has denied the accusations.
"I'm glad to be attacked by my opponents tonight; this is kind of refreshing," said Mr. Clinton, whose rivals took aim at his record as Governor of Arkansas but steered clear of the personal assertions , until the closing moments.
Then, Edmund G. Brown Jr., former Governor of California, raised the woman's assertions, an issue that Mr. Kerrey quickly denounced as "not legitimate." Mr. Clinton himself said that he had addressed the matter sufficiently.
Mr. Kerrey, still trying to ignite his campaign, spent much of the two-hour session emphasizing his commitment to cutting the deficit and reorganizing and streamlining the Government. He also touted his plan for national health insurance, which sparked one of the sharper exchanges of the night when Mr. Harkin asserted that Mr. Kerrey's plan was far too costly to the average taxpayer.
 
Special Interests Assailed
 Mr. Tsongas continued his efforts to present himself as the truth-teller, willing to avoid the easy path of tax cuts for the middle class, which are the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's platform. "I'm not running to be Santa Claus," said Mr. Tsongas. "I'm running to be President."
And Mr. Brown argued, once again, that the source of the nation's woes was a political system in the control of special interests.
The debate, the second of seven to be held during the Democratic primary season, was broadcast on PBS and held at the WETA-TV studios in suburban Virginia outside Washington. It was moderated by Robert MacNeil and Jim Lehrer.
After Mr. Lehrer suggested that Mr. Harkin's ideas were throwbacks to the New Deal, the Senator readily agreed. "The New Deal unleashed the greatest productive capacity Americans have ever seen," he said.
At one point Mr. Clinton jumped in and answered "yes" to a question posed to Mr. Kerrey about pumping up industry. That led Mr. Kerrey to take a swipe at Mr. Clinton, saying, "You're saying 'yes' to a lot of people these days."
While the candidates agreed that the Government must take more drastic steps to enhance the economy, they offered varied remedies.
Mr. Harkin said the most important thing the Government could do was to invest more in the manufacturing base. "I say the Federal Government has a responsibility to invest the resources of this country to building up the economic base," he said. "We're the richest country in this world. If we're so rich, then how come we're so poor?"
Mr. Tsongas took issue with Mr. Harkin, saying that businesses would not invest more without financial incentives. "I challenge you," he said to the Senator. "You go out in the real world to people trying to survive and you tell them what you said tonight."
The candidates also engaged in heated exchanges over their proposals for health care. Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Tsongas insisted that their plans were the most thought out, as Mr. Harkin argued that neither of them addressed the issue of prevention.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Harkin Searches for the Main Campaign Highway

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 30

 BODY:
Twice in one afternoon this week, Senator Tom Harkin's campaign motorcade abruptly pulled off the side of rural New Hampshire roads, doubled back and eventually found its way to events with voters.
They were apt side trips for a campaign that despite some enthusiastic crowds still seems like a stranger in the state that will hold the nation's first Presidential primary on Feb. 18. 
 Though Mr. Harkin was one of the first contenders to campaign actively in New Hampshire last year, the Iowa Democrat's organization somehow veered off course. He has remained at or near the bottom in polls of likely voters, and many strategists say his campaign lacks a political presence.
Unlike other Democrats who have fine-tuned their message or their delivery, Mr. Harkin continues to preach the same themes he did when he started here. But he has taken several steps to energize his campaign.
 
Adding Specifics to Message
 Most notably, he doubled the number of days he traveled in New Hampshire this week, making as many as 10 stops a day. To counter criticism that his message was too general while his rivals were offering details, Mr. Harkin produced a 35-page booklet that he cites at every stop. The booklet lays out his plan to revive the economy by spending less abroad, toughening trade policies and investing more in rebuilding the country. He also delivered a foreign policy speech at Harvard University, outlining his vision for slashing military spending and relying "less upon brute force and more on economic strength."
And to drive home his message, Mr. Harkin is starting to broadcast a third set of television commercials that emphasize his plan to stimulate the economy with new jobs and investment. They build on advertisements that the campaign began using last week, showing the Senator talking about creating jobs while the camera pans an abandoned mill in New Hampshire.
One new advertisement again uses the mill as a backdrop for Mr. Harkin, who recounts how he has defeated Republicans for 17 years and how he is "not trying to be all things to all people" and is the only "real Democrat" in the race. In a second commercial, Mr. Harkin speaks to an interviewer off camera about his opposition to tax breaks for the rich.
 
Drawing His Largest Crowds
 Mr. Harkin said these efforts were paying off. Indeed, he drew some of his largest crowds during his swing through the state this week. One reason for that, though, may be that the campaign only this week began using advance workers to help plan events and bring out crowds.
After speaking at a union hall here Wednesday night, Mr. Harkin was surrounded by several enthusiastic people, some of whom said they appreciated his folksy, traditional Democratic appeal. "I've been looking for someone like a next-door neighbor that I can vote for," one man shouted at Mr. Harkin.
As his van pulled away from the appearance, Mr. Harkin cited the event as evidence that voters were now focusing on the race and on his candidacy. "We've built a strong foundation," he said in an interview, "not on media hype, not on puffery. I've built my foundation on people who believe deeply in the things I believe in."
Despite the positive signs, even Mr. Harkin's supporters concede that he is still struggling to win notice.
"Why he doesn't seem to be catching on, I don't know?" said Michael Rowan, a New York consultant who has managed campaigns in New Hampshire and is informally advising Mr. Harkin. "He's got this ability to strike emotional chords, but it's not an ability that's been used. Everybody's struggling. How do you get the guy's message out?"
 
Accentuating the Positive
 Searching for even the most meager signs of momentum, Barry E. Piatt, the campaigns press secretary in New Hampshire, boasted that Mr. Harkin's support in the polls had quadrupled. But it was hardly a surge: from 2 percent to 8 percent in one survey.
While Mr. Harkin has insisted that he wants to challenge Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas on the issues, not on assertions about his personal life, the Senator's aides say the campaign is positioned to gain from Mr. Clinton's troubles.
"Clinton has kind of stalled in his tracks right now," said Kathi Rogers, the Harkin campaign director in New Hampshire. "We're moving up."
But rather than gain from Mr. Clinton's troubles, Mr. Harkin has been overshadowed by them.
On Monday, the Senator traveled across New Hampshire visiting disabled people to celebrate what he called his greatest legislative achievement, the Americans With Disabilities Act. The sometimes emotional visits drew scant attention in the local press, which was filled with news about Mr. Clinton's trials.
Even with his stab at specificity on an economic blueprint, Mr. Harkin's basic speech remains unchanged. He prefers anecdotes about growing up "on the wrong side of the tracks" and the one-liners about "whipping George Herbert Hoover Bush," sarcastically changing one President's middle names from Walker.
"People are looking not for someone to solve all their problems but for a fresh approach," said Representative Dick Swett, a New Hampshire Democrat who is staying neutral in the primary. "I don't know if that's the reason they haven't flocked to Harkin."
 
'It Hasn't Changed'
 After listening to Mr. Harkin's speech in Portsmouth, Finn Connell, an entrepreneur, complained: "It's the sixth time I've heard it and it hasn't changed. The same questions. The same answers. The same speech."
Joseph Miller, a doctor from Plymouth, said, "I'm an old-time liberal and I'd like to go with Harkin, but he doesn't stir fire in my gut yet. At the moment, I feel he's haranguing rather than presenting a thoughtful discussion of the issues."
But Mr. Harkin is counting on people like Marie Shaginaw, an elementary school teacher who shivered for nearly an hour in the cold the other day before Mr. Harkin appeared to meet residents of Andover, N.H.
"He seems sincere when he talks," she said. "I like the way he comes across. And I think the way a candidate comes across sometimes is more important than what they say."

HEADLINE: Spotted Owl Dispute Jolts Another Timber Region

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RESERVE, N.M., Jan. 24

 BODY:
Six months ago, the sawmill in this remote mountain town was the area's largest employer, humming 20 hours a day and providing jobs for 140 people as mill hands and loggers.
These days, though, the work forces here and at other mills in the Southwest have been reduced by about 40 percent, a reflection not of the sagging national economy but of an environmental dispute usually associated with a very different part of the country. 
 The issue here is the Mexican spotted owl, a cousin to the northern spotted owl, which lives in the deep woods of the Pacific Northwest and is the focus of a bitter dispute involving the Federal Government, logging interests and environmentalists.
In June 1990, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service designated the northern spotted owl a threatened species, saying excessive logging of its habitat was a major cause of its decline. The agency has since proposed restricting logging on 6.9 million acres to save the owl from extinction.
Two months ago, the wildlife service determined that logging in the Southwest was rapidly destroying the dense forests in which the Mexican spotted owl lives and proposed that that owl also be listed as a threatened species.
Because logging accounts for only a small part of the Southwest's economy, the spotted owl debate here has not risen to the fevered pitch that it has in the Pacific Northwest. Still, timber-reliant towns in New Mexico and Arizona, the states where the most Mexican spotted owls have been found, are suffering.
Under a plan to protect the owl while it is studied, the United States Forest Service has temporarily closed thousands of acres of Federal land in the Southwest to logging. Michael Gardner, a Forest Service ranger, said timber production in the Gila National Forest, which surrounds this town of 500 people, was down 50 percent from a year ago and was expected to drop another 25 percent next year.
 
A Rippling Effect on Town
 The town of Reserve is already reeling. Public school enrollment has fallen 20 percent, teachers have been laid off and businesses have lost customers as families moved away in the search for jobs.
"It's been like a stone dropped in the water," said Sue Spurgeon, the school district's business manager. "The ripples are going everywhere. Some people think that protecting an owl is more important than making a living."
But area environmental advocates say officials of the Forest Service and the logging industry, not spotted owls, bear responsibility for any turmoil.
"There has been overlogging going on in the Southwest for years," said Robin Silver, a doctor and environmentalist in Phoenix who petitioned the Government to protect the Mexican spotted owl. "And one result is that there are hardly any old trees left for wildlife."
Forest Service officials estimate that 2,000 Mexican spotted owls live in the United States, about one-third the number of the northern spotted owl. To the casual observer the two look almost identical, but the Mexican variety has darker background plummage and larger and whiter spots, giving it a somewhat brighter appearance.
A big question in the public debate is whether the two owls, while similar in appearance, differ in habits.
 
Questions About Habitat
 Forest Service officials, who oppose designating the Mexican spotted owl as a threatened species, maintain that the bird behaves differently from its northern cousin and as a result is not in danger. They say that while the northern variety is typically found only in ancient forests with dense canopies, the Mexican variety has adapted to a wider range of habitats.
Wildlife researchers who want the Mexican spotted owl protected say that while it does inhabit a diverse area, older and denser forests are its principal habitat. A further danger from logging, they say, is that it has opened the area to two predators of the Mexican spotted owl.
Whatever its preferred home, the Mexican spotted owl has become a symbol of a larger debate over public lands and logging. James Norton, regional director for The Wilderness Society, said his group was pushing hard for protection of the Mexican spotted owl because Forest Service officials plan to open steep mountain slopes in several national forests to logging. "Those are the last places in the Southwest that haven't been logged," Mr. Norton said.
While the primary method of logging here differs from that in the Northwest, Mr. Norton and some scientists say the effect on the owls is the same. The favored technique here, known as shelterwood, involves cutting all older trees in an area and then periodically harvesting other trees when they reach a particular size.
Mr. Norton said, "the net effect of shelterwood is the same as clear-cutting," the primary method in the Pacific Northwest in which all trees in an area are cut at the same time.
Jerry Drury, a manager with the forest products division of Stone Container Corporation, said he believed that such concerns were overstated. "We are being forced to carry the Northwest's environmental baggage," said Mr. Drury, whose company operates the sawmill in Reserve.
Public hearings on whether to protect the Mexican spotted owl are under way, and a decision by Federal wildlife officials is expected in about a year. But as people here await that decision, the discussions in coffee shops and on street corners in communities like Reserve echo those 1,000 miles away in the Northwest.
"This isn't just about wildlife," said Vic Jenkins, a rancher. "It's about a way of life."

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Securities Inch Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in light trading yesterday, a bounce that most traders said represented a slight correction to big declines posted earlier in the week.
Credit market participants have been ignoring reports of continued economic weakness all week, and data released yesterday, including a three-tenths of a percent drop in the Government's index of leading economic indicators during December and a 6.6 percent decline in new-home sales, were no exception. 
 Instead, traders spent much of the session speculating on the Treasury's coming quarterly refunding auctions, and whether the size of the bond auction will be cut from the $12 billion sold in November.
 
Anticipated Size of Auction
 "The market is looking for the size of the bond auction to be cut by $2 billion to $4 billion," said Stephen W. Gallagher, a money market economist at Kidder, Peabody. "Since Treasury has spent so much time talking about the issue, I would expect some selloff if they don't cut it."
Comments by Richard G. Darman, the Federal budget director, reinforced the notion among traders that the size of the bond auction would be pared. An announcement on the refunding auctions is expected from the Treasury on Wednesday.
After saying his remarks should not be construed as indicating that a decision had been reached, Mr. Darman told the Senate Budget Committee that any move to issue fewer 30-year bonds would represent a "prudent, modest shift" toward shorter-term maturities.
The remarks helped to push up bond prices slightly, but market participants said the session was mostly one of preparing for what promises to be a full week.
"There are a lot of important events coming up next week that will likely set the market tone for February," said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
In addition to the refunding announcement, the Federal Reserve's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled to begin a two-day meeting on Tuesday. And on Friday, January employment data are expected from the Labor Department.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 10226/32 , up 9/32 , to yield 7.75 percent, compared with 7.78 percent late Thursday and 7.70 percent on Jan. 24.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10119/32 , up 7/32 , to yield 7.26 percent. And the 4 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9919/32 , up 5/32 , to yield 5.09 percent.
 
Rates on Bills Slip
 Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower. Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.82 percent, down two basis points, or two-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.90 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 4 percent, down four basis points.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT AT THE U.N.;
Bush Asks Security Council To Put Sanctions on Libya

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 31

 BODY:
In meetings with members of the United Nations Security Council, President Bush sought today to shore up support for a new resolution imposing sanctions on Libya for its refusal to extradite two suspects in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am 103 for trial in the United States, Administration officials said.
In his meetings at the United Nations, Mr. Bush spent 20 minutes with Prime Minister Li Peng of China, the first meeting between the leaders in nearly three years. 
 With the Administration facing another fight with Congress over the extension of China's trading privileges, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said Mr. Bush had told Mr. Li that the Chinese record on human rights was "insufficient" and needed "significant improvement."
 
Response 'Not Acceptable'
 But Mr. Baker indicated that Mr. Li had merely dismissed Mr. Bush's concerns by saying that China did not accept the idea that its record on human rights can be judged by other countries' standards, a position that is increasingly likely to result in Congress's placing conditions on favorable tariff treatment for Beijing.
Mr. Baker said Mr. Li's response was "not acceptable under our standards."
Mr. Li's address to the Security Council earlier, which made the same point on human rights, offered little comfort to American officials.
Earlier today, Mr. Baker said Mr. Bush and President Francois Mitterrand of France, who met this morning at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, had discussed the wording of the proposed new resolution against Libya, which American officials said was being drafted and could be presented in early February.
The United States wants the resolution to go beyond merely condemning Libya for not complying with a resolution passed unanimously by the Security Council on Jan. 21 demanding that the two suspects in the 1988 bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland, be surrendered.
"Terrorists and their state sponsors must know there will be serious consequences if they violate international law," Mr. Bush said in an address to a summit meeting of the 15 Security Council nations, seeking to link the Western standoff with Libya to the Council's concerted action against Iraq after it invaded Kuwait.
The Bush Administration wants some sort of sanctions imposed against Libya, at a minimum an embargo on airline flights to and from Libya and on sales of aircraft parts, officials said. "There's not much support at the Security Council for more than that," one official said today.
 
Policy Produces Little
 Although Mr. Bush pressed Mr. Li to improve China's human rights record, American officials said Mr. Bush had already concluded that the current leadership in China is unlikely to do that.
They conceded that his policy of "engagement" with Beijing since the nationwide crackdown on dissent in China in 1989 has produced little in the way of results.
Still, the officials said, Mr. Bush is likely to veto any measure by Congress that would attach conditions to the extension of China's most-favored-nation tariff treatment. Such legislation could be passed as early as next week.
In this political climate, officials said, Mr. Bush hoped primarily to get through the meeting, which the Chinese requested, with as little embarrassment as possible.
"It was our judgment that we had to do this meeting and we're trying to do it with as little attention as possible," a senior official said.
 
Preparing for Yeltsin Meeting
 While Mr. Bush met with his fellow leaders in New York, the Administration was preparing for the meeting at Camp David on Saturday with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
Officials traveling with Mr. Bush said the two were expected to announce a date for a formal summit meeting sometime between April and July. One said an earlier date seemed the likeliest possibility.
But American officials said arms control was not at the top of either leader's list of issues for their first meeting since the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the emergence of Russia as the successor to the old Soviet state.
Mr. Bush is eager, however, to get more details from Mr. Yeltsin on his recent arms control proposal.
The Russian leader's plan was a response to Mr. Bush's suggestion that both sides eliminate land-based multiple-warhead missiles -- the heart of Russia's deterrent force -- in exchange for a one-third cut in the number of nuclear bombs the United States keeps aboard submarines.
Mr. Yeltsin replied by calling for even deeper cuts than Mr. Bush suggested, and by proposing that the United States abandon its "Star Wars" antimissile program in favor of a global network to protect against missile attack.
The Bush Administration's initial response to that proposal was cool.
Because the two proposals remain inchoate and because the United States is still unclear about Mr. Yeltsin's arms control philosophies and the depth of his knowledge and engagement on the issue, the two leaders are expected to confine their pronouncements on nuclear disarmament to a vague commitment to "continue the process."
"Bush expects most of the discussion tomorrow will be on economic reform," a senior official said in New York.

HEADLINE: Donors Give Again and Again to The Times' Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
"This is the first time I am making a second contribution to the Fund," began an anonymous letter attached to a $100 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "Although I expect to lose my white-collar professional job, and I also expect to have a difficult time finding work, I realize that I have many more resources to fall back on than many and that no matter how bad things get there are many others that are far worse off than I."
As the 80th annual Neediest appeal enters its final month, many people who gave earlier in the campaign have sent additional contributions. Rather than holding off because this year's campaign has already raised a record amount of money, they have responded because of their concern that the recession and government cutbacks have left New York's poor, sick and disabled more dependent on private charity. 
 Matthew D. Wachsman of Scarsdale has made at least three separate contributions. One of them -- a check for $100 -- honored his mother: "My mother and her husband have escaped to the beaches of St. Thomas, where they are doubtlessly luxuriating under warm sun. However, they know that the city that awaits their return is still filled with hopelessness and despair. They are sensitive to the seriousness of the situation and speak of 'answers.' I have, on many occasions, spoken with them about homelessness, welfare and the effects of a slow economy. We do not always agree. However, we all agree that your Neediest Cases Fund is an important part of what helps to keep many of the neediest going."
Diane Siebert Reed of Edison, N.J., made her first contribution in December when she asked her company to donate the money it usually spent on employee gifts to the Neediest Cases. "However, great ideas start at home, so with that in mind, enclosed is my donation," she wrote. She sent $50.
Philip and Fay Cohen of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., gave an additional $2,000. "We recognize that you provide a sorely needed service in alleviating the suffering of those unable to meet their basic needs," they wrote.
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's destitute. The newspaper covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed on directly to seven charities.

HEADLINE: Shoe Chain For Gap Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Gap Inc., the highly successful retailer of casual clothes, plans to start a separate chain of shoe stores, according to a published report.
New York Newsday reported yesterday that the Gap's real estate offices on the East and West Coasts were searching for sites for the new stores. 
 A Gap spokesman said the company would not comment on the article.
It had been expected that the Gap, which is expanding at an explosive rate, would begin looking for other retailing directions to move in. As the company reaches its saturation point in stores, it must find other ways to continue to grow financially.
The company, based in San Francisco, had 1,221 stores at the end of December, up 12 percent from a year earlier. Besides its flagship Gap stores, the company also has Gap Kids and Banana Republic outlets.
The Gap's sales have been soaring despite the recession that has sliced into sales and profits for other big retailers. The chain's moderately priced sweaters, shirts and jeans appeal to a wide range of customers.
The company's sales at stores open at least a year -- considered the best yardstick of a retailer's performance -- rose 12 percent during the first 11 months of the 1991 fiscal year.

HEADLINE: Acts of Hate From the Past: Bias Crimes in New York City Are Nothing New

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Thirty-four years ago, Luis Garden Acosta was a pudgy 13-year-old eager to show off the streets of Brooklyn to a country cousin newly arrived from Puerto Rico. But when he refused to step aside for six black teen-agers on De Kalb Avenue, he found himself shoved, cursed and dragged screaming down the street until blood seeped through his shredded clothing.
Days later, a gang of Hispanic youths surrounded him and shouted, "Get the chink!" refusing to believe that the boy with almond eyes was not Asian until he spewed out a torrent of Spanish pleadings. 
 Mr. Garden has been thinking a lot about 1958 lately.
For many New Yorkers who came of age in working-class neighborhoods in the 1950's and 1960's, last month's bias attacks and retaliations have jarred loose recollections of an era when such beatings were not uncommon and often unreported.
"Somehow we accepted the danger of not making it to school in one piece," said Mr. Garden, 46, the executive director of El Puente, a youth center in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. "It was a kind of purgatory. If we got through and atoned for whatever sins, we would reach the promised land of adulthood."
In many ways it is a different world. There are legal guarantees against segregation and penalties for bias crimes. With the public more sensitive to these issues, victims of bias crimes no longer have to endure their indignities in silence while the offenses are swept under the rug.
But while there is no valid comparison of the crimes then and now, and the tensions between race and turf may be harder to sort out, there are those who wonder how far the city and race relations have advanced in the decades since they ventured through the streets.
"All that stuff existed, you know," said Dion DiMucci, who was a Bronx teen-ager who rose to fame as leader of the singing group Dion and the Belmonts. "There was a lot of denial in the 50's. It was all suppressed."
 
'It's a Blindness'
 Many times, neighborhood youths would declare they were going to chase after some black youths, even though nobody knew why. "That always struck me as a real peculiar shortcut to becoming a man," said Mr. DiMucci, now 52 and living in Florida. "If I could just put somebody under me because he's poorer, Puerto Rican, black, Chinese or whatever. It's a blindness."
As a teen-ager in love with rhythm-and-blues, he traveled often between his Italian Bronx neighborhood and the recording studios and Harlem stages where he jammed with the black musicians he admired. Once, he brought Frankie Lymon, the boyish heartthrob who sang with the Teenagers, to his block only to be surrounded by his friends bristling with anger at the sight of a black person in their close-knit neighborhood.
"My friends wanted to beat him," Mr. DiMucci recalled. In fact, he said, he defused the situation by breaking into impromptu street singing.
But he was less successful when the neighborhood's first black family moved next door to him on Prospect Avenue and East 183d Street, provoking a barrage of rocks and invective from the neighborhood toughs.
"I remember walking into my house one day and catching the eye of one of the family next door," he said. "Time kind of froze for me because I was looking at this person there. Is this supposed to be an enemy? He looked a lot like me. In the eyes, anyway."
 
The Wrong Look
 Growing up on the Lower East Side, Carlos Mateo knew that when he ventured too far from the Vladeck Houses and gave someone the wrong look, he could expect a fight. He and his Puerto Rican friends, who belonged to a clique they called Club 16, learned to avoid walking past the candy store on Henry Street where the May Rose, a clique of Italian and Irish youths, often taunted and fought with them.
"Our situation was more in groups that had a certain area they wanted to control as a group," said Mr. Mateo, 50, who now lives on Long Island. "There was always the name calling, they'd call you spic and you'd call them wop. But that was just the way we talked."
By the time Ernest Kelly became a teen-ager in the 60's, the turf battles grew in intensity and consequences. This was the dawn of the street gangs. He joined the Dirty Dozens, a gang with many black members.
Entire neighborhoods were off limits, like Soundview and Parkchester where white gangs like the Golden Guineas would clash with outsiders, drawing certain retribution.
The recent spate of bias crimes unleashed memories of those clashes and prompted the 38-year-old youth counselor to speak to the teen-agers at his Bronx center about the futility of retribution.
The only consolation he and others took was that such crimes were being highlighted today, although sometimes they felt they were being milked for sensationalist value by the media.
Richard Price, the Bronx-bred author of such novels as "The Wanderers," an account of street gangs, said the notion of a bias attack is only a convenient handle for something that has been going on for ages. "It seems to me that it's every group's God-given right to hate every other ethnic group," he said sarcastically.
He said that current concern over these crimes often degenerates into ethnic scorekeeping as groups trade accusations.
"It's like 'You did it!' 'No, our boys were victims!' 'Oh yeah, what about that girl?' Nobody is talking about it, they're just taking sides," he said.
Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said the clashes and attacks that have occurred since the 1986 death of Michael Griffith in Howard Beach show that the city hasn't come that far since the 50's and the advances of the civil rights era.
He said that city officials and civic leaders have to go beyond condemning the bias crimes and put together a strategy that goes to the economic and sociological roots of the problem.
"In the absence of that," he said, "the bully back on the street corner gets the silence and gets the impression that it's O.K. to beat up on people."

HEADLINE: Brady Finds Upbeat Message Reciprocated

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAPLES, Fla., Jan. 31

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady came to this opulent Florida seaside resort today to convince the captains of American industry that an economic recovery was on its way and that the President's economic proposals would hasten it. The surprise was that his audience, which has been struggling for three years in the toughest economic times since the early 80's, needed little convincing.
"I think we're ready to take off," said Dexter F. Baker, the chairman and chief exeuctive of Air Products and Chemicals Inc. in Allentown, Pa. "We have all the ducks lined up. Washington has done enough." 
 The affable Mr. Baker, who accompanied President Bush to Japan last month, is chairman of the annual meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers here this weekend.
Despite their disappointment with the swollen Federal budget deficit and Washington's unwillingness to do more for them, the executives generally said that the President's economic package presented this week would help their companies. Virtually all the executives interviewed here said they expected a modest rebound later this year and no significant decline before then.
"My personal forecast is that the economy will start to turn by summer," said Stanley C. Gault, the chairman and chief executive of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in Akron, Ohio.
But most executives were not quite as upbeat as Mr. Baker or Mr. Gault. They said they planned to act cautiously in hiring and spending on inventories and on new plants and equipment.
"We're not counting on a 3, 4, 5 percent recovery," said Larry D. Brady, the executive vice president of the Chicago-based FMC Corporation, which makes chemicals and industrial equipment.
A minority of executives, including Mr. Baker and Mr. Gault, reported evidence of a rebound already. "January is off to a good start," said W. H. Clark, the chairman and chief executive of the Nalco Chemical Company, which is based in Naperville, Ill.
 
Goodyear Recalling 900
 Consumers are finally starting to replace the tires on their cars, said Mr. Gault. The result: Goodyear is producing 9,000 more tires a day and has just recalled 900 furloughed workers. "We're delighted to be leading the crusade," Mr. Gault said.
Mr. Brady, the Treasury Secretary, said in a speech that his own neighborhood economic consultants -- his car mechanic, his grocer, his convenience store manager -- also saw a turnaround. "There's been a change in feeling out there," he said. "It's not abrupt, but it's a sea change."
But for most of the executives at the Naples meeting, business remains sluggish. "We haven't seen a pickup, though we've seen no deterioration, either," said Jack Hartley, the chief executive of the Harris Corporation, whose products include communications and office equipment
The executives cited lower interest rates, low inflation, successful cost-cutting and brisk buying by foreign customers as setting the stage for an economic rebound.
Cooper Industries, a maker of electrical equipment and power tools in Houston, said Robert Cizik, its chairman and chief executive, is saving tens of millions of dollars this year in interest costs. FMC's interest savings this year are the equivalent of a 5 percent jump in its operating earnings, the company said.
 
Expecting Quick Demand
 After several years of cutbacks, companies expect a quick pickup in production once demand improves.
"We've gone through restructuring," said Daniel J. Krumm, the chairman and chief executive of the Maytag Corporation in Newton, Iowa. "We froze salaries and all that; inventories are way down, and so, more importantly, are our dealers' inventories. The minute business turns up, we'll crank up our factories, and that will mean more jobs."
Manufacturers have discovered that selling in foreign markets is a boon in bad times. "That's where the rubber meets the road," said Mr. Baker of Air Products, which is selling more oxygen plants in Japan than in the United States these days.
Mr. Krum of Maytag reported record exports, with sales booming in the former East Germany. "I didn't know they had carpets over there, and now we're selling vacuum cleaners like gang busters," he said.
 
Being Optimistic
 The Treasury Secretary urged the executives to "err on the side of optimism." But while a number of the executives said they were spending more on new plant and equipment last year and hiring selectively, others said they would remain cautious.
"We will be frugal in our investment, frugal in our inventory," said Mr. Brady, the FMC executive vice president. "We will continue to bet on the downside rather than the upside."
Mr. Bush's economic package, which includes tax breaks for investment, first-time home purchases and the real estate industry, won the executives' approval. "The right issues are being addressed," said Mr. Brady of FMC. "They need to be addressed on a permanent basis."
The Treasury Secretary said that Jerry J. Jasinowski, the president of the manufacturers' association, had a hand in the Treasury's crafting of the investment tax allowance and alternative minimum tax relief.
 
$10 Billion to Be Raised
 The Treasury estimates that the combination of the investment tax allowance and the changes in the alternative minimum tax will raise corporate cash flow by more than $10 billion, a prospect especially appealing as companies are finding it difficult to raise prices in order to lift profits.
Mr. Brady of FMC said his company had not made up its mind to increase investment beyond the $30 million hike already scheduled over last year's $230 million.
But some companies have already decided that Mr. Bush's inducements are too good to refuse. Mr. Baker of Air Products said his company would dig into the $100 million backlog of projects that had been postponed this year. "We will increase investment 10 or 15 percent above what we had planned," he said.
 
Sampling Others' Thoughts
 Even as this gathering takes place, many executives are forming their plans by mingling with others, most of them in candy-colored golf clothes.
"Executives are sampling each other's opinions," said Mr. Jasinowski, the association's president. "What they get out of this meeting will be big input into their plans."
And this approach has the approval of Treasury Secretary Brady himself. "I don't base my judgment on economic statistics," he said. "The way to tell where the economy is going is to talk to people."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metal Prices Rise Despite the Slack Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metals futures advanced yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange despite economic news that could signal a dwindling need for the metals.
Gold for February delivery settled $3.60 higher at $357 an ounce; March silver was 3.5 cents higher at $4.18 an ounce. 
 Investors in precious metals futures normally look to a healthy economy before buying. Silver prices often rely on industrial demand for the metals. Gold is bought as an investment hedge against inflation.
Economists, noting weak housing starts, fewer orders for durable goods and continued layoffs, said the nation's gloomy outlook was likely to continue through the first half of the year.
Despite that outlook, traders have been reluctant to let precious metals fall below certain key levels, said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York.
"I think the market is just reacting to the oversold conditions from yesterday," Mr. Cardillo said yesterday. "There's nothing really out there to cheer about."
Energy futures were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude prices were held to a narrow range as traders mark time ahead of the Feb. 12 meeting in Geneva of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which could make significant cuts in production to prevent prices from collapsing.
Crude for March delivery settled 4 cents higher at $18.90 a barrel; February home heating oil advanced 0.71 cent, to 52.85 cents a gallon; February unleaded gasoline rose 0.38 cent, to 55.89 cents a gallon; March natural gas advanced 1.4 cents, to $1.180 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Corn and soybeans futures prices ended mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade at the close of a lackluster session. Wheat advanced.
Wheat for delivery in March settled 4 1/2 cents higher at $4.40 1/2 a bushel; March corn was 1/2 cent higher at $2.64 a bushel; March oats were 4 cents higher at $1.52 3/4 a bushel; March soybeans were 3/4 cent lower at $5.72 a bushel.
Investors in corn and wheat futures were hoping the Agriculture Department would announce as early as next week new purchases of the crops. The former Soviet republics get their next export credit allocation at that time, and there was some thought that the Government would move up other aid disbursements. Traders hoped that President Bush might announce more United States aid to the Commonwealth of Independent States after a meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia this weekend at Camp David.
"People were afraid to sell ahead of that just in case something comes out of it, which it probably won't," said Dan Cekander, a grains analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. in Chicago.
Wheat also gained on tight supplies and strong near-term export demand.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Post Sharp Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Sales of new homes tumbled 6.6 percent in December, the Commerce Department said today, wiping out nearly all of November's gains and dragging down the year's total sales to the lowest level in nine years.
Sales fell in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 522,000, after a revised rise of 7.9 percent in November. It was the biggest decline since a 10.8 percent drop in January 1991, when sales fell to 414,000 as the Persian Gulf war began. 
 The actual sales total for 1991 was 504,000, down 5.6 percent from 1990. The decline made 1991 the third straight year of falling sales. Sales were the lowest since 1982, also a recession year, when they slumped to 412,000.
 
Looking for a Tax Break
 Nonetheless, some housing industry analysts remained upbeat about the prospects for 1992, especially if Congress approves the $5,000 tax break for first-time home buyers that was proposed by President Bush in his State of the Union Message.
"Needless to say, we are looking forward hungrily to the prospect of a tax cut," said Dave Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders.
Economists also said they were heartened by Monday's report of a slim rise in sales of existing homes in December. The gain, nine-tenths of 1 percent, put those sales at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.34 million. The rise, the third straight monthly increase, was reported Monday by the National Association of Realtors.
 "We still have evidence, in combination with existing-home sales, that fourth-quarter 1991 new-home sales were generally on an upward path, and we think that continued in January," said Dick Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association.
 
A Significant Sector
 Although new-home sales are a smaller proportion of the housing market than sales of existing homes, they are a more sensitive barometer of consumers' willingness to take on large financial commitments. Many new homes are bought by people moving up to larger, more expensive houses as their financial circumstances improve.
The Commerce Department said the biggest drop in the December sales rate was in the South, where sales fell to 210,000, from 258,000 in November. Sales also fell in the Midwest, to 90,000 from 96,000.
The sales rate rose in the West to 164,000, from 155,000 in November, and climbed in the Northeast to 59,000 from 50,000.
Mortgage interest rates, although still close to their lowest levels since the 1970's, have risen slightly in recent weeks.
Interest rates on longer-term Government bonds strongly influence the rates offered to homeowners seeking 30-year mortgages. The bond rates were coming down sharply until two weeks ago, when they began rising.
 
The Industry's Outlook
 Mr. Seiders, whose association includes thousands of small building contractors, said: "We are forecasting a 15 percent increase for sales of new homes in 1992 because we believe there is a lot of pent-up demand that lower interest rates so far have not let loose. But the red herring is that recent backup in long-term interest rates. It is of great concern to us."
 On a year-to-year basis, the median price of a new home fell in 1991 for the first time in more than 20 years.
The median price -- at which half the homes cost more and half cost less -- was $120,000 in 1991, down from $122,900 in 1990. The last decline occurred in 1970, a drop to $23,400, from $25,600 in 1969.
Today's report said the median price in December was $123,800, up 5.5 percent from the November level.
In a separate report released today, the National Association of Realtors said new homes became less affordable in December because prices were creeping upward.
The realtors group said a family earning the median income of $36,696 had 124.2 percent of the income needed to qualify for a mortgage on a median-priced house, down slightly from 124.4 percent in November.
Still, the group said that homes remain more affordable than they have been in more than a decade.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
How to Evaluate Early Retirement

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
With corporations across America reducing their payrolls, thousands of older workers are being offered early retirement. Evaluating the offer is the first big decision, and if the answer is yes, a series of important choices follow.
"Where an employee truly has a choice as to whether to keep working or to retire early, all income and expense aspects of continuing to work must be balanced against those of retiring," Sidney Kess, co-editor of Commerce Clearing House's audio cassette series that accompanies its Federal Tax Advisor information service, said recently. 
 Addressing a continuing education conference sponsored by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, Mr. Kess said, "Sometimes a person may find he's continuing to work for just a few dollars an hour." He gave this example based on 1991 rates: Elizabeth, age 62, has a salary of $72,000. After Federal income taxes of $22,320, Social Security and Medicare taxes of $4,355 and commuting and work-related expenses of $5,040, she nets $40,285.
If she accepts an early-retirement offer, she will receive a bonus of $30,000, or $10,000 for each of the three years prior to age 65, as well as full pension benefits of $21,000, or 30 percent of her average earnings of $70,000 for the last three years. She can also get I.R.A. income of $10,000, Social Security benefits of $9,400 and distributions from her 401(k) plan of $2,000. She will have to pay $14,787 in Federal income tax and $4,800 in medical insurance premiums that her employer now pays. That leaves her with a net of $32,813.
The difference between working and retiring is $7,472, Mr. Kess said, and based on a standard work year of 1,960 hours, in effect, she would be working for $3.82 an hour. Of course, such numbers must worked be out for each person, and often state and local taxes must be considered.
For people nearing retirement or already retired, T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore-based mutual fund manager and investment adviser, is offering an excellent free kit called "Retirees Financial Guide." Like the Retirement Planning kit, which the firm began offering two years ago to help working people plan for retirement, the new kit has worksheets and extensive help in filling them out, as well as information on issues that affect financial security in retirement. It is available by calling, 1-800-541-4041.
Steven E. Norwitz, vice president of the firm, who spent a good part of the last year putting the kit together, said, "The kit is designed to help retirees determine how much they can afford to spend and maintain their purchasing power throughout retirement."
These are among the topics covered:
*Investing a bonus offered as an incentive to retire, as well as other savings.
*Tax and investment implications of leaving money in a pension plan, rolling it over into an I.R.A. or taking it as a lump sum.
*Budgeting for expenses in retirement, making inflation-adjusted projections based on life expectancy.
*Withdrawing money from retirement plans, including I.R.A.'s, and Keogh and 401(k) plans.
*Evaluating health insurance for people below age 65, coverage available for those 65 and over from Medicare, Medigap and long-term care coverage.
*Benefits and filing requirements for Social Security.
Social Security is available at age 62, but monthly payments are reduced, so people who plan to work part time after retirement may want to delay filing for Social Security and get full benefits later. Another factor in making this decision is that up to half the benefits are taxable for people above certain income limits. The kit has examples of how working after retirement can result in reduced benefits, as well as increased taxes on the benefits -- one of the many tax pitfalls retirees face.
Mr. Norwitz said, "The need for financial planning is as great after retirement as it was during the working career." Also, he noted, with the current decline in interest rates, many retirees need to reposition holdings to maintain income.
"As far as their investments are concerned, we find that many retirees tend to be too conservative in their strategy and overlook the impact of inflation on their savings," he added. "People who retire in their early 60's can expect to live another 25 or 30 years. As a result, they should have some growth-oriented investments in their portfolios to preserve their purchasing power. In the kit, we discuss various strategies to cope with inflation."
Of course, there are personal considerations, as well, in deciding whether to take early retirement. Mr. Kess recalled that one client found his office more peaceful than his home, where three generations lived under one roof, "so I told him to continue working." Another person, generously inclined, had soon given away a good portion of her retirement bonus to relatives with sudden needs. "You have to look at the psychological aspects," Mr. Kess said, "not just the numbers."

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush Reneges on Mass Transit

 BODY:
President Bush wants to chop half the Federal aid that New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and more than 60 other large cities hoped to get for operating buses, subways and commuter rail lines next year. Those cities and their environs have roughly half the nation's population and 90 percent of its mass-transit traffic. Is Mr. Bush serious about helping urban America? Apparently not.
Mass transit has been starved by Washington since President Reagan took office. Transit aid, discounted for inflation, is now 50 percent smaller than in 1981. The six-year Federal transportation program enacted last year was supposed to reverse that. It authorized $5.2 billion for the 1992-93 fiscal year, starting Oct. 1 -- nearly 40 percent more than this year. But the President's budget proposes only $3 billion. That's a devastating 20 percent cut from current spending, and less than Mr. Bush himself proposed last March. 
 Mr. Bush conceded in his budget message that Federal clean air standards would put a heavier burden on transit systems. He didn't mention that America's cities and snarled suburbs need relief from traffic jams, nor that the entire nation needs to conserve oil. And he seems to have forgotten that he hailed the transportation bill for providing "jobs, jobs, jobs." His mass-transit cuts would mean 130,000 fewer.
Mr. Bush wants only to help build new systems and modernize old ones, not keep them running. Incredibly, he thinks their survival is not a national concern. His budget shrinks next year's operating subsidies to $1 billion, where the new law authorized an increase to $2 billion.
New Jersey offers a grim example: The current subsidy for N.J. Transit's buses and commuter rail lines would be slashed 90 percent, to $4 million. This could only mean higher fares and reduced service. Nationwide, even new projects and modernization take a hit. The new law authorized $2.8 billion; Mr. Bush would provide only $1.6 billion.
The good news from the White House on this score is the President's endorsement of Congressional proposals to increase the tax deduction for businesses that subsidize employees who commute by mass transit. For the rest of his proposals, it can only be hoped that Congress will abide by last year's promise.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Create a U.N. Fire Brigade

BYLINE: By Joseph S. Nye Jr.; Joseph S. Nye Jr. is author of "Bound To Lead: The Changing Nature of American Power."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
If a new world order is ultimately to emerge from yesterday's summit meeting of the world's leaders at the U.N., they will have to stretch their imaginations.
The U.S. should go beyond rhetoric to promote a new order because it will remain the world's largest power well into the next century. To achieve this, the U.S. ought to propose the creation of a U.N. rapid-deployment force. 
 The climate seems highly suitable for such a force, given the mood at the summit for an expanded role for U.N. peacekeepers.
We had a chance to help create a new order in the 1920's but refused to join the collective security system of the League of Nations and to cooperate in stabilizing the international economy. This isolationism returned to haunt our country with the rise of Nazism.
By contrast, growing interdependence today justifies our need for a cooperative world. Evidence of this interdependence is overwhelming.
In 1950, trade was 4 percent of our gross national product; today, it is 13 percent. Thirty-three percent of American economic growth since 1986 can be traced to exports. The international monetary flow, which is 25 times as large as the flow of goods, constrains our ability to control capital markets and determine interest rates.
More and more, political issues -- migration, global warming, the drug trade, the spread of AIDS -- cut across national boundaries. No country can manage them alone.
The technology of destruction is spreading. At least 10 poor countries have major weapons-exporting industries, 20 of them can make chemical weapons, 15 can make ballistic missiles and 9 probably have nuclear weapons.
In enforcing collective security against Iraq, the U.S. had to take the lead because it was the only country that could do so. On the other hand, the Bush Administration was wise to urge the European Community and U.N. to take the lead in mediating the conflict in Yugoslavia and to encourage the Organization of American States to deal with the coup in Haiti.
But what about aggression in which the U.S. has no direct interest beyond the abstract principles of collective security: Libya's invasion of Chad, the mercenary invasion of the Maldive Islands, the invasion of Rwanda by Uganda-based exiles?
A rapid-deployment force that could deal with such problems should be made up of 60,000 troops in brigades from 12 countries.
This force, intended to repel aggressors, would be different from United Nations peacekeeping operations that are interposed between sides in civil wars after the fighting stops.
It could be formed around a core of 5,000 soldiers, who would hold regular exercises to develop operational procedures.
Such a small force could not stop civil wars like the one in Yugoslavia or intervene if, say, there was military conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia or major aggression like Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Under these circumstances, an American-led coalition would be necessary. (In the event of a clash between nuclear states such as Russia and Ukraine, a U.N. role would be unlikely because of the Security Council veto.)
But the force would insure that the collective security effort established during the Persian Gulf war would not be squandered by indifference to smaller conflicts.
America does not want to become a world policeman, dragged into every distant dispute. Our involvement in a rapid-deployment force should be limited to logistical support.
Although the two-superpower world order has collapsed, a one-power world is an illusion. The need for new institutions is at hand.

HEADLINE: The Hollowing of New York

BYLINE: By Ronald K. Shelp; Ronald K. Shelp is president of the New York City Partnership, a group of business and civic leaders, and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

 BODY:
New York City is threatened by a corporate exodus as dangerous as that of the early 1970's, when more than 30 major corporations and their thousands of jobs left. While that involved the departure of entire companies, today we face a hollowing of the business base, as companies move thousands of mid-level jobs out of the city while their corporate headquarters remain here.
In the 1980's, many businesses moved data processing and other routine back-office functions out of Manhattan. But recently, many front-office positions in administration, legal affairs, sales and marketing have been transferred. 
 Modern technology permits many jobs to be done as effectively in Kansas, Florida or even Ireland. Other locations are often closer to markets, safer and more affordable for employees, and offer a higher quality entry-level workforce.
Contrast these advantages with New York's rising costs and eroding services, and even executives who would prefer to keep employees here find it increasingly difficult to justify such a decision to their partners and directors.
This hollowing process draws fewer headlines than did the corporate departures of firms such as J. C. Penney, W. R. Grace and American Home Products. But companies as varied as Metropolitan Life Insurance, I. T. T. and Salomon Brothers are relocating thousands of employees elsewhere.
New York City can take immediate steps to change the growing negative perceptions about doing business here.
* Put an end to the cost spiral. Combined city and state taxes are the highest in America. Mayor David Dinkins made a welcome proposal this week for a four-year freeze on property taxes. The city budget should go further and put a four-year freeze on all personal and business taxes, while proceeding with the scheduled elimination of the personal income tax surcharge in 1993.
* Improve management in order to maintain services during restructuring. Cutting services to the bone merely to keep the city out of the hands of the Financial Control Board is not the answer. As revenues decline, the city needs to take the same difficult steps that service companies have taken to transform themselves. The administration's most recent financial plan calls for workforce reductions of at least 20,000 jobs. But more important than the final headcount is persuading municipal unions to make significant concessions in work rules and productivity. This would help halt job cuts, improve services and bring the budget closer to permanent balance.
* Send the right signals. New York City residents and businesses need to know that government leaders have a vision for the future and are taking steps now to fulfill it. The Mayor should quickly name an experienced and distinguished business executive to fill the vacancy created by Sally Hernandez-Pinero's expected departure as Deputy Mayor for Economic Development. The city should institute a few highly visible projects such as cleaning up the roadways between the airports and the central business districts, to demonstrate that it can do things quickly and effectively.
* Speed up privatization. The city's financial plan cites Off-Track Betting and the Parking Violations Bureau as candidates for privatization. The processing and recycling of solid waste should be added to that list immediately. And we should take advantage of new Federal laws encouraging privatization of transportation projects including building, maintaining and operating bridges and roads.
City officials can be justifiably proud of their efforts in recent years to prevent the relocation of a number of major corporations. But we must remember that we cannot afford even partial desertions. Limiting our focus to retaining headquarters in the city could lead to a hollow victory.

HEADLINE: A Victory for the New American Family

BYLINE: By James D. Marks; James D. Marks is a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union.

 BODY:
Six years ago, a New York City couple, one a pediatrician, the other a psychologist, had a child. They had lived together since 1978. Together, they changed their son's diapers, attended P.T.A. meetings, learned the names of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Until the decision on Thursday in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan, though, only one of the adults was recognized as the boy's legal parent. Why? Because both are lesbians.
Before the ruling, New York closed its eyes to the bonds between the boy and his non-biological mother, the pediatrician. If the boy were sick, the pediatrician could not have given permission for treatment, let alone use her insurance to cover medical costs, unless she had the most progressive of employers. If she died, the law would not have recognized the boy as her heir automatically. If she and his legal mother, the psychologist, had separated, he would have had no certainty of economic support or even contact with both parents. 
 With the decision -- in a case in which I represented the couple -- New York joins California, Oregon, Washington, Alaska, Vermont and the District of Columbia in permitting same-sex second-parent adoption. If both members of a same-sex couple wish to be a child's parents, the legal parent's partner may adopt the child and become its second parent, just as stepparents adopt the children of their spouses.
According to various studies discussed by the court, three million to four million gay and lesbian Americans have had children. Some gays and lesbians have adopted children and others, like the Manhattan couple, have arranged to conceive children biologically.
Despite the numbers, legal acceptance of gay and lesbian parents has been slow in some places.
In fact, Florida and New Hampshire have enacted laws prohibiting lesbians and gays from adopting under any circumstances. The remaining states have not formally addressed the issue.
Some people opposed to such households argue that lesbian or gay parents adversely affect the psychological development of children. But research accepted by the New York court shows no difference between their children and those raised by heterosexuals. The boy, who now has two legal parents, has grown up with plenty of contact with men and women, straight, lesbian and gay, and their children. He is happy, well-adjusted and, incidentally, no more likely to grow up gay than a child of heterosexuals.
Other fears are older and subtler. Roman law termed the male head of household the paterfamilias and gave him complete authority over his children, including the right to sell them or put them to death. Today, in issues related to privacy, like abortion, euthanasia and same-sex parents, some people think of the state as paterfamilias, with rights to manage the bodies of its citizens. Permitting gays and lesbians to raise children challenges that model of state authority: if the family does not need a traditional father, neither does the nation.
The state, like a family, is dysfunctional when it forces nontraditional relationships into the closet. Until a 1967 Supreme Court ruling, some states prohibited marriage, sex or procreation between blacks and whites. Today, a black Supreme Court Justice is married to a white woman. Our nation can learn to open its eyes and accept diversity.
This week's decision is a triumph. It recognizes a functioning family in law as well as in practice. Other states should follow New York and sustain the very real bonds between children and parents who love and care for them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New York Piers Make Business Go Elsewhere

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Because of the increase in containerized rail cargo, you report Jan. 13, millions of tons of products arrive in the New York City region annually without ever crossing a Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pier. 
 When I was in the used-clothing-export business a decade ago, the prohibitive economics of using New York piers made it cheaper for exporters to truck thousands of tons of bailed clothing to Philadelphia for loading on ships bound for Asia than to use the local piers.
Three or four days later, I could see the same ships docked at Port Authority piers in Brooklyn from the offices of our warehouse, also in Brooklyn. But despite the proximity, loading fees, fueled by the city's rent and other charges, union work procedures and operational inefficiency, made it cheaper for exporters to ship through Philadelphia.
Apparently, importers now find the same conditions exporters experienced 10 years ago.
 
AVRUM HYMAN
Bronx, Jan. 16, 1992

HEADLINE: Observer;
. . . And Go to Sleep

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
The tipoff came when the Bush people said the speech would be a "defining moment." That was what they had called the gulf war this time last year -- a "defining moment" -- and now they were recycling it to ballyhoo a speech.
They didn't even have any new phrases, for Pete's sake. How could they possibly have a new idea? Applying "defining moment" to that perennial brain-glazer, the State of the Union speech, should have told us how things stood: to wit, that this outfit is so sure it's home safe for another four years that it doesn't even feel the need for fresh bluster, much less a fresh thought. 
 As if to flaunt his contentment with last year's crowd-grabbers, the President addressed the economic recession with the same chilling words he used after Saddam Hussein seized Kuwait: "This will not stand."
What does this mean? That the recession is going to get Schwarzkopfed unless it comes to its senses and clears out of America pronto? Of course not. It means, "Prosperity is just around the corner."
This seems to be the Republican belief. It rests on faith that low interest rates will work restorative magic in time to assure the usual Republican Presidential victory. While waiting for Mr. Prosperity the masses can presumably be calmed with the action-packed oratory of yesteryear.
"This will not stand."
Republican calmness about the recession owes a lot, too, to the Democratic Party, as it is still called out of ancient custom and utter disregard for fact. Bush and Friends now seem to believe the Democrats as usual will come along quietly and not raise a fuss when the campaign starts.
If the election is the usual Republican cinch, the President can stay relaxed about the recession, as a good hard-money Republican ought to, instead of falling for cockamamie quick-fix schemes now being urged by big-government hotheads.
Hence: "This will not stand." Or, in the less dynamic Hoover idiom, "Prosperity is just around the corner."
What was well defined by Mr. Bush's speech was his contempt for the possibility that the Democrats can threaten his re-election. At present, contempt seems thoroughly justified.
Democratic Presidential campaigns in modern times invariably become catastrophes sooner or later. This year's went catastrophic earlier than sooner. What fun imagining the cackling with which Roger Ailes, the Republican Party's own Doctor Huer, must be rubbing his hands as he watches the Clinton story unfold.
(All right, kiddies: Dr. Huer was the scientific genius with the lightbulb-shaped head without whom Buck Rogers would surely have lost outer space to dark-eyed Killer Kane, who was sort of the Willie Horton of the 25th century.)
It wasn't bad enough that the press's anointed Democratic front-runner had Gennifer Flowers to deal with. Not bad enough that this associated him with the kind of newsmakers who see Elvis and J.F.K.
No, that wasn't bad enough, so on television his wife, Hillary, managed to offend Tammy Wynette, the favorite country singer of many a music-loving American whose vote the Democrats would love to have, including white Southern males. It was almost as though Roger Ailes had already started his devilish work, but it still wasn't bad enough.
So Gennifer Flowers, who had been taping her phone chats with the Governor, produced a tape to outrage Mario Cuomo: a piece of chitchat with Gennifer saying she "wouldn't be surprised if he didn't have some Mafioso connection" and Governor Bill saying, "Well, he acts like one."
"An offense to Italian-Americans and it's an offense to every other ethnic group," said Cuomo. Clinton's phone apology to Cuomo only emphasized how bad things could get when Cuomo said Clinton "should save himself his quarter."
Roger Ailes won't really take advantage of all this when the time comes to carve up the Democrats for Bush, will he? Say you won't, Roger, so we can see how fast the Republicans will hire somebody who will.
Still, it could be even worse. Yes, and what's more it is even worse. The Gennifer-Bill-Tammy-Hillary-Mario farrago has the press so mesmerized (see this column) that it never gets around to mentioning the other Democrats in the running, some of whom even look competent.
No wonder George Bush can't be panicked into giving the recession the Schwarzkopf treatment. Prosperity is just around the corner.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Seize the Hour, Day or Moment

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
AS RICHARD NIXON, IN the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, lifted a glass 20 years ago to toast the beginning of a new relationship between the United States and China, he quoted from a poem by Mao Zedong: "So many deeds cry out to be done/Always urgently./The world rolls on./Time passes./Seize the day. Seize the hour."
When it came to titling his new book, however, about America's challenges in a "one-superpower world," the former President seized neither the day nor the hour. The title: "Seize the Moment." That was no spur-of-the-day decision; Mr. Nixon wanted to instill an even greater sense of urgency, or to express the essence of the idea without slavishly following the cliche. 
 Others are willing to stick with the old form. In the final scene of Steven Spielberg's new movie, "Hook," a sequel to "Peter Pan," the rejuvenated old man named Tootles, after a liberal sprinkling of Tinkerbell's fairy dust, flies out the window and soars over London shouting, "Seize the day!"
Robin Williams, who plays the grown-up Peter, starred in an 1986 film based on a 1956 novella by Saul Bellow. Its title: "Seize the Day."
The historian David McCullough, in his new book, "Brave Companions," makes the same choice as Nixon. He relates an anecdote about the painter John Singer Sargent, who had been hanging around the White House hoping to talk Theodore Roosevelt into posing for a portrait. The two men met unexpectedly as the President was descending the stairs, and the artist asked when would be a convenient time to pose. Said Roosevelt, in his typically decisive way: "Now!" McCullough writes: "So there he is in the painting, standing at the foot of the stairs, his hand on the newel post. . . . Moments come and go, the President was telling the painter. Here is the time, seize it, do your best."
As should be apparent, moment-seizing is in, even more than day-seizing; hour-seizing seems to be missing its time. The phrase's origin, presuming there to be no earlier usage in Chinese literature, is in the Latin carpe diem. The verb carpere means "to pluck, grab, seize," from the Greek karpos, "fruit"; it's what you do to ripe fruit on the vine. There may be a connection between carpere and the verb to carp, of Scandinavian origin, "to pick on, find fault with," as in "those carping liberal Democrats" in Mr. Bush's what-recession rhetoric. The noun diem is "day," as everyone who puts in for per diem knows, though few expense-accounters pronounce it correctly: it's DEE-em, and the whole phrase is KAR-peh DEE-em.
There's a phrase that has changed its meaning radically. When Horace wrote his odes, carpe diem, quam minimum credula postero meant "seize the day, put no trust in tomorrow." Lord Byron, a swinging Romantic poet, wrote in an 1817 letter: "I never anticipate -- carpe diem -- the past at least is one's own, which is one reason for making sure of the present."
That live-for-today meaning was expressed in the 1867 novel "Under Two Flags" by "Ouida," the pseudonym of the English novelist Louise de La Ramee, writing of "the reckless life of Algeria" with its "gay, careless carpe diem camp-philosophy." The Daily News of London grumped in 1901: "The 'Carpe diem' philosophy is not the philosophy of happy people." Its synonymous expression is "Eat, drink and be merry," the advice of the worldly author of Ecclesiastes (8:15), to which the prophet Isaiah added a fatalistic note: "Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we shall die."
The amalgam of hedonism and existential resignation, of the pursuit of pleasure and the anguish of transience -- the only-come-this-way-once ambiance of beer commercials -- is the opposite of the phrase's meaning today. Now we think of riding the tide in the affairs of men, which Shakespeare said could lead on to fortune; to change metaphors, seize the day has come to mean "strike while the iron is hot." No longer is carpe diem the what-the-hell attitude of the dwellers in the present; it has become the battle cry of the gutsy opportunist with an eye on the future.
I had to handle this topic today. You know what attitude drove me to it.
 
 
BANAUSIC AIN'T BANAL
The Supreme Court struck down New York State's "Son of Sam" law, which would have denied profits to perpetrators from writings about their crimes; as a First Amendment freak, I read with fascination the text of Simon & Schuster v. New York State Crime Victims Board.
Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, writing the Court's opinion, quoted Henry Hill, a gangster now in the Federal Witness Protection Program and the subject of Nicholas Pileggi's 1985 book, "Wiseguy: Life in a Mafia Family" (as the Court opinion put it, "hereinafter Wiseguy").
Although Mr. Hill admitted pulling off the largest cash robbery in United States history, the 1978 theft of $5.8 million from Lufthansa Airlines, Justice O'Connor wrote, "Most of Hill's crimes were more banausic."
That word was new to me (and to Robert D. Sack of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, who called the case to my attention). Banausic (pronounced buh-NAW-sik) is defined in Merriam-Webster's Ninth New Collegiate as "concerned with earning a living." It is rooted in the Greek banausos, "artisan," a word that then had a pejorative connotation: working with the hands was considered a grubby thing to do by the types who strolled about in sheets.
On further review, as they say at football games, the adjective banausic now has two senses: one is "banal, spiritless, having no character or zip"; the other is "mechanistic, mired in routine, lacking in creativity." The Oxford English Dictionary's Supplement notes that the word (which comes after banana) is no longer rare, evidence of a pickup in usage, but adds no new definition to its original "merely mechanical."
What did Justice O'Connor mean? I shot her a postcard: "Was your meaning banal or mechanical? Have you used banausic before?"
"I intended it to mean 'mundane,' " she replies. "I have not used the word previously in an opinion, but once in a while it is satisfying to include a word that is not overused."
Mundane has two senses: "prosaic, commonplace, workaday," as the context of Justice O'Connor's opinion suggests, and the less common "materialistic, temporal" as opposed to "spiritual." I would drearily go into the etymology of mundane, but that would be (what's the word that follows banana?) banausic.
