HEADLINE: ABOUT MEN;
Prime-Time Heroes

BYLINE: By Eric V. Copage; Eric V. Copage, an editor of this magazine, is the author of "Kwanzaa: An African-American Celebration of Culture and Cooking."

 BODY:
No one told me that because I am black I couldn't be Superman. No one told me I couldn't be Peter Gunn, the wild, wild James West or John Drake, Secret Agent Man.
These television paladins of yesteryear came up during a recent dinner conversation. A companion told me a black friend of his, roughly my age, had felt hobbled by the lack of African-American heroes and the prevalence of negative stereotypes on television during his childhood. While I knew that television programs could adversely affect self-esteem, I also knew, through my own experience, that it needn't be that way. And as my 4-year-old son and 16-month-old daughter hurtle through the world, I know I must do my best to nurture them the way I was nurtured. 
 When I was growing up, virtually all the main characters on TV were white. But that didn't prevent me from being lost in space with Billy Mumy or diving under the sea with Lloyd Bridges. When "I Spy" premiered in 1965, the precedent of Bill Cosby's starring role was lost on my 10-year-old mind. I watched because Scotty (Cosby) and Kelly (Robert Culp) were so cool that they could wisecrack in the face of death, which was the same reason I admired John Steed and Emma Peel -- "The Avengers" -- played by Patrick Macnee and Diana Rigg, both of whom, of course, were white.
It's not that I was oblivious to color. I remember feeling an emotional dissonance between ending the pledge of allegiance at school "with liberty and justice for all," and going home to see TV news footage of blacks fire-hosed for demanding to eat and walk where ever they chose. In the integrated and white middle-class neighborhoods of Los Angeles, racial epithets had been hurled at me. Yet the racial violence seemed distant and surrealistic, and I never went home crying as a result of a racist remark.
Rather, the reality of my home was the most powerful one I had. The adults in my life told me I could do anything if I was determined and resourceful. Granted, being middle-class made this easy to accept. But the people who gave me this advice had come from backgrounds that were far from middle-class. My father, for instance, grew up during the Depression in the ghettos of Chicago, yet managed to become a successful real-estate broker and never dwelt on the disadvantages dealt him. My mother, a housewife and sometime actress, grew up poor but didn't seem alienated from society.
And when, as a youngster, I'd tell my father my big plans for the future -- to buy the company that made Colgate toothpaste and change the name to Copage -- he'd just give me a sly smile that seemed to say proudly, "That's my boy," as any middle-class father would. I was expected to be ambitious because there was an intrinsic pleasure in excelling, not because I had to prove anything to whites.
Even the Watts riots of 1965 failed to convince me that to be black was to be helpless and hopeless in America. My father owned a hamburger stand in Watts as an investment, and hired local teen-agers to work at the counter. They didn't dress as I did, and they sure didn't take the music, karate and acrobatics classes children in my neighborhood routinely attended. Yet I believed that if these teen-agers continued to work hard and look for opportunities, they could make better lives for themselves, as my father had for himself.
Over the next two years, however, a sense of otherness took root in me. In my mostly white junior high school, I was asked whether I preferred being called Negro or black. I began hearing chants of "black is beautiful." That being black was to be somehow tragic and full of rage was played out on the TV news, where I saw black Americans talking about revolution and shooting clenched-fist salutes in the air. In the midst of this, I began to doubt myself and the values I had grown up with. I feared I might be an "Oreo."
This conflict was brought into vivid relief for me in 1968. I was 13 when my 6-year-old brother, Marc, was tapped to play the part of Corey Baker in "Julia," the half-hour sitcom that starred Diahann Carroll as a widowed nurse trying to raise her young son (my brother). Julia was middle-class, beautiful and smart, and lived with her son in an integrated apartment building.
Being the first series since "Beulah" in 1950 to star a black woman, "Julia" received a fair amount of publicity, and more than a fair amount of vitriol. Black activists and some white television critics said the series, produced and written by whites, was "unrealistic" because it did not address the black rage blazing across America's inner cities.
But for me, "Julia" was as real as television gets, no more sanitized or hyperbolic than "I Love Lucy" or "The Patty Duke Show." And besides, the show, with its black characters functioning without pathology in a "white" world, was enough like my life to seem grounded in reality. Were the show's critics charging that my family had forsaken our blackness? Yes, I avidly listened to Bach and Beethoven, but to Charlie Parker and Miles Davis as well. True, when my grandmother cooked chitlins, I shut the kitchen door to contain the stench, but did that make me less black?
For years after that I had a knee-jerk response to television's depiction of black people and black family life: Was the "social reality" that was not a part of "Julia" more "black"?
Still, the fact is that no black person ever complained to me about the life depicted on "Julia." On the contrary, in our conversations about the show, blacks of my acquaintance seemed proud. Certainly, I reasoned, seeing Greg Morris as the expert technician on "Mission: Impossible" or Denise Nicholas as a concerned and conscientious school counselor on "Room 222" could inspire a black child to reach beyond his social limitations.
Recognizing the power of television made me restless for further change. Sidekick status was just not good enough. Why didn't James Earl Jones play Chief Ironside and get chauffeured by some trusty white soul? Why couldn't Captain Kirk be black? And speaking of the Enterprise, why hadn't it ever run into black aliens?
As my friend and I walked to his bus stop after that recent dinner party, we talked about how the depiction of blacks has changed over the past 25 years. Today my children routinely see black judges, lawyers, obstetricians and cops on "Sesame Street," "The Cosby Show" and "Mister Rogers's Neighborhood." This is good. And with Cosby, Oprah Winfrey and Quincy Jones, blacks are beginning to control their own images. That is even better.
But a parent's encouragement, regardless of his or her economic or social circumstance, is more powerful than any cathode-ray-tube hero. Besides, throughout America's history, its good will toward blacks has always come sporadically, been slow to gather force and quick to dissipate. Television has been a mirror of that. As my friend boarded the bus and waved goodbye, I thought I'd continue to teach my children what I had been taught: that they needn't see a black become President or win the Indy 500 on television before feeling they can do it in real life.

PUB-DATE: February 2, 1992

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1983 words

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
On Rap, Symbolism And Fear

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
Over the last decade rap has become the epicenter of popular music and a significant influence on fashion, visual arts and language. But to much of the American mainstream, rap is an outlaw music that otherwise well-informed people vilify and fear. Rap marks a generation gap. As young people dance to it, some elders pronounce it unlistenable and others are disturbed by its messages. There's a perception gap, too, reinforced by media, both responsible and irresponsible, that reflexively connect rap and violence. The reasons generally have less to do with rap's rhetoric than with larger tensions of race and class.
Trouble at the movie "Juice"? Commentators point not just to its crime-story plot, but to its rap soundtrack. (No riots have been reported, however, at "The Addams Family," which has a theme song by Hammer.) People trampled to death at an ineptly promoted, poorly policed basketball game at City College in New York? Out come the statistics about violence at rap concerts, although the rap celebrities were invited to shoot hoops, not to perform. 
 No one considered it odd when City College revealed it has a standing policy against presenting rap-related events; imagine the reaction if klezmer or country music were prohibited. And when, shortly after the City College deaths, three times as many people gathered without arrests or major incidents for a rap concert at Madison Square Garden, at least one television correspondent played up a minor altercation as if it eclipsed the whole show. Television, tabloids and some newspaper columnists tend to present rap as one indivisible, alien morass: "an increasingly sociopathic form of pop music," quoth one Washington Post contributor.
Rap gets plenty of publicity when it turns most offensive. When Ice Cube spews racist demagoguery on his album "Death Certificate," or when Public Enemy releases a video clip that sets out to honor Martin Luther King Jr. by killing a fictitious senator and governor of Arizona, shows like "Nightline" pay attention.
But too many people leap from a handful of lyrics to blanket denunciations. The bulk of rap lyrics, in fact, completely ignore whites, to concentrate on boasting and, lately, lectures on black self-help. While rap-haters focus on the racism of Ice Cube and the sex-and-guns fantasies of N. W. A., they tend to ignore the many rappers who plead for an end to violence, and who find a wide audience. Chubb Rock, for instance, had a No. 1 single on Billboard's rap chart with "Treat 'Em Right," which urges fellow rappers to bring "decency" back to lyrics and tells would-be gang warriors, "Leave the knife and gun in the store and ignore temptation."
Hip-hop culture, which also includes dancing, fashion and visual arts, has been widely available for at least 13 years -- longer in the right neighborhood. As early as 1974, disk jockeys in the South Bronx were chopping up and recombining music on multiple turntables, and they were soon joined by rhyming rappers. In 1979, the Sugar Hill Gang released "Rapper's Delight," the single that announced the arrival of a new genre. Kurtis Blow took rap further up the pop charts with "The Breaks" in 1980; Blondie's "Rapture," the first white rap hit, followed in 1981.
In pop terms, that ought to be ancient history. By the time rock-and-roll was 13 years old, in the mid-1960's, only the most lunatic of fringes still denounced the entire genre as a threat to public morals and safety. Rap hasn't had it so easy. There are still some people proclaiming that it's not music, and more who are convinced that rap exists only to incite violence, corrupt children and destroy all that is good and decent.
Why hasn't rap's success, with performers ranging from Run-D. M. C. to Hammer to P. M. Dawn, made it just another branch of entertainment, taken for granted? Obviously, rap has become a symbol in a United States obsessed with race.
Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat, wrote in The New York Times that contemporary political campaigns use crime as "a marker for race." Rap is an even more precise marker: despite the growing number of rappers who are white, female, suburban or all three, rap is still overwhelmingly made by young, black, urban males -- a demographic segment that many Americans consider threatening. Hating rap, a purportedly esthetic judgment, can be a synonym for hating and fearing young black men.
Yet clear-cut racism is only part of the anti-rap sentiment. As a matter of taste, hip-hop does challenge older pop esthetics. Unless a rap song lifts a whole melodic hook from an older song, as Hammer does, it's likely to be atonal or tuneless, building its catchiness on a slogan, a rhythm or a sound effect -- closer to non-Western music than to Tin Pan Alley. In that, however, it is part of a larger trend in popular music; other styles like speed-metal and industrial rock also downplay melody in favor of rhythm, texture and impact. To listeners weaned on the jolting jump-cuts and assertive self-promotion of television and the electronic soundscape of video games, rap sounds familiar. If it annoys parents, all the better.
Rap is also foreground music, abrasive and insistent, perfect for blasting from a club sound system or a portable boom box or a car stereo; people who use Bach or Bon Jovi as congenial background music are irritated by the noise. But opera also shrieks for attention, and it doesn't trigger the kind of self-righteous response that rap does.
Some reactions against rap involve historic friction among races and classes. In "Popular Musics of the Non-Western World" (Oxford University Press, 1988), Peter Manuel writes that new kinds of music usually arise from "an unassimilated, disenfranchised, impoverished, socially marginalized class." Styles as far flung as Greek rebetika, Jamaican reggae, Argentine tango and American jazz have all trickled up from outcast or gangster netherworlds, eventually to be embraced by middle and upper classes (some seeking vicarious thrills), while drawing widespread denunciations on the way up. In that, hip-hop is true to form.
But when suburbia embraced hip-hop during the 1980's, the alarmist reactions only increased. For one thing rap remains defiantly unassimilated, profane and disdainful of middle-class proprieties. In the mainstream American imagination, blacks have historically been considered the Other, the opposite of the mainstream's genteel self-image. That mysterious, imagined Other is considered uncivilized, sex-crazed, irrational, angry.
Hip-hop, many commentators have inveighed, is intended solely to spur violence, race hatred and general lawlessness. Not so coincidentally, that's what those commentators fear from an urban black population whose prospects deteriorated steadily through the 1980's.
It's not hard to detect signs of a guilty conscience projected onto the Other. Rap often sounds like a young black man shouting; what else would he be shouting about, thinks a listener who can't understand all the words, but how angry he is at people like me? And how he's going to hurt us?
Rap is not so single-minded. Hundreds of thousands of words have been rapped on recordings in the last decade, on innumerable subjects: Egyptology, sex, sneakers, gang vendettas, the recession. Chuck D. of Public Enemy has compared rap to a black cable-news network, but rap also has something in common with citizens'-band radio and computer bulletin boards. Rap mixes public messages and private references, distress calls and jokes, information and fiction, retorts and pontifications. Sensationalism and images of violence appear, along with occasional glints of racism.
Rappers, of course, are not philosopher-kings. Like rock musicians, many rappers are immature or stupid or wildly egotistical, and they don't always hang out with the nicest people. Some rappers use criminal records as proof of authenticity, as Leadbelly did in the 1930's. And some, recognizing that outlaw images sell, set out to shock and titillate, claiming the same artistic license as the makers of, say, "A Nightmare on Elm Street." If young black men are to be stereotyped, their raps suggest, then they'll exaggerate the stereotype as far as it will go.
To be "hard" -- to please a hypothetical "street" audience that will only accept the most brutal scenarios -- too many rappers confuse manliness with misogyny and homophobia. Gangster rap, rap's equivalent of action-adventure films, offers frightening messages in abundance, for those who want to find them.
Many political rappers are followers of the Rev. Louis Farrakhan's Nation of Islam, whose message of black self-reliance has been widely criticized for invoking anti-white and anti-Semitic racism. Farrakhan-ite rappers tend to be more circumspect, saying "devils" instead of "white devils" and usually condemning the system rather than the race of the people who run it. Lately, Public Enemy and other rappers have denounced self-destructive elements among blacks -- drug dealers, gangsters, alcoholics -- as much as they've attacked outsiders. But Public Enemy gets far more attention for its blunders, like the video clip for "By the Time I Get to Arizona," which ignores Martin Luther King Jr.'s philosophy and chooses revenge (and machismo) over persuasion.
Even at its rare racist extremes, rap simply picks up demagogic ideas that have long been heard on ghetto streets, allowing them to be monitored -- and answered -- and reminding a wider public that racism can cut two ways. Sensible or virulent, rap also continues to be a voice of the disenfranchised; unlike David Duke, no rapper has yet been a serious contender for public office.
David Samuels, writing in The New Republic (Nov. 11), contended that gangster raps and racist raps (which he conflates with all of rap) foster a "voyeurism and tolerance of racism in which black and white are both complicit," particularly when whites treat gangster raps as a window into ghetto life. But only a naive listener would fail to distinguish between tall tales and reportage.
As a business, hip-hop has problems akin to early jazz and early rock-and-roll: a mixture of honest and fly-by-night entrepreneurs, some of whom exploit both performers and fans. And yes, rap audiences, with some members from poor, crime-wracked communities, can include troublemakers. But the vast majority of concertgoers are happy to see metal detectors and extensive security, and rappers on stage invariably urge audiences to stay peaceful. The sensationalist image of rappers inciting slavering hordes to acts of mayhem has no basis in reality.
Rap's internal troubles reflect the poverty, violence, lack of education, frustration and rage of the ghetto. Yet in the end, rap is not a way of exporting those troubles, but a way of transcending them.
People who can't afford musical instruments or lessons -- and who aren't getting much music education in the wake of school budget cuts -- have made their own music with turntables, changing the passive act of playing records into the active creation of new songs. People who might be proving their toughness in street fights are, instead, proving themselves with elaborate boasts and taunts, trading physical threat for verbal dexterity. Rap has also provided new, legitimate avenues for entrepreneurs and technicians -- it testifies to the spirit of free enterprise.
It's time to recognize what rap is: a huge, varied symbolic realm, too big to be stereotyped. There are smart rappers and idiotic ones, positive forces and nasty ones, rappers who want to teach and rappers who want to pander and rappers who just want to make people laugh. Until rap is treated as something other than a terrifying monolith, people within hip-hop may well be justified in thinking that, to the outside world, they all look alike.

PUB-DATE: February 2, 1992

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1834 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
One People in Two Worlds

BYLINE: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN; Samuel G. Freedman is the author of "Small Victories," a finalist for the 1990 National Book Award, and the forthcoming "Upon This Rock," about a black church in Brooklyn.

 BODY:
As Idi Amin expels the entire Asian population from Uganda, early in Mira Nair's new film, "Mississippi Masala," soldiers halt a busload of fleeing Indians. They order one woman outside, at gunpoint, and open her suitcase, searching for currency or jewels. Instead they find a tape recorder and, still suspicious, demand she play the cassette already cued. Out pours a song from an Indian film, its words translated by subtitles into English.
"My shoes are Japanese/ My pants are English/ My red hat is Russian/ But my heart -- it's all Indian. 
 With the odd and abrupt power of popular culture, the song becomes the anthem of a diaspora, the Indian diaspora that animates Ms. Nair's film, which opens Wednesday. She follows the woman's family from Uganda through England to Mississippi, where they manage a roadside motel called the Monte Cristo and shop at the Piggly Wiggly even as they cling for identity to a homeland few of them have ever inhabited.
In evoking their odyssey, with its agonizing compromises between fidelity and assimilation, Ms. Nair has undertaken one of the most gripping subjects for contemporary Indian and Pakistani artists, many of them born or educated abroad. Salman Rushdie's novel "The Satanic Verses" and the film "My Beautiful Laundrette," written by Hanif Kureishi, followed the migrants to England, while V. S. Naipaul has set books in the expatriate communities of Africa and the Caribbean, and Bharati Mukherjee created in the novel "Jasmine" a Hindu heroine who comes to rest in Iowa.
Like all of them, Ms. Nair knows firsthand the dialectic of diaspora, the constant tension between departing and arriving. "When I left India at 19, I was rooted in a very certain reality," the 35-year-old director said recently. "And since then, life has been very fluid. Back and forth, back and forth. And I realize in hindsight that I use that fluidity as part of my work.
"I used to have a joke when people asked where I live," continued Ms. Nair, who won an Academy Award nomination for best foreign film for "Salaam Bombay!" (1988). "I'd say, 'I live on Air India.' But the other side is that you live between your ears. You carry your home within yourself. That's a nice-sounding cerebral concept, but the truth is that you're torn."
One half of the film's title, "masala," refers to a variety of spices in different shades, and to Ms. Nair symbolizes the polyglot culture of Indians who were colonized in their own nation by the British and then forced by poverty to seek survival elsewhere. Often they served in those adopted countries as the mercantile class, comfortable enough to be resented from below, not comfortable enough to be protected from above.
That is precisely the situation for Jay (Roshan Seth), a lawyer of Indian descent and Ugandan birth, as "Mississippi Masala" opens in 1972. A lifelong black friend named Okelo saves Jay from arrest and possible execution as an outspoken foe of Amin, yet endorses the dictator's decree ousting Asians.
"I was born here!" Jay shouts in exasperation. "I have always been Ugandan first, Indian second. All my life I have devoted to justice -- I have been called a traitor and a bootlicker by my fellow Indians. Uganda is my home."
"Not anymore," Okelo replies softly. "Africa is for Africans. Black Africans."
Eighteen years later, when the film resumes its narrative, Jay is managing a motel in Greenwood, Miss., and petitioning a new regime in Uganda for restoration of his assets and citizenship. His wife, Kinnu (Sharmila Tagore), owns a liquor store in the black section of town. And their only child, a 23-year-old daughter named Mina (Sarita Choudhury), has grown into a self-proclaimed "masala" who wears the traditional smock called a kameez, hangs a John Lennon postcard by her bedside and still remembers a few childhood words of Swahili.
She suffers, in one respect, from inertia, maddening Jay with her refusal to attend college. But in other ways, she stands as the family rebel, shouting in one moment of intergenerational anger, "This is America, Ma!" and proving it by her romance with a black man.
The relationship between Mina and a small-business owner named Demetrius (Denzel Washington), like that between a black architect and his white secretary in Spike Lee's "Jungle Fever," sets off violent tremors in both extended families. And, in Ms. Nair's design, it places the sharpest edge on Indians' ambiguous position in the racial and economic landscape.
Only decades after his forebears were shipped to Uganda by the British for the bitter labor of building a railroad, Jay dresses in a tweed coat with pocket square and owns a hilltop villa surrounded by gardens, literally and figuratively perched above the black masses. Once in Mississippi, his family rapidly surpasses blacks who have lived there for centuries, in terms of both income and white acceptance. And while the Indian diaspora includes a fierce attachment to the foods and songs and gods of the subcontinent, the salves that make exile tolerable, the African diaspora embodied by Demetrius has been systemically stripped of its culture and history.
"There's a tension around the issue of alliances," Ms. Nair put it. "The black folks think, 'All of us people of color must stick together.' And the Indians cash in on that when it suits them. But the white people are glad the middle class isn't black. I once asked an Indian motel owner if he'd experienced racism, and he said, 'No, I'm just a white person who stayed in the sun too long.' "
At one point in the film, facing Jay's opposition to the interracial love affair, Demetrius declares: "I've never left Mississippi, but I do know something about the world. I know that folks can come to this country and be as black as the ace of spades, but soon as they come here they start to act white -- treat us like their doormats."
Such attitudes, Ms. Nair said, underline the hard lessons of Uganda. "It's popular to show Amin as this violent buffoon," she said, "but, in part, he had a very acute political grasp of that time. He knew it would be shrewd to cash in on the nationalism. And it's also true that the Indians were the ones running the country on the visible level -- the merchants, the moneylenders, the businessmen. Even though the British, who had wedged them in, were the experts in divide-and-conquer."
Ms. Nair's familiarity with the daily lives of Indian expatriates comes from more than her own perience at Harvard University, where she studied after leaving the town of Bhubaneswar, some 350 miles south of Calcutta. Rather, it attests to her background as a documentary film maker and to her creative partnership with Sooni Taraporevala, a Harvard classmate who has become Ms. Nair's regular screenwriter. Even the pair's first feature, the highly lauded "Salaam Bombay!," largely eschewed trained actors in its portrait of the city's street children.
Only 15 years old in 1972, Ms. Nair does not remember hearing news of Amin's edict. Rather, she learned of it elliptically through Mr. Naipaul's novel "A Bend in the River," which is set in an unnamed African country, and more directly through an article by Jane Kramer in The New Yorker about an Indian family that had moved from Kampala to London under the dictator's expulsion order. Ms. Nair would later spend several weeks in Uganda, interviewing many of the 500 Indians who had remained in defiance of Amin's order, after nearly 80,000 left.
In the precarious existence of Uganda's Indians Ms. Nair found a parallel to those countrymen increasingly operating motels in the American South. With her documentarian's talent for research, she drove from South Carolina to Mississippi in March 1989. So numerous were Indian-owned motels that one or two billboards for competitors bluntly stated, "100 percent American."
The reasons for the boom became readily clear to Ms. Nair. Sponsored for immigration, trained in the trade and sometimes even lent money by relatives, Indians could buy motels for as little as $100,000. Much like Koreans with greengroceries, the Indians could rely on family members for labor and could conduct business with only a cursory knowledge of English.
More important, Ms. Nair discovered the texture she calls the "inexplicability of life." "The Indians inhabited this no man's land, and yet it was their oasis," she said. "Here they were, face to face with truck drivers or prostitutes or lovers having a tryst, with blacks and whites. And yet here are these Indian hymns and the smell of garlic. One Indian couple I met couldn't afford the insurance on their motel's swimming pool, so they made it into a garden of Indian vegetables."
On a subsequent trip, Ms. Nair brought along Ms. Taraporevala. It was her life, more than the director's, that came to inform the coltish character of Mina. Ms. Taraporevala's father, who ran a money-exchange business in Bombay, allowed her to apply to Harvard only because he was certain that even if she won admission she would never receive the necessary scholarships.
"There's always this tension and pull," she said. "My parents always assumed that I would grow up and earn a living and be independent. But as years go by, you change and have new ideas, and they start to not recognize you anymore. When I would come back from college and do something my father did not like, he would say, 'I should not have sent you to America.' "
On one trip home, Ms. Taraporevala was joined by her college boyfriend, a white Chicagoan. Her parents treated him with courtesy, only expressing their true trepidation after the couple broke up.
"My father's always believed that I think with my heart instead of my head," said Ms. Taraporevala, who puts very similar words in Jay's mouth in the film. "He really thought I had screwed up, that I should get my life together, stop mooning. Then the issue of Indian and American came up. He thought maybe the reason things didn't work out is the cultural gap was too broad to bridge."
The role of Mina went to an unproven actress, but one with a particular affinity for the role. Sarita Choudhury grew up in Jamaica, where her father worked as a government biologist. India was "like a storybook more than a reality," she recalled, kept alive by her father's stories and celebrations of the Hindu festival of Divali. Outside the household, however, Ms. Choudhury became so Jamaican she learned the patois of Kingston's slums. It was her own grace note to have Mina wear a Bob Marley T-shirt in several scenes.
"When I read the script, it took away my paranoia that I couldn't act," said Ms. Choudhury, who is 25, "because I found a story I could identify with, and I instinctively felt I could portray this character. Mina is someone who's mixed and matched until she's mixed up. When you have a mixed heritage, you can't be patriotic to any one place. The strength of that is that you're much more open-minded, but the downfall is that you have no home."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mira Nair, the director of "Mississippi Masala"--"I used to have a joke when people ask where I live. I'd say, 'I live on Air India.' " (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)(pg. 13); Charles Dutton and Denzel Washington play Southern businessmen involved with an Indian family. When characters played by Sarita Choudhury and Denzel Washington fall in love, trouble follows. (Samuel Goldwyn)(pg. 14)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography; Review

TITLE: MISSISSIPPI MASALA (MOVIE)

COUNTRY: INDIA (94%); UGANDA (93%); ENGLAND (88%); AFRICA (78%); CARIBBEAN ISLANDS (74%); UNITED KINGDOM (56%); 

STATE: MISSISSIPPI, USA (90%); IOWA, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: A DIRECTORY OF CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
New Ships, New Destinations

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO; TERRY TRUCCO frequently writes about travel.

 BODY:
LAST year at this time, cruise line executives were nervous. There was a war in the Persian Gulf, a recession at home and Americans simply weren't taking cruises. "It was as if the phones had been disconnected," said Rod Seeley, president of Cruise Pro, a cruise-only travel agency in Thousand Oaks, Calif. In addition, three enormous ships were about to be launched, adding more than 6,500 berths to the market. The industry's response was a blizzard of discounts, everything from 2-for-1 promotions to deep reductions on last-minute reservations. Apparently, the ship lines got the desired result, for according to the Cruise Lines International Association, a trade organization, cruise ships had an occupancy rate of around 87 percent in 1991, about the same as in 1990, not bad for a year that once looked disastrous.
A year later, there is still a recession, and 18 new ships are set to start cruising, offering more than 12,000 additional berths. Yet throughout the cruise industry, there is a mood of cautious optimism. "We've certainly had a much better start to the year," Mr. Seeley said. "This may not be a banner year for the cruise lines, with all the discounting, but it's going to be a banner year for the consumer." 
 Cruise passengers have rarely had so many choices, from exotic destinations to spectacular accommodations. And the cruise industry has seldom courted passengers as ardently. This is a year for the adventurous, with ships visiting once-forbidden ports, like Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam, and sailing to the newly independent Baltic capitals Tallinn in Estonia and Riga in Latvia. And this year people taking cruises can visit a lake in Russia or be among the first non-Russians to sail the river between Moscow and St. Petersburg. Ships are also returning to the Mediterranean, many tying up in Barcelona for the Olympics. Cruises prepaid in dollars are considered a particularly good way of visiting cities in Europe and Asia where the dollar is weak.
The year's new ships range from the enormous (2,354 passengers can be accommodated on Royal Caribbean's Majesty of the Seas) to the almost intimate (the luxurious Royal Viking Queen holds just 212). Among the in- between are the Club Med 2, a 386-passenger sailing ship with computerized sails, and five ships carrying between 1,000 and 1,300 passengers. Celebrity's 1,374-passenger Zenith, a Caribbean vessel, will serve meals devised by a noted London chef, Michel Roux. And Holland America's 1,250-passenger Statendam, set to sail in late December, will have a 17th-century Italian marble fountain in the atrium.
Discounting should continue through 1992, though industry executives expect the discounts to be more predictable and consistent than in 1991. A number of lines, for example, including Princess, Holland America and Royal Caribbean, are offering big incentives for early bookings in an effort to discourage 11th-hour bargain hunters.
If last month is any indication, the cruise industry could be on its way to a buoyant 1992, at least as far as occupancy rates go. (The record was 1989, when occupancies reached 90 percent, according to the cruise lines association.) Several cruise lines reported record bookings, including Royal Caribbean, which set a single-day company high of 11,102 bookings on Jan. 8 and Carnival, which reached an unprecedented 65,000 bookings the week of Jan. 6.
True, January is traditionally a strong month for cruise bookings, and much of the volume resulted from last-minute reservations, discount offers for early bookings and pent-up demand. "Because of the recession, everybody is booking late, even for round the world and Mediterranean cruises," said Stanley Rhodes, an agent with Linden Travel in New York.
Among the discounts still being offered, Norwegian Cruise Line is featuring a 2-for-1 deal on selected three- and four-day Bahamas cruises, through Feb. 24. Holland America is offering substantial reductions, linked with stringent restrictions, for early reservations on selected autumn cruises. And several lines, including Renaissance Cruises and Royal Cruise Line, have introduced reductions on the supplements single occupants pay for use of double cabins on selected sailings. The availability of group discounts is also growing rapidly as well, with cruise lines accepting looser definitions of groups. "A group can be three or four people, not an obvious affinity group," said Stanley Buchin, a cruise management consultant for Arthur D. Little, a management consultant company.
FOR customers in the market for longer trips, cruise lines often have good prices on so-called positioning cruises, including trans-Atlantic trips to move a ship from the Mediterranean to the Caribbean. "Demand for these cruises is lower, and prices can be negotiated more easily." said Steve Wellmeier, marketing director for Travltips, a travel agency in Flushing, Queens.
Yet in spite of discounting and concerns about possible overcapacity, cruising is viewed as one of the few bright spots in the travel industry these days. "The cruise industry grew about 10 percent last year," said Arthur Sbarsky, senior vice president in marketing for Crystal Cruises. "Airplanes, hotels, trains and buses didn't."
Some believe the single all-inclusive cost of a cruise is especially attractive in today's economic climate. "With cruising, once you've paid the initial price, everything is taken care of," said Joyce Landry, a partner in Landry & Cling, cruise specialists in Coral Gables, Fla.
Cruises are becoming particularly popular with families. According to a 1990 survey by the cruise lines association, 28 percent of those who had taken a cruise in the previous two years took their children. "The baby boomers are taking their kids on cruises, and not just to the Caribbean," Mr. Seeley said. A number of cruise lines, including Carnival, Royal Caribbean and Norwegian Cruise Line, now offer year-round youth programs. Royal Caribbean will have a specially designed teen disco, called Flashes, on its new Majesty of the Seas, which will set sail on April 26. (A similar disco, with light shows and music, is on its sister ship, Monarch of the Seas.) Cruises linked to land trips are attracting families as well. Premier, for example, offers moderately priced Bahamas cruises that conclude with a visit to Florida's Walt Disney World.
The recession does not seem to have greately dampened the demand for luxury accommodations, either. Cruise lines and travel agents report that the year's hottest sellers are the cheapest cabins -- and the costliest. Some passengers are asking for the cheaper cabins in the hopes of an upgrade. But premium-priced suites are selling, often to cruising's traditional constituents, older affluent passengers.
Many in the industry, in fact, are betting that luxury is the future. One of the year's most talked about new ships is the $125 million Radisson Diamond, a futuristic looking 354-passenger luxury liner with a twin hull. The ship, due to spend much of the year in the Caribbean, will have a five-story atrium, glass-enclosed elevators, saunas, steambaths and a $600 a day price tag without air fare. The company plans to launch a sister ship, the Radisson Ruby, in 1993.
Among cruise companies, the two-tiered approach -- both a luxury and a moderately priced line -- is proving itself. The veterans include Kloster Cruises, with its mass-market Norwegian Cruise Line and sybaritic Royal Viking Line; and Chandris Cruise Companies, which runs the mass-market Fantasy line and more upscale Celebrity line. .
New to the two-tiered market this year are Costa Cruise Line and Dolphin Cruise Line. The 1,300-passenger, $325 million Costa Classica is the first in Costa's Euro-Luxe line, aimed at the high end of the mass market and the low end of the luxury market. The ship, launched last month, has all the trappings of a floating hotel, with marble walls and floors, teak decks and an enormous bronze sculpture by the Italian artist Arnaldo Pomodoro.
The 1,056-passenger, $220 million Royal Majesty, the first of three handsomely appointed ships in Dolphin's new Majesty line, will start running short cruises in September from Miami to Nassau and Royal Isle, the line's private island in the Bahamas. "I think the lines are discovering that once passengers go on a second cruise, they want upgraded vessels," Ms. Landry said.
The North American cruise industry, by far the world's richest market, has grown dramatically in the last two decades, and is expected to continue to grow in the 90's. The Cruise Lines International Association is predicting passenger growth of between 8 and 10 percent in 1992. The current year began with 90,000 berths on 122 ships; an additional 30,000 berths are expected by 1994. Last year four million passengers from the United States and Canada took cruises, a big increase over the industry's 500,000 passengers in 1970. And, despite concerns by some in the industry that too many ships are coming on line, others insist cruising is in its infancy. "An enormous number of Americans have never cruised," Mr. Sbarsky said.
Many attribute the growth of cruising to a change of strategy on the part of the cruise lines. "Until the mid 80's, cruise lines were run by maritime people, and passengers were considered just another cargo to move around," said Mr. Buchin. These days, cruise lines are managed and marketed like resorts or hotels.
The creation of sharply focused lines like Carnival, and television shows like "The Love Boat," attracted new types of passengers, as well. According to the 1990 survey by Cruise Lines International, 41 percent of the adults who had taken a cruise in the previous two years were under 40.
Income levels were also surprisingly varied. In the same survey, 35 percent had incomes under $40,000, while 30 percent exceeded $60,000.
Cruising's broadening audience is reflected in the popularity of short cruises, particularly the affordable three- and four-day cruise, one of the market's fastest growing segments. In 1984 there were three or four ships offering short cruises, according to a spokesman for Carnival. This year there will be 10.
This market could expand dramatically if Cuba is opened to Americans, according to Ron Bitting, owner of Personal Touch Cruise Consultants in Freeport, L.I., and president of the National Association of Cruise Only Agencies. " It would be one of cruising's most exciting events, and it could happen in 1992."
At the same time, demand continues for longer cruises by older passengers. In most cases, older, smaller ships are used for the longer journeys. Fantasy's Britanis, which dates from the 1930's and is one of the oldest cruise ships afloat, makes a 50-day South American cruise each autumn. "It carries 926 passengers, but they take about 500 and use the more comfortable cabins," said Mr. Wellmeier.
Ships in 1992 will sail to nearly every corner of the world, from Antarctica and the Amazon to Africa and the so-called Atlantic Frontier (Boston to Labrador). Alaska has become a cruise classic, though just 16 ships will visit this year, six less than in 1991. (Most cruise lines, concerned that last year's Gulf War would last for months, diverted Mediterranean ships to Alaska and New England.) Eighteen lines will visit the Mediterranean this summer. Cruises are also going to Australia and Indonesia. Because of the civil war in Yugoslavia, Dubrovnik has been dropped by most cruise itineraries, though Ocean Cruise's Ocean Princess, among other ships, still plans to stop there.
The Caribbean remains cruising's major destination, with year-round visitors and 56 percent of the market. A number of the year's new ships are expected to make the familiar stops -- St. Thomas, Grand Cayman, St. Martin, Jamaica, Puerto Rico, Barbados. Travel agents agree that these ports are nearly overwhelmed by cruise ships, yet until other Caribbean islands develop the tours and facilities to accommodate daily arrivals of over 1,000 visitors, these will remain the Caribbean's cruise capitals.
And there seems no end in sight to ships destined for the Caribbean. The ship of the future could be the Phoenix World City, an ultramegaship built to hold 5,600 passengers and a crew of 1,800. Currently in the final stages of design, construction on the $1 billion project could start in the United States later this year, according to John Rogers, president of Phoenix World City Corporation.
The supership, brainchild of Knute Utstein Kloster, founder of Kloster Cruises, would have three hotel towers, 13 restaurants, a 20,000-square-foot casino and home base in Port Canaveral, Fla.
From there it could cruise the southern coast of the United States or venture into the Caribbean, where its 400-passenger tenders could deliver passengers to nearly any island.

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
An American Modernist, at Home and Abroad

BYLINE: By John Russell

 BODY:
Some of this critic's most favorite American paintings are included in the centennial exhibition of the work of Stuart Davis (1892-1964), which one can still catch at the Metropolitan Museum for two more weeks. The show is large -- 175 paintings and drawings, some of mural size -- and there are those who think that it could with advantage be smaller.
This regular visitor to the show does not agree. For one thing, a thinned-down and generally approved version of Stuart Davis's career might leave out my favorite paintings altogether. Quite apart from that, what we have in "Stuart Davis: American Painter" is something that goes way beyond Davis himself. 
 The underlying subject of this show is the modernist spirit in America. From the moment in 1913 when Stuart Davis, not yet 21, showed five watercolors at the Armory Show in New York, he was a part of that spirit. He saw everything. He read everything. Modernism was the very air he breathed.
The catalogue of the present show reminds us that in 1920 William Carlos Williams chose a drawing by Davis as the frontispiece for a new book of his poems. Even more telling, perhaps, is the fact that in that same year a drawing by Davis appeared in the Little Review to accompany the first publication in this country of an extract from James Joyce's "Ulysses."
As a history of American modernism, the show is necessarily both elliptic and incomplete. But as a diary of one man's responses to his century, it repays many a visit. Stuart Davis identified strongly with his century, and with the United States as a society that had a virtually unlimited potential that might or might not be realized. Meanwhile, his eyes and ears were finely attuned to the rhythms of American life. (He named his son, Earl, after the great jazz pianist Earl Hines.)
From his first teacher, the painter Robert Henri, he inherited a sharp eye for the down side of society. As to that, he knew what the late Stuart Chase meant when he wrote that improved technology would in the end cause widespread unemployment and the proletarianization of the middle class.
But the paintings by Stuart Davis toward which I move as if magnetized were not inspired by social problems. They are the hedonistic and unpopulated Parisian townscapes that he painted in 1928-29 in the course of his first and only visit to Paris.
The visit was a key episode in his long career. Financed in part by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, and in part by Juliana Force, the first director of the Whitney Museum, he stayed in Paris for 13 months, with intense enjoyment. But he never went back. As he summed it up in 1931, his time in Paris "allowed me to observe the enormous vitality of the American atmosphere, as compared to Europe, and made me regard the necessity of working in New York as a positive advantage."
So what did Stuart Davis do in his Paris pictures? To begin with, he edited out every one of the human figures that would otherwise have crowded the Parisian streets. He went on to change, revise and omit the given scene as he thought best. He used color in a completely arbitrary way. The color was gentle and elegiac, moreover, with none of the Sousa-like bounce that came naturally to him back at home. He played around with scale, too. What was big, in reality, often became small, and what was small -- an old-style soda syphon, for instance -- stood tall in the foreground.
Next, he took the weight and the volume out of the given scene, so that it looked flat, and light, and thin. Change and omission were fundamental to his procedures. Not everyone cares for the paintings that resulted. The critic Brian O'Doherty, who knew Davis well and loved his work, once described them as "confected idealized stage sets for a nostalgic musical of an American artist in Paris."
But they were not sets for someone else's work. They were complete in themselves. Love letters to a certain Paris, they worked as well with august architecture (see "The Place des Vosges" of 1928) as with the anonymous, awkward and cheerless suburban scenes with which he took just as much trouble.
It is relevant to these quietly seductive pictures that Davis painted them at precisely the time when George Gershwin was writing his "American in Paris." Between them, though quite independently, Gershwin and Davis immortalized the moment at the end of the 1920's when Paris was wide open to the intelligent high-stepping American and the dollar went a very long way.
I never hear "An American in Paris" without imagining the kind of lanky, rangy, young American couple who might have danced their way in and out of one of Stuart Davis's Parisian paintings. Nor do I ever look at one of those paintings without hearing the jaunty, irrepressible orchestration with which Gershwin responded to the idea of Paris.
Those were glory days for the young American in Paris. This was the time when Alexander Calder was making fast friends with Joan Miro, when Man Ray and Berenice Abbott between them were photographing everybody worth knowing in Paris, and when Marsden Hartley and Isamu Noguchi were the American artists in town. A young black American, Josephine Baker, was beloved of almost every Parisian. As for Ernest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald, they were perpetrating a dream of Paris that still has potency for the young American visitor.
Read with that period in mind, these paintings can give enormous pleasure. They may not be "major Davis," but they are not second-rate Davis, either. Where Paris was concerned, he went, he saw, he enjoyed it, but he wasn't conquered. Back at home, he had a richer set of options.
He moved forward, and he moved sideways, and in his last decade he moved backward to give a final energy and a symphonic completion to ideas that he had initiated long before. (In 1961, three years before he died, he wrote that "completion must be understood as the economical use of past accomplishment, not a redoing of it.")
Of that economical use, and that completion, there is a prime example in "The Paris Bit," which he painted in 1959. Essentially a symphonic enlargement of his "Rue Lipp" of 1928, this has a congested, full-bodied look that is exactly the opposite of the spare, cool distillation of the earlier painting. We can make out the cheap French hotel, the soda syphon, the carafe of water and the words "Belle France" written billboard size on the wall. But the lean, snaking, soft-shoe stance of "An American in Paris" has gone.
Yet, in his very last paintings, France made a final, coded reappearance. In two small paintings, "On Location" (1963) and "Punch Card Flutter" (1963), and in the large last one, "Fin (Last Painting)" (1964), Davis took as his point of departure a photograph (clipped, by the way, from The New York Times) of the walls of Carcassonne with a forked French tree in the foreground.
A quick and secret mover throughout his 50-year career, Davis seems never to have spoken about that photograph. (It turned up when his son Earl was going through his father's papers.) But it was the prime mover, in essence, of all three of the last paintings, even if in one of them the castellations of the city walls take on the jagged outline of a computer punch card.
Even the title of "On Location" gives us a clue to his feelings about the clipping of Carcassonne. "On Location," in movie parlance, means working in a given scene at first hand and away from headquarters. The idea should perhaps not be pressed too far, and in his catalogue essay William C. Agee points out that the forked tree, as a compositional device, was used by Davis already as early as 1919, and again in 1921. The sturdy form of the French tree may be simply another instance of the "economical use of past accomplishment."
But I doubt that the use of that image from The New York Times was accidental. An ancient loyalty to "la Belle France" must surely have played a part in it, just as Davis must have had a reason to write the word "Fin" at the top of his last painting. "Fin" is a word that he must have seen come up on Parisian movie screens when the night's main feature came to an end and it was time to go home. What can it be, in that big painting, if not a coded "Goodbye" to a world, and a century, that he had served so well?

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Houston Dares To Be Different

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
The "Parsifal" at the Houston Grand Opera on Thursday evening will begin its second scene with agonizing stealth. A great ring, shining from within, will float into view from above. It will tilt and -- ever, ever so slowly -- descend around an equally glowing crystalline iceberg in the center of the stage. From it Amfortas will extract the Grail.
Where is everybody? The knights and their somber procession? We hear their voices offstage, but people get short shrift in Robert Wilson's long-suffering but finally produced version of Wagner's music drama. The Houston Grand Opera, in another of the calculated risks it has come to be known for, is giving the American premiere of Mr. Wilson's marriage of glacial motion and neutron-bomb stagecraft -- one in which humans often disappear and only constructions are left standing. 
 Will this slow-motion "Parsifal" exasperate Houston's faithful subscribers right out of their seats and into the street? "In some cases, it probably will," said David Gockley earlier this season, "but it won't be a worrisome number." Twenty years at the head of this company have given Mr. Gockley the confidence to face hard facts. He has lifted his troupe from a minor stop-off on the provincial opera circuit to an $18-million-a-year organization with a new theater and 12 productions a season.
In the process, Mr. Gockley has acted as a sort of personal trainer for the tastes and cultural aspirations of Houston audiences. "You stretch them, or you're not an opera company," he said. "This 'Parsifal' is something you put on for your public and in spite of it." Mr. Gockley's strong personality is one of the reasons the Houston Grand Opera can regularly do new operas (Meredith Monk's "Atlas," Michael Tippet's "New Year" and John Adams's "Nixon in China") and get board members to put up the money and audiences to come.
He is a firm presence at every level of the operation, from high-finance board meetings to low-level lighting rehearsals backstage, idealistic enough to have staged Dvorak's sweetly reticent "Rusalka" last fall yet tough enough to cancel "A Little Night Music" because of a projected budget shortfall of $415,000.
If Mr. Gockley's perseverance represents a good percentage of the company's success, most of the rest probably lies with the historical peculiarities of this 150-year-old city. Like Los Angeles and perhaps Dallas, Houston began not as a human reaction to congenial natural surroundings but as a cantankerous act of will. Flat, hellishly humid in summer and 50 miles from the Gulf Coast, Houston was built from sheer stubbornness.
Until the great Spindletop oil find at the turn of the century, it was the economic and cultural inferior of Galveston, a sophisticated port city of merchants and bankers that had long brought in (usually by boat from New Orleans) "Il Trovatore," "La Traviata," "Fra Diavalo" and "The Magic Flute." As early as 1867 these traveling productions began to find their way to Houston. The Metropolitan Opera's touring arm first arrived in 1901 with "Lohengrin" and came again in 1905 to put on -- of all operas -- "Parsifal," one of a series of American performances that defied the Wagner family's interdiction of productions outside Bayreuth.
Touring companies continued to visit during the first half of this century, largely at the instigation of a benefactor-cum-impresario, Edna W. Saunders, who took Houston's taste and musical development into her own hands. The present organization stems from 1955, when a German emigre conductor, Walter Herbert, stirred Houston's moneyed and music-hungry class into backing the city's own opera company. Early seasons, almost all conducted by Herbert, offered three, then four, productions a year.
A topography and climate bordering on the hostile might be expected to repel the advances of culture, but seemingly the opposite has happened. For even though Houston is now a city of striking skylines, endless shopping centers and air-conditioning, there seems to survive in it the sense of a cultural community drawing together for its own self-preservation. Imminent physical threats to survival are long gone, but perhaps something of the early reactions to them has been inherited and sublimated in the hearts of Houstonians.
"New York has its pockets of connoisseurs," said Fredericka Hunter, an art dealer who owns the Texas Gallery. "But there isn't that division of the arts here. The same people go to the music, the exhibitions, the plays. The ones who give money usually give equally to all these things."
Mr. Gockley said, "Houston is not a city of remarkable natural beauty. What makes us different is our arts life." Mr. Gockley's long and evidently happy marriage with such Houstonians allowed him and his board to finance and build a new opera house in the midst of the city's devastating oil recession of the 1980's. Indeed, the spirit of Texas's oil explorers has spilled over into the arts. "They are used to taking a chance," said Ms. Hunter. "They aren't afraid of a dry hole."
Mr. Gockley said: "This is not a town that suffers poor fiscal management. The board tells me to hold on to my audience and keep expenses in line and then lets me run the company. I involve them in policy and major decisions but not the choice of operas."
This "Parsifal," shared with the Hamburg Opera, which gave a not trouble-free version of the production last March, has some natural ties to Houston. Mr. Wilson grew up in Waco and went to school at the University of Texas in Austin. His "Parsifal" was originally intended for Bayreuth, then the Kassel State Opera, but it was canceled with charges that Mr. Wilson had not lived up to agreements.
"Hamburg welcomed our co-sponsorship," said Mr. Gockley. "We sent our technical director over, and he helped them work out some of the production problems. There isn't a lot of built scenery that takes up space and costs a fortune. It's a labor-intensive operation, and it will cost us $1.5 million.
"With Wilson, things must happen with excruciating precison. The expense is in the preparation: the technical rehearsals, the stage movement. In the average show there are three or four follow-spotlights. We use 15 -- for Gurnemanz's head, his hands, the different parts of his body that are moving at a significant moment. Some of the technology was only available in Europe."
Christoph Eschenbach, the music director of the Houston Symphony, will be conducting his first staged Wagner opera, with his own orchestra in the pit. Warren Ellsworth, who trained at the company's Opera Studio, will sing Parsifal. The cast also includes Monte Pederson, Harry Peeters and Vera Baniewicz.
"Wilson reduces images to a level of abstraction not seen before," said Mr. Gockley. Indeed, the image of the knights' round table is reduced to an object, the flying ring. The killing of the swan, usually left offstage, is here represented by a giant two-dimensional wing descending from the flies. Klingsor's tower rises from a lake, hydraulically lifted. The magic garden is portrayed in the abstract as underwater. The ring returns in the last act, now black and tarnished with disuse, referring, too, to Parsifal's black armor.
"The major problem is matching the visual tension with the music," said Mr. Gockley. "But there is a real empathy between Wilson and Eschenbach. They are soul mates."
"Parsifal" required a bigger than usual overall budget for the company this year; Conoco and other companies kicked in extra, and individuals have come up with $600,000 more. Mr. Gockley denied that "A Little Night Music" was a victim of the "Parsifal" production.
He expected little from government agencies and got little. "Grants to us from the state dropped from $150,000 to $18,000 in four years," he said. "We are squeezed three ways: on the Federal level by Jesse Helms's pressure on the National Endowment for the Arts; on the state level by a political climate that spreads arts grants geographically around many smaller communities, and in the city by different cultural and ethnic groups competing for the same money."
Houstonians, on the other hand, are used to taking care of themselves, and for "Parsifal" they have pulled together to do so again. Let's hope they like it.

HEADLINE: Ecuador

 BODY:
To the Editor: Your notice of the State Department warning on travel to Ecuador (Travel Advisory, Oct. 6) in particular cited high levels of street crime in Quito and Guayaquil. 
 I returned from a weeklong trip to Quito in July. Like other South American countries, Ecuador is poor in material wealth, but possesses natural resources and beauty. I walked through different parts of Quito, both day and night, and did not feel any danger, except from stray dogs. Ecuador relies on tourism and so it seems that the State Department warning deals this little country an unfair blow which could have a serious economic impact.
 
THOMAS SCHNECK
San Jose, Calif.

HEADLINE: Battle-Scarred Lawmakers Confront Spending

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
STATE residents who saw their taxes rise dramatically last year with the advent of the new tax on wages may soon face a new shock: getting a lot less for their money. When the General Assembly goes back to Hartford this week, lawmakers in both parties say, deep cuts in spending are inevitable, with everything on the chopping block from higher education spending to municipal aid.
Although the income tax is producing about what was expected when it was passed last August, the state's other taxes -- notably sales taxes and the levy on corporate income -- have continued to slide, as the recession has eaten away jobs and profits. And rising state spending on nursing homes and prisons, for instance, are battering the budget from the other side. 
 The expected result is a shortfall of $700 million to $1 billion in the year that begins on July 1, which means a battle over how to resolve that figure without raising taxes again. Politicians across the spectrum -- most of whom are running for re-election in November -- say that any major tax hike is out of the question. What is left, they say, is the equally unpleasant election-year task of slicing up the shrinking pie that remains. "People are totally and completely unprepared for the magnitude of cuts that will be required," said Representative Jonathan Pelto, a Democrat from Storrs and a deputy majority leader in the House of Representatives. "I think it's very likely that this year will be as bad, if not worse, than last session."
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who will propose his budget to the legislature on Wednesday in his State of the State speech, has declined to provide much illumination about his plans, except for these: it will not likely include any new taxes, but it will make everyone howl in pain just the same.
"Nobody's seen the budget, and it's not going to be nice when we do, I know that," said the Speaker of the House, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington.
Mr. Balducci said he expected that all of the state's main spending priorities -- municipal aid, education, prisons, and social spending for welfare and Medicaid -- will come under intense scrutiny, and that every area could potentially become a battleground.
There are other complications as well. Lawmakers say that the grim economic news in recent weeks about layoffs at the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney plants in the state and the prospect of tens of thousands of more lost jobs in southeastern Connecticut from proposed cuts in submarine construction at the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics have crystallized the need for some state effort to help companies diversify from military work.
The state's largest cities, especially Bridgeport, also continue to suffer from staggering burdens of crime and poverty. Those needs are expected to fuel a drive to try to widen Connecticut's legal gambling system, perhaps including slot machines in Off-Track Betting parlors or elsewhere.
Senator Frank David Barrows, the co-chairman of the Public Safety Committee, which oversees gambling laws, has said he would support such an expansion. Mr. Balducci also said last week that he might support the introduction of slot machines, if the money could be dedicated specifically to distressed municipalities. And many lawmakers say that the scars of 1991 have also yet to heal.
Through the long months of debate on the income tax, both the Democratic majority and the Republican minority repeatedly fractured on what direction the state should take on the pivotal tax question. In December the bitterness reached a high-water mark during an effort to amend the income tax, when a group of moderate Democrats joined with the Republican minority in the House to overturn a procedural ruling by Mr. Balducci from the Speaker's chair, an event that legislative veterans said had not occurred in Connecticut in decades, if ever.
Many Democrats have asked that Deputy Speaker Dean P. Markham of East Hampton, who sided with the Republicans and against the Speaker, be stripped of his job. But Mr. Balducci said last week that a decision on whether the Democrats who rebuked the party's leadership in that vote would be punished might not come until the opening day on Wednesday.
Also uncertain is how vigorously various groups in the General Assembly will fight to repeal or amend the income tax. The special session that ended in December tried on both those counts and failed. The repeal bill, though passed by a bipartisan majority in the House and Senate, was vetoed by Mr. Weicker. The bill to amend the tax never even came up for a vote after it died on the vote against the Speaker.
"There's a lot of stuff that's on the public record in the last 12 months that now comes back to haunt," said Representative Richard Foley Jr., a Republican from Oxford who is also his party's state chairman.
 
Confusion and Anger
 What could temper the hostilities and ultimately force a budget compromise within the three-month regular session is the realization that more chaos at the Capitol will not likely be seen in a kindly light by voters in November, regardless of their feelings on the income tax, state spending or anything else. All 187 Senate and House seats are up for re-election this year.
"Confusion and anger won't do any incumbent any good," said Representative Thomas S. Luby, a Democrat from Meriden. Mr. Luby, who opposed the income tax last year and also helped block the effort to amend the law in December, said that he was now more inclined to support some effort to make the tax law more fair for middle-class taxpayers if the proposal could be tied to further cuts in business taxes.
"The political reality will tend to restrain people from obstructionist or unreasonable behavior," Mr. Luby said. "I'm sure you'll see a calmer, more orderly session."
Mr. Foley, the Republican party chairman, agreed that the session could indeed produce smooth results, at least in theory, because people will feel the need to get back to their districts to start campaigning.
"That's the best scenario," Mr. Foley said. But he added, "This being the State Capitol, it is unlikely that it will happen."

HEADLINE: Talking: Jumbo Loans;
Qualifying Becomes Tougher

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
IN higher-priced regions like the New York metropolitan area, many people who want to buy a home must apply for a jumbo mortgage.
A jumbo loan is one that exceeds $202,300, the current limit imposed by the Federal National Mortgage Association and Home Loan Mortgage Corporation -- known, respectively, as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac -- that regularly buy mortgages from lenders. Such loans must be sold to private pools of investors who set their own rules about what is acceptable. 
 Although in most instances the money will still be forthcoming, it is no longer being offered without extensive documentation on the creditworthiness of the borrower and the value of the property.
In the past, the private secondary market investors were extremely liberal about qualifying criteria -- more liberal, often, than Fannie Mae -- since the properties tended to be in more select neighborhoods and thus wereconsidered good collateral for the loans. In addition, the borrowers were normally more affluent people and were viewed as good credit risks.
This is why, for example, so many of the "no doc" loans so popular in the late 1980's -- loans that did not require independent verification of income or assets -- were jumbos.
No longer. Anthony Harney, a mortgage consultant of Wyckoff, N.J., who acts as an intermediary between jumbo lenders and their secondary market investors, reports that the "white collar" recession, as it is being dubbed, is creating major concerns about even an affluent borrower's ability to make payments as well as the true value of the property. He noted, for example, that in areas like northern New Jersey, higher-priced properties have plunged steeply in value. Many of the people in the jumbo-loan category have also faced the most severe cutbacks in income, whether from lost jobs or failed businesses.
Terms and attitudes vary sharply from lender to lender. "You'll need to do a lot more shopping around," said Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates of Butler, N.J., a nationwide mortgage monitoring service.
In general, however, borrowers can expect lenders willing to make jumbo loans to require a large downpayment to protect their equity. "While they used to write 80 percent jumbos," said Mr. Harney, "the cut-off point at most places is now 75 percent or even lower." The lender may also seek a second appraisal and even interior photos.
Further, a prior banking relationship with the borrower may be a prerequisite. Assets and income will be carefully investigated. And, as in the past, the interest rate is likely to be 1/4 or 1/2 a percentage point higher than for a conforming loan, although the points charge should remain comparable.
Consider, for example, the policies at Republic National Bank of New York. Cliff Broder, senior vice president of domestic private banking, reports that the bank has imposed a 70 percent limit on jumbo loans (75 percent for a newly bought property). This falls to 60 percent for loans over $500,000 -- a sharp contrast to 1986, he noted, when the limit was 80 percent up to $1 million.
Republic now requires two appraisals in many instances. A set of interior photos can also help bolster requests for loans over $500,000, added Mr. Broder. Republic does not require an existing banking relationship but will reduce the points charge if the applicant is willing to use the bank for other personal or business banking needs.
In addition, Republic looks more closely at the jumbo borrower's potential exposure to other temptations that could result in delinquencies. These could include an existing revolving line of credit, high borrowing limits on consumer credit cards and even overdraft privileges. In some cases, he said, borrowers may have to agree to close down some of these lines before a jumbo loan is granted.
NOT all jumbo lenders are as stringent. The CreditFlex program introduced last month by Arbor National Mortgage of Westbury, L.I., for example, takes note of the growing number of responsible borrowers who have been struggling with temporary cash-flow problems that stain an otherwise pristine credit history. CreditFlex gives a loan officer greater discretion in overlooking such blemishes, said Nancy Boles, Arbor's vice president of marketing.
The blemishes may include recently delinquent mortgage or credit card payments, liens and judgments and even a bankruptcy -- provided it was discharged at least three years ago. As the loan-to-value ratio drops -- say, to 60 percent or less -- the lending officer is permitted to take greater risks with blots that might normally disqualify the borrower entirely, said Ms. Boles. But she emphasized that it is not for anyone whose history suggests irresponsibility.
CreditFlex is available to anyone seeking to refinance up to $400,000 ($350,000 for new purchases) and provides an adjustable-rate loan starting at about 8 percent. The points charges depend on the amount of interest the borrower is willing to assume as a trade-off. Arbor, one of a handful of lenders still willing to lend up to 90 percent of value for jumbos under $400,000, has offices in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Connecticut and Virginia.
Even so, jumbo borrowers should not overlook the chance to grab a lower-cost conforming loan where feasible, said Mr. Havemann of HSH. This may be easier than expected, he said, now that Fannie Mae has lifted its maximum to $202,300, up $11,000 from $191,250 last year.
As a result, anyone who needed a jumbo loan when originally buying the home may now qualify for a conforming loan, especially if a significant amount of principal has since been paid down. "Or, you could buy down the balance to $202,300 by putting some cash in yourself," suggested Mr. Havemann.
Finally, anyone buying a co-op apartment in an exclusive Fifth Avenue or Park Avenue building that does not allow shares to be pledged as collateral can rest assured that the generally tighter lending climate should not adversely affect them.
These noncollaterized jumbo loans are still being made to high-net-worth people, reports Barbara Fox, president of the Fox Residential Group, Manhattan real estate brokers specializing in more expensive properties. Ms. Fox said that in December she had two buyers who took out such loans with ease. However, as in better times, the borrowers must normally establish a solid banking relationship with the lender before such a loan will be considered.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Orange County Condos;
Sales Without Giveaways

 BODY:
The region's sickly economy has sent many home developers scrambling for buyers, with some resorting to such last-resort sales measures as auctions and deep discounts.
But the builder of a condominium community in Orange County, N.Y., is trying to buck the trend by opening his project with low prices designed to bring in bargin-hunting buyers. The units in the Windsor Crest complex in New Windsor start at $107,900 for a two-bedroom apartment and go up to $139,900 for a three-bedroom residence. With the first, 46-unit phase of development nearly completed, 9 residences have been sold. 
 "We have been selling to first-time buyers and people looking for new homes," said Michael Landau, president of New Hilltop Development Corporation of Fort Lee, N.J., the company building the complex.
The 22-acre community is on Route 32 just south of Union Avenue and four miles south of Newburgh. The first phase includes 16 apartments and 30 multilevel town-house-style units. The apartments range in size from 1,150 to 1,350 square feet and in price from $107,900 to $124,900. The town houses, which have three bedrooms and two and a half baths, range in size from 1,650 to 1,750 square feet, not including the garages and basements, and are priced from $137,900 to $139,900.
The residences were designed by the architectural firm of Denker & Bodnar of Nyack, N.Y.. They are in a traditional pitched-roof style with decorative features like window shutters. The recreational amenities include a clubhouse, a pool and tennis courts. The plan calls for a total of 149 residences.
Occupancy is expected to begin at the end of the month and completion depends on the pace of demand.
