HEADLINE: Jumping the Barriers to a Refinancing

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
HARRY LeFEVRE will receive an extra $12,000 this year -- without a raise, overtime or moonlighting. The 41-year-old high school teacher from Amawalk, N.Y., will merely refinance his home.
"We wanted to look at a way to improve our cash flow," said Mr. LeFevre, who is trading his 9.87 percent, 15-year, fixed-rate mortgage for a 4.25 percent, one-year adjustable-rate loan. Closing costs and points, about $10,000, will be rolled into the lifetime cost of the mortgage. 
 "And now, by refinancing, I'm saving $1,025 a month in mortgage payments," he said.
Spurred by the sharp drop in mortgage rates over the last year, Mr. LeFevre and millions of other Americans are rushing to convert their mortgages into shorter or longer terms and usually with lower -- often dramatically lower -- monthly payments.
But a large percentage of homeowners seeking refinacing, as many as half in some parts of the New York region, are discovering that they do not immediately qualify because their income has declined, their indebtedness has risen or the value of their home has fallen.
Even some of these homeowners, however, are paying the extra amounts of cash necessary to lock in low long-term interest rates on the one-family homes, condominiums and co-op apartments that many of them bought in the high-interest 80's.
"In those situations where the appraisal comes in lower than required, the borrower has the option of paying down their mortgage, and I would say in 50 percent of the cases, they are doing that, when they have the money to do it," said Bruce R. Lublin, president of Homerica, a mortgage broker in Harrison, N.Y.
In the past, when homes were generally increasing in value, the old "2-2-2" formula was the prime way to determine whether it made financial sense to refinance. The numbers meant that if borrowers had been in their home at least two years, intended to stay at least two more and refinanced at a rate at least two points lower than their current mortgage rate, then refinancing was practical.
Today, though, those guidelines are more flexible and depend in large part on an individual's circumstances. Homeowners who qualify for refinancing should calculate how much they will pay in closing costs, fees and points -- a point is 1 percent of the amount borrowed. Then they should figure how much their monthly mortgage payments will drop and how long it will take before their monthly savings cover the refinancing costs.
IF, as in Mr. LeFevre's case, the costs are recouped in the first year, then how long he stays in the home is irrelevant. If, however, a homeowner plans to stay in a home no more than five years and expects it to take three years to recoup the refinancing costs, it might not make financial sense.
"We have had people refinance when the rate was less than 2 percent, 1.5 percent or less," Mr. Lublin said. "If we could get them in for a no-point loan and we kept the closing costs to a minimum, then we have seen cases when it made sense for people with only a 1 percent drop."
The lesson in this for homeowners who want to seize the opportunity to cut their borrowing costs is to analyze carefully, get professional advice, be persistent and shop around.
What one lender may not do, another might. The drop in rates may not produce for everyone the dramatic savings achieved by Mr. LeFevre, but a refinancing may be worth pursuing anyway, even if a new loan requires an additional down payment.
Nationally, according to a Mortgage Bankers Association of America survey of 20 large mortgage banking firms, the number of refinancing applications has risen fivefold since a year ago and 12 times since March 1990. About 1.5 million households saved $3 billion in 1991 by refinancing mortgages. About 3 million are expected to refinance this year and save $6 billion.
Thomas M. Holloway, a senior economist with the association, termed the volume of refinancing activity "extraordinary." He noted that more than 70 percent of all loan applications in January nationally are for refinancing rather than for original mortgages, compared to the average a year ago of about 29 percent.
He said that the flood of refinancing started after Dec. 20, when the Federal Reserve Board cut by a full percentage point its discount rate, the rate it charges member banks for loans. He added that the volume has been especially strong in the last three weeks because many borrowers waited until after the holidays to apply. He also said a small "up-tic" in interest rates during the week of Jan. 17 appeared to signal that the decline in interest rates may have bottomed out.
"People are saying that now may be the time to go," Mr. Holloway said.
Interest rates, now at an 18-year low, have been falling steadily, for the most part, since the mid-80's. The national average for a one-year adjustable-rate mortgage has dropped from a high of 12.05 percent in July 1984 to 5.92 percent in January, according to preliminary figures released by HSH Associates in Butler, N.J. The rate on a 30-year, fixed-mortgage has dropped from 14.74 percent in July 1984 to 8.34 percent last month.
HSH Associates, which surveys 2,000 lenders around the country, also found 370 banks and brokers offering 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages at 8 percent or less and 180 offering adjustables at 5 percent or lower.
Besides sparking a boom in refinancings, the lower interest rates nudged up home sales by 0.9 percent in December over the previous month. "Since the drop in interest rates, we have seen more buyers and refinancings, I being one of them," said Carol Rothe, a vice president of the William Higgins real estate agency in Hillsdale, N.J.
HOMERICA, which currently charges 4.25 percent on its one-year adjustable-rate mortgage, has been offering the lowest rates in the nation for the last several weeks. It also charges borrowers 3.25 points for the loan. Mr. Lublin said his office has been getting literally thousands of calls, 90 percent of them inquiries about refinancing. "We are inundated," he said.
Elsewhere, the Dime Savings Bank in Manhattan has been receiving 4,000 to 5,000 calls a week inquiring about refinancing, compared to a weekly average a year ago of about 1,000 calls. Moreover, 83 percent of the residential mortgages it processed in the first half of January were refinancings. A year ago, the figure was about 20 percent.
"We have had significant refinance activity for the last quarter, especially since about early October," said David J. Totaro, a senior vice president and chief marketing officer at the bank.
Mr. LeFevre, who refinanced at Homerica, said his monthly mortgage payments will drop from $1,930 to $905 during the first year of the loan, which can be converted to a fixed-rate mortgage during the third, fourth or fifth year. With a 2 percent cap on the amount the interest rate can increase or decrease, the highest amount he will pay during the second year will be $1,130. Thus in the first two years he stands to save at least $21,000.
Though in some instances, points and closing costs are paid at the time of closing, Mr. LeFevre's 3.25 points, or $5,980, and $4,000 in closing costs are being paid over the life of the 30-year, $184,000 loan, which also has a 6 percent lifetime cap, meaning the most he will ever pay will be 10.25 percent.
"He's making it back in the first year," Mr. Lublin said, referring to the points and closing costs.
Although the super-low, one-year adjustable rates may be the most eye-grabbing, they do not appear to be attracting the most interest from customers.
"The one-year adjustable is popular with first-time buyers, not for refinancing," said Mr. Totaro of the Dime Savings Bank, which is offering a one-year, adjustable-rate mortgage at 5.5 percent with no points and a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage at 8.12 percent with 1.5 points. The bank's 30-year fixed-rate mortgage has an interest rate of 8.625, with 1.25 points.
"People are trying to get into a fixed-rate for the 15-year and the 30-year," he added. "If they can't get into a fixed-rate, they are trying for either a three-year or a five-year adjustable."
Andrew Zartolas Jr., a senior vice president at Westport Bank and Trust in Westport, Conn., said that mortgages called "7-23's" are also popular. These are fixed for the first 7 years and then adjusted for the last 23 years to the 10-year average of Treasury bill rates.
"A lot of people don't anticipate being in their homes for seven years," he said. "And, for them, this is a good opportunity for good savings for seven years. And since T-bill rates aren't that volatile, it's a chance worth taking."
Most borrowers are refinancing to lower their monthly mortgage payments. Some, however, are arranging the new loans to consolidate other debts or incur new ones. For example, Noel Nichols of Norwalk, Conn., switched from a 13.75, fixed-rate, $107,000 mortgage that he took out in 1983 for a 9.12 percent 30-year, fixed-rate with no points at $122,000. His monthly payment, $982, will stay the same, but he borrowed $12,000, the interest on which will be tax-deductible, to buy a car. The refinancing cost him $1,800 for legal and other fees.
"I had been intending to do this, but the uncertainty over my employment situation made it difficult," said Mr. Nichols, who is a financial consultant.
Homeowners are finding that there are many barriers to refinancing. First, there are new qualifying restrictions imposed by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, which buys loans made by banks and other lenders. Fannie Mae now calculates a borrower's ability to pay at a minimum of 7 percent even if the borrower finds a lender offering a lower adjustable rate mortgage.
Moreover, if a borrower's down payment is less than 25 percent, the ability to pay may be computed at two points higher than the offered rate. Thus, if a borrower found a one-year, adjustable-rate mortgage offered at 6 percent, the approval would be based on his ability to pay 8 percent.
A buyer would not pay at the higher rate but would have to show he could do so if it became necessary. The additional percentage points give Fannie Mae added assurance that the borrower would be able to meet the payments if the interest rate rose. Adjustable loans usually are capped to limit rate increases to two percentage points in a year.
MORE problematic than higher ability-to-pay levels may be drops in appraised property values, higher household debt or lower family income. Mr. Totaro said that 60 percent of those making telephone inquiries to the Dime Savings Bank either didn't qualify or were only shopping for rates. And as many as half of the applicants have a problem with a decline in their property's value.
Suppose, for example, that to buy a $300,000 house, someone put down $60,000 and took out a $240,000 mortgage. If the house declines in value to $240,000, the most the owner would be able to refinance would be $192,000, since most banks will not let a loan exceed 80 percent of a house's appraisal value.
"A lot of customers are coming in here very surprised their homes are no longer worth what they paid for them, and, in some cases, their mortgage value is higher than the value of the home now," Mr. Totaro said. "Primarily condo and co-op owners are having this problem."
R. Frank Gooden, owner of First Merchants, a mortgage lender, in Brooklyn, said that owners of property bought between 1986 and 1990 often run into problems with refinancing, especially if the down payment was less than 25 percent. "It depends on the location," he said. "But in some places the appraised value could have dropped 25 to 30 percent."
"What we tell people in that situation," he added, "is if they expect to be in their homes more than four to five years, given the low interest rate, it does make sense to pay down the mortgage."
TOUGHER credit restrictions can also be troublesome, particularly for homeowners who bought with easy-to-obtain, no-verification loans, which were popular in the mid-1980's. Lenders of those high-interest loans did not check the income or assets of borrowers.
Renuka Chainani, for instance, bought her $136,000 studio apartment in Battery Park City in Lower Manhattan in 1987 with a no-verification, 11.25 percent mortgage from the Dime Savings Bank. When she inquired about refinancing last fall, she was told that because she was late on her student-loan payments to another bank, she would not qualify.
"I could get a mortgage four years ago, but now my credit isn't good enough to refinance," she said.
For those who qualify for refinancing, the surge in applications has increased processing time markedly. Mr. LeFevre, for example, applied in November and is scheduled to close later this month.
"We're on fire -- we're seeing record applications, and 91 percent of them are refinancings," said Alan J. Cicchetti, a senior vice president at the Connecticut National Mortgage Company in Hartford.
According to a Mortgage Bankers of America survey, application processing time has increased by 20 days, to 50 days. It also showed that virtually all of the 20 lenders surveyed have employees working on overtime or have hired temporary staff to handle the overload of applications. About half of them have also added telephone lines, increased office space and hired additional permanent staff.
"We have customers just showing up without calling first because they can't get through," Mr. Lublin said. "It's incredible."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

The 40-Year Mortgage
 
Question: I have heard that a bank in California offers 40-year mortgages. Is it possible to get such a home loan in this area? . . . S.G. Belwood, Manhattan
 
Answer: Maybe. Elizabeth Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Service, a mortgage brokerage in Manhattan, knows of no New York or regional lender that currently offers 40-year loans. However, both the Bowery Savings Bank and Great Western Bank offer these loans. Both are lenders based in California with operations in New York City. 
 "Essentially, the 40-year loan is like other loans," said Mrs. Scott, "except that the payments are amortized over a 40-year period instead of the 15, 20 or 30 years of the typical home loan."
Mrs. Scott said that there are advantages and disadvantages in the 40-year mortgage. The main advantage is that the loan carries a lower monthly payment than more conventional mortgages. But the 40-year loan ends up costing significantly more over the long run.
Take for example, a $100,000 mortgage that carries an 8.5 percent interest rate. The monthly payments for this mortgage on a 30-year term would be about $769 while the monthly payments on the same loan with a 40-year term would be about $733. But over the life of the loan, the cost of borrowing the $100,000 for 30 years would be $276,840 and, for 40 years, would be $75,000 more, or $351,840.
Also, Mrs. Scott said, some lenders that offer 40-year mortgages put more stringent prepayment penalties on these loans.
"The 40-year mortgage is almost an all-interest loan in the beginning," said Mrs. Scott, "so the loan is probably most useful for a borrower who could use the advantage of the lower monthly payments but does not expect to own their home for a long time."
 
Assessments in Co-op
 
Question: I am a shareholder in a co-op. Last year, for the first time, the co-op board assessed each apartment owner $50 for the employee Christmas fund. In the past I have contributed to a fund on a voluntary basis.
I can see nothing in the bylaws or proprietary lease that requires shareholders to make these contributions. Is it legal for the money to be raised through an assessment? . . . Samuel Galewitz, Rye, N.Y.
 
Answer: It is, according to Ronald A. Sher, a lawyer who practices in White Plains.
"Presuming that the co-ops bylaws or proprietary lease gives the board the authority to implement assessments," said Mr. Sher, "then a holiday bonus for employees could constitute a legitimate expense for which the board could assess the shareholders."
However, it is more usual, Mr. Sher said, for a holiday bonus to be part of a co-op's regular expense budget and not a special assessment.
 
Rent Increases
 
Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment and I received notices about the Rent Guidelines Board increases. It says that the allowable increase on a two-year lease is 6.5 percent and that it is 4 percent for one-year leases.
It seems to me that I would pay more money -- 13 percent -- if I took a two-year lease than I would if I took two one-year leases even if the next increase for the one-year lease is higher than it is now. Is this true? . . . Ann Thornburgh, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. The 6.5 percent currently allowed for leases signed between Oct. 1, 1991, and Sept. 30, 1992, is for both years, not for each of two years in the lease term.
Joseph D'Agosta, an assistant commissioner at the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which oversees rent-stabilized housing, said the rent increase system is designed so that tenants save money by taking two-year leases rather than consecutive one-year leases.
For more information on the guidelines for stabilizied rents call the D.H.C.R. hotline at 718-739-6400.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: City College;
A Case of Terra-Cotta Failure

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
THE 19th-century architect George B. Post had an engineering degree, excellent credentials and a reputation for sober, conservative designs.
So up at City College they are still wondering what happened at the turn of the century when Post used unproved technology for Shepard Hall, City College's main building of 1907 -- which has become the largest example of terra-cotta failure in New York City and perhaps the country. 
 Now architects, engineers and workmen are swarming over the landmark's exterior and the total cost of their repairs will exceed $200 million -- over $600 a square foot.
City College was established in 1847 and soon built a large, neo-Gothic building at the southeast corner of 23d Street and Lexington Avenue. But by the 1890's, the city grew up around the site and enrollment increased and City College -- like New York University and Columbia College -- began to look for a campus farther uptown. The trustees eventually settled on a rocky plateau running from 138th to 140th Streets, from Amsterdam Avenue to St. Nicholas Terrace.
When Post won the design competition he had had 25 years of experience with everything from tenements to mansions and skyscrapers and his firm was considered a leader in the profession.
He designed a group of buildings in the collegiate Gothic style of which the centerpiece was the main building, later named Shepard Hall.
In form, Shepard Hall is like a giant cathedral: a front with two towers faces the campus, behind which the "nave" is terminated by a huge, square, central tower, something like that over the crossing in a Gothic church. Two curving wings of classrooms extend out from the sides.
For the sake of economy, the buildings were faced with Manhattan schist taken from the site and trimmed with bright, white terra cotta. The dark, rough, rocky schist and the bright, smooth, angular terra cotta form a startling combination.
At the time of the City College commission, glazed terra cotta had been only recently introduced and was considered a versatile material -- it looked like stone, but could be mass produced and was light in weight.
Most of the facades at City College were bearing walls, instead of masonry veneers supported on steel framing, and Post used the terra cotta as if it were stone, piling one block on top of another, sometimes with no real backing or other stiffener, especially in the big, square central tower.
But terra cotta is not like stone -- it cracks easily, is not nearly as strong and its hollows easily trap water which can freeze and expand.
The current work is being supervised by the Stein Partnership. An associate, Christopher Tavener, said that patchwork repairs indicate that problems with the terra cotta arose decades ago. In recent years, the main tower walls have shifted dramatically -- and with no steel skeleton, the entire structure depended on their stability.
The Stein Partnership has had to redesign the building from the inside out, install new concrete walls and floors, and remove 12,000 pieces of terra cotta -- so far. These have been replaced with a hollow material called Design-Cast, a cast of cement reinforced with fiberglass carefully supervised for color and glaze. This in turn is bolted onto an internal spiderweb of steel so that one piece may be removed in the future without jeopardizing the ones above. Ultimately, says Mr. Tavener, all 50,000 elements will have to be replaced.
IT'S a 10- or 15-year project, costing at least $210 million, according to Robert McLaughlin, project manager for the owner, the Dormitory Authority of New York State.
Terra-cotta failure is familiar now in projects like the Woolworth Building, where 26,000 units had to be replaced in the 1970's because water penetration rusted internal steel pins and cracked the blocks. In the strictest sense, such a failure is not one of design but of maintenance.
But the case of Shepard Hall shows an experienced architect using a new material in new ways on a large scale and apparently without considering the possibility that the material might not hold up. He left little margin for safety or evidence of awareness that something new was under way.
This upends notions of older times as periods in which builder and architect worked in unison with tried and true techniques to build structures that could last for centuries. In the case of Shepard Hall, Post's terra-cotta experiment will be completely gone by its 100th birthday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Parapet at Shepard Hall, City College's main building, in 1908. (The American Architect and Building News)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: The Convention High;
For Manhattan's Hotels, No Fear of July Doldrums

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
SIX months from now, New York City, traditionally a Democratic town anyway, will be positively swarming with Democrats. Local Republicans may find that daunting, but Manhattan hotel operators see a lip-smacking prospect.
They are preparing to play host to the 30,000-or-so delegates, reporters and their ancillaries -- and, of course, tourists -- that the Democratic National Convention, which begins on July 13, will bring to town. 
 And, they are sending a strong signal to the Democratic National Convention Committee that they will do whatever it takes -- extend room-service hours, provide extra meeting space, what have you -- to make the visitors feel at home. "The hotels have been incredibly accommodating," said Mario Cooper, the committee's manager.
Indeed, the operators of the 56 hotels that have contracted with the committee to provide 18,000 rooms for five nights -- most at corporate rates or lower -- are spending millions on fancy facelifts. Their fervent wish is that the convention will provide both a momentary adrenalin rush for hotels, which rarely have more than 50 percent occupancy rate in July, and a longer-range public relations shot in the arm for the city at large.
"We're banking that what is good for the city is good for the real estate industry," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
Clearly, everyone is hoping for a replay of the happy experiences of 1976. Back then, when New York's economy seemed in even more dire shape than it is now, the confluence of the Democratic National Convention and the Bicentennial celebration was enough to send spirits and bottom lines soaring. Tourists, politicos and reporters poured into town, spending an estimated $20 million and sending out signals to the rest of the world that New York, despite its problems, was an exciting, vibrant place.
The rekindled interest in New York was so strong that tourism, which had been faltering, rose steadily for five years straight, succumbing only to the effects of the soaring dollar and the recession of 1981.
Hotels are hoping that the combination of the Columbus Quincentennial, with its attendant Operation Sail, and the convention will provide an equal infusion of cash and enthusiasm. Throughout the city, they are whipping themselves into physical shape.
The ITT Sheraton Corporation is spending $200 million to revamp the Sheraton New York and Sheraton Manhattan hotels. The U.N. Plaza-Park Hyatt Hotel is spending $30 million to redo one of its two towers, a feat that includes renovating about 200 rooms, the lobby, the health club, even the sprinkler system.
The Ramada Hotel Pennsylvania at Madison Square Garden, which will spend $4 million to $6 million on renovations this year, redid its lobby four months ago, is working on its ballrooms, and is redoing some bathrooms, carpeting and wallpaper.
Loew's has spent $17 million to refurbish the Regency, $26 million to spiff up the Loew's New York, and a total of $10 million to refurbish its two Eighth Avenue hotels, the Ramada and the Howard Johnson Plaza. Loew's insists the fix-up activity has nothing to do with the convention.
Indeed, many of the renovations would have proceeded, convention or no. But many have been crunched to be ready before July. "The convention has sped up what was already on drawing boards," said Joseph E. Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York City.
IT has also inspired some construction on its own. ITT Sheraton always planned to renovate the Sheraton New York and Sheraton Manhattan (new names for the Sheraton Centre and City Squire) as soon as it bought out the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, its former partner.
But Robert W. Motley, director of marketing for the two hotels, doubts that the Sheraton New York would have built its Presidential Suite, a 3,600-square-foot duplex carved out of eight rooms, had the hotel not been named, along with the New York Hilton, as convention headquarters.
"I don't think we would have taken eight rooms permanently out of inventory if we didn't expect to hold some highly publicized convention events there," Mr. Motley said.
Indeed, the push for publicity is industry wide. Kenneth I. Walles, general manager of the Ramada Pennsylvania, is talking about a cocktail reception in its Presidential suite just for the media. The New York Hilton is planning "a week full of festivities," said Lola Price, a spokeswoman.
The two Sheraton hotels are adopting a convention theme -- red, white and blue hats for staff, and such -- 60 days before the convention, in hopes of advance publicity.
The U.N. Plaza-Park Hyatt Hotel is pointing out to its convention guests that, if they stay over on a Saturday night, they can get cheaper air fares. The hotel will, in fact, let any delegates extend their stay at the convention rate for as long as they wish. "It's July, our normal occupancy would be 55 percent, so if someone wants to stay here for three weeks, that's great," said Pamela Malkani, director of marketing and sales.
To help spread the welcome mat, the New York 92 Host Committee, a privately financed group that exists expressly to show New York off at its best, is arranging for volunteers to meet delegates at airports and shepherd them through the city. It is preparing welcome kits and is working with the hotels to set up extra information desks.
"If we present New York in its best light, it will have an impact on our hospitality industry for years to come," said Leslie Marcus, the Host Committee's executive director.
Some unpleasantnesses may yet dim that light, though.
Ramada Hotel Pennsylvania, for example, has contracted to rent 1,200 rooms to media people, many of whom will want to come in a few days earlier to do pre-convention stories. Television crews in particular will want to run cables, set up lights, and otherwise prepare meeting spaces for press conferences and interviews.
THE problem is that from July 4 to 11, the hotel is headquarters to Esto 92, an Estonian convention that is expected to bring some 15,000 Estonians to Manhattan. The hotel and the city tried to persuade the Estonians to change their dates, or at least turn back some meeting space earlier, all to no avail.
"Maybe we would have considered changing the dates for decent monetary considerations, but they weren't offered," said Urmas Karner, president of the Esto 92 Committee Inc. The result is that the Convention Committee may have to house early arrivals from the press and electronic media elsewhere, while the hotel must be prepared to "turn on a dime," as Mr. Walles put it, to wire up meeting rooms after the Estonians leave.
The city's nonunion hotels would probably love to have such overbooking problems. The Convention Committee will not use them to house delegations or as a site for special events. ("We are a union party, after all," said Tina Flournoy, the committee's general counsel.) So they are trying to drum up business of their own.
The Marriott Marquis says it has already booked more than 1,200 of its 1,900 rooms for government dignitaries, both domestic and foreign, and foreign media representatives.
The Embassy Suites, which doesn't have Marriott's international cachet, is embarking on a huge direct mail program to foreign reporters. It is taking booths at international hotel shows. And it is quizzing international reporters as to what might entice their colleagues. Among the suggestions being considered: facsimile machines in each room, transportation to Madison Square Garden, mini-business centers in some suites.
"We're still looking for the million-dollar idea that will sell the hotel out," said Kevin J. Breen, director of marketing.
Indirectly, the New York Convention & Visitors Bureau may do that for him. Already, the bureau is devising street fairs, tours and other special events that will tie together the convention, Op Sail and the Columbus Quincentennial celebrations. And, Steven E. Trombetti, vice president of communications, has prepared a video news release on the "democratic process in action" that will make it clear that convention delegates and entourages will not use up even half the city's 67,000 hotel rooms.
"We have to avoid the sold out syndrome that always accompanies world fairs, Olympics and other major events," Mr. Trombetti said. "We must make sure no one thinks there's no room at the inn."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
In Fairfield County, the Cachet Persists

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
FAIRFIELD COUNTY'S appeal to home buyers, even during real estate slumps, has been demonstrated clearly in this recession.
While the county's home market has suffered free-falling prices and overloaded inventories, it has been sustained better than most areas by a stream of buyers seeking its cachet and its proximity to New York, particularly now that its properties are attainable at lower cost, many of them through foreclosure. 
 Statistics gathered by The Commercial Record, a Connecticut business journal, show a rise of 8.03 percent in Fairfield County residential sales from October 1990 through October 1991. The only county in Connecticut to experience a gain, it eased the statewide decline in sales to only 2.8 percent.
Fairfield also showed the smallest drop in house prices, from a median of $230,000 to $225,000, or 2.17 percent. Statewide, the median price fell 3.03 percent, from $148,500 to $144,000. Sales in the mid-range of $150,000 to $300,000 exceeded all others in Fairfield in 1990 and 1991. A total of 8,207 residences were sold in the county through October 1991 for a total volume of $2.26 billion, up over the previous year's figures of 7,286 residences for a total of $2.03 billion.
Robert Vossler, president of the Home Buyers Assistance Corporation of Westport, a relocater, said some Fairfield communities did not do so well. "Bridgeport will continue to have difficulties and Danbury and Shelton are slow," he said. "Because of the drop in prices and interest rates people who would normally opt for Shelton can now afford Wilton and Westport."
William Raveis, president of the statewide Raveis Realty, based in the Town of Fairfield, said: "Fairfield County is always an indicator. If historical data hold true, the rest of the state will follow. It's noteworthy that sales are up in spite of the United Parcel Service move to Atlanta, leaving 300 houses."
Stanley Klein, president of Empire Realty in Greenwich, does not share the view of Fairfield as bellwether. "It is less affected by recession than the rest of the state and recovers earlier," he said. "Mortgage rates are not as significant here. People with mortgages at 45 to 50 percent of purchase price are usually overqualifed."
Sales in Greenwich, which his company tracks, were up by 40 percent in 1991 over 1990. "The reason is simple," he said. "Prices are down." The average among 644 sales in 1991 was $780,469, down 3.2 percent from 1990, when 459 homes were sold with an average price of $806,086. "Sales were also down in 1990 from 1989," he added, noting that it was the first time in 40 years that Greenwich had a two-year decline in prices.
Condominium prices in 1990 averaged $303,726, declining 5.8 percent last year to $285,989. "In 1989 there was a 20 percent decline," Mr. Klein said. He expects condominium prices to begin rising in the second quarter, while home prices will continue to slide.
Stamford prices have fallen about 8 percent, says Tom Purcell, director of the Stamford Board of Realtors. "The average home price in 1990 was $340,000," he said. "In 1991 it was $330,000. We are up 8 to 10 percent in sales of houses and condos for 1991, with 995 sales compared to 870 sales in 1990."
Renters are choosing not to buy until they are more secure in their jobs, he said. "The companies that are coming in are smaller," he added, "and they don't offer the relocation perquisites that big corporations used to give."
Pamela Schwanke, manager of the William Pitt Realty office in Stamford, is optimistic about what she called "our best year in recent memory." Dollar volume for 1991 increased 52 percent over 1990, and the number of sales jumped 43 percent, she said.
In 1990, the Pitt organization, which has offices in Fairfield and lower Litchfield Counties, had 50 foreclosure sales for a total of $8 million. In 1991, there were 133 such sales, totaling $25.8 million, and more are expected this year.
"The lowest price was $100,000 for a 3-bedroom house in Norwalk, marketed for six months at $169,000 before foreclosure," said Michael O'Dwyer of Pitt's foreclosure division. At the high end was a six-bedroom Greenwich home listed for two years at $3.2 million and sold in foreclosure for $1.8 million.
Prudential Connecticut Realty, headquartered in West Hartford, sold 87 foreclosed properties statewide in 1991, and currently holds 200 listings. "In 1990 we had none," said Julia Strayer, vice president for marketing. "Our sales are up 42 percent in Fairfield County and down 2 percent in Hartford County for the year."
REALTORS are resorting to extraordinary means to sell corporate- and bank-owned houses more quickly. Many of them subscribe to the services of Home Marketing Associates of Fairfield and Showhomes of Westport. Both firms install temporary tenants and their furniture in vacant homes on the theory that a warm, attractively furnished, lived-in house sells faster and at a better price.
Roger Jewell and nine rooms of his furniture are currently ensconced in a Show homes house in Rowayton. "They match you and your furniture with the style of the house," Mr. Jewell said. He has lived, temporarily, in Westport, New Canaan and Wilton, where he occupied a house listed at more than $1 million, paying $750 in rent to Show homes. He is responsible for moving costs in and out, utilities and maintenance, leaving the owner free of most expenses except property taxes. Owner, tenant and Showhomes share insurance costs.
"We have 70 houses in our Connecticut inventory," said Noreen Dwyer-Kimball, marketer for Showhomes, a nationwide company. "That's up more than 65 percent from last year."
Home Marketing Associates has most of its 48 homes in Fairfield County. "Last year 70 percent of our properties sold in 30 days," said Joanne Paone, a company partner.
Another service aimed at making houses more salable is offered by Homestagers of Westport and Farmington. Interior designers rearrange the owner's possessions and supply written recommendations for repairs and cosmetic improvements for around $175.
When 30-year fixed-rate mortgages edged up a half point to 8 1/2 percent late last month "our brokers' phones did not stop ringing," said Carolyn Weber, vice president of regional development for Century 21. "Customers who had been waiting for lower rates were nudged into action. The scary part is how long can these rates hold?"

HEADLINE: 'Florio II': Remaking an Image

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

 BODY:
AFTER one of the stormiest two-year openings to an administration in memory, Gov. Jim Florio is looking to recapture the public support he lost through enactment of an ambitious tax program in 1990 and to position himself for a possible bid for re-election in 1993.
The Governor said he was taking a page out of his book as a Congressman, when he met with patrons of a diner in Camden to get the public pulse, and would increase his travels around the state during the next two years.
Perhaps never before in the state has a chief executive entered office with a clearer idea of what he wanted to do and then managed to alienate the very people he was trying to help by the manner in which he achieved his goals. 
 After two successive general elections in which Democratic candidates were punished largely because of voter anger over the Governor's programs, Florio-watching has become a principal preoccupation around the state. Political observers and business leaders admit to being fascinated by the prospect of seeing how the Governor deals with a Legislature controlled by Republicans for the first time in decades while he reaches out for public support. A battle over the budget could provide a first test.
Bruce Coe, the president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, is among those who say that Mr. Florio is showing signs of curbing his penchant for "charging off with solutions to problems before people are even aware of them."
Mr. Coe referred to the Governor as "Florio II" in a recent interview and said he believed that the necessity of working with a Republican legislative majority large enough to override the Governor's vetoes would force Mr. Florio to seek public support for his positions. 
"At the beginning of his administration, the Democratic-controlled Legislature was a wholly owned subsidiary of the Governor's office," Mr. Coe said. "We really had only two branches of government, the judiciary and the executive.
"And while the Governor did an excellent job of identifying the issues, the solutions he pushed through, whether good, bad or mixed, got lost in the manner in which they were done."
"How do you pour millions of more dollars into education and get every teacher in the state mad at you?" Mr. Coe added. "Or move to cut property taxes and have social economists express disdain for what you're doing?"
Mr. Florio's inability to sell his program was underscored in the recent legislative elections. The program included increasing income tax rates for the wealthiest wage earners to provide rebates for less affluent property-tax payers, increasing school aid and adding a penny to the sales tax to close a stubborn budget gap largely created by the national recession. Voters who benefited by the tax changes overwhelmingly voted for Republicans who opposed Mr. Florio's program.
Mr. Florio's aggressive hands-on style also generated some grumbling among members of the administration. Mr. Coe said one Cabinet officer complained to him that he could not talk to Mr. Coe or anyone outside the administration "without first clearing it with three honchos from the inner sanctum."
In an interview in his office, Mr. Florio agreed that "for the first year or year and a half, my efforts to change things led to perhaps too much control." But he said this was a reaction to a lack of accountability that he and a committee of business leaders he had appointed found when he took office.
"They were astounded at the lack of controls," Mr. Florio said, citing a proliferation of the number of state cars assigned to public employees as an example.
He also said that in his 26 years in public office he had never seen the level of pessimism that was abroad today. People who hope for a better future are confronted by forces that seem geared to prevent progress, he said, and in that atmosphere, attempts by government at problem solving are often met with suspicion.
Mr. Florio has begun moving around the state, holding town meetings and listening to local concerns. He has also started a program called "Capital for a Day," which will see him set up a mini-seat of government complete with Cabinet officials in various municipalities around the state. The idea is to give residents a look at the workings of their government and to explain to them what he is trying to accomplish.
He said the public outreach was already bearing fruit. "After a recent meeting, a woman came up to me and said, 'Things are not as black or white as I thought; they're much more complicated than I realized,' " Mr. Florio said.
 
Contention Draws Support
 The Governor's contention that New Jersey is in better financial shape than other states in the Northeast, as evidenced by its triple-A bond rating, and doing more than other states in meeting its infrastructure needs was supported by Charles H. Marciante, president of the State A.F.L.-C.I.O.
"If you look around the Northeast and the nation, you'll see we're in better shape than almost any other state," Mr. Marciante said. "The Governor has put together tons of dough for infrastructure improvements that is easing the burden of the recession and is designed to carry us through to 1993."
Mr. Marciante said Mr. Florio "has been an ace," not only because of the construction program but also because he signed a minimum wage bill that will set a $5.05-an-hour minimum wage in New Jersey on April 1, while the Federal minimum wage remains at $4.85.
Mr. Marciante also praised the Governor for "putting the Legislature's feet to the fire" by saying he would not sign an extension of the Uncompensated Care Trust Fund beyond the end of July. The fund pays the cost of hospital care for the indigent by adding a surcharge to bills of paying patients. Mr. Florio's position will force lawmakers to look for some alternate way of paying for care of the indigent.
Two initiatives by Mr. Florio's predecessor, Gov. Thomas H. Kean, including the creation of the Transportation Trust Fund and revision of the Unemployment Compensation Fund, have figured in improvements for the state's hourly workers. The transportation fund has provided some of the money for the construction program, and the state's healthy unemployment fund enabled the state to extend unemployment benefits to idled workers before the Federal Government authorized its extension.
The unemployment fund contains $2.5 billion and generates $250 million in interest annually at a time when other states' funds are being depleted, Mr. Coe said.
 
Cooperation Pledged
 Mr. Florio has pledged his cooperation to the Republican Legislature, as long as it does not entail giving in on a matter of principle. Though Mr. Coe said he believed that he has seen a calmer, more accommodating Mr. Florio in recent public appearances, others have not been so sure.
Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers University and a political consultant to the Republican Party, said that Mr. Florio "has a real chance to make some positive changes, but it all depends on whether he chooses confrontation or compromise, and everything in his background says it will be confrontation."
Some means of accommodation between the administration and the Legislature will have to be found, Mr. Salmore said, since the Republican majorities include many people who are new to public office. While the party is certain to redeem its campaign pledge to roll back the penny increase in the sales tax, deep cuts in government spending will have to be made to offset the $590 million the tax change will cost in addition to hundreds of millions more to close an anticipated budget gap caused by the recession and the use of one-time revenue raisers that helped balance the current $14.7 billion state budget.

 
Budget Sent to Legislature
 Last week, Mr. Florio sent his proposed 1992-93 budget to the Legislature, calling for spending $15.7 billion and counting on revenue from the current 7 percent sales tax. The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, Republican of Scotch Plains, criticized the Governor for not giving credence to Republican promises to roll the tax back to 6 percent. On Tuesday, Mr. Florio told lawmakers he would sign a tax-cut bill if his budget goals could be met.
Mr. DiFrancesco was happier, however, with Mr. Florio's decision to change the way the state's pension system is carried on the books. The move will increase the value of the system to $29 billion from $24 billion and result in a benefit to the State Treasury of more than $1 billion over the current fiscal year and the next.
On Tuesday, state education officials released revised school-aid figures that provide $341 million in additional money, mostly for middle-income districts. The new aid was generated through the proposed reduction in the state's contribution to the pension system.
Republican leaders said the change would make it easier to cut taxes. In addition, the Republican majority is said to be considering making the sales tax cut effective next Jan. 1, in the middle of the fiscal year, instead of on July 1, when the fiscal year begins. This would cut the anticipated revenue loss in half to about $300 million.
 
Effect of Marches on Trenton
 Mr. Salmore said many of the Republicans in the Legislature were "new and they could become very scared, especially when they see the marches on Trenton and the rallies."
The Presidential election this year could also have a profound effect on Mr. Florio's future, Mr. Salmore said. If a Democrat defeats President Bush, a change in the national agenda would follow that could engender Federal funds for so-called compassionate programs that Mr. Florio could champion.
If Mr. Bush wins re-election, the agenda will remain focused on Republican issues like taxes, budgets and the economy, and the Governor's hands will be tied, Mr. Salmore said. "How can you help people if you can't spend money?" he said.
He said one issue that was certain to reappear was educational financing. "The State Supreme Court left the state with an impossible set of alternatives," Mr. Salmore said.
The court has ordered the state to increase state aid to the poorest school districts and to continue increasing it to keep them on a spending level with the wealthiest districts. Mr. Salmore said the middle-class districts, which are losing aid, "are not going to stand by and let all the aid go to urban districts."
Mr. Salmore said what probably had to emerge was a bipartisan political solution to school financing that the court would accept, or a constitutional amendment to redefine the state's responsibility to provide a thorough and efficient education for all students.
 
Florio 'Mellowing' Seen
 Richard W. Roper, the executive director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University, said Mr. Florio "has mellowed a bit and has not panicked" in the face of his party's political reversal.
Mr. Roper said that the Governor "faces a stiff challenge from the Republican legislative leaders as the agenda is being shaped over the next two years, and his best hope is to take the public policy high ground, lay out the broad themes and program direction and then work closely with the Republican leadership in designing the programs."
He said Mr. Florio's aggressive style in pushing his programs during his first year in office "created powerful enemies who fought him the rest of the way." Although the Governor's tax program does not appear in any real danger of a major repeal because of the economy and the need for revenue, some other initiatives "appear to have unraveled," he said.
The state's auto insurance system continues to produce large deficits despite a major realignment, and the state's tough ban on the sale or possession of assault rifles weathered one attempt by the National Rifle Association to weaken it, but the gun lobby is expected to try again in the current session.
In addition, the education revision that produced increased financing for public schools was cut back by Democrats in the Legislature to provide more money for property tax relief in a futile attempt to hold on to control of the Legislature in the November elections.
The Democrats attempted to repeal the Governor's tax program in the lame-duck session after the elections, but the bills failed to clear the Assembly. Mr. Florio never said he would have signed the bills if they had reached his desk, and he said in his interview that he would never sign anything that would threaten the fiscal integrity of the state or undo his property tax relief and school financing programs.
 
'Guilty of Hypocrisy'
 But he clearly enjoyed watching the Republican lawmakers and state business leaders squirm as the Democrats tried to do what the Republicans said should be done during their campaign, roll back the taxes. "They were guilty of blatant hypocrisy in opposing the tax changes and then saying it would be fiscally irresponsible to repeal them," he said.
Mr. Florio said that the state was positioned to make a strong comeback once the economy rebounded from the recession, and that if the state got "a fair shake" on Federal revenue, the comeback would be dramatic.
He said he was looking forward to working with the Legislature over the next two years. "People need hope, but they also need help," he said.
And he appears to enjoy the prospect of watching the new Republican majority wrestle with knotty problems instead of sniping at proposed solutions from the sidelines. "They won't have the luxury of criticizing any longer," he said.
The Governor said he would "work with anybody" to find solutions, but would continue to veto bills he did not agree with and would stand by his position even if he were eventually overriden.
One such fight may come over the expected attempt to weaken gun control. Mr. Florio said he was not afraid to stand before the voters on that issue.
"That's the democratic process," he said. "It's called accountability."

In an interview in his office, Mr. Florio agreed that "for the first year or year and a half, my efforts to change things led to perhaps too much control." SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: State Moves Against '900' Number Schemes

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
WHEN Sherry Haggerty of Newton received a notice in the mail telling her that she had been pre-approved for a gold credit card, she was initially somewhat skeptical. The presence of the familiar Visa and Mastercard logos, however, quelled her skepticism. She called the "900" telephone number printed on the notice.
A short time later, she received a catalogue and a gold plastic card. "The gold card was nothing like a Visa or Mastercard," Ms. Haggerty said. In fact, she said, the card was good only for ordering merchandise from the catalogue itself. And even though she ordered nothing, Ms. Haggerty was nevertheless charged for the card. 
 "It ended up being a scam for a gold card," she said. "But what they don't tell you is how you're going to be billed and that it's going to come on your phone bill, and that you're going to drop dead because your phone bill is $80."
Over the last year, the number of complaints filed by victims of illegal 900 schemes shot up from nearly none to more than 300, said state officials, who suspect that many more are unreported. As a result, the State Attorney General's office and the Division of Consumer Affairs have begun an aggressive assault on operators of illegal telephone marketing schemes.
Their efforts were augmented last month with the passage of a law that sets strict guidelines for operators of 900 numbers in New Jersey. The law, which goes into effect on April 1, requires 900 operators to make detailed disclosure of their rates and services in written advertisements and during calls and allows callers a reasonable time to disconnect without incurring charges.
"We are pursuing frauds in this area as vigorously as we possibly can," said the State Attorney General, Robert J. Del Tufo, who is also chairman of the National Association of Attorneys General Telemarketing Task Force.
 
Penalties or Refunds Paid
 Mr. Del Tufo said that in the last year alone the Division of Consumer Affairs had taken action against 11 companies that were operating 900 lines in New Jersey. Each of those companies has stopped advertising in the state, paid a penalty or provided refunds to consumers.
"It became very clear to me that if you wait until the wrong has occurred, you've lost the game," Mr. Del Tufo said. "You may detect one violation, but by the time you detect it, the defrauder has already taken advantage of thousands of consumers."
The 900 business has quickly grown into a billion-dollar industry, Mr. Del Tufo said. Though most operators of such services are reputable, he said, "there are more people getting into it for the wrong reasons."
Helen M. Pohlig, managing director of the National Association for Information Providers, a trade organization based in Washington, said that her organization supported the aggressive enforcement actions Mr. Del Tufo was taking, but that the organization did not believe that the number of unscrupulous operators was increasing.
"I'm not suggesting that there aren't scam operators out there," she said. "But we believe that we have seen a turnaround and that people who are deciding to get into the business now are truly legitimate providers."
Most 900 businesses provide information or services to consumers who call their "pay per call" numbers. The call is carried over long-distance lines provided by companies like A.T.& T. and MCI Communications. The long-distance carrier charges the company for carrying the call, but the company itself sets the price that the consumer will pay for the call.
Through agreements that the long-distance carriers have with local telephone companies, those charges are included on the consumer's monthly telephone bill. But that, Mr. Del Tufo said, can make it easier for a unscrupulous operator.
 
'Amount of Legitimacy'
 "The fact that the charge comes in on a telephone bill gives it a certain amount of legitimacy," he said.
Ms. Haggerty, for example, immediately paid the charges for the gold card that were included on her monthly telephone bill. "I didn't want to not pay the phone bill and then have them give me a bad credit reputation," she said. "I just paid it. I didn't dispute it with the phone company."
Ms. Haggerty eventually received a refund as a result of action taken by officials against the 900 company.
But New Jersey Bell officials said that if a customer refused to pay charges for a 900 number, the company would remove the charge from the bill and refer it to the long-distance carrier for handling. A customer's telephone service is not disconnected for nonpayment of 900 charges only, nor is the customer's credit rating affected.
The long-distance carriers also try to cooperate with consumers on questionable bills. "We have an agreement with New Jersey Bell to handle customer complaints," said Frank J. Walter, communications manager for MCI Communications. "They have the authority and are instructed to make credits where appropriate."
 
Many Customers Just Pay
 But many consumers, like Ms. Haggerty, simply pay the charges without protest. And that, officials say, is what permits unscrupulous operators to proliferate.
"The question is, why is New Jersey such a prime target?" said Emma Byrne, director of the Division of Consumer Affairs.
Many of the schemes now being worked in the state, Ms. Byrne said, are directly tied to the effects of the recession. Some stratagems, like the one used on Ms. Haggerty, involve offering credit cards or low-interest loans to consumers.
Others, she said, involve "job lines" that offer virtually meaningless promises of employment.
"People who are three missed paychecks away from being able to meet their mortgage payment might be willing to pay $5 and $10 a minute to listen to 'new inside information' on job opportunities," Ms. Byrne said. Unfortunately, she said, the information provided is often just a "recitation of the want ads."
 
Not Told About Cost
 Nancy Erickson, a spokeswoman for the Division of Consumer Affairs, said that one company recently investigated by officials had been distributing fliers urging recipients to call a toll-free 800 number for information on job listings. When consumers called the number, Ms. Erickson said, they were then told to call a 900 number but were not told that the call would cost as much as $24.
After being confronted by state officials, Ms. Erickson said, the company agreed to stop doing 900 business in New Jersey.
Ms. Erickson added that at least 10 900 job lines and several other telephone marketing schemes were currently under investigation.
One company now being investigated, she said, has been sending consumers an official-looking postcard that says that it is the consumer's "last chance" to call and claim a package. The package, Ms. Erickson said, contains "a worthless piece of jewelry."
The scheme, she said, has generated more than 66,000 telephone calls. "They have brought in $670,000 in under three months," Ms. Erickson said.
Louis Jonas, section supervisor in charge of investigations for the division, said that companies using 900 numbers could be investigated if officials received as few as four or five complaints that portrayed a common illegal pattern. In addition, he said, the division will conduct an investigation even without specific complaints.
 
'Not Necessary to Have Victim'
 "It's not necessary to have a victim," he said. "We can move on an advertisement if something in the advertisement doesn't smell right or doesn't look right."
Mr. Jonas said most illicit 900 stratagems fell into a few basic categories. "We pretty much know the most popular ones," he said. "High up there on the list would be the 'free gift, you've won something' scam," like the one described by Ms. Erickson.
And even if the gift or prize isn't worthless, Mr. Jonas said, the practice would still violate the state's Consumer Fraud Act, which prohibits deceptive advertising.
"If you tell me it's a gift, it has to be a gift," Mr. Jonas said. "You can't use it to lure me into a $10 call."
Another common technique used to defraud consumers, he said, involves an offer of a free vacation.
Typically, Mr. Jonas said, such a solicitation requires the consumer to call a 900 number. The call, which can cost $5 a minute or more, usually results in a virtually worthless vacation offer.
"You find out that the room is free, but you have to pay outlandish fees for the air fare," he said.
 
150 Suspicious Numbers
 Mr. Jonas said that officials had accumulated a file of about 150 suspicious 900 numbers in the last year and a half, but because of the large number of companies involved it was impossible to investigate all of them."So we try to be selective and target a company that appears to be hurting a large number of New Jersey consumers," he said.
Mr. Jonas said one of the main difficulties officials had in protecting consumers was keeping ahead of defrauders. "No matter what rules and regulations you come up with, the operators will find a way around them," he said.
Daisy Ottman, a spokeswoman for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, agreed. She said the company ran regular compliance checks to insure that 900 providers met the company's guidelines. "As we become more familiar with some of the subterfuges, we've gotten more sophisticated in our own compliance reviews," she said.
She added that A.T.& T. had shut down a number of 900 providers on its own and also worked with law-enforcement agencies investigating possible fraud claims.
"The minute they notify us of a problem, we take it very seriously," Ms. Ottman said. "We make our records available on demand, and we generally escrow the company's funds."
 
Credit Card Ploy
 Mr. Jonas said that despite the active cooperation of long-distance carriers, some of the illegal ploys continued to flourish.
"The one that bothers me the most is when they hit the poorer people," he said. "And that often turns out to be with the credit card scam."
The credit card ploy, Mr. Jonas said, involves offers of credit cards and even loans to people who have not established credit ratings. Just calling for information can cost as much as $50, he said.
"Sometimes they'll be crying as they tell me their story," he said. "Fifty dollars doesn't sound like much, but when you talk to these people, it's a big chunk for them."
"Sometimes they can't even speak English, or they may be new arrivals in this country," he added. "They seem to have a little more faith in American business than may be warranted."
 
<HBWhat Callers Must Be Told
 One of the last bills passed in the final days of the 1991 legislative session provides sweeping regulation of the state's "900" telephone line industry.
The bill, which was signed into law last month and takes effect on April 1, augments similar Federal legislation that was passed in December. The new state law requires 900 operators in New Jersey to follow strict guidelines when advertising and providing their services.
In all written advertisements, providers must describe the service and its cost, tell minors that parental consent is necessary and list the provider's name and address.
In addition, for all 900 number calls costing more than $5, the law requires the operator to provide a verbal description of the service and its cost, a parental consent instruction to minors and a statement advising callers that they can disconnect after the disclosure without incurring a charge.
The law also prohibits the advertising of 900 services through the use of automatic dialing systems, the offering of services that require the dialing of more than one telephone number for a fee and the providing of services that require the consumer to call another "pay per call" number to claim a prize or gift.
At the bill signing, Gov. Jim Florio said, "With this bill, New Jersey's consumers can now reach for the phone knowing that con artists won't be reaching for their wallets."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (90%);

HEADLINE: ART;
Russian Works Come to the Forefront

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
WHAT started as the Rutgers University Art Gallery has long since metamorphosed into the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum here, at the corner of George and Hamilton Streets. And, having prospered for 25 years, 21 of them under the direction of Dennis Cate, this repository of prints, painting and sculpture is celebrating its anniversary with a bevy of shows.
Chief among these is "New Directions," so called because the recently acquired collections featured require larger premises. To this end, the museum, propelled by an anonymous gift of $1 million, has embarked on a five-year fund-raising campaign. 
 Of the collections, the one bestowed by George Riabov, a Rutgers alumnus, covers Russian art from the 15th century to the present, contains 1,100 pieces and includes a library of 5,000 books and publications. That donated by Norton and Nancy Dodge numbers more than 5,000 works of contemporary Russian art, the kind banned from public display under Communism. Remember Communism?
Formerly director of the American Institute for Polish Culture, in Miami, Mr. Riabov is now a consultant -- on foreign languages for the Museum of Modern Art, on Russian art for Christie's auction house. Mr. Dodge, a professor emritus of economics at St. Mary's College of Maryland, heads the CASE Museum of Contemporary Russian Art in Exile, which opened in Jersey City a decade or more ago.
How the collectors acquired their treasures during the last 40 or so years is a story that has yet to be told publicly. Their ambition, however, is clear: Rutgers is to be a center for the study of Russian art.
The Riabov excerpt opens with icons and other devotional objects dating from the 15th to the 19th century. All reflect Byzantine influence, except for a double-sided medallion from the 18th century, which is three and a half inches in diameter and depicts scenes from the life of the Virgin. Executed in lace, the design would be extraordinary enough, but it is of rosewood carved into strands scarcely thicker than hairs.
After this comes the lineup of painters, beginning with the Ukrainian-born Ilya Repin (1844 to 1930), a master of anecdote in the grand manner and, though he died in exile (in Finland), generally regarded as a major inspiration to the Social Realists. His picture is of a red-nosed soldier seated at a table playing a balalaika. A beautifully painted scene, it should attract many admirers, now that the illustrative past of Western art is back in favor.
A soldier turned painter, Alexei von Jawlensky (1864 to 1941), started out in the St. Petersburg circle around Repin, then "defected" to the more esthetically advanced climate of Munich, where he was involved for a while with Kandinsky. His "Head of Christ" is a lovely late work in which the thick black lines defining the nose and eyebrows suggest a cross.
Mikhail Larionov (1881 to 1964) and his lifelong mistress, Nathalia Gontcharova (1881 to 1962), are here, the first with a sinuous line drawing of the poet Nikolai Gumilev, the second with a costume design for the ballet "Le Coq d'Or," both circa 1914.
Other notables include Leon Bakst, Alexander Benois, Oskar Rabin, Olga Rozanova, Valentin Serov, who is represented by a study of Czar Nicholas II smoking a cigarette in a holder as he writes, and Mikhail Vrubel, a Symbolist with overtones of both Klimt and Redon.
Though this extraordinary flow of art can't be fully appreciated without a chronological chart, it is obvious that the revolutionary artists did not march with their generations. Liubov Popova was 32 when she produced her Cubo-Futurist abstraction of 1921; Kandinsky did his not dissimilar watercolor in 1924, when he was 58; Ilya Chashnik was 21 when, in 1923, he did the Malevich-like red disk hovering in blackness, attended by smaller geometric shapes (he died six years later).
Hung together, these precise, astringent little images augur a utopia that never arrived in Russia (or in Europe), as later developments in the Dodge collection prove.
As if to show what the dissidents were up against, this begins with "The Cosmonaut's Dream," by Sergei Sherstiuk. The subject, drowsing in his space suit, is suspended diagonally over rural landscape against a cloudy blue sky. It was painted in 1986, four years before Gia Edzgveradze's "Derby," a de Kooningesque abstraction with collage that may allude to horses.
Vyacheslav Kalinin pursues a figural Surrealism packed with incident and touched with a whimsy that recalls the English illustrator Arthur Rackham, as well as old covers of Time magazine. In his predominantly blue "Self-Portrait" (1978), the artist is two men, one holding a palette garnished with a glass containing, it seems, liquor; the other turning back to contemplate a view seemingly of Paris. Edging the central image like shingles are small scenes like that of a man drinking from the spout of a teapot.
One recalls a similar dream by this artist in which two lovely ladies in diaphanous drapery lounge on a rooftop, a samovar with a chimney between them and a view of the Kremlin behind.
Komar and Melamid, humorists well known in this country, contribute a Plexiglas case containing a pebble that is actually a Pravda newspaper compressed. More Conceptualist but equally funny is Viktor Pivovarov's "Daily Regime of a Lonely Man." It is the diagram of a clock divided into periods for reflection, meeting and talking with other lonely people, contemplating nature in the evening (through "the window of opportunity"), reading, shopping, cooking, eating and, finally, sleep. Could Steve Martin have known about this when he came up with his "Lonely Guys Club" routine?
On view through Feb. 25, the two collections, along with that of stained-glass windows and the watercolor designs for them, a gift from Gordon Henderson, are a must-see. So much art; so little space.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Suprematist Composition," an oil on panel by Ilya Chashnik, at Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers in New Brunswick.

HEADLINE: Missing Link of Parkland Is for Sale

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THE "verdant glades, picturesque meadows and stretches of woodland" known as the Bronx River Parkway Reservation stretch from the Kensico Dam south to the Westchester County border, enveloping the river in its midst. Except for one glaring detour.
There's a missing link where the river leaves the reservation, flowing instead through an industrial area that has grown up along its banks. The 24-acre site has come on the market as three lots, one of them a wooded parcel west of the Bronx River between the parkway and the river, which County Legislator Katherine S. Carsky wants the county to acquire. 
 The eight-acre wooded property, bordering the river in Yonkers and facing Tuckahoe across the water, would be the first undeveloped open space in the southern part of the county to be acquired in a decade.
 
'What an Opportunity'
 Mrs. Carsky recently wrote County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and asked him to begin the acquisition process. If the move is initiated by the County Executive, the Board will be asked to vote on the proposal.
"What an opportunity this would be," said Mrs. Carsky, who has often criticized the county's open-space policy as favoring northern Westchester. "It is the only place where the river leaves the reservation and it's the only open recreation space in the middle of southern Westchester, an area with the most people per square mile of the whole county."
Mrs. Carsky added that a recent county appraisal indicated that the eight acres could be purchased at a price she called "incredibly possible." She refused to provide any details, saying that to do so would compromise the county's ability to complete a favorable arrangement.
Acquiring the property, Mrs. Carsky added, would also give the county a staging area for Bicycle Sundays, the county-sponsored program that closes the Bronx River Parkway to automobiles each Sunday in May, June and September for 5,000 to 8,000 bicyclists. The site could provide space for parking, picnic tables and a children's play area overlooking the river, Mrs. Carsky said.
 
O'Rourke Notes Budget Restraints
 A spokesman for Mr. O'Rourke said the acquisition is "certainly something the county is considering."
Noting that the County Executive "agrees with Mrs. Carsky that acquiring open space in the southern part of the county is certainly important," Kara Bennorth, the spokeswoman, added that "every acquistion must be very carefully considered because of the county's current economic situation."
This is the second opportunity the county has had to acquire the acreage, which includes a large stone cotton mill completed in 1810, one of the first built in the United States. The original Bronx Parkway Commission, established in 1906, spent $16.5 million to acquire or condemn 1,338 parcels of land to create the reservation protecting the river. But the tract with the cotton mill on the banks of the river facing Tuckahoe was considered too expensive to acquire.
"It isn't often that opportunity knocks twice," Mrs. Carsky said. "I can think of nothing more suitable than this piece of land because it would enable us to complete the Bronx River Reservation, one of our most extraordinary park holdings."
 
The First Median Strip
 Heralded worldwide for its design, the Bronx River Parkway and its reservation began as one the century's earliest pollution-control measures, an effort to halt the degeneration of a once beautiful river into a "noxious, odiferous and unsanitrary condition," as a historian wrote in 1906.
The solution was to create a park and a roadway, planted with 30,000 trees and 140,000 shrubs, some of which were used to separate north and southbound lanes, a concept unusual at that time but one that formed the basis for later highway median strips.
From 1913 to the opening of the parkway in 1925, 454 parcels were condemned, miles of billboards were removed and 370 buildings were moved or torn down. The 20-year joint venture with New York City led to the completion of the Bronx River Parkway and the surrounding reservation in 1925. It was praised then as an unusual example of planning, "balancing the needs and desires of the population with conservation techniques."
 
Yonkers Bans Shopping Center
 The old mill became a rubber factory, and motorists looked forward to trying out the 15 1/2-mile length of parkway, believed to be the first public road in the world built with entrances and exits rather than intersections.
In the 77 years that followed, the mill underwent other transformations, forming the visual centerpiece for the campus headquarters of two corporate owners, the Burroughs-Wellcome Pharmacutical Company and after that the Revlon Health Care Corporation.
In 1987, the 24-acre property and its 21 buildings were sold to a developer, Howard Sturman, but he was unable to attract new tenants and could not persuade Yonkers to allow a shopping center on the 8-acre site bordering the river. Last March, the Boston Safe Deposit Corporation foreclosed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Legislator Katherine S. Carsky on land by the Bronx River she wants the county to buy. It would be the county's first purchase of open space in southern Westchester in a decade. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Bucking the European Bond Trend

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The consensus strategy for bonds this year is to buy European. Stuart C. Hochberger, the global fixed-income portfolio manager at Fiduciary Trust International in New York, agrees. But last week he spotted an opportunity that has temporarily turned his attention back toward the United States.
He is making an aggressive move that depends on good timing over the next four or five months. "I take an active approach to global management," he explained. 
 The opportunity he sees is in reaction to the recent rise in market interest rates in the United States, which began after the Federal Reserve Board Chairman, Alan Greenspan, testified to Congress on Jan. 10. Since then, although there has been no increase in official interest rates, the market has pushed rates on 10-year Treasury bonds 55 basis points higher, or just over half a percentage point.
Mr. Hochberger, who has been at Fiduciary for 11 years and manages $1.5 billion, believes that this interest-rate trend will reverse itself, providing the opportunity for capital gains as bond prices rise when market interest rates fall. Rates will come down again, he said, because growth in the United States will continue to be slow and inflation will remain low.
What makes this market-rate run-up in the United States an opportunity worth taking, he said, is that there is little chance of near-term capital gains in Europe. A recent decline in market rates in Europe, where yields on 10-year French bonds fell 17 basis points, appears to be over for the time being.
Through last Wednesday, when Mr. Hochberger started rearranging his portfolio, European bonds, with their higher interest rates, had outperformed American bonds, which had capital losses, by five percentage points since the beginning of the year. In that period, the return in the United States was down about four points compared with a one-point increase in Europe.
Mr. Hochberger is betting that he can realize capital gains in the United States that will outstrip the high yields still being paid on notes and bonds in Europe. At week's end, the rate on a seven-year French note was 8.3 percent, compared with 6.9 percent on a seven-year note in the United States.
To put the strategy in place, Mr. Hochberger last week took profits in a third of his European portfolio and a third of his Japanese bonds and moved the money into intermediate United States notes in the 7-to-10-year range.
He has now realigned his portfolio so that 48 percent is invested in the United States, up from 30 percent at the beginning of the year. Europe has been cut to a 20 percent share, from 30 percent, and Japan to a 17 percent share, from 25 percent.
Neither President Bush's State of the Union address nor the testimony of Mr. Greenspan last week altered strategy, Mr. Hochberger said. Yet, Mr. Greenspan's testimony on Wednesday did help to nudge imtermediate-term interest rates up a bit. Mr. Greenspan indicated again that it did not appear that the Federal Reserve needed to push short-term rates lower.
Mr. Hochberger said it was possible that the Fed would ease interest rates further, but this is not essential to his strategy. The market itself could bring rates down in response to low growth and low inflation.
Mr. Hochberger expects the window of opportunity to close soon, probably by the second half of the year. By then, when he expects to be moving money back to Europe, the fall in interest rates in the United States will be over, he said, making Europe's much-higher yields a better choice again. In addition, if the consensus forecasts are correct, the Germans will begin to cut official interest rates by then, which will increase the prospect of capital gains throughout Europe.
Some investors may avoid Mr. Hochberger's strategy because it is easier and still profitable to stay in Europe, where yields are attractive compared with the United States. And interest rates on the Continent should come down this year, meaning capital gains and the potential for very nice returns over all for the year.
Clearly, there are risks in Mr. Hochberger's strategy. Market rates here could move higher or just not ease. Interest rates in Europe could come down earlier than Mr. Hochberger is figuring, especially if the current round of wage negotiations with German steelworkers results in agreements of 6 percent or less.
Mr. Hochberger, however, argues that an active manager must make such moves and take such risks.
"I think we will work harder," he said, "but also generate a greater total return when it comes to year-end."
 
The January Effect
 Stocks have often soared in January, and most leading foreign markets did just that last month. Leading the pack was Italy, which rose 8.2 percent. In Germany, the market finished 7 percent higher, just off its high for the month.
Britain ended the month at its peak, up 3.4 percent, according to the Financial Times index of world markets. In Canada, the market rose 2.5 percent, and French stocks jumped 6 percent. The exception was Japan, which was down 5.1 percent.
