HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Bush to Public: Forget Saving, Spend Now

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Call it George Bush's war on savings.
Behind the State of the Union rhetoric about getting the economy moving again lurked what seems to be an important part of Mr. Bush's re-election strategy: Get Americans to stop saving for retirement and instead spend the money now. 
 Consider Mr. Bush's plans for Individual Retirement Accounts. He wants to allow first-time home buyers to raid their accounts for up to $10,000 this year, without tax penalties. And he proposes a new kind of "flexible" I.R.A., which holders could tap for any reason after seven years, tax free. That will make investors hesitate to add to regular I.R.A.'s until they see if the proposal will become law.
Then there was Mr. Bush's plan to halt tax-free accumulations of money in most types of annuities, a popular retirement vehicle. As proposed, it would have been effective immediately, drying up annuity sales. But Friday night, after the insurance industry screamed, the Administration backed down and delayed the effective date until Congress acts. Still, Mr. Bush's hope to slow annuity sales seems clear.
There was also confusion over Mr. Bush's capital gains tax proposal. First the Treasury said the cuts, if enacted, would be effective yesterday. Then it published an explanation saying the effective date would be delayed. Then it said it was right the first time. So starting Monday an investor can sell stocks held for at least a year and know that the profits will be taxed at the lower rate if the cut is enacted. For nervous investors with profits, that removes one reason for holding onto stocks.
One effect of the Bush proposal would be to make the next two Decembers more likely to be bad months for the stock market. Consider a stock bought in October 1991. If sold next November, after it has been held for 12 months, the capital gains rate would be 15.4 percent. But the required holding period rises to 24 months in 1993, and a January sale would incur a tax rate of 19.6 percent. "There is a major incentive to sell early rather than late," says Robert Willens of Lehman Brothers. And in 1994, the required holding period would rise to three years.
Politically, of course, what counts is whether, or when, people begin to believe the economy is improving. One possibly false signal of recovery will come this week, when the new employment report comes out. Betting is that it will show a substantial increase in employment, due to a surge in retail jobs.
If that sounds absurd, welcome to the wonderful world of seasonally adjusted numbers. In December, stores employed 487,000 more workers than they had in October, but the Government had expected them to hire even more temporary workers, so it reported a decrease of 108,000. The workers who were not hired in December were not laid off in January, so now the Government will report higher employment, and politicians will hail a sign of economic growth.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2893 words

HEADLINE: The Gadfly C.E.O.'s Want to Swat

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

DATELINE: NAPA, Calif.

 BODY:
The corporate chief executives who gathered last month for a conference at Northwestern University's business school campus in Evanston, Ill., became nearly apoplectic when Graef S. Crystal made his presentation. And who could blame them? Mr. Crystal had some fairly harsh things to say about the way C.E.O.'s are compensated. He has been delivering his message with evangelistic fervor for several years, though frequently with all the impact of a pesky mosquito.
But suddenly he is being courted by the media and widely listened to by politicians, reformers, the public -- and even C.E.O.'s -- thanks mostly to the furor over President Bush's recent trip to Japan. Seeking trade concessions, Mr. Bush was joined by a gaggle of American corporate chieftains whose average compensation last year, in the midst of a protracted recession, was $3.4 million, six times the average for their Japanese counterparts. . 
 Mr. Crystal has seized this moment in the limelight, and many corporate heads are furious with him.
Ask Mr. Crystal, for instance, what he thinks of the compensation of Anthony J.F. O'Reilly, chairman of H.J. Heinz ($3.6 million in 1990 salary and bonus, plus $71.5 million from stock options granted in prior years), and he wails: "If they gave him one more dime, the 60th floor of the building would collapse."
What about William A. Anders, chairman of General Dynamics (about $9.4 million in 1991)? "The C.E.O. of General Dynamics must be the laziest man it he world," he clucks. "Look at all the incentive plans they have to give him to go to work in the morning."
Well, how about Linda J. Wachner, head of Warnaco ($21.4 million in 1990)? "It'd be churlish to become outraged by Wachner's excess, now that she's the only overpaid woman in America," he said.
The C.E.O.'s do not take Mr. Crystal's remarks lying down, of course. In Evanston, one of them accused Mr. Crystal of slander and later snubbed Mr. Crystal's wife, Sue, when she tried to engage him in small talk. Mr. Crystal became furious in his own right. "From now on," he declared, "no more Mr. Nice Guy."
 
A Course Called Greed
 Nice guy? To the C.E.O.'s who have been dodging Mr. Crystal's blistering barbs, the idea that he could be even more of a gadfly than he already is must have been frightening. "I'm a rebel with a cause," said Mr. Crystal, who teaches an executive compensation course at the University of California in Berkeley known informally as Greed 259A.
"There's no question that he has sensitized C.E.O.'s to an issue," said David R. Meredith, a compensation consultant who was once a competitor of Mr. Crystal's. "It's really brought the spotlight fully front and center on both the levels of pay and how pay is being done."
Mr. Crystal's message is a simple one: C.E.O.'s are paid too much in relationship to their companies' performance, and their pay seldom reflects downturns in corporate fortunes. He has become the point man for a growing movement of shareholders, employees, legislators and others who feel executive pay must be reined in if the country is to regain its economic vigor.
"People are interested in this topic because while the average person is hurting, C.E.O.'s have done very well," said Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, who held hearings on the topic Friday. "People know there's something wrong."
Just as the threat of corporate raiders kept managements on their toes in the 1980's, so there is the threat of Mr. Crystal in the downtrodden 1990's. Mr. Crystal has particular credibility, even with his critics, because he spent the better part of his career advising companies about how to use many of the razzle-dazzle, pay-boosting techniques he now lambastes. "He knows what he's talking about and companies know that, and that's a scary thing," said Abraham Nad, publisher of Directorship, a newsletter in Westport, Conn., that tracks corporate board issues.
Some companies have begun paying attention. The crusade Mr. Crystal led against the ITT Corporation last year resulted in some concrete changes in the company's incentive plan this year.
"We certainly felt the pressure and have made prudent reforms," said David H. Rhael, ITT's compensation director. The company switched from giving outright grants of stock to 10-year stock options that cannot be exercised early unless the stock price rises at least 40 percent.
Other companies are not waiting for Mr. Crystal to show up at their doors. American Telephone and Telegraph now insists that its stock price hit certain thresholds before exec utives can cash in the bulk of their last option grant. Itel and Becton Dickinson granted options that only pay off if their stocks outperform Treasury bills or the stock market.
But Mr. Crystal's views are far from being endorsed by other compensation experts, who say there are valid explanations for high compensation levels.
"The average worker is being eliminated in many ways by improving efficiency and automation. They are a dime a dozen," said Jude Rich, chairman of Sibson & Company, a consulting firm in Princeton. "What we really need is leadership and the good leaders are really scarce."
And some academics quibble with Mr. Crystal's rigor, particularly his use of a statistical tool known as regression analysis. "His methodology and accusations are leveled at those who are highly paid, but not necessarily those who are overpaid," said Kevin J. Murphy, a professor at the Harvard Business School.
Professor Murphy argues that of the $9.4 million in 1991 pay for Mr. Anders at General Dynamics, $3 million was based on a sharp spike in the company's stock price, which reflected Wall Street's conclusion that Mr. Anders and his team are doing right by shareholders.
 
Activist Shareholders
 Mr. Crystal has made his mark with a personal computer and the public records of 550 corporations. Because he is so quotable, and willing to be quoted, his ideas have found a wide audience, especially with some of the state pension funds which have begun to take an active role in companies whose shares they own.
Some of these investors are now quietly calling on big companies like International Business Machines before their shareholder meetings to urge cuts in pay for their key executives or injections of more risk into the packages so that top management's fortunes rise -- and fall -- in line with those of the shareholders.
Politicians, who see executive pay as a populist issue in an election year, are on the case.
"The issue he's highlighting is one that concerns most Americans," said Representative Martin O. Sabo, Democrat of Minnesota, another proponent of reform.
He and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential candidate, are looking at ways to use the tax code to curb excessive pay by making it more expensive for the company or for the executives. Of all the proposals being floated, corporations like this idea the least, arguing that it smacks of government interference and ultimately would only harm shareholders by reducing earnings.
"Whatever happened to the spirit of Horatio Alger?" said Ms. Wachner of Warnaco. "Isn't the hope of every red-blooded girl and boy that they can grow up and run something? I grew up and was able to take over the company I worked for 20 years ago. What's wrong with that?"
Senator Levin's three-pronged proposal is considered somewhat more acceptable because it is more mild. It would force companies to improve the quality of information made available in their annual proxy statements and would require companies to do a better job of accounting for stock options than they do now. He also favors giving shareholders the right to cast a vote on executive pay, albeit a nonbinding vote.
There are also some common-sense suggestions being bandied about, aimed at keeping government out of the picture. Aside from replacing stock grants with options, and tying option payouts to a significant rise in the stock price, some suggest that corporate directors hire their own compensation consultants instead of relying on the recommendations of the chief executive's expert.
Even the Bush Administration has gotten in on the act on the grounds that outsized paychecks not only stain America's image but also hurt the country's ability to compete abroad. Though he has yet to propose anything concrete, Vice president Dan Quayle has joined the chorus of critics, an effort, some say, to blunt the criticism of President Bush's trip to Japan with the corporate executives.
The Japanese bristled at the compensation for the American executives. The $3.4 million average is not only six times what similar Japanese executives earn, despite a higher maximum tax in Japan, it is also 188 times what the average American worker makes.
 
When Performance Falls
 The ones that often seems utterly baffled by the fuss are the C.E.O.'s. "It is a fact that musicians and ball players and actors make more money than executives," said Edmund T. Pratt Jr., chairman of Pfizer, the pharmaceuticals company, and a member of the General Motors board. "Whether that's more of a contribution than someone running G.M. is certainly subject to question."
What the executives don't mention, but Mr. Crystal does, is that the pay of an athlete or rock star can plunge almost instantly if his or her performance is found wanting. Not so with corporate executives.
"The easy part of pay for performance is high pay for high performance," said Mr. Crystal. "The hard part is no pay for no performance."
Mr. Crystal has run statistical tests on executive pay searching for evidence that high pay reflects, say, increased shareholder returns. He contends the relationship between pay and performance would not be much different if corporate compensation directors simply used random numbers as their guides in setting pay levels.
How did pay scales get so out of whack?
Mr. Crystal and other critics say that lax accounting rules deserve some blame for promoting the attitude that the granting of stock options is "free" to shareholders because a company's earnings are not reduced.
Board chairmen are also to blame for naming so many other well-paid executives, with a vested interest in high pay scales, to their compensation committees.
Companies may not see it that way, but they aggravate the problem when they deliberately set their pay levels above the "going rate," hoping to keep their top talent from being lured away by the competition.
"It's very big," said Richard Cyert, president emeritus of Carnegie-Mellon and a member of the H.J. Heinz board committee that gave the "big" compensation to Anthony O'Reilly, the Heinz chief. "But there isn't anybody to match Tony. He has some tremendous external opportunities. The arrangement we arrived at was market driven."
The biggest culprit, however, is the widespread reluctance to cut compensation in lean years, which companies circumvent by layering one incentive plan on another, virtually insuring that something will pay off under any scenario.
Mr. Crystal began developing his expertise as a compensation analyst at RCA in 1959. He spent the next 28 years alternating between consulting jobs and jobs in industry. At the pinnacle of his career, he was billing $500 an hour. He was sought out by such corporate bigwigs as Charles L. Brown at A.T.&T., William S. Paley of CBS and Joseph D. Williams of Warner-Lambert.
He had an apartment in Trump Plaza in Manhattan and a house in the San Francisco Bay area, and, at various times, vacation homes in South Hampton, L.I., and Maui, Hawaii. At one point he owned three grand pianos, reflecting his passion for music. Any time he got on a plane, there were two seats waiting, one for him and one for his companion -- a computer, which accumulated its own frequent flyer miles under the name of Ramsey Crystal.
In 1987, at the age of 53, he took early retirement and joined the business school faculty at the University of California in Berkeley. He soon began a newsletter on executive compensation and kept a few of his consulting clients.
He made the biggest splash as a commentator, writing columns for Fortune and Financial World and, last year, "In Search of Excess," a kiss-and-tell book chock full of zingers about some of the most private moments of some well-known business figures.
 
Some Painful Choices
 His notoriety, however, forced him to make some apparently painful choices. Some long-time clients, like Martin S. Davis of Paramount and Mr. Pratt of Pfizer no longer wanted to have anything to do with him. Other clients, like Michael D. Eisner of Disney, he dropped rather than allow people to attack his motives for criticizing some executives but not others.
Many C.E.O.'s clearly hope the compensation issue will go away. But Mr. Crystal believes it will not -- and some executives agree with him.
"Executive pay generally is a minute fraction of total cost," said Michael D. Rose, chairman of Promus Companies, a casino and hotel company, and a board member at three other companies. "But it's symptomatic. At companies where executive pay is out of line, you'll probably find other things where they are not cost conscious. It will be an indication of a not very demanding management and board."
Mr. Crystal and others argue that competitiveness is a state of mind, achieved one step at a time. "I don't mean to say that if we solve this, the Japanese will suddenly fall over dead," he said, "but every little bit helps. This is one area where we have to look in the mirror, and we can't blame them for it."
 
FROM THE FAST LANE, DOWN TO HIS LAST PIANO
 For Graef S. Crystal, whose friends call him Bud, the price of his convictions about executive compensation has been steep. For one thing, his annual income has plunged from $850,000 or so in his consulting days to about $120,000. Had it not been for some unwise investments in tax shelters, real estate, and wives (he calls himself a "serial monogamist" now wedded to his "fourth and final wife," Sue), he might have squirreled away more of the money he made in the good years to live on now.
Moreover, being a gadfly can be expensive. He has five telephone lines into his home, a $12,000-a-year computer data bill and an enormous brokerage bill because he must buy at least one share in every company he tracks just to get the documents he wants for his research. (Dealing with the dividend checks, many for as little as two or three cents, is a problem. Banks just don't want to be bothered. These days the Crystals send the stacks of checks to Mrs. Crystal's father "because he's 81 years old and they won't yell at him for cashing a two-cent check," she said.)
Mr. Crystal's former life style is fading fast. Fortunately, his home in Napa, a $650,000 two-story modern house nestled into a mountaintop near some vineyards, is paid for. Also, there is a red Porsche in the garage, a wine cellar and a luxurious swimming pool that he lovingly calls his "last capitalistic gasp." But other homes -- a Trump Plaza apartment in Manhattan and two vacation houses -- are gone, through sale or divorce settlements, or are on the block. And, he notes, he is "down to my last piano."
"The money's not important to me anymore," said Mr. Crystal, who is 57 years old. "I have to have a concert grand, a high-powered computer and a good wife. Other than that I can live in a small apartment."
What counts, he said, is the freedom to express his views with total candor. And to name names.
 
GOOD GUYS, BAD GUYS
 Part of Graef S. Crystal's success in attracting attention for his ideas is his skillful use of executive compensation war stories.
For example, he is quick to praise Cummins Engine for doing the right thing back in the early 1980's when a complex incentive scheme he had designed unintentionally produced big bonuses where there should have been no bonuses. The executives realized the mistake and did not demand the extra pay.
He also has kudos for one John S. Reed, the C.E.O. of Citicorp. "His base salary is up there at about $1.2 million, a bit higher than my tastes suggest it should be," said Mr. Crystal. "The nice thing about him is, he hasn't taken bonuses for a few years or long-term incentive grants, and yet he's given bonuses and incentive plans to people underneath him."
Even more impressive, he said, is Mr. Reed's recent purchase of $2.5 million worth of Citicorp stock with his own money, an investment that is so far under water it won't do well unless Mr. Reed performs mightily.
But he regrets advising Salomon Brothers in 1987 that it grant its chairman, John H. Gutfreund, a raft of stock options to make up for the lack of a bonus in a year that the company's results were dismal.
And he says he won't forget an incident nearly two decades ago involving Michael D. Dingman, then chairman of Wheelabrator-Frye, who asked Mr. Crystal to explore starting a bonus plan. Mr. Crystal recommended that Mr. Dingman cut his base pay. When Mr. Dingman reminded Mr. Crystal who was paying for his services as a consultant, Mr. Crystal says he told Mr. Dingman that the last time he looked, it was the company's signature on his checks. The two never spoke again.
Through a spokesman, Mr. Dingman said he did not recall the incident.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A Ticklish Quiz for the Japanese

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
When Alice Tepper Marlin, founder of the Council on Economic Priorities, visited Japan six years ago to describe the nonprofit organization's effort to evaluate the social and environmental responsiveness of American businesses, journalist Mitsuko Shimomura was fascinated. As a result, the latest edition of the council's "Shopping for a Better World" guidebook for "socially conscious" consumers has entries for several major Japanese companies for the first time and Japan has its own version of such corporate ratings.
"I immediately wanted to do something like that in Japan," said the 53-year-old Mrs. Shimomura, who was in New York last week to help launch the 1992 guidebook. "The corporation is the center of Japanese society and you have to change corporate culture or nothing will change." 
 She first found herself well situated to do something in May 1990, when she became editor of the Asahi Journal, a weekly magazine published by the powerful Asahi Shimbun group. She quickly linked up with Koji Nato, a professor at Tokyo International University, to distribute a survey to 100 of Japan's largest companies.
The results were published a year ago after generating controversy. Critics charged that questions about matters like safety records, charitable giving and pay gaps between junior employees and top executives were too invasive and un-Japanese.
"We ran into fears that we were out to bash corporations," said Mrs. Shimomura, the only woman editing a major Japanese publication. Those fears have diminished: For the second annual survey, she said, 93 of the top 100 corporations responded to at least some of the questions, up from 70 a year ago.
But "some Japanese still think this is too American," Mrs. Shimomura said. "There's a long way to go."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A Market for Smog

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Regulators, as a rule, do not like to promote deregulation, and James M. Lents, who heads the primary air-quality regulator for southern California, is no exception. But last week Dr. Lents announced that the regulatory agency would take a radically new course in trying to clean up the Los Angeles area's smog problem by freeing most large companies from the tight rules they have operated under in recent years.
In place of the old approach, Dr. Lents and the staff of the South Coast Air Quality Management District proposed a long-studied concept that relies primarily on free-market economic forces to goad polluters into compliance. Companies that are major polluters will simply be told how much they have to reduce their emissions each year, and then be left to make their own decisions on how best to achieve the goal. Those that exceed the required reduction on their own will generate credits that can be sold on the open market; those that cannot meet the requirement or find it uneconomical to do so will have to purchase those credits on something akin to a smog market. 
 Dr. Lents, a 48-year-old physicist who has run the air-quality district since 1986, said that after years of ever-tighter regulation it has gotten much harder for industry to achieve further emissions reduction, and that the new approach would provide greater incentives to many businesses to redouble their smog-cutting efforts. He also acknowledged pressure on the regulators to provide more flexibility to industry at a time when California is being battered by recession and many companies are leaving the state, complaining about the high costs of air-quality regulations.
The plan is the largest of its kind to date, and Dr. Lents said he expects it to be approved next month, at least in general form, by the district's board.
"There is some disagreement about the details of the program," he said. "But there is a broad conceptual agreement about a marketable permits program that goes all the way from the environmental groups to the business groups."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1679 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 26-31

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
The Bush Economic Plan: Why Save When You Can Spend? 

"I know we're in hard times," President Bush said last week in his State of the Union address, adding, "This will not stand." Trouble is, if Congress approves the measures outlined in the address, those hard times just may drag on -- and on. The plan calls for cutting the military, but there is nothing in it to retrain workers. "It also focuses on finding small nuggets of savings that are squirreled away and spending them," said Charles W. McMillion, head of MBG, an economic consulting firm. Those nuggets are the nation's individual retirement accounts. Mr. Bush proposes removing penalties if people spend that money to purchase a home, pay for school or buy medical care. Since most economists say the United States already saves too little, the President's plan is likely to make matters worse. "People should not spend the money they put away for their retirement on current needs," Mr. McMillion said.
 
Darman, the Stylist
 
"Here at home," wrote budget director Richard G. Darman in a phrase that could be from the novel "Being There," "the euphoria of summer has been replaced by another winter's gloom." That line, along with President Bush's $1.52 trillion budget, was submitted to Congress last week. The budget calls for moderate increases in a number of domestic programs, including $2.7 billion in new unemployment benefits for people who have already exhausted theirs. (President Bush vetoed a bill to extend those benefits last summer, but that was before the New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign.) This budget packs a bigger deficit wallop than ever before -- $399 billion in fiscal 1992 and $352 billion in 1993. But at least one new Federal program will generate some cash. It proposes to charge some Federal prisoners $20,000 to cover their first year of incarceration.
 
Waiting for Recovery
 
If you follow the pronouncements of the nation's top economists, for at least a year and a half now the recovery has been exactly six months away. It still is. According to the Commerce Department, orders for durable goods -- long-lasting, big-ticket items like airplanes, freezers and automobiles -- fell 4.6 percent in December. That was the largest drop since 1982. And if it weren't for the strength of military orders, "durables would be down 9 percent for December," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh. So when will the recovery set in? "It won't be visible until the summer," Mr. Hoffman said. In other words, six months from now.
 
The Adept Fed
 
Last week, when Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, appeared at his Senate confirmation hearings (he's a shoe-in for a second term) he said there was no need for Congress to lower taxes since that would only increase the size of the budget deficit. Besides, he said, the Fed is on top of things and can manipulate monetary policy to promote a recovery -- and without lowering interest rates further. Today's rates are low enough "by any historical standard," Mr. Greenspan said. That last point -- no further interest-rate cuts -- sent conniptions through Wall Street and the bond markets. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 74 points from its high, closing down 47.18 points for the day. As Mr. Greenspan said, the Fed is in control.
 
Shopping Wasteland
 
It's no secret that buyers are staying home. The reason, according to the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index, is that they're scared. And when they're scared, they don't spend. The index fell to 50.4 in January from 52.5 in December. It was a buoyant 100 in 1985. What worries people most is jobs.
 
The Expanding Wallet
 
While nervous consumers stay home clutching their security blankets, their wallets are growing fatter. Consumer income increased by a solid 1 percent in December, the Commerce Department said last week. That was the sharpest gain in the last three years. The most important element in the statistic -- wages and salaries -- increased by a strong $18 billion in December after gaining just $2.7 billion the month before.
 
Lateral Movement
 
Lacking a crystal ball, or even Joan Quigley's astrological savvy, the Government peers into the future with the aid of the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators. The index fell 0.3 percent in December. It also slipped in November. "The economy is chopping sideways," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities. "The economic mix is uneven. Some industries will continue to have a rough time, even with growth. They'll feel like we're in recession."
 
Sickly G.D.P.
 
America's gross domestic product -- which measures all goods and services produced within the country -- is also suffering. According to the Commerce Department, G.D.P. grew by an anemic three-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of last year. It grew 1.8 percent in the summer and 1.4 in the spring. "Economic activity was essential flat in the fourth quarter," said J. Antonio Villamil, the department's chief economist.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Macy Takes Its First Step Back
 
Now that R. H. Macy & Company has filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11, it will join some of the nation's classiest acts -- six other retailing chains and a quarter of the nation's airlines. Chapter 11 gives battered companies fresh starts. Last week, Macy's wrangled a fresh $600 million line of credit from Chemical Bank and Bankers Trust. But what about its pre-Chapter 11 creditors? The big store owes suppliers $275 million and bond holders about $3.2 billion. Suppliers will get about 60 cents to 75 cents on the dollar, said Ray Jurgela, corporate credit manager for Russ Togs Inc., a clothing maker. Analysts expect bondholders to get even less.
 
The Downsizing of Defense
 
The way the analysts are reading President Bush's new budget, the weapons systems most likely to be deleted from the arsenal are those designed for war with the extinct Soviet Union: The B-2 stealth bomber, built by the Northrop Corporation; the Seawolf submarine, built by General Dynamics Inc.; the Commanche helicopter, built by United Technologies Inc. The budget contains no money to help the companies retool.
 
Thoroughbred for Sale
 
No ocean liner was faster. The S.S. United States, launched in 1952, had engines that put out 240,000 horsepower. Though it was an engineering marvel, the liner "has been laid up since 1969 in Newport News," said Frank O. Braynard, the author of 27 books on liners. "It is now owned by Richard Hadley, a real estate developer from Seattle." Last week, Mr. Hadley said the S.S. United States would be put on the auction block. "It could become a museum or sail the trans-Atlantic route in summer," Mr. Braynard said. But much more likely, Mr. Braynard said, whoever buys the United States will turn it into scrap.
 
Icahn in the Bankruptcy Queue
 
Last week, Trans World Airlines filed for Chapter 11. T.W.A. became the fifth major airline to file for bankruptcy protection in the last two years. T.W.A.'s owner, Carl C. Icahn, said that the filing "will result in a stronger, more competitive airline." Analysts say the odds are against it.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Japan's Change of Heart
 
Japan's Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, must be a very brave man. Not only did he have the courage to sit next to President Bush again last week, but he also had the guts to change his mind in public. When Mr. Bush took a planeload of American auto executives to Tokyo, Mr. Miyazawa promised Japan would import 20,000 American cars by 1995, and increase imports of auto parts. But a week later, he said he had merely set a target. Last week, he changed his mind again and said Japan would indeed make good on its pledge to buy more cars and parts.
 
 
Just 20,000? Japan can afford to buy far more. At least that's what the Big Three and a lot of economists are saying. They may be right. According to the Finance Ministry, Japan's current account, the broadest measure of its trade in goods and services, more than doubled in 1991 to $72.60 billion, up from $35.76 billion in 1990. That's a world record. The rise would have been larger had Japan not transferred $8 billion to the United States to pay for the Persian Gulf war.
 
I.B.M.'s Many Ties
 
It's becoming a complex task at the International Business Machines Corporation just keeping track of all those Big Blue alliances. After joining forces last year with Apple, Intel, Thinking Machines, Motorola, Siemens and N.E.C., I.B.M. said it was taking a $100 million stake in Groupe Bull, France's troubled state-owned computer maker. That makes France's socialist Government and the buttoned-down capitalists from Armonk, N.Y., practically family. The deal gives Groupe Bull the right to use I.B.M.'s powerful RISC chip technology in its computers -- something Bull needs. It also gives I.B.M. something it needs: a ready supply of laptop computers. I.B.M. also gets a stronger foothold in Europe. "I.B.M. is buying market share and a strong distribution system," said Dedene Nelson, an analyst at Dataquest, a research firm. So far none of the alliances have ended in divorce.
 
American-Japanese Cooperation
 
American auto makers and Japanese politicians may be hurling invectives across the Pacific, but some companies find it much more profitable to do a little business. Last week a consortium including the Mitsui Corporation, the giant Japanese trading concern, the Marathon Oil Company, which is owned by the USX Corporation, and McDermott International Inc., which makes oil platforms, won the right from Russia to explore for oil and gas just off the coast of the Sakhalin Islands. The group expects to be pumping crude by 1995.
 
Last week Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand signed a free-trade pact that will cut tariffs between the countries.

LENGTH: 829 words

HEADLINE: Between Courses at 4 1/2-Hour Dinner, 575 Cigars Smoked With Great Glee

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

 BODY:
They didn't sing "Smoke Gets in Your Eyes" on Tuesday night at Windows on the World but they should have. Because it did.
At the restaurant's first Cigar Lovers' Night, no fewer than 575 stogies, none of them Cuban, were handed out to the 84 men who attended. Two of the four women present stuck to cigarettes. 
 Windows gave the $95-a-seat, four-and-a-half-hour party for the members of its private lunch club, who eat and freely light up in the Grill Room, and for the public. In the conviction that what this economy needs is a good $5 cigar, Windows encourages the members to store their assets in a floor-to-ceiling glass humidor next to the elevators.
Karl Schmid, the executive chef, hatched the idea for the smoke-in when he saw an advertisement in Food Arts magazine, a companion publication of The Wine Spectator, that said, "Wanted: Cigar Lovers." At the time, Marvin R. Shanken, the magazines' editor and publisher, was deciding about starting a cigar magazine; the first issue of Cigar Aficionado, a quarterly, is to appear in September. That explains why Gordon Mott, its managing editor, was casing the party.
At the reception, he and others watched Rafael Lopez, a fleet-fingered employee of Koler Cigars in Manhattan, demonstrate how he rolls 500 cigars a day -- fat, thin, long, short -- with leaves from Jamaica and the Dominican Republic.
David Feeney, a lawyer, took one, sent up cumulus clouds and issued a pronouncement: "The fresher the cigar, the better the smoke. Very mild. Very even. No bitterness. This is obviously very young." Thirty seconds' young, to be exact.
As the guests crowded into a party room, 107 floors up, Johannes L. M. Tromp, the director of Windows, realized that he'd forgotten something. He quickly dialed building operations and asked the duty officer to desensitize the smoke alarms. Who wanted the sprinklers to add two fingers of water to the Scotch, bourbon and -- horrors! -- red wine?
 
Clashing Viewpoints
 Health was not on the agenda. Blowing smoke in a hostile society's eye was. A livid Sidney Zion, a writer and former restaurateur, told how far anti-smokers were pushing things. "I am on the beach at Fire Island," he said. "This is last summer. A guy comes up and says, 'Put out that cigar.' I say, 'This is the beach!' He says, 'It bothers my wife.' This is a crazy smoke fascist." (He put the cigar out.)
Shirley Colucci, the manager of a security-guard company, took a more liberal view. As her husband, Michael, tapped an ash, she said, "This is the most delicious room I ever smelled."
Joseph Daley, a lawyer, scanned the defiant counterculture: thick eyeglasses, balding heads, beards and potbellies that brought to mind William Howard Taft. "These are people who live on the razor's edge," he said.
A fragment of conversation, source unknown, floated over his shoulder: "What I'd also like to know from Bill Clinton is where he stands on cigars."
It was a time to try hedonists' souls. Asriel Rackow, a real-estate developer and wine maven, clasped a California chardonnay, a 1990 Chateau St. Jean, in his left hand and a cigar in his right. In an emergency, he was asked, which would he put down first? Long hesitation. Introspection. Pained, he said, "The cigar."
As the guests filed in to eat, Peter Klink, the banquet headwaiter, asked, "Smoking or nonsmoking?" Mr. Schmid's four-course dinner was saturated with alarm-clock flavorings intended to awaken numbed palates.
Richard Gilbert, a real-estate developer, shirt unbuttoned, tie pulled down, said: "This is the first time I can smoke and eat at the same time. My wife doesn't let me. My daughter doesn't let me." Before him was a plate of honey-coriander glazed cote de boeuf with fried sage and celery root. He was asked, "Can you taste your food?" "No," he replied, "but it doesn't matter."
Bill Scheft, a comedian and writer for David Letterman's show, was the dinner speaker. Putting the fumes in perspective, he said, "The air in Los Angeles is so bad that I use my cigar as a filter."
"I can't tell you," he went on, "what a pleasure it is to walk into a restaurant and see the fire marshal bound and gagged."
Between courses, Maryanne Scully, the Grill Room's manager, and an assistant brought around progressively stronger cigars: Macanudo Claybourne Cafe, Partagas No. 1, Macanudos of the 1984 and 1988 vintages and Partagas Special Reserve. Still, there was a longing, often expressed, for the forbidden: cigars from Cuba, perhaps the ultimate smoke.
Smoking styles mirrored the man: John M. Dempsey 3d, a specialist on the New York Stock Exchange floor, angled his cigar upward, as if it were a line on a Dow Jones graph on a good day, and emitted quick, decisive puffs.
One diner ran up to Ms. Scully, waving his menu and crying: "Miss! Miss! I didn't get this cigar!" He pointed to the 1989 Bonny Doon Le Cigare Volant.
"Sir, this is a wine," she replied. "Would you like me to light it for you?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: David LaMarca, right, was one of the 88 diners at the first Cigar Lovers' Night at Windows on the World. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Camera

BYLINE: By John Durniak; John Durniak is a freelance writer, editor and consultant on photography.

 BODY:
Despite a tough economic climate -- or perhaps because of it -- stock photography, the business of selling generic photographs to clients, is doing well these days.
Among the businesses that rely on stock photos are magazine and newspaper advertising, promotional photography, billboards, catalogues and direct mail. 
 A stock photograph is a generic one kept on file, rather than one made specifically for an advertisement or catalogue.
In stock photography, a client buys the right to use the picture. For example, a company that publishes calendars might need shots of outdoor scenes, or an insurance company might want family scenes for its advertisements.
"Over the last two economic slowdowns, 1973-1974 and 1980-1981, stock photography became an alternative to more expensive assignment photography for obtaining images," said Bob Roberts, president of H. Armstrong Roberts, a 70-year-old stock photography agency in Philadelphia. And in New York, there is now "more sales activity than we've had in a long time," he said.
New York is the center of the stock picture market. Every year about $150 million is spent on stock pictures in the United States, Mr. Roberts said, and about half of the sales come from the files of some 26 New York picture agencies. (There are about 80 major agencies in the United States.)
Comstock, the biggest of the nation's top three agencies -- the others are Image Bank and F.P.G. -- is looking to one of its best years so far, said its president, Henry Scanlon. The company, whose offices are near Union Square in Manhattan, is bullish on the worldwide economy.
"Everybody in stock is now looking to the global marketplace," Mr. Scanlon said. "Comstock's European expansion is going extremely well." The company has offices in Berlin and Paris and is about to open one in London."
"We are growing a modest amount in the United States," he added. "Our economy is kicking, but we have more significant growth in Europe."
Those who might envision a stock picture agency as a place full of cardboard-mounted slides, stacks of dusty envelopes and clerks running up and down narrow rows of file cabinets would be surprised by Comstock. It is a carefully planned complex on three floors.
The middle floor holds the picture collection, the heart of the operation. A control center is surrounded by researchers and sales people in offices along the walls. Working hours are from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., so that the company can handle calls from all over the continental United States.
Every Comstock transparency and print carries a bar code that can be scanned to see where it was last used. The agency is constantly researching what styles of pictures are being used in the news media; for example, nostalgic soft-focus photos were in style a while back. Once a trend is spotted, the company updates its own files by assigning its staff photographers to produce images that fit current concepts. There are more than four million images in the company's files and thousands of new ones are added every month, many from photographers who are not on staff.
Some experts in electronic imaging call Comstock's use of computers and scanners the most sophisticated in photography. And the company continues to expand into the use of electronic picture disks, each of which can hold 441 pictures.
Most customers today, however, select pictures from catalogues, or they can ask for specific types of pictures from the files. The customer buys the right to experiment with several pictures in layouts. Once a picture is selected, the client must then negotiate for reproduction rights.
Customers are charged for the way the photograph is used. The cost for printing it in a mass-circulation magazine would be higher than for a newspaper with a small circulation.
Photographers who do not submit their unused pictures to a stock agency may be missing out on royalties, Mr. Scanlon said. Comstock prefers that interested photographers write to Jane Kinne, the Comstock Building, 30 Irving Place, New York, N.Y. 10003.

HEADLINE: Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
When the Japanese began their invasions of countries in Southeast Asia 50 years ago, they brought their own money, notes printed in Japan for use in local markets using local denominations. Today, these occupation notes turn up in collections or as souvenirs, and sometimes they are valuable. But most are worth only a few dollars, no matter how good their condition. Still, they make marvelous reminders of World War II and of Japan's dream of empire.
In 1930, Britain and the Netherlands controlled most of Southeast Asia, while the United States controlled the Philippines and France governed Vietnam. Japan wanted a larger part of the region's economy and so began developing what it called the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere, a title that may be more euphonious in Japanese than in English. Japan wanted to establish puppet governments to rule each country within an economic system dominated by Japan. While Draconian, that system at first appealed to many nationalists in the various countries, who hated European rule. 
 By the end of 1942, Japan had either conquered or had treaties with every country in Southeast Asia except Australia and New Zealand. And with the Japanese came the occupation notes. The first were printed in Japan and numbered. Later, lithographed series without the serial numbers were made in the occupied countries.
Five countries were involved, and each country's notes can be distinguished by the first of two code letters on each. Malaya was M; Burma was B; the Dutch East Indies was S (for Sumatra); the Philippines was P and the British islands of the Southwest Pacific were O (for Oceania).
The second letter in the code indicated which printing the note came from. For example, PD means the note was for use in the Philippines and was the fourth printing of that style of note.
The Japanese distributed different printings in different areas of a country as a way of keeping track of the comings and goings of the population. The notes, in essence, served somewhat as passports in these countries, where travel was usually restricted. For example, if a note distributed in Manila appeared on the island of Mindanao, the person carrying it was immediately under suspicion.
When the war began going badly for the Japanese, the value of the notes decreased, so larger denominations were printed. In the Philippines inflation increased when the Allies parachuted thousands of dollars' worth of counterfeit Japanese occupation notes to guerrilla armies.
These counterfeit notes are so good that they are indistinguishable from the originals. Such good quality was possible because the United States discovered a quantity of Japanese note-grade paper in a warehouse in this country. Also, an officer serving with Filipino guerrillas provided samples of the inks used and copies of the original printing plates. Both the United States and Australia began printing the notes and, in effect, became branch mints for Tokyo.
As the Allied armies began taking island after island in the Pacific, they captured large quantities of Japanese occupation money and began overprinting the notes with these words: The Co-Prosperity Sphere: What Is It Worth? These propaganda notes were dropped over Japanese-controlled areas to demoralize the Japanese and rally the Filipinos.
Today, these marked notes are rare and more valuable than unmarked ones. Counterfeits of marked notes began appearing almost immediately and were sold as souvenirs to American soldiers. These are easily detected, as they were stamped with a rubber stamp and the phrase appears in quotation marks. The counterfeiter apparently never saw real propaganda notes but read about them in a newspaper. Thinking the quotation marks were part of the real slogan and not just punctuation added by a newspaper editor, he simply copied them onto his rubber stamp.
When the Allies entered Manila they found tons of real uncirculated occupation notes and burned most of them. But caches of notes turned up later in bank vaults and in remote Japanese compounds, and these became the basis of a strong souvenir trade. Today, most of the Japanese occupation notes are worth only a few dollars each. But a few of the rarest series may sell for about $100.

HEADLINE: Builder Incentives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While your article on tax incentives for builders tried to be even-handed in its analysis of the appropriateness of maintaining them for the developers of commercial real estate in New York City, I fear that it left a perception that such incentives are the panacea for the city's much publicized economic malaise. Nothing could be further from the case. 
 Rarely, if ever, does a firm locate in a particular city (or suburb) because of the availability of one more building. Even if space were an overriding selection criteria, availability of office, back-office and other commercial space -- in virtually any quality, size or sublocation -- is not likely to be a constraint for New York given its enormous vacancy and sluggish absorption. The factors cited consistently by business leaders for selecting a location include the following:
* Availability of an appropriate work force.
* Convenience relative to the firm's customers and suppliers of materials and capital.
* Availability of reasonably-priced housing for employees.
* Overall cost of doing business.d
* Quality of life for its employees and especially for its executives.
The relevant marketplace is the supply and demand for attractive environments for firms and organizations, conventioneers and tourists. Buildings such as offices and hotels merely serve demand whose origin is far broader; they do not generate demand ordinarily. Once in an era a truly noteworthy building is constructed, one with some degree of gravitational pull. Such buildings tend not to be the offspring of tax-incentive programs.
The representatives of the real estate industry and builders' associations desire to promote employment via such incentives seems parochial, and embrace the same misguided notions as American car makers and consumer electronics producers in terms of blind faith in production based approaches. While foreign providers were tailoring their offerings to the style, quality levels and price-value relationships sought by American consumers, domestic providers continued generally to produce more of the same old things.
There is a message for the real estate industry in the woes of the Big Three U.S. automakers and the absence of American firms from the VCR business. Producing more of something, no matter how great the projected profitability may be, will not stimulate demand for it. Hence, artificially buoying that profitability will have no impact on demand.
 
DAVID R. SMITH
Manhattan
 
The writer is the principal of David R. Smith Company, consultants specializing in hotel acquisition, development and planning.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Congress Poised to Act But Maybe Not for Bush

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On one level, it looks very much like business as usual on Capitol Hill. Congress will almost certainly pass an election-year tax cut that it can say helps the middle class. It is almost certain to reject President Bush's call to eliminate 246 Federal programs, slash mass transit and impose some still undefined cuts in Medicare. Nor will it seriously try to enact Mr. Bush's economic proposals by the March 20 deadline he set in his State of the Union Message.
But on another level, Congress seems different this year. Both parties and Mr. Bush have already found the right accounting gimmicks to "pay for" another extension of unemployment benefits, instead of using the issue as a political club the way they did last year. 
 In both houses, the tax-writing committees plan to meet through the regular mid-February recess, working on Mr. Bush's economic package. And with a degree of coordination rarely even attempted, the House Budget and Armed Services Committees are trying to get their major legislation to the floor by mid-March, rather than May, their typical schedule.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley, who joined in the leadership harumphing about Mr. Bush's chutzpah in proclaiming deadlines for Congressional action after taking months to produce his own still-unfinished program, told a conference of House Democrats Friday, "Our first task, which has not been easy in the past, is to be both faster and clearer."
As to faster, there are really three important dates.
One is Mr. Bush's March 20, and all that anyone expects it to produce is a lot of speeches by him and Republican lawmakers about how the Democrats aren't meeting his reasonable expectations of tax legislation. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 House Republican, was trying out some lines last week, saying that he feared delay because Democrats want to keep the recession going to hurt Mr. Bush. But in fact neither of the key committee chairmen, Dan Rostenkowski of House Ways and Means and Lloyd Bentsen of Senate Finance, goes out of his way to challenge Mr. Bush, despite the urging of other Democrats. More important, each runs a committee that is not particularly inclined to rush serious business like tax legislation.
The real deadline is probably April 10, the Friday before Congress's scheduled Easter break. It will mean fewer Mondays and Fridays off, but it can be met. As long as Congress is working, Republicans' complaints about Mr. Bush's March 20 deadline will carry little weight, but it would be another thing to miss a deadline and then take a vacation.
The other important date is Feb. 18, when New Hampshire holds its primary. It will measure Patrick J. Buchanan's challenge to Mr. Bush, and may end it. Until then, it would be suicidal for the Bush Administration to talk of compromising its tax legislation; until then, the Democrats cannot know whether a Republican refusal to deal is only short-term posturing. So serious law-making, whether it involves a search for common ground or a battle over an emerging Democratic position, may begin Feb. 19. Even an all-out House battle would leave time for compromise in the Senate by spring break.
To a remarkable degree, this year's agenda is dominated by the budget. There are no major competing issues like civil rights or clean air. Of course, the President mentioned several other bills in his speech, devoting a couple of paragraphs to his crime bill and then proclaiming, "Congress should enact the bold reform proposals that are still awaiting Congressional action -- bank reform, civil justice reform, tort reform and my national energy strategy."
President Bush did not spend much time on theses proposalsin his speech, but he did not spend much of an effort to get them passed last year, either, and no one expects Congress to follow his lead on any of them.
Congress will probably pass its own, more modest, versions of energy, education and crime bills, and a family leave measure that the President is still committed to vetoing. And if the Supreme Court reverses Roe v. Wade, Congress will probably pass a measure aimed at re-establishing abortion rights, though not with veto-proof strength. The legislators will also try to do something on health care, an issue where both parties seem way ahead of Mr. Bush.
 
Spending the Savings
 Aside from taxes, the $280.9 billion military budget is central. The Administration's proposed cuts left Congress few easy targets. The issue is what to do with the Administration's $7.6 billion in savings, plus however much more Congress can find to cut. Democrats want to spend it on the domestic programs that Mr. Bush wants to freeze; Republicans would rather use it for tax cuts.
Some kind of tax/growth bill is almost certain to pass. A series of Administration proposals designed to help the housing industry are relatively cheap and almost sure to pass. Something will be done to encourage business investment, either thgough a tax credit or Mr. Bush's accelerated depreciation scheme. The existing temporary tax credits for research and development and for low-income housing are likely to be made permanent.
But the real uncertainty is over whether each side can reach its bottom line.
The Democrats want a bill they can say makes the tax code fairer. Mr. Bush and the other Republicans want a capital gains tax cut, which the Democrats usually decry but say they could live with if it was targeted to developing new businesses. Republicans say they cannot abide the tax increases for upper income Americans that the Democrats say are necessary to help the middle class, and so on.
There are strong reasons to believe that Congress will act. One impetus for action is the members' awareness of their reputation for delay and bickering, which was reflected in a poll rating last month that was as bad as any ever recorded. In the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, just 17 percent approved Congress's handling of its job, while 71 percent disapproved.
There are more motives for Congressional action than just the desire to avoid ridicule, or even the desire to serve the national interest. It is an election year for Congress, too. No one exemplified that cold reality last week better than Mr. Rostenkowski. He usually lends an air of statesmanship to his committee's work, but last week he announced its hearings by saying, "I'll be asking our witnesses a simple question -- what the plan will do to help people on the Northwest side of Chicago -- and I'll reject any plan that fails that test."
Mr. Rostenkowski has a primary on the Northwest side of Chicago on March 17.
 
 
 
THE PRESIDENT'S TAX PACKAGE
 Major propsed changes in tax laws, all of which must be approved by Congress, made by President Bush last week.
 * An effective reduction in the maximum tax on capital gains to 15.4 percent from the current 28 percent. Democratic leaders oppose any capital-gains cut not accompanied by higher tax rates on upper-income people. The Internal Revenue Service says 72 percent of capital gains are reported by people with incomes over $100,000.
 * An increase of $500 in the personal exemption for children under 18 years of age.
 * A 10 percent tax credit, up to a maximum of $5,000, for any home bought this year after Jan. 31 by a person who has not owned a home during the last three years. The credit -- subtracted directly from taxes owed -- would be divided evenly between returns filed in 1993 and 1994.
 * Restoration of a tax deduction for interest on student loans.
 * Allowing individuals with incomes up to $60,000 and couples with incomes up to $120,000 to set aside up to $2,500 a year in a new type of Individual Retirement Account. If the account were kept intact for at least seven years, the principal and interest would be tax-free. People would have the rest of this year to transfer old-type IRAs into the new variety -- after paying tax on the old accounts.
 * Encouragement of business investment by having the Government, in effect, pay 15 percent of the cost of equipment bought this year after Jan. 31. This would be done by accelerating first year depreciation.
 * An increase to $60 a month, from the current $21, in the amount of employer-provided mass-transit benefits on which a worker could avoid tax.
 * A new tax break to a person who sells a home at a loss. The portion of loss exceeding 10 percent of adjusted gross income could be deducted.
 * Repeal of the luxury tax on yachts and expensive planes. The 10 percent tax applies to that portion of the cost of a boat above $100,000 and of a plane above $250,000.
 * Allowance for real estate developers to use losses to offset taxes on other income, like wages.
 * Making permanent a 20 percent tax credit for increased business investment in research.
 * Temporarily extending special tax benefits for investors in low-income rental housing, bonds that finance moderate- and low-income homes, and wage subsidies that encourage the hiring of poor young people.
 * Tax credits and deductions for medical insurance.
 
(Sources: Associated Press; Office of Tax Analysis; Treasury Department )

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Driven to Abstraction;
With These Data, the Enumerator Always Wrings Twice

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Each year for the last 110 of them, the Bureau of the Census has published The Statistical Abstract of the United States, a compendium of statistical detail about the country, from "Abortions" and "Abrasives, stone," to "Zinc, production and value." The 1991 edition, recently published, is the Census Bureau's largest and the first to tabulate the 1990 census results among its 1,490 statistical tables in 1,000 pages. Besides reporting the big numbers, about the 1990 population (248 million) or steelworkers on the job (169,000, down from 399,000 in 1980, but producing the same tonnage), the Census Bureau culled other sources to collect small details about how Americans are living, where they are working and what they are eating (more broccoli).
The states are, of course, compared, though explanations are rare. There is no clue as to why Maryland ranks first in doctors per 100,000 people, with 325, and Idaho last, with 120. Or why Vermont is first and Utah last in percentage of undergraduates in state who are women. Nor why New York was 44th in percentage of women who work -- 53 percent, versus Utah's 61 percent. 
 The abstract also reflects the country's interest in comparing parts of the population against the whole; women and blacks are separated out in nearly 600 tables.
In between, the browser may find that Americans paid veterinarians $26 million for the care of pet birds in 1987, and that spending is up on all sports equipment except, for some reason, water skis.
Taken altogether, the Abstract is a list of answers looking for questions. It is $28 in paperback, and ordering information is available at (301) 763-4100. Among its findings, both meaningful and whimsical:
 
Health
The number of people treated at hospitals for injuries from drinking glasses declined from 121,951 in 1985 to 114,923 in 1988. Injuries from pet supplies also declined slightly. But injuries from jewelry increased, as did those from "Sound recording, reproducing equip." The figures did not say whether those injured were deafened, electrically shocked, or crushed by speakers. The leading causes of injuries are falls, bicycle accidents, knives and scissors and playground equipment.
Not surprisingly, money is often the best medicine. People with incomes under $10,000 a year spent an average of 26 days with an illness or disability, while those with incomes over $35,000 spent less than 10. Poor people suffer disproportionately from high blood pressure; the middle class from back problems.
Cigarette smoking appears to have become a great social divide. In 1970, college graduates were almost as likely to be smokers as high school dropouts were. By 1987, 34 percent of all dropouts still smoked. But only 16 percent of college graduates did.
 
 
Food
There is evidence that Americans are eating a more healthful diet. Or is there? Red meat consumption is down, from 132.4 pounds per person per year in 1970 to 111.3 pounds in 1989. Fish and shellfish consumption, meanwhile, went up from 11.8 pounds to 15.7 pounds. Whole milk dropped from 219 pounds per person to 95.
Yet consumption of fats and oils rose steadily over the same period, from 52.6 pounds a person to 60.7 pounds. The reason? Salad.
Iceberg lettuce consumption rose from 22 to 29 pounds. Onions and carrots showed similar growth. Cauliflower almost tripled. And broccoli, President Bush's taste notwithstanding, was the big winner, going from half a pound per person in 1970 to 4.5 pounds in 1989.
As for balance, there is scant difference between either the races, sexes or regions on the composition of the American diet. Almost everywhere, it averages 16.5 percent protein, 47.2 carbohydrates, and 36 percent fats. Most nutrition experts say a healthy diet should be 12 to 15 percent protein and certainly less than 30 percent fat.
 
 
Education
The distinctions between races and income levels are sharpest in education. Black children enroll in school later and leave earlier, score lower on tests, and are less likely to enter college. Between 1960 and 1989, the total number of college-bound high-school graduates of all races increased dramatically, to 6.8 million whites from 1.2 million, and to 867,000 blacks from 141,000. But the gap between the two had widened: In 1960, 24.3 percent of white high school graduates and 18.7 of blacks enrolled in college; by 1989, 39.1 percent of whites did, but only 31.5 percent of blacks.
The abstract even tracks the use of computers by parents' income. In 1989, 36.7 percent of children from homes earning less than $10,000 used computers in school. At $75,000 a year or more, 51.2 percent did.
Women earned 52 percent of the 993,000 bachelors' degrees granted in 1988, 51.5 percent of the 299,000 masters' degrees, but just 35.2 percent of the nearly 35,000 doctorates. Women took most of the Ph.D.'s in education, foreign languages, health sciences, home economics, letters and psychology. Men took most of them in computer sciences, engineering, physical sciences and, by 6 to 1, philosophy and theology.
 
 
Jobs
Blacks and women bought or started many businesses in the 1980's. The number of black-owned businesses grew from 308,000 in 1982 to 424,000 in 1987. Their total sales receipts rose from $9.7 billion to $19.7 billion.
The number owned by women increased from 2.6 million to 4.1 million, and took in 16 percent of the nation's business receipts.
Most companies owned by women were retail or service businesses -- shops, lodging or health concerns. But the number of trucking and warehousing operations owned by women grew from 16,000 to 27,000. Women also own about 21,000 of the nation's service stations, auto dealerships and repair shops -- about 10 percent of the total.
New Hampshire had the fastest increase in ownership of businesses by women from 1982 to 1987. New Jersey was second, Connecticut was fourth, New York was seventh. Wyoming was last.
Among state and local employees in 1987, 73 percent got free parking, but only two percent received child care.
The abstract says there were 62,000 "authors" in 1983 and 82,000 in 1989. The number of editors and reporters grew from 204,000 to 253,000 over that period, but public relations employment stalled. Actors and directors increased from 60,000 to 96,000, but librarians declined from 193,000 to 188,000.
 
 
Crime
The rule for avoiding crime is, avoid crowds. New York State reported 1,131 violent crimes per 100,000 population in 1989, the nation's highest, followed by Florida and California. North Dakota was safest, with 60 crimes per 100,000. Montana and Vermont were the next safest.
In 1975, there were 449 bomb threats at airports in the United States, and four bombs exploded. In 1989, there were 489 threats, but no explosions.
 
 
Leisure
The stereotypical suburban house with a lawn and a dog is going the way of the big family that filled it. The percentage of home owners who care for a lawn declined from 64 percent in 1985 to 57 percent. Only 38.2 percent of all households had a dog in 1987, versus 42.5 percent in 1983. But cats become more popular, inhabiting 28.4 percent of homes in 1983 and 30.5 percent in 1987.
The most expensive magazine subscriptions in 1989 were for chemistry and physics publications, which averaged $368 per year. The cheapest, at $28.62, were for philosophy magazines.
There were 4,038 first-year rodeo riders in 1980; in 1989, there were only 3,584.
The higher the income, the more likely someone is to own equipment for several sports. Rifles are the lone exception to the trend. While the purchase of shotguns grows steadily with income, rifle-buying tops out in families earning about $50,000, at which point 32 percent own one. Above $50,000, however, only 12.5 percent have bought a rifle.
Attendance at operas has skyrocketed since 1970, going from 4.6 million then to 21.4 million in 1989. But don't be too impressed. In 1987, American symphony orchestras grossed $306 million. And coin-operated video games, which didn't exist in 1970, grossed $1.4 billion.

HEADLINE: MODEST AIMS;
Missing From Politics: The Blueprints for the Future

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In their State of the Union Messages and budget presentations, Presidents used to stress bold ideas -- a Great Society, say, or a Star Wars missile defense system. Their challengers in New Hampshire often were politicians like Nelson A. Rockefeller and Hubert H. Humphrey with long track records and national identities. Giants sat in Congress with names like Taft and Dirksen, Rayburn and Fulbright and Mansfield, men with distinct world views, recognizable faces and respect that transcended party lines.
There were bad times, to be sure. Nuclear war was a constant threat. Recessions came and went. People were segregated by race. Students demonstrated. Cities burned. But by and large Americans were confident things would improve, probably for themselves and certainly for their children. 
 Times have changed.
President Bush's address to the country Tuesday night and the budget he sent Congress the next morning had been ballyhooed by his staff as a defining moment of his Presidency and the keynote of his re-election campaign. He had the opportunity to rally the country the way he did last year for the war in the Persian Gulf; to say that after winning the cold war, the United States was ready to face a new challenge; to say, in essence: "Watch out, Japan. Watch out, Germany. Here we come."
Indeed, he began by saying, "I mean to speak of big things." But after some strong words about nuclear disarmament that would have been unthinkable even a year ago, he reverted to form. He urged Congress to "modify the passive loss rule" and to "fund our H.O.P.E. housing proposal" -- hardly words to stir the people or give them new confidence that better days are ahead.
 
Hardly Breathtaking
 "We must revolutionize America's schools," the President said at one point. "We must do something about crime and drugs," he said at another. But his proposals are hardly breath-taking. His primary idea in education is to help poor people pay private school tuition. He would fight crime by expanding the number of Federal offenses punishable by death, limiting the appeals by inmates on death row and permitting the use in court of illegally obtained evidence if the police acted in good faith.
Among economists and others outside the Government, there is no shortage of sweeping ideas. They deal not so much with the recession, which will almost certainly pass in time, but with the critical long-term problems of overconsumption, meager economic expansion, a lack of investment in essential public and private projects and insufficient money to meet the nation's needs, matters that the President addressed hardly at all.
Mr. Bush, said Stuart M. Butler, director of domestic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation, a research institute that espouses conservative economic policies, "just doesn't have confidence that bold ideas can motivate people."
The President's opponents say he has no ideological core, but his three years in office and his speech Tuesday night belie that notion. In fact, he seems to have a bedrock political principle: He believes that the Government should take a hands-off approach to the economy and that people with capital should be free to develop it.
"People will do great things if only you set them free," he declared. And perhaps his most forceful words were about capital gains. His own economists say his proposed lower tax on investment profits would improve the economy by only about a half a percentage point a year, but Mr. Bush set the stakes high. "This time, at this hour," he said, "I cannot take no for an answer."
To people who say his strategy sounds like a way to make the rich richer, Mr. Bush made a joke: "You kind of remind me of the old definition of the Puritan who couldn't sleep at night worrying that somehow someone somewhere was out having a good time."
 
The Hot Issue
 But if Mr. Bush is not thinking daring thoughts, neither are his challengers, in New Hampshire and in Congress.
The main question on the Presidential campaign trail last week was not about solving the country's problems but about how badly Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas had been damaged by tabloid claims of a sexual affair. The two junior Senators who are running, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Tom Harkin of Iowa, have hardly broken into the public consciousness. The best-known of the Democrats at the outset, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, has been out of public office for a decade and hardly seems a serious contender now. And former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who may be running the best campaign in New Hampshire, looks grim on television and has hardly any organization or recognition outside New England.
In Congress, there are no leaders in large part because there are no followers. There are a dozen different Democratic plans for dealing with the recession and a dozen more for changing the country's health care system. Egos are such that getting one lawmaker to agree to another's idea is often an excruciating process. The only Democratic consensus is on a tax break of $400 or $500 a year for middle-class households, and that is an election-year campaign gimmick and not an economic policy. When anything bold is proposed, some lobbyist or committee chairman can usually squelch it.
Outside the political system, however, some sweeping, creative ideas for solving the country's long-term problems are emerging.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker, talks of a "vast national program of public investment" in schools, airports, roads, bridges, technological and scientific research and the like. He would pay for it with deep cuts in the military budget, a gasoline tax increase of 50 cents a gallon, a temporary 5 percent surtax on income to pay off the savings and loan debt and additional taxes on rich people to offset part of their Social Security and Medicare subsidies.
Robert Heilbroner, the liberal economic historian, advocates similar kinds of public investment, but he would overhaul the nation's tax system and impose a national sales tax like those prevalent in Europe. Taxes on income, he wrote in a recent essay in The New York Review of Books, "are considered by most taxpayers to be a kind of plunder on the part of the Government, seizures of money that is rightfully theirs." Taxes on goods and services "appear to have a voluntary character," he wrote, because "one can decide not to buy a particular item because of its tax."
Mr. Butler and his colleagues at the Heritage Foundation favor a $1,000 per person tax cut, and they emphasize private investment. They want to let poor people own their own housing projects and overhaul the entire medical care system. They would also abolish a variety of popular Federal spending programs and reduce Social Security and Medicare payments to all but the poor.
What these innovative plans have in common is that they would require some immediate sacrifice -- a gasoline tax, a national sales tax, elimination of popular spending programs -- to achieve their eventual goals. Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief professional economist, compares it to "an athlete who's out of shape -- the first few months of exercising are going to be painful, but they will pay off in the long run."
But almost all of the politicians eschew any mention of pain. The John F. Kennedy line about asking not what your country can do for you has become passe. One theme of Mr. Bush's State of the Union address was that Americans had sacrificed enough to defeat Communism and could now rest on their laurels.
"It's difficult," Mr. Reischauer said, "for a politician to begin talking about short-term pain when we're in the midst of a recession. It's like saying to the athlete he should begin exercising when he has the flu. We have to get over the flu first and then do the exercise regimen. The problem with our political system is that when times are better, the will and the realization that things must be done evaporate."
The public seems to be ahead of the politicians. Reporters who interviewed ordinary citizens last week after Mr. Bush's speech found the view widespread that the President had been too passive about addressing the nation's problems.
The New York Times/CBS News Poll published last week showed Americans by a large margin willing to pay significantly more in taxes to get a better medical care system. Large majorities also favored increased Federal spending for education and job creation. Only one person in 10 agreed with most Democrats in Congress that a $400 or $500 tax cut would help end the recession, but 6 out of 10 said increased Government spending would do so.
The poll found the public's sense of "how things are going in the United States" more pessimistic than it has ever been since The Times and CBS News began asking the question in 1979. Three out of four respondents said times were worse now than they were five years ago. Perhaps most striking, 48 percent said they thought the future for the next generation of Americans would be worse than life today, compared with only 26 percent who said things would get better.
All this is bad news for President Bush, but it is by no means critical. His approval rating is only 43 percent, the lowest of any sitting President at this stage of his Presidency in 40 years. But Richard M. Nixon's rating in January 1972 was only 49 percent. He went on to win 49 states in November.
But history shows that Presidential elections turn more on the economy than on any other issue, and Mr. Bush's record -- following his stand-pat, hands-off philosophy -- is bleak. In his first three years in office, the economy grew an average of less than 1 percent a year, the worst record of any post-war President. His economists forecast growth this year of 2.2 percent. The last two Presidential election years when the rate was that low were 1960 and 1980. Both times the incumbent party was ousted.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 4; Week in Review Desk
