HEADLINE: THE REGION;
A Plan With Something For Everyone To Swallow

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
WHAT if David N. Dinkins proposed a budget and nobody groaned?
That's more or less what happened last week when the Mayor released the latest in a long line of gloomy spending plans for New York City that prompted measured praise from many quarters, instead of the howls of outrage he has heard for so much of his term. 
 The trick was to spread a little bit of pain among practically every constituency in a way that made each feel it got a little something in return. The City Council and business groups exacted the promise of a four-year freeze in property tax rates and more cuts in the work force, while the Mayor's liberal supporters won a pledge to protect vital services for the poor.
City workers would get no raises for two years -- music to the ears of fiscal monitors and bond raters -- but would not be laid off and could end up sharing in the gain if they agreed to improve productivity -- a grace note for the unions. Everyone would get the most politically popular prize of all: more police officers. "I think it reflects a more thoughtful approach to those different groups that are out there making demands," said Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger. "He's telling them what he will do to meet some of their concerns, and what he absolutely will not do."
Not that anybody much liked Mr. Dinkins's $29.4 billion preliminary budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1. It would increase class sizes for early grades, slow down recycling, close a firehouse and cut parks maintenance to help close a projected gap between revenues and expenditures of more than $1.5 billion. It depends on some new taxes on gasoline, cars and the income of commuters that Albany might not approve and other revenues that might not materialize, making deeper cuts a real possibility.
But the Mayor's staff consulted so closely with the City Council in drafting the plan that mayoral aides joked that the Council's chief finance staff aide, Marc V. Shaw, had become deputy in the administration's budget office. Mr. Shaw scoffed at that notion, but he did produce a list of Council fiscal priorities issued last year that closely paralleled the Mayor's new plan.
"We're very pleased to say the least," said the Speaker of the newly expanded Council, Peter F. Vallone, who has jousted with the Mayor on issues large and small for months. "Now we can get to the details."
Since the Council has the sole power to approve the budget, that was good news for the Mayor. But it also raised the question of who had co-opted whom. The Mayor's promise to hold property tax rates constant ties one hand behind his back just as he gears up to run for re-election and wants to keep as much control over shaping the city's spending priorities as possible. He would face all-out war with the Council should he try to renege.
Or, as Mr. Vallone said, "God has an expression: Not in my lifetime."
Of course, the Mayor's political needs also helped drive him to make the freeze in the first place, to appeal to middle-class homeowners who feel alienated from his administration. That is also part of the reason he proposed more savings over the next four years.
But an equally compelling reason was his reluctant acknowledgment that even if the economy booms, the city would still face a shortfall of $1.6 billion between revenues and expenses in 1996 if current spending trends continued unchecked. That marked the ultimate evolution of the thinking of a Mayor who last year mostly urged New Yorkers to hang on until better times.
"New Yorkers aren't expecting good news," Mr. Dinkins said last week. "But they are expecting -- indeed, demanding -- sober and realistic solutions to our problems, and some assurance that their government is looking toward the future, with courage and optimism."
 
Crunching Numbers
 Hard work is still to come. Because of the strict laws that have governed the city since the fiscal crisis of the 70's, Mr. Dinkins's plan is required by law to show how he would keep the budget balanced over the next four years. Because he wants to borrow $700 million through a bond refinancing to help stretch out the pain, state fiscal monitors and Wall Street credit-rating agencies have pressed him harder than usual, and they are reserving judgment on the plan until they crunch its numbers.
The bond raters have pressed the city to save money by cutting its spending for construction projects financed by bonds. But other politicians and some of the Mayor's own top aides worry that canceling plans to build schools, jails and other projects could undo the hard-fought improvements in the city's infrastructure since the last fiscal crisis.
Business groups were wary that the Mayor did not provide more specifics for winning greater efficiencies from the labor force, while the unions were skeptical of his plans for squeezing them harder. "The Mayor is trying to show the Wall Street people and bond raters that he can put together a snazzy financial plan on paper, but what does it mean to us in reality?" asked Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the city's largest union. "We don't know. We need more specifics on gain-sharing."
Still, the Mayor managed to stitch together a plan inspired by disparate sources. After months of repeating the mantra of the moment, "downsizing," and imposing flat percentage cuts across the board in city agencies, he has taken to saying his goal is "rightsizing" government, and proposed the latest round of cuts after piece-by-piece reviews of each department's programs.
As he left City Hall Thursday night after a long day of explaining the plan, First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel smiled ruefully and wondered to a reporter if critics really liked it any better or were just worn out. In a city so demanding, the staying power that question implied would be no small achievement for the Mayor.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How to Be Europe's Big Power Without Awakening the Old Fears?

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
Germans, it turns out, may be having a harder time than others at figuring out what to make of their recent commandeering of the common European policy toward Yugoslavia. Even the minimal fears that their audaciousness aroused abroad have proven distressing to the Germans, and they are now engaged in a debate over whether they might have been too assertive after all.
The hand-wringing is over the leading role Germany is taking not only in Yugoslavia, but in defending its economic and political interests throughout central Europe and in lobbying for aid for the impoverished republics that were once the Soviet Union. 
 Throughout the cold war, Germans lived with the principle that if they pursued their own interests too single-mindedly, or if their policies strayed from the European consensus, they risked arousing memories of the horrors of the last war.
That principle remains on German minds; there is also concern that the United States, caught in economic recession, may be turning increasingly inward, and that this will not help Europe in the long run. That concern was in the background when Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher helped to galvanize European interest in the conference held in Washington last month on aiding Eastern Europe.
The question of German assertiveness arose most dramatically in December and January, when Germany dragged the rest of the European Community into recognizing the secession of Croatia and Slovenia from Yugoslavia -- a move that officials in Washington, at the United Nations, and in some European capitals had resisted as an obstacle to achieving peace.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl's efforts to address the criticism included a news conference last month at which he said Germany was now a nation of 80 million people in the center of Europe and would have to learn to live with such criticism the way it lives with the weather. Such remarks, however, quickly drew sharp domestic attacks. "Leaving Hitler aside," the weekly Stern said in an editorial last week, "you have to reach far back before you find a German government leader who expressed himself so provocatively and insensitively toward the outside world, on which we depend."
The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung was more circumspect, warning that continued doubts in the West about German reliability would lead the Germans themselves to doubt their partners. "Paradoxically, what everyone feared and sought to avoid would then become reality," the newspaper wrote.
 
U.S. Encouragement
 American officials, on the other hand, showed themselves more than reluctant to isolate the Germans with excessive criticism. At a meeting attended by prominent members of the opposition Social Democrats, the American Ambassador, Robert M. Kimmitt, declared last week "that we welcome and value this German assertiveness in collective actions designed to achieve common goals and objectives." He urged Bonn to take a more forceful role in areas like Central America and Africa, and he urged the Social Democrats to drop objections to a broader military role in peacekeeping efforts. American officials said the remarks were prompted by concern that a perception in Germany that "it is damned if it does, and damned if it doesn't" could produce unpredictability.
But German officials make it clear that they find the whole discussion uncomfortable. "We're standing in a show window," said Hanns Schumacher, Mr. Genscher's spokesman. He complained that Germany was being judged with the "criteria of the traditional national state," when its situation is quite different.
Officials like Mr. Genscher like to stress that Germany's policy since the days of Konrad Adenauer has been embedded in the actions of supranational organizations like the European Community, NATO and the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. This week, for example, the conference's foreign ministers meet in Prague to lay out, at German insistence, a timetable for bringing the old Soviet republics into the 35-nation organization.
Nevertheless, the forces that drive German foreign policy are becoming, as in most countries, increasingly parochial. The fear now haunting Germany is that the former Soviet republics, some having nuclear arms, could be the site of warfare over nationality issues, or of civilian nuclear accidents. Last week, Germany promised the republics a huge amount of aid to improve reactor safety, and Chancellor Kohl reiterated a frequent complaint that it made no sense for the West to provide humanitarian aid while the old Soviet republics discuss new armies in dimensions that could upset Europe's balance of forces.
Germans also fear an even greater migration to Germany than they are already undergoing, and this heightens support for xenophobic rightist parties. While formally maintaining the open-door policy, Bonn has quietly sought a temporary suspension of fresh approvals from an agency that approves migration requests for ethnic Germans in the former Soviet Union.
Domestic considerations work in other ways as well. Approval of friendship treaties with Czechoslovakia and Hungary have been held up for months out of deference to the so-called Sudeten Germans who were driven from Czechoslovakia after World War II and who have not forsaken their claims to property there. Last week, though, the Cabinet decided to sign the treaties within a month, showing that there is some resolve to override parochial interests if they impinge on broader national goals and Germany's reputation abroad.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, right, meeting last week in Bonn with the Prime Minister of Slovenia, Loyze Peterle. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Diplomacy's New Dance: U.S. and Many Partners

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
In the last two weeks Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has been swept up in a festival of multilateral diplomacy. First he convened 47 nations in Washington to help coordinate aid to the former Soviet Union; then he flew off to Moscow to bring together 36 more countries to promote regional cooperation between Arabs and Israelis in the Middle East. Those two conferences alone spawned 10 different follow-up working groups, which will collect data and no doubt plan more meetings.
But this sudden flurry of many-sided meetings raises a fundamental question: Is the United States increasingly sharing responsibilities with a host of other countries because this is a more effective way to solve problems, or because this is a more effective way to dodge problems -- by creating the appearance of working on them without the reality? The answer is: both. 
 The relative decline in American wealth and power in recent years, and the fragmentation of the bipolar world, have increasingly forced Washington to try to conduct diplomacy with other people's money and with a lot of other people's help -- but without forfeiting its leadership role. This approach made its debut with the Persian Gulf war, in which United States, British and French Armies teamed up with Arab, German and Japanese money to defeat Iraq. The approach was also evident last week when President Bush, alongside President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, took part in the first summit meeting held by the United Nations Security Council.
But multilateral diplomacy worked in the war against Iraq because there was one essential ingredient: The United States knew exactly what it wanted and how far it was ready to go, and it demonstrated a willingness from the start to make the biggest sacrifice by sending its own men and women to fight and die. It was such clear American commitment, led by the President, for clear objectives, that gave Washington the moral credibility to make demands on its allies, as well as the right to claim -- unchallenged -- the mantle of leadership. It is precisely such a clarity of purpose or depth of commitment that have been lacking in the Russian aid and Middle East peace efforts.
The Middle East conference in Moscow was conceived by the Bush Administration as a vehicle to promote the separate bilateral negotiations between Israel and its immediate Arab neighbors -- Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and the Palestinians. The idea was that if Israel could get into a dialogue with the wider ring of Arab states, like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, it would feel more accepted and more willing to trade land for peace with its immediate neighbors. The Moscow conference did get Israel's Foreign Minister and the Saudi Foreign Minister to sit across from each other for the first time ever. That breakthrough should not be dismissed; it contains the seeds of all sorts of new relationships.
But these secondary relationships will not sprout until the core issue is addressed -- the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians -- and the Moscow conference only underscored how far the parties are from that. The Palestinians refused to attend because they insisted that their delegation be allowed to include Palestinians from all corners of their community: from the West Bank and Gaza Strip, from East Jerusalem and from the refugee diaspora. This was to underscore their point that they are a diverse nation and that the solution to their problem is some form of national homeland.
 
Having It Both Ways?
 The Israelis, however, insisted that their only responsibility was to speak with Palestinians under their occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and only about autonomy under continued Israeli rule. American officials say they sympathize with the Palestinians' problem: On the one hand the Israelis won't let them be represented by their chosen leaders, the Palestine Liberation Organization, and on the other hand they won't let them be represented by non-P.L.O. Palestinians from a full cross-section of their community. As Palestinian officials pointed out, Israel cannot have it both ways; if so, their negotiators will have no legitimacy. The reason the Israelis want it both ways, Israeli analysts acknowledge, is that they are still ambivalent about what, if anything, they want to offer the Palestinians now that talks with them are finally under way.
Mr. Baker did not want to confront Israel for fear of blowing up the peace process. But unless America serves as clarifier and arbiter, he most likely won't have a peace process on his hands, but rather a peace industrial complex -- a floating crap game of meetings, seminars and negotiations that never quite comes to closure.
The same ambivalence was evident at the Washington conference on Russian aid. At one level, the meeting succeeded. It got a lot of new countries involved in the aid effort and it forced Washington, out of sheer embarrassment, to increase its own contributions -- in order to answer Europeans who said the conference was just a gimmick to let the United States appear to be leading a global aid effort that would not cost Americans a dime. Even then, the American contribution of $645 million was modest, and the Administration still has not even explained where the money will come from. Robert Hormats, a former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said the additional pledges at the conference did not add up to a "critical mass of support behind a clear-cut plan of action and bold Western commitment."
"If you think we are dealing with an historic opportunity, then you need a conference that produces historic results," he said. "This didn't."

HEADLINE: Headliners;
In the Rough

 BODY:
Minoru Isutani realized part of a dream in 1990 when he bought the Pebble Beach golf resort, one of America's most famous, for a whopping $840 million. Now all he has to do is figure out how to pay for it. Originally the Japanese businessman had planned to sell 760 private memberships for $740,000 each, a feasible price for wealthy Japanese. But with the recession, the potential value of the memberships dwindled to $150,000. That meant that Mr. Isutani would have to sell so many memberships that an untouchable tradition at Pebble Beach -- public access -- would be threatened, and the California Coastal Commission rejected the plan. Mr. Isutani has a $400 million loan payment due later this year. A spokesman said last week that Mr. Isutani has not yet come up with a new plan for financing the purchase. In a recent interview with the San Francisco Examiner, Mr. Isutani admitted that he may have been a bit impulsive. "I bought the property with 50 percent of my business mind," he said, "and 50 percent of my golf mind."

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
New Bridgeport Mayor, Same Old Quagmire

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT Bridgeport's bankruptcy bid last summer, a young lawyer named Joseph P. Ganim hung around the edge of the furor, telling anyone who would listen that his city should not go down that unknown road.
He also said something that sounded odd to outsiders more familiar with the troubles of Connecticut's largest city than with its hold on the hearts of its long-suffering residents: he wanted to be Mayor. 
 Now Mr. Ganim, 32 years old, is Mayor. And he is ending the bankruptcy case, withdrawing the city's appeal of a Federal judge's decision that Bridgeport does not qualify -- not yet, at least -- for protection in his court.
But Mr. Ganim's election, and his decision to end the bankruptcy action, do not set Bridgeport right. The city, like scores of others in the Northeast and Midwest, has been declining for decades as basic industries moved to cheaper regions and the middle class to the suburbs. The bankruptcy action, filed last June by Mayor Mary Moran, was cast as a challenge to the state and Federal governments: this city has done what it can, and now it needs extraordinary help.
The action sunk Bridgeport's bond ratings, but did wonders for its reputation. Now it was a national symbol of urban distress. But little else has changed.
 
An Uncertain Year
 Mr. Ganim still faces the same $19.5 million budget gap that prompted his predecessor to make Bridgeport the nation's first large city to pursue bankruptcy. With residents already paying the highest property taxes in the state, and getting less than ever from them, he is no more ready to raise taxes than Mrs. Moran was. Just how Bridgeport will get through the year is no clearer now than last June.
One of Mayor Ganim's first efforts was to persuade the Chase Manhattan Corporation, which had just bought two of the city's largest banks, to keep its Connecticut headquarters in Bridgeport (the banking crisis has reduced the number of banks with headquarters here to 3, from 11). Then he played a leading role in efforts to keep the failing University of Bridgeport open through its spring semester.
Now he faces a Feb. 13 deadline for giving the Bridgeport Financial Review Board, the state agency that has overseen the city's finances since 1988, his plan to cover the shortfall in this year's $320 million budget. Half of that sum appears attainable within City Hall, through measures including a plan to recover delinquent property taxes by selling tax liens to a a private collection agency. For the remainder, Mr. Ganim is counting heavily on concessions from the city's unions, whose contracts were a main target of the bankruptcy suit, and whatever aid the state can offer.
Ending the bankruptcy appeal, Mr. Ganim said, has healed the city's relations with the state, which fiercely opposed bankruptcy. "It's easier to help somebody if they're asking for help, instead of telling you you have to help them," he said.
The chairman of the review board, William Cibes, who is also Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s budget director, said at a recent board meeting, "The good faith shown by the Mayor in withdrawing the bankruptcy action has certainly created a climate of greater cooperation with the state."
But the state has not offered any direct grant to help close the budget gap, said one of Mr. Cibes's chief aides, Douglas M. Cutler. "We're basically hampered by the state's own financial problems," Mr. Cutler said.
Instead, the state may take over maintenance of some city roads and bridges, and assume responsibility for the railroad station and possibly the city jail. Those measures, Mr. Cutler said, would remove some costs from the city's budget while insuring that important facilities do not deteriorate because of finances.
The long-term strategy for Bridgeport, everyone agrees, is economic development, to replace the jobs and tax base lost as large factories closed or left.
 
Plans for the Harbor
 "Bridgeport's economic crisis cannot be resolved by the city just cutting its budget," said Paul S. Timpanelli, president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council. The council wants to attract small manufacturers to the old industrial area that extends north from the harbor. The plan also calls for tourist attractions, but he acknowledges that such development lies years in the future.
The state's long-range efforts are centered in the Greater Bridgeport Regional Economic Development Commission, headed by the state's economic development commissioner, Joseph J. McGee. The commission is trying to identify common development goals for the city and its suburbs and ways to further them.
"We want to get past stigmatizing the city of Bridgeport, because we have a regional economy that crosses town boundaries," Mr. McGee said.
Jacquelyn C. Durrell, the First Selectwoman of neighboring Fairfield, said efforts at regional cooperation had revived since Mr. Ganim's election, and pointed to a regional anti-car theft program as one result.
"As goes Bridgeport, go all of us," she said of the suburbs' developing sense of identification with the city. "Two or three years ago, there were not many people on suburban streets who had lost their jobs."
But Bridgeport's $19.5 million shortfall, and a requirement that it balance its budget, must first be tackled. And Mr. Ganim, like Mrs. Moran before him, wants to avoid both layoffs and higher property taxes.
Those goals are not unreasonable, said Kathleen Burke, executive director of the Management Advisory Committee, a partnership between the city and business council that has helped reorganize and modernize the city's administration in 1988.
In a City Hall where the planning department, in recent years, has gone from 10 employees to 1, there aren't many people left to be laid off, she said. Under the financial review board's supervision, she said, "The budget has been balanced every year until now. But at what cost?"
Cesar A. Batalla, president of the city's Puerto Rican Coalition, is encouraged by the Mayor's success in mending fences in Hartford and finding allies in Washington.
But only the Federal Government, he fears, can turn around Bridgeport. "Washington," he said, "has to say to cities, 'We need you to be what you were before.' "

HEADLINE: BUSH AND YELTSIN DECLARE FORMAL END TO COLD WAR; AGREE TO EXCHANGE VISITS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today proclaimed a new era of "friendship and partnership" as they declared a formal end to seven decades of rivalry, then agreed to exchange visits in Moscow and Washington by year's end.
Meeting in casual winter clothes under snowy skies at the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., the two leaders reviewed the prospects for further support for Mr. Yeltsin's program of reforms and for arms control proposals that could reduce the number of nuclear warheads that each nation deploys to as few as 2,500. 
 But they indicated at a news conference after their three-and-a-half-hour meeting that no agreements had been reached on either issue, and that the matters would be taken up this winter. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will visit Moscow this month to establish the basis for further arms talks, Mr. Bush said.
 
Restatement of Principles
 The centerpiece of the meeting was a declaration signed by the two men that outlined general principles for relations between the United States and Russia. The declaration was largely a restatement of cooperative policies established between Washington and Moscow before the Soviet Union collapsed and Mikhail S. Gorbachev resigned as Soviet President at the end of December. [The text of the declaration and excerpts from the news conference appear on page 8.]
But by endorsing and signing the statement today, Mr. Bush lent prestige to Mr. Yeltsin as the leader of Russia, giving him a boost of the sort Mr. Gorbachev often gained in his trips abroad.
"Russia and the United States do not regard each other as potential adversaries," the declaration says. "From now on, the relationship will be characterized by friendship and partnership founded on mutual trust and respect and a common commitment to democracy and economic freedom."
 
Many Advisers on Both Sides
 The two leaders were accompanied to Camp David by senior aides, including a roster of advisers to Mr. Yeltsin who are largely unknown to most Americans. They included the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev; Marshal Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, who commands the combined military of the Commonwealth of Independent States; Yuli M. Vorontsov, chief Russian delegate to the United Nations; Yevgeny P. Velikhov, deputy chairman of the Russian Academy of Sciences, and Vladimir P. Lukin, the Ambassador-designate to Washington.
With Mr. Bush were Mr. Baker; Defense Secretary Dick Cheney; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser; Robert S. Strauss, the American Ambassador to Russia, and Dennis Ross, the director of the policy planning office at the State Department and Mr. Baker's senior adviser on Russia.
The only new issue of substance to emerge from the session appeared to be an offer by Mr. Bush to set up a joint center in which American scientists would pursue research with some of the 2,000 or more Russian nuclear experts who are being displaced by Mr. Yeltsin's sharp military cutbacks.
Mr. Yeltsin said he enthusiastically supported the proposal, which is aimed at preventing the scientists from selling their services to terrorists or other nations seeking to develop a nuclear arsenal. Russia has already begun offering raises and other benefits to the scientists to keep them from leaving, he said.
At the news conference, the two leaders warmly praised each other's leadership.
The American President said he has "a very warm feeling in my heart about what he has done and is trying to do, and I consider him my friend." In return, he received effusive praise from his guest.
 
'Tremendously Impressed'
 "I consider I would be very lucky in life, both as a political person and just as a man, to have met George Bush," Mr. Yeltsin said. "I'm just tremendously impressed by his wisdom. I think he has incredible qualities not only as a political person but also as a person, as a really great political figure of the United States."
Later, perhaps with a measure of pride, he said: "We call each other on the telephone. We say Boris and say George. And already this says a lot."
Translating affability into substance, the two leaders said the enmity that had separated their countries over most of seven decades was ended.
As Mr. Yeltsin put it: "Today one might say that there has been written and drawn a new line, and crossed out all of the things that have been associated with the cold war.
"From now on we do not consider ourselves to be potential enemies, as it had been previously in our military doctrine. This is the historic value of this meeting. And another very important factor in our relationship, right away today, it's already been pointed out that in the future there'll be full frankness, full openness, full honesty in our relationship."
Mr. Bush said: "Russia and the United States are charting a new relationship, and it's based on trust; it's based on a commitment to economic and political freedom; it's based on a strong hope for true partnership."
Yet for Mr. Bush, the embrace sometimes remained at arm's length, especially when nuclear weapons came up.
Mr. Yeltsin discussed the possibility of cutting strategic and tactical nuclear warheads to 2,500 for each nation. That figure, which Mr. Yelstin proposed earlier this week, is roughly half the number that Mr. Bush suggested retaining in a proposal he made in his State of the Union address on Tuesday.
Mr. Bush said he had agreed only that further cuts in nuclear weapons would be taken up when Mr. Baker goes back to Moscow. "We didn't go into any agreements on categories or numbers, but we decided that we would let the experts talk about this in much more detail," Mr. Bush said. "But we saluted his very broad proposals."
He also refused to say whether the United States had reciprocated Mr. Yeltsin's decision, made public last week, to cease aiming nuclear missiles and bombers at American targets.
"We agreed all these matters will be discussed in Moscow," he said.
Similarly, Mr. Yeltsin said he and Mr. Bush had discussed developing a global space-based defense against nuclear missiles "on a mutual basis," perhaps in conjunction with other nuclear nations. But Mr. Bush said only that they had reached no decision and that their aides would take it up later.
Although President Ronald Reagan began research on a defense against incoming missiles with a pledge to share the technology with the Soviet Union, Mr. Bush has so far ruled out any transfer of missile-defense secrets.
Although he made no specific pledges, Mr. Bush was more positive in his support for Mr. Yeltsin's political and economic reforms, saying he was "totally convinced" of Russia's commitment to democracy and hoped to assist "in any way possible."
 
Money, and More . . .
 Mr. Yeltsin said that his country needed far more than money if it was to make the transition to democracy, and that the cost of failure would be great.
"I didn't come here just to stretch out my hand and ask for help," the Russian President said. "No, we're calling for cooperation, cooperation for the whole world, because if the reform in Russia goes under, that means there will be a cold war. The cold war is going to turn into a hot war. This is, again, going to be an arms race."
Back in Washington after the Camp David meeting, Mr. Yeltsin met for an hour and 10 minutes with Congressional leaders, and the lawmakers said the conversation focused on economic reform and the assistance that Russia and the other former Soviet republics need. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the House majority leader, said Mr. Yeltsin "delivered a loud, clear message that if there's going to be help, it needs to come now."
Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the minority leader, said of Mr. Yeltsin: "He may be the last hope. That's the message he gave us. This may be the last chance."
While he was in Washington, Mr. Yeltsin also presented a medal to Mstislav Rostropovich, the Russian emigre cellist and conductor, who suggested that he would perform more and more in his homeland in the years ahead and live part of the time there.
Mr. Rostropovich left the Soviet Union after being barred from performing, and became conductor of the National Symphony here, vowing not to return while his homeland remained under Communism. He did return when Communism collapsed, and was on a visit to Moscow during the unsuccessful coup against Mr. Gorbachev last summer where he joined Mr. Yeltsin's supporters in defending the Russian Parliament.
Mr. Yeltsin left Washington about 4:40 P.M. to fly to Ottawa for a meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Yeltsin and Mulroney Meet
 OTTAWA, Feb. 1 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Yeltsin made the final stop of his three-day visit to North America in the Canadian capital today for talks with Canada's Prime Minister.
On arrival from Washington, Mr. Yeltsin broke away from Mr. Mulroney and other Canadian officials to talk briefly with spectators who had gathered at the airport to greet him in the sub-zero weather. "We're not here to quarrel, we're here to do business," Mr. Yeltsin said. "We come not as enemies, but as allies."

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Why Mainstream Economists Expect a Recovery This Time

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
To meddle or not to meddle? For President Bush and many in Congress, the question of speeding the economic recovery has become a question of electoral survival. Hardly anyone who serves at the voters' pleasure, it seems, is ready to defend the patient approach. But even as the juggernaut for economic stimulus gathers strength, the economics establishment, led by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is digging in.
Mainstream economists acknowledge that they were far off the mark in predicting a recovery last year. And many say they may be wrong again in 1992. "There's an above-average risk the consensus forecast is too optimistic," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office. 
 Yet in spite of last week's discouraging news on factory orders and unemployment benefit claims, there are reasons to believe that the economy is poised for a modest recovery. Most forecasters expect December's sharp cuts in interest rates to bear fruit by midyear, yielding a 3 to 4 percent growth rate in the second half of 1992.
And if the economy does fail to show signs of coming alive by spring, they say the loss is likely to be measured in a few months' delay in growth and a few tenths of a percentage point in the unemployment rate.
 
'Tax Cut Could Be Lethal'
 By contrast, they insist that moving too far, too fast could seriously damage the economy. Their worries focus on a budget-busting tax reduction. "A tax cut would be lethal," said Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution, "or at least deleterious to long-term economic objectives."
It is no mystery why many Americans are pounding the table for tax relief, or why politicians want to deliver that relief very soon. What most analysts, including Mr. Greenspan, predicted would be a shallow downturn -- a pause after the longest economic expansion in American history -- has metastasized into a nasty recession of exceptional staying power.
Measured by the book, Mr. Reischauer notes, the recession came and went in a mere 11 months, from the summer of 1990 to the spring of 1991, while the unemployment rate peaked at a relatively benign 7 percent. But in this case, he insists, the book is misleading.
In the year preceding the downturn, economic growth averaged but 1 percent. And while the economy has been creeping back since the recession hit bottom last summer, the forward momentum has barely been measurable. "We slithered into this recession," Mr. Reischauer said, "and we've been bouncing around the trough for months."
The persistence of the recession has broadened and deepened its impact. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that 15 percent of the labor force was out of work for some portion of 1990 and that 17 percent was in 1991. Meanwhile, the gap between actual output and total productive capacity has ballooned to 4.8 percent -- roughly the average for postwar recessions -- and is still growing.
For the last three years, forecasters have been saying that happy days will be here within six months. What reason is there to believe that they will be right this time around, and what makes Mr. Greenspan so content to tread softly?
The public has every right to be skeptical. Forecasts generated by computer models rely on the highly questionable assumption that the economic world does not change in ways not captured by the underlying equations. And the fact that almost all forecasts agree that a moderate recovery is around the corner should not inspire great confidence. While each computer model sports its own bells and whistles, the key equations of all the models are remarkably similar. These relate consumer spending and business investment to such policy variables as the supply of bank credit and government outlays.
 
Explanations After the Fact
 What forecasters can do, however, is tell more or less plausible stories about the unique factors that led their models astray in 1991 and explain why the models are not likely to fail in 1992. This time, the stories center on the crisis in confidence.
Consumers' willingness to spend and businesses' willingness to invest are linked in part to the confidence people have in the economy. To the degree confidence can be predicted from variables that can be observed and measured -- say, unemployment and mortgage rates -- the computer models can take account of this psychological factor.
But John Taylor, a Stanford University researcher who until recently served on President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, acknowledged, "We just don't understand confidence problems." Roger Brinner, the chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a forecasting firm in Massachusetts, agrees. "The free fall in confidence exceeds anything that can be explained by economic variables," he wrote in December.
 
The Risk of Bad News
 The promised 1992 recovery could, of course, be bushwacked by unpredictably bad news. But there are common-sense reasons to believe that the stage is better set for growth than it was a year ago. Mr. Reischauer of the Congressional Budget Office notes that by objective measures, credit is easy to obtain. The Federal Reserve has pushed the bellwether Federal funds interest rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans -- down a full 4 percentage points since the fall of 1990, substantially more than in earlier recessions of comparable severity.
David Wyss, the research director at DRI/McGraw-Hill, notes that the economy's failure to pick up since the Federal Reserve moved to lower rates in December proves little. It takes six to nine months to feel the full effect of a change in monetary policy, he said.
When it does hit, the impact should be felt in two ways. As in previous recoveries, easier money will make it more attractive for businesses to invest and for consumers to buy. But unlike previous recoveries, much of the gains should be come through increased competitiveness in world markets.
 
Some Help for Exports
 Lower interest rates have made it less attractive to hold assets in dollar securities by pushing down the dollar's exchange rate against other leading currencies. That, in turn, is making American exports cheaper for foreigners and imports less competitive in domestic markets.
"Fully half the gain from a reduction in interest rates now comes through the trade balance," said C. Fred Bergsten, the head of the Institute for International Economics.
If all goes according to Hoyle, DRI/ McGraw-Hill expects an upturn in the spring and solid growth in the last half of 1992. The Congressional Budget Office agrees, estimating an overall growth rate of gross domestic product of 1.6 percent in 1992 and 3.6 percent in 1993.
That would certainly be good in comparison with the eight-tenths of 1 percent increase for 1991. But is it good enough? Most recessions have been followed by a burst of very rapid growth that quickly closed the gap between output and productive capacity. Not this time, though: Under the Budget Office scenario for this recession, unemployment would remain above 6 percent until well into 1995.
Why, then, not push a little harder, using fiscal stimulus to speed the recovery? Most economists agree that with enormous excess capacity in industries ranging from construction to retailing, and with labor running scared, there seems little risk of pressure on product prices or wages. "Inflation is not a problem," Mr. Wyss of DRI/McGraw-Hill said flatly.
What is a problem in the minds of economists is the budget deficit. While many would be pleased to see a quick, one-shot surge in Federal aid to local governments or a temporary cut in taxes, they do not believe Washington is capable of taking back in 1993 what it hands out in 1992. Those who speculate in bonds are equally skeptical: long-term interest rates have risen substantially in the wake of talk about tax cuts, apparently reflecting the market's fear that the deficit will rise and more borrowing will be needed to finance Washington.
In the post-Reagan years, says Mr. Aaron of the Brookings Institution, issues of macroeconomic policy have been overshadowed by the imperative for self-discipline in government. "It's political economy," he concluded, "not pure economy."

HEADLINE: U.S. STARTS RETURN OF HAITI REFUGEES AFTER JUSTICES ACT

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Hours after the Supreme Court lifted an injunction that barred the forced return of Haitian exiles, the United States today began sending refugees back to Haiti from the American Navy base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
About 150 Haitians boarded a Coast Guard cutter this afternoon for the trip to Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital, said Lieut. Comdr. Gordon Hume, spokesman for the Joint Task Force managing the Haitian exile crisis, in an interview from Guantanamo. 
 Haitians have been crowding into boats to flee a nation in political and economic turmoil since the military coup against the elected Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide on Sept. 30. At least two-thirds of those who have fled have not been permitted to apply for asylum in the United States because the Bush Administration considers them to be economic migrants, not political refugees.
 
'Ready to Go Back'
 More than 10,000 Haitians are in custody at Guantanamo, and more asylum-seekers are on cutters offshore. The task force spokesman said the first Haitians to return today were exiles who said they were "ready to go back." About 400 had returned voluntarily through the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
The repatriations, by means of the 12-to-14-hour boat trip from Cuba to Haiti, come within a week of the Bush Administration's strong condemnation of growing political violence in Haiti and the recall of the United States Ambassador, Alvin P. Adams Jr.
Mr. Adams's recall followed an attack by policemen in civilian clothes on a political meeting on Jan. 25. The meeting had been called by Rene Theodore, who was nominated to be Prime Minister in a compromise that was seen just a few weeks ago as the first step to the restoration of civilian government after difficult negotiations.
A political solution to Haiti's problems no longer seems possible at least in the short term, officials in the Administration and the Organization of American States appear to agree.
In the first comprehensive human rights report since the September coup, Amnesty International said in January that Haitians were living in "a climate of fear and repression."
"Hundreds of people have been extrajudicially executed or detained without warrant and tortured," the report said. "Many others have been brutally beaten in the streets. Freedom of the press has been severely curtailed and property is being destroyed by members of the military or the police forces."
An economic embargo imposed by the United States and other members of the O.A.S. has added to the problems of Haitians, who are the poorest people in the Western Hemisphere. The embargo was intended to cripple or at least inconvenience the military Government in the hope that it would be more amenable to negotiations.
But many Haitians say that the embargo has struck hardest at ordinary citizens, who are without public transportation because of a shortage of fuel and have lost jobs as factories close. Members of Congress have expressed concern that food, medicine and potable water shortages may soon become acute.
Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn and a member of the House subcommittee on international law, immigration and refugees, said in an interview today that he would try to get legislation to the floor of the House in the next two weeks to grant "temporary protected status" to Haitians. That would allow them to remain in the United States or in American custody at Guantanamo until the political crisis in Haiti ends.
Mr. Schumer will also seek to set aside 2,000 slots in refugee quotas for Haitians with genuine fears of persecution, which would allow them to remain in the United States indefinitely.
"People all over the world look up to the Statue of Liberty," he said. "If America is going to start shipping people back, it will be a signal that America has changed. It's no longer the beacon of freedom."
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere, said in an interview Friday that the embargo was "punishing those who are the most vulnerable."
"Those who were attempting to block deportations have the best of motivations, but the practical impact would be very dangerous," he said. "Thousands of Haitians were interpreting the court's delaying actions to take to small and dangerous boats."
Repatriation of Haitians from Guantanamo resumed after a month of delays caused by repeated injunctions against the forced return of Haitians picked up at sea.
Concerned that as many as 20,000 more Haitians were preparing to leave their country, the Bush Administration sought an emergency order from the Supreme Court to lift the ban imposed by a Federal District judge in Miami.
Without comment, the Supreme Court voted 6 to 3 late Friday night to lift the stay. Justices Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens and the court's newest member, Clarence Thomas, opposed the action.
Earlier in the day it appeared that the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, had ruled in favor of the Administration on the constitutional merits of forced repatriations, overturning a lower-court ruling. But hours later, the Atlanta court rescinded its order, saying that it had been issued prematurely in error.
While the Supreme Court's action a permitted the Government to begin the deportations, it did not decide the repatriation issue on its merits. If that issue is appealed to the Supreme Court, it would not be decided before next year.
At Guantanamo, Lieutenant Commander Hume said the order to begin assisting in the return of Haitians came this afternoon. The last forced repatriation of Haitians took place on Nov. 18 and 19, when 538 asylum-seekers were returned.
More than 15,000 Haitians have been picked up by the United States Coast Guard since Oct. 29, when a trickle of refugees began to turn into significant numbers, as it became apparent that the exiled President was unlikely to return soon. Coast Guard interdictions at sea were at their highest in January, when 6,653 Haitians were rescued.
Many Haitians are believed to have drowned in their attempts to reach Florida in very small and usually unseaworthy boats, the Coast Guard says.
About one-third of the Haitians intercepted at sea have been found by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to have a plausible case for asylum, which entitles them to land in the United States and lodge a formal asylum appeal.
The State Department had announced this week that it would introduce a program in Haiti under which would-be refugees could seek permission to go directly to the United States if they were found to have a credible fear of persecution. Being granted refugee status abroad insures resettlement legally in the United States. Asylum, a different legal category, can be obtained only after an applicant arrives on American soil without legal standing but with fears of persecution.

HEADLINE: Morrilton Journal;
Old-Time Politician Tells the Truth, Maybe

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRILTON, Ark.

 BODY:
For years, there was talk that the elections in Conway County were rigged. But there was never any hard evidence.
Then, a few weeks ago, 200 forged paper ballots from a 1968 Democratic primary were discovered in a Piggly Wiggly grocery sack in the attic of a house once owned by a deputy sheriff, who died in 1974. 
 The discovery coincided with the publication of a book, "How I Stole Elections," by Marlin Hawkins, the Conway County sheriff and the tax collector from 1950 to 1978.
Mr. Hawkins, now 78 years old, was also head of the Conway County Democratic Party for 25 years. While he admits in his book that he paid voters' poll taxes (although he does not mention that all the voters were Democrats), took care of traffic tickets for college students and witnessed ballot stuffing by others, he denies tampering with ballots to win elections.
In short, Mr. Hawkins contends that he "stole elections" by providing favors and good services to county residents.
In a recent interview at his home, Mr. Hawkins said his adversaries are linking him to the 1968 ballots to hamper sales of his book, which he published himself and sells from his home here, advertising it with a small sign on the main highway in town.
"I didn't know any more about those ballots than you did," Mr. Hawkins said in the interview. "I don't want anyone accusing me of violating the law. I stole elections by helping my neighbor."
Mr. Hawkins is in poor health after living through a plane crash and two auto accidents, suffering a broken hip in another accident and undergoing heart surgery, but his combative spirit is a strong as ever. And no one disputes the commitment he had to his constituents.
As sheriff and county tax collector Mr. Hawkins donated food and clothes to the poor, drove the sick to the doctor in the middle of the night and found jobs for the unemployed, including his wife, nephew and son, all of whom he put to work at the sheriff's office. Through his contacts with state officials and members of Congress, he made sure that the roads were paved, and he donated 20 acres for a vocational-technical school. He never lost an election.
But during his first two decades in office he was the target of six grand jury investigations and a Congressional committee inquiry into accusations of election tampering, bid rigging and converting county money to personal use. He was indicted only once, for false pretense, in connection with a state highway construction contract, and was acquitted. In 1968, Mr. Hawkins was ordered by the courts to repay $10,000 in unaccounted for bail bonds and fees that he had collected for the county.
He admits in his book that he forged 100 ballots in 1946 for a friend who was running for governor, Bryan Sims, who lost. "I regret it to this day," Mr. Hawkins wrote.
But any ballot tampering in the 1968 election was "finagling" behind his back, Mr. Hawkins said in the interview.
Eight races were on the ballot in the 1968 primary election in Conway County, including one to fill the office of prosecuting attorney for a five-county district. Robert E. Irwin lost that election by 23 votes to a candidate endorsed by Mr. Hawkins, and immediately asked the county election committee for a recount. But the committee members, most of them Mr. Hawkins's friends, rejected the request, saying they had full confidence in the election officials.
"We knew what was happening but we couldn't prove it," said Mr. Irwin, now a 61-year-old lawyer in nearby Russellville. "They'd just make enough extra votes for what they needed to win. You have to understand the climate there in Conway County. There were no elections in which the vote people cast came out that way. Of course Marlin Hawkins was involved. Absolutely. His book is a fairy tale because he never told the truth in politics or otherwise."
Jack Bland, the county clerk who oversaw the 1968 election, said of the ballot discovery, "I'm just dumbfounded about it." Mr. Bland was charged with destroying ballots in a 1975 Conway County special election held to replace a state senator convicted of tax evasion, but the charges were dropped in exchange for Mr. Bland's resignation in 1978.
After the 200 ballots were found in the attic, the Morrilton police began an inquiry, but quickly ended it, saying the six-year statute of limitations on ballot fraud had expired.
"All this does is prove that the allegations had a basis and the corruption was here," said Larry Miller, a Conway County native and reporter for The Petit Jean Country Headlight, the local newspaper. "A group of people here now are saying we're wanting out of this. We're trying to bury our past."
Yet Mr. Hawkins's book and the recovered ballots serve as a reminder of change.
Mr. Hawkins, meanwhile, said the "art of politics" rarely changes. "There will always be finagling of elections," Mr. Hawkins said.
Then he added: "Someone once told me, 'Sheriff, you need voting machines.' I told them, 'Hell, I don't need voting machines. I've got one.' "

But he denies tampering with ballots to win elections. (David Gottschalb for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Not a Gorbachev Waltz, But a Yeltsin Quickstep

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The President from Moscow went to Camp David. He talked to President Bush about arms control, economic reform and world peace. He received high-powered members of Congress at his embassy. He roared through town in his Zil limousine surrounded by security agents in fur hats. He pressed the flesh on a Washington street corner.
It was a familiar, almost predictable sequence of events. But this was Boris N. Yeltsin, not Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and if it was East-West summitry, then it was in miniature. 
 Thousands thronged downtown Washington at lunchtime to see Mr. Gorbachev, who made unannounced street-corner stops his political trademark on two visits here. Today, about 20 people huddled on a windy corner near the spot where Mr. Yeltsin's helicopter was to land, most of them caught up by the roadblock with little idea of who was arriving.
And it all took place in about six hours instead of two or three days, a speed more appropriate for two of Mr. Bush's golf rounds than for a Russian leader's visit, as Mr. Yeltsin hurtled today through his hastily arranged and even more hastily executed visit to the capital.
There was a formal paper to sign, the "Camp David Declaration," in which Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Bush promised their nations would stop being "potential adversaries" and become friends. There was a sense that this was a significant moment in the two countries' new relationship.
But there were no long receiving lines and glittery state dinners at the White House. The Marine Corps Band was not there to play "Ruffles and Flourishes." There was no red carpet or color guard. All that will be saved for the "real" Bush-Yeltsin summit meeting, to be held here in the spring.
Today's quick trip seemed intended by both sides to have Mr. Yeltsin touch all of Mr. Gorbachev's bases and let the world know that the new Russian President was taking over all of the former Soviet President's roles, including the up-close-and-personal relationship with Mr. Bush.
"Gorbachev went to Camp David, so Yeltsin's going to Camp David," a White House aide had said on Friday. "Gorbachev met with the Congressional leadership, so Yeltsin's going to do that. We want to make sure that we know he knows we're taking him seriously."
 
He's Come a Long Way

In his autobiography, "Against the Grain," Mr. Yeltsin writes of his childhood in rural Russia: "We lived in near poverty, in a small house, with one cow. We did have a horse, but when it died, we were left without an animal to pull the plow."
In 1935, the cow died too.
Fifty-seven years later, Boris Nikolayevich Yeltsin, Russia's answer to the prairie populist, spent more than three hours with George Herbert Walker Bush at Camp David, the hideaway in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland that is one of the enduring symbols of American Presidential power.
As they drove away in one of Mr. Bush's beloved golf carts, the two Presidents seemed an odd pairing. Mr. Bush, the product of Andover and Yale, drove, with Mr. Yeltsin, with his silver hair and prizefighter looks, sitting beside him and looking just a bit ill at ease in his Camp David-correct turquoise golf shirt and casual tan jacket. Mrs. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin's wife, Naina, followed along in another golf cart, this one driven by a Secret Service agent.
During the meeting, Mr. Bush gave Mr. Yeltsin a pair of hand-tooled cowboy boots from Houston that bore a silver map of Russia and American and Russian flags. The American President also produced a birthday cake with one candle for the Russian President, who turned 61 today.
But Mr. Yeltsin did not seem interested in gifts. "The best present is meeting President George Bush at Camp David," he told reporters as he arrived at the retreat.
 
First Things First

As Mr. Yeltsin returned to Washington from Camp David, he paused between his Zil limousine and the Marine Corps helicopter that had delivered him, with the seal of the American President on its door.
He looked at the car that was to whisk him away to a meeting with lawmakers.
He looked at the small crowd that had gathered nearby chanting, "Boris! Boris! Boris!"
He looked back at the car.
The Congressional leaders were waiting.
In a split second, the instincts of the populist politician took over and Mr. Yeltsin, grinning broadly, walked over to the crowd. "Spasibo," he shouted his thanks as he moved along, shaking hands and submitting to picture taking. "Spasibo. Spasibo."
"The man's got a strong handshake," said an enthused Steven Frost, a firefighter from Redding, Calif., who happened to wander by and described himself as "optimistically skeptical" at all the talk of Russian-American friendship. "He's O.K. We can talk to him."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
After Ordeal, Is Clinton Tempered Now, or Burned?

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
After attending the father-daughter party at the Little Rock Y.W.C.A. on Thursday night, Bill and Chelsea Clinton went home to the Arkansas Governor's Mansion and the 11-year-old taught her father a card game called "Spite and Malice."
"It is a game which is quite appropriate for the last few days," Mr. Clinton said dryly. 
 As the campaign's faltering golden boy, Mr. Clinton has been forced to endure shots from Republican and Democratic rivals on the fidelity issue. But for public consumption, Mr. Clinton acts more worried about his weight -- "I'm getting fat as a wood tick" -- than the fate of his campaign, even though, as he says with a grim smile, "the money merchants are still combing the back alleys."
It has been a week since he was strafed by what the aides commissioned to generate sympathy for him call "tabloid terrorism," and he watched his campaign teeter amid charges by Gennifer Flowers in the newspaper Star that he had a 12-year affair with her and helped her get an Arkansas state job, an account he denies.
The candidate, whose pouty expression, sandpapery voice and Elvis imitations have led photographers to dub him "Elvis," appears laid back, as the squadron of strategists around him buttonhole reporters to suggest that he has come through his trial by fire stronger than ever. And Mr. Clinton has begun to suggest that voters will relate to his confession of imperfection.
 
Keeping Worries at Bay
 "Have you heard that song, 'I Ain't Going to Worry No More' by Ray Charles and Ronnie Milsap?" Mr. Clinton asks reporters traveling on his small plane, singing a few bars in a voice hoarse from allergies. "That should be our campaign song. As long as there's moonlight in Virginia, there ain't nothing to worry about."
Mr. Clinton's poll taker, Stan Greenberg, put it differently, but no less hopefully. He said that as long as voters believed the candidate had not lied and that his marriage was "real," that they will not turn on him.
Hillary Clinton, in vivid appearances on television and in the latest campaign commercials, has tried to foster the image of a "genuine" marriage, Mr. Greenberg said.
"I'm not sure people aren't right when they say she is the one who ought to be running," Mr. Clinton said of his wife, in an interview here before the Democratic debate on Friday. "You know, we like each other. You can watch me watch her speak sometimes, and I've got the Nancy Reagan adoring look."
"I think she's one good argument for voting for me," he added.
Mr. Clinton launched into a stream-of-consciousness tribute: "If the choice for us, is my having gotten a divorce a couple years ago and being single and going up to New Hampshire and winnning and being free of this almost unbelievable set of behaviors to which I and my family and our friends have been subjected, but ultimately being nominated and going on to the White House, or just going home to the rest of my life with her and Chelsea, I think now everybody in America ought to be able to see why I would choose to go home.
"I think she's just been extraordinary," he said in a rare reference to the embarrassing situation his wife has faced. "One of the reasons that I guess I'm in elected office and she isn't is, she's always wanted to guard her privacy much more, and I've always kind of hated to have to discuss some of the things that we have discussed in the last few weeks. If I learned anything it's like every other challenge that I've ever seen her face, she was able to rise to it."
He said he and Chelsea watched his wife's appearance on "Prime Time Live" on Thursday night. "Kids today, if they're given the kind of emotional support they need, if they know they're important and they're good and their folks are committed to them, they can deal with reality better sometimes than we think they can," he said.
Mr. Clinton says he believes it will be ineffective for his opponents to try to turn his confession of past troubles in his marriage into a political noose.
"Most people down deep inside always want to do better, and most people down deep inside know that we're all imperfect, that even the very best lives are a daily lifelong struggle for integrity, for continuing to do better," he said, sinking back in the seat of a car taking him from airport to hotel. "Remember that great story about Oliver Wendell Holmes in his 90's, and a law clerk asked him why he was straining his eyes reading an old dog-eared copy of 'Plato's Republic'? And he said, 'I'm doing it to improve my mind.'
"I feel that way about character. It's about the continuing search for belief and conviction and action and the ability not to disappoint yourself as well as others. It's a lifelong process. And I think that people know that different folks have different difficulties to deal with, but they identify with people who seem to be on the journey."
On the road, Mr. Clinton's manner is in stark contrast to that of Gary Hart, after the charges involving Donna Rice charges erupted in his Presidential campaign.
Where Mr. Hart would cringe whenever anyone would try to take his picture with an attractive blonde, Mr. Clinton does not censor his behavior. When a pretty blonde with a black puppy came up to the candidate in Hampton, N.H., the other day, the pack of photographers exploded in a burst of picture-taking fervor.
Mr. Clinton did not rush, and took several minutes to talk to the young woman and cuddle her puppy.
 
The 'Elvis' Look
 When his former classmate at Yale Law School, Douglas Eakley, introduced Mr. Clinton at a fund-raising event in West Orange, N.J., on Wednesday night by saying that they had shared a bachelor pad on the beach in their first year at Yale, the audience giggled and ooohhhed, and Mr. Eakley chastised them, "Can't you get your mind on the issues?"
The candidate was not flustered. He offered his trademark "Elvis" look, featured heavily in his commercials, of biting his lower lip and crinkling his eyes a bit, a look meant to convey an appealing combination of decency and deviltry.
"Elvis," he explained later, "was the major cultural figure of my childhood and my neighbor in Mississippi and later in Memphis. I like the comparisons."
On the plane, when he was not reading articles about his campaign, he tried, as usual, to charm every man and woman in his path, finding just the right compliment or common ground for each.
In the middle of a photo session at a T-shirt factory in Salem, N.N., Mr. Clinton caught the eye of Patrick Bruchet, a photographer for the magazine Paris Match, and took several moments to discuss the theory of French socialism and health plans in the books of Jacques Attali, the former economic adviser to President Francois Mitterrand.
The Clinton campaign has the eerie feeling of a drama being played out in two dimensions: At stops this week in New Hampshire, New Jersey and Arkansas, the professed feeling among aides was that Mr. Clinton has triumphed in the first round against the tabloids.
The Clinton campaign was a din of spin. James Carville, the fast-talking gonzo strategist wearing jeans with holes so large his underwear was leaking out in the back, pinned reporters to their chairs with a wall of words. "In Washington, you get stories that this is a beleaguered campaign. WOW! No! No! No! People in Washington are not people. They're human beings and all, but they're not people. Washington is never right about anything. Even a broken clock is right twice a day. Look at the polls -- have you ever seen a front-runner get out of the race?"
But in Washington, Democratic Party leaders and elected officials were very nervous and fearful that there could be another slipper yet to drop.
Could one more disclosure tilt voters against the candidate? Is there a subterranean Puritanism that public opinion polls are not picking up right now?
Democrats and Republicans are divided about whether Mr. Clinton has been fatally wounded, or whether he has shrewdly inoculated himself.
 
Barbs Grow Sharper
 Mr. Clinton's Democratic opponents, seemingly frantic at not being able to get any traction from his troubles, grew sharper as the week wore on.
On Wednesday night, John Durkin, a former New Hampshire Senator, introduced Senator Tom Harkin at a labor rally in Manchester, saying, "I don't care much about Bill Clinton's infidelity in his domstic life." But Mr. Durkin said he did care about Mr. Clinton's "infidelity" to the environment, working people and the middle class.
Senator Bob Kerrey, who is divorced, raised the subject by complaining that Mr. Clinton had implied that working out a troubled marriage was morally preferable to parting. "I reject the pious notion that one is either perfect or divorced," he told The Boston Globe.
Mr. Clinton said Mr. Kerrey had misunderstood him.
"The only point I tried to make is that having said that it's okay for divorced people to be President, we shouldn't go in the other direction and say if you've ever had troubles in your marriage and you want to run for office, just forget it," he said. "But I was never negative on Bob Kerrey for getting divorced. As a matter of fact, when my mother remarried my stepfather, I was against her doing it. I think sometimes divorce is not only appropriate, it is the only sensible thing to do in life."

HEADLINE: Yeltsin, a Charmer, Ventures Into Capitalist Den

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia challenged and charmed New York's business leaders on Friday night with such a forceful sales pitch for his country that some said later they were more likely to consider ventures in Russia than before.
Guests at a dinner for Mr. Yeltsin at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said the Russian leader scribbled notes furiously throughout the meal, and was disarmingly frank about his own ignorance of the fine points of capitalism. 
 He exhorted the business leaders to act, noting that the vast Russian federation had mineral wealth and saying that it was willing to mortgage its gold, diamonds and gas deposits as backing for investment. "What's holding you back?" he demanded at one point.
Herbert M. Allison Jr., executive vice president and chief financial officer of Merrill Lynch & Company, said: "All he could have hoped to accomplish was to open people's minds to the possibility of participating productively and profitably in Russia's transformation. I think he did. I was quite impressed."
People present also noted, however, that Mr. Yeltsin had to win the backing of the governments of major industrial nations and of world financial institutions like the International Monetary Fund to induce investors to take risks in an economically devastated nation, one without a convertible currency.
The Russian's meeting with New York business leaders was his second since being elected President.
The dinner, sponsored by Gerald E. Corrigan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, brought Mr. Yeltsin together with about 50 prominent people now or recently in government, finance and business -- among them Cyrus R. Vance, a former Secretary of State; David Rockefeller, former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, and Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company.
Some of the Americans spoke of an unexpected rapport with Mr. Yeltsin.
And they noted that the Russian leader was startled when Mr. Corrigan told the guests that yesterdaywas Mr. Yeltsin's birthday. He hugged Mr. Corrigan and said that even his closest advisers had not remembered.
Mr. Yeltsin put aside his prepared text and challenged his listeners to help him rebuild. "I promised you when I saw you last year that I would destroy Communism, and I was as good as my word," one participant quoted him as saying. Then he challenged them, asking why they had not given him advice on creating a strong central bank or help in establishing a joint Russian-American bank.
He pointed out that foreigners can now own property in Russia and that there are no barriers to full foreign-owned companies. "I hate saying this," he told the business leaders, but noted that Russia can provide them with cheap labor, as wages are extremely low.
Still, some present remained skeptical. "It always helps to be a strong and dynamic personality," said Walter V. Shipley, president of the Chemical Banking Corporation, "but I also doubt if any bankers walked out last night saying, 'Gee, let's go lend money.' "
He said bankers' experiences with loans to developing countries had made them wary of the kinds of financing that Mr. Yeltsin is seeking. "Pure infrastructure development-style finance will need more government-to-government aid or finance than traditionally," he said.
