HEADLINE: Travel Is Flat This Winter, Agents Say

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
ON the outside, it looks like a glamorous business, but people on the inside know better. With few exceptions, travel agents in Westchester say that although they are working harder than ever, business this winter has been flat, for the second year in a row.
"Customers are cautious," said Jeffrey Dash, owner of Dash Travel in White Plains. "They are booking shorter trips later, and they're spending less."
Mr. Dash added: "Air fares are still a mess. In Westchester, we have a lot of people who commute to Florida, and those who can't take advantage of the few promotional Florida fares this year find themselves paying 40 to 50 percent more on Florida routes than they did last year." 
 The Florida round-trip fare in January was a minimum of $400, he said, and that "makes it very difficult for Florida hotels to keep up their occupancy rates."
Even some of the lowest promotional air fares ever to Europe haven't helped stimulate county residents to travel there or to the Winter Olympics, said Jack Lepetich, president of Oliver's Travel, another White Plains agency.
"What a disappointment!" Mr. Lepetich said. "Especially when everyone in the industry was convinced that in 1992, with the Persian Gulf war behind us, travel to Europe would be strong." He said that even Icelandair's $298 round-trip fare to Luxembourg had few takers.
"What happened was, the Winter Olympics died," Mr. Dash said. "The event wasn't promoted right, and, frankly, ground transportation arrangements were very difficult to make."
Cruises, Mr. Lepetich said, were a bright spot and were selling well this season.
"Cruises are hot," he said. "The buys are unbelievable, with all the major cruise lines offering deep discounts. Just comparing cruise prices today with the prices in the 80's, which rose steadily -- on the average of 10 percent a year -- is enough to convince anyone to go on a cruise."
 
10 New Ships Built Since 1990
 A glut of megaships is what has caused the drop in prices, he said, with 10 new cruise ships built in 1990 and 1991.
"The Caribbean is flooded with new luxury cruise ships, and each of them has about 2,000 cabins to fill," Mr. Lepetich said. "And rather than send them out half empty, cruise lines are offering such things as 2 for 1 deals or 50 percent off for the second passenger."
Allen N. Rich, director of Rich Worldwide Travel in Scarsdale, said that when it comes to pricing, cruise lines now resemble airlines.
"Every morning our fax machine brings not only the new overnight airline fares but the latest cruise line discounts," Mr. Rich said. "From a travel agent's point of view, it's a nightmare. If you booked a client in advance on a luxury cruise ship, that client naturally expects to be rebooked at the lower price.
"The same holds true for the airlines," he added. "When one weak airline offers a kamikazi fare, the others flying the same route are forced to follow suit. The time and energy travel agents now spend spinning their wheels -- that is, rebooking -- I believe has contributed to the demise of many of them."
Mr. Rich and his wife, Ina, who is president of the company, also have agencies in Somers, in Rockland County and in Manhattan. The company, Mr. Rich said, does a volume of $32 million a year.
"We have 48 people in our Scarsdale office alone," Mr. Rich said. "In Westchester, we are the largest independent travel agency, and we have been ranked as the 11th largest privately held company in the county." But nevertheless, he said, this is so far not one of the agency's better years.
"But judging from the number of inquiries we've been getting lately, we are hoping that we will get a good number of late bookings this year," Mrs. Rich said. "Deluxe travel has definitely been cut back this season. On all levels, there seems to be a reluctance to splurge."
 
Uneasiness About the Economy
 People are taking shorter vacations and looking very carefully for the best deals, she said, and added: "Travelers are wary of Europe because the dollar is so bad. The Summer Olympics are not selling as they should be."
Ski resorts in the West, however, are popular. "In the off times, especially during the lulls, there are good buys and a lot of space, and customers are responding," Mrs. Rich said.
Across the board, in every price range, customers are balking at putting down deposits for accommodations six months ahead of time, Mrs. Rich said.
"It's a reflection, I believe, of most people's uneasiness about the economy," she said. "People are worried about their jobs and their businesses. I know in our own industry there are many agencies up for sale; others have gone out of business."
According to Travel Agent, an industry magazine, 2,300 agencies nationwide closed or went bankrupt during the first nine months of 1991.
Yet there are always the exceptions. Three and a half years ago, when Judith Schumacher opened her agency, the Travel Loft, in Rye, she said: "People thought I was mad. It was a low point; travel was not great."
Yet Ms. Schumacher, who started in business with four salespeople and now has nine, said she has been able to increase the agency's volume at a rate of about 10 percent a year.
 
'You Can Make Money'
 "Yes, the paperwork involved is horrendous," she said, "and there is a lot of wasted effort. But you can make money in this business. Our agents, who are all travelers themselves, spend a lot of time with clients and are able to give them firsthand information. They have the right attitude. They're enthusiastic, and customers respond by giving us repeat business and sending us their children when they want to travel."
This winter, she said, people are taking fewer and shorter vacations. "The lower-priced Caribbean islands are popular, and ski trips are selling, especially since the snow out West is the best it has been in seven years."
As for the big spenders, there are fewer of them around.
"But there are still people with plenty of money," Ms. Schumacher said. "They may be fewer in number, but the young two-salaried yuppie couple who can afford to pay $700 a day at a top resort are still traveling. They may not stay as long as they did during the 80's, but the luxury level of their trips hasn't dropped."
 
An Increase in Calls
 At Singleworld Cruises and Tours in Rye, which caters to singles only, from ages 20 to 80, the director, Randall L. Russell, said: "Our business is O.K., not great. But recently we've had an increase in the volume of phone calls. At this point we still don't know how many of those inquiries will turn into bookings."
And beginning around the first of the year, Patrick Grimes, president of Grimes Travel in White Plains, said, he was surprised, if not astonished, to see a jump in inquiries and bookings.
"Frankly," Mr. Grimes said, "I wasn't expecting it. All you hear is that fewer people are traveling. But in January, we were well ahead of last year -- a surprising increase. What's more, another encouraging sign is that a number of our clients are booking trips for next summer. We've received a number of deposits for cruises to Alaska in August."

People are taking shorter vacations and looking very carefully for the best deals, she said; Ina and Allen Rich of Rich Worldwide Travel say clients are taking shorter vacations and looking for good deals. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Case of the Impotent Millionaire

BYLINE: By Walter Mosley; Walter Mosley is the author of the forthcoming mystery novel "White Butterfly."

 BODY:

FUGITIVE NIGHTS
By Joseph Wambaugh.
336 pp. New York:
Perigord Press/
William Morrow & Company. $22. 
 MANY books are rolled into one in "Fugitive Nights." It is a hard-boiled police novel that moves at a fast clip through the California desert. It is hilarious and chilling, told to us by Joseph Wambaugh at his most cynical (cynicism is, at least in this case, the flip side of romance).
It is also a mystery (actually two mysteries) with a murder thrown in. Not your usual kind of mystery. The culprit is known to you almost from the moment he is introduced. You know, or think you know, the crimes that have been committed from the beginning, and soon you have a good idea of a crime that is intended. What you do not know is why.
You do not know why the impotent and shy millionaire is going to a sperm bank, or why his wife, who rarely even sees her husband, cares. What does this domestic case, taken on by a former police officer named Breda Burrows, have to do with a burly, dark-skinned man who has accosted a policeman at a small border airport? How does it concern a diminutive and immature desert cop whose heroes are Oliver North and G. Gordon Liddy? And why would the alcoholic, overweight and misanthropic retired police detective Lynn Cutter get involved when it will jeopardize his pension?
The answers come at you from oblique angles. They lie in the characters that Mr. Wambaugh reveals with humor and care. Almost everyone in this book is either a cop or has been a cop. They are a lovable crew of misfits who try, hopelessly, to align themselves in American society. Nelson Hareem, the young desert policeman, just wants a beat where he can have a little shade. Breda wants to stay a size six and meet a man who is mature. Everyone is worried about AIDS; maybe from last night's encounter, or lurking in that swig of Scotch.
"Fugitive Nights" is a psychological novel that is topical in its approach. Jesse Jackson, Iraq, Sinead O'Connor, the recession and George Bush are to be found in its pages. Lynn Cutter gives a running, cynical account of what's wrong with the world. He lashes out at politics, poetry and the institution of marriage with a lewd wit. I found myself laughing out loud every few pages.
It is also a book about the desert. Mr. Wambaugh has certainly captured the beauty of the barren Southwest. Anyone who has been there will recognize the subtle and magnificent landscape.
"Fugitive Nights" has its ugly side, too. The forensic particulars turned my stomach. Breda Burrows gives more than enough detail when she remembers being a female police officer trying to make it in a man's world. The lives of cops, and ex-cops, are shown in a harsh light. They are idealists with guns, children with blood on their hands.
Mr. Wambaugh, who delights in his varied characters, gives us a fine supporting cast. It includes a nervous police captain, who spends every extra moment helping his wife run Tupperware parties, and Jack Graves, a modern-day Bartleby the Scrivener. Jack was my favorite character in this novel. He is a policeman who once mistakenly shot and killed an innocent Chicano youth. First he was hounded by the law and later by his own conscience. Jack is the best detective in the book because he has looked deep into his own life and has developed an abiding concern for others. But his concern extends to the perpetrators. He would really rather not turn anybody in.
There are problems with the novel. Mr. Wambaugh has been a little too ambitious. He has so many interesting characters that he has had to take some short cuts to flesh out their personalities. Jack Graves, for all the beauty of his character, is too predictably trapped in the story. I could not help feeling that there was a side of Lynn Cutter that was left unrevealed.
What I liked most about this book was that it was filled with little surprises. Characters are not what you expect them to be. They have qualities that come out only after you have listened to them for a while -- just like real people.
I cannot end without saying that "Fugitive Nights" is also a political, moral novel. There is continuous and powerful criticism of the United States, a land in which child murderers are paroled, a land filled with alcoholism, racism, chauvinism and rage.
"Fugitive Nights" had me wide-eyed and alert until the very end. And even then I was wondering: is there more?

HEADLINE: All About/Retailers;
Down the Scale With the Major Store Chains

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH; Isadore Barmash, formerly a reporter for The New York Times, writes on the retailing industry.

 BODY:
Last week, when R. H. Macy & Company filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy action, it was just the latest in the series of calamities to hit the nation's retailing industry. Two years of dismal sales and huge accumulations of debt, largely from the leveraged buyouts of the 1980's, have pushed some of the country's largest retailers to the brink. Since the beginning of 1990, Federated Department Stores, Allied Stores, Carter Hawley Hale, Ames and Hills have all filed for Chapter 11. More than 1,000 department-store outlets have been affected -- some closed, others with their staffs and inventories cut and all with the need to scramble.
Fortunately, the problems of the bankrupt chains are not those of the entire industry. Few retailers are as deeply in debt as Macy's and some of the largest chains have had strong sales even in the recession. Though final figures are not yet in -- retailing's fiscal year ends in March -- analysts expect 1991 to be a strong year for Wal-Mart, K-mart, the Gap, the Limited and Dillards.
 
Emphasis on Upsizing
One-Stop Concept Gets a New Spin
 The list of who is doing well illustrates one of the most important lessons for retailers in the 1990's: Low-priced apparel is the seller. As a result, according to Kurt Bernard, president of Bernard's Retail Marketing Report, many department stores will be allocating more space for low-priced and what the industry calls "bridge" lines, secondary designer lines that sell for about 40 percent less than the primary apparel lines. The popularity of these lower-priced fashions is shown by the reported $150 million a year in sales of Donna Karan's D.K.N.Y. Bridge Line, Mr. Bernard said. 
 Even with the bankruptcies -- and America's increasingly downscale tastes -- retailers plan to open about the same number of stores in fiscal 1992 as they did in 1991. But there will be a difference. "One of the biggest changes in 1992 will be the larger size of stores from Wal-Mart to the Gap," said Robert F. Buchanan, an analyst at Alex Brown & Sons, an investment firm in Baltimore.
The aim of the large-store strategy is to maximize sales, raise market share and capitalize on the concept of one-stop shopping. Some of the new properties combine discount, department and grocery stores all in one super site. Others are designed as no-frills warehouses. "More super stores and warehouse type stores are opening both in malls and at off-mall locations." said Walter F. Loeb, president of Loeb Associates, a New York retail consultant.
This year, Wal-Mart will opt for 110,000-square-foot stores instead of its standard 76,000-square-foot models. K-mart is designing 100,000-square-foot and larger stores, up from its standard 81,000-square-foot designs.
"Our big store growth was in the 1980's," said Joseph Antonini, K-mart's chairman and chief executive officer. "We slowed it in the early 1990's to catch up but now we are revving it up again with the large super K-mart combination stores and specialty stores." A 148,000-square-foot Super K-mart store, selling food as well as apparel, has been successfully tested in Medina, Ohio, he said, and the company plans to open more of these units.
Retailers see these superstores and warehouses as growth vehicles, Mr. Loeb said. The stores are intended to become shopping destinations, and, he said, "scream out 'Look I'm big, I'm important.' " They will try to carry everything for everyone.
But bigger stores could spell trouble for the malls, said Cathleen W. Mackey, a retail analyst at Dillon Read & Company, in New York. As individual stores expand in size, she said, they siphon off business from nearby malls, especially their anchor department and specialty stores. "I can buy practically all my needs except fashion at Wal-Mart," Ms. Mackey said. "All the basics of life are there. This is is leading to new and different configurations in retailing."
The trend to big is sweeping beyond just department, discount and specialty stores too. Last year, Radio Shack, the electronic subsidiary of the Tandy Corporation, opened eight Computer City superstores on the West Coast, in the Midwest and in the East. Fifty Computer City stores are planned by 1994.
 
Is Bigger Better?
Efficiency Looks Like the Key
 Will the large-store strategy work? A number of analysts have their doubts. A recent study by Smith Barney Harris Upham, the New York investment firm, indicates that larger stores may not prove to be the panacea some retailers hope for. The problem, according to the report, is that the rate at which sales per store have been increasing has slowed remarkably in the last decade. And size doesn't matter.
According to the report, sales per store in 1987 dollars grew at a rate of 3 percent a year between 1948 and 1977. But since 1977 -- for all stores -- the annual rate of sales growth slowed to just sixth-tenths of 1 percent.
So far nothing -- not even size -- has "offset the slower growth in sales volume per store during the 1980's," said Gregory Gieber, the Smith Barney analyst who authored the study.
Since sales per store have been slowing, the retailers that fare best, in Mr. Gieber's opinion, are the ones that are the most efficient. Making stores more efficient, analysts say, means using technology more effectively to automate back-room operations and to make it easier for customers to help themselves.
But increased productivity can also result from simple changes like extending the hours the store are open -- especially during the Christmas season -- to better accomodate today's busy shoppers.
 
New Wrinkles
A Scattering Of Fresh Ideas
 Aside from the big-store strategy, analysts are not expecting many new retailing concepts to emerge during the 1990's. Slack investment by venture capital firms and sluggish sales are the reason.
"The 1990's will be a period of consolidation." Mr. Loeb said. "Sponsorship of new retailing ideas has fallen to a trickle with about $2 billion of venture capital languishing in uncommitted capital, begging to be put into new ventures. Little if any of these monies will go into retailing," he said.
Even so, a few new ideas are being tested.
Home Limited Inc., located in the Garden Gate Shopping Center in Lombard, Ill., has staked out the Midwest for warehouse home furnishings stores. Its first store, which occupies 120,000 square feet, sells ready-to-assemble home furnishings and accessories at 10 percent to 40 percent below regular prices. The role model for the store is the IKEA chain in New Jersey, Long Island and California.
Books & Company Inc., a 10-year-old book retailer in Dayton, Ohio, recently opened separate stores for children's books and for business publications. The owners, Annye Camara and her husband, Joseph Neri, are excited by the potential of new niche segments among book customers. If the concept succeeds, Books & Company is expected to open more stores.
Rooms to Go Inc., a 14-store chain in Tampa, Fla., is the brainchild of Morton Seaman and his son Jeffrey. The older Mr. Seaman, who built up Seaman's Furniture into a major New York chain before it recently fell into bankruptcy, is acting as an adviser to his son. The Rooms to Go strategy is to sell a room- or apartment-full of furniture with related accessories. Items are individually priced but cost customers less, the more they buy. At this chain, an entire apartment can be furnished for $1,800.
One of the more unusual retailing combinations is the store-within-a-store. Nicole Miller, a fashion boutique, will be placed within a dozen upscale Sharper Image Stores later this year.
 
CUTTING OUT THE MIDDLEMEN

Aside from the bankruptcy of R. H. Macy & Company, the hottest issue discussed among retailers is the plan by Wal-Mart Stores Inc. to cut out middlemen.
"They just want to deal directly with Mr. Corning or Mr. G.E.," said a wholesaler last week, referring to Corning Glass Works and the General Electric Company. The reason? Cutting out brokers or merchandise representatives will save the nation's largest retailer the 2 to 3 percent commissions the wholesalers usually add to the price of goods.
The move to eliminate the middle step in the distribution ladder began at least a decade ago when the Army and Air Force exchange service threatened to circumvent the rep. Opposition to the military's plan grew so heavy that the idea was shelved.
Now, it is Wal-Mart, eager to maintain its competitive edge, particularly its "everyday low pricing policy," that is pushing the idea. Aided by a retailer-to-vendor computer system that makes much reordering automatic, it hopes to cut out the extra cost increment. And Wal-Mart's major competitors, such as Sears Roebbuck & Company and K-mart Inc., are said to feel the same.
But brokers and reps don't like the move at all. Nor do all producers. Many of the smaller producers prefer to use reps, who may handle various lines of goods, rather than set up their own sales force.
With some rep groups threatening to sue Wal-Mart for discriminating against them, the issue may soon proceed to the courts. So far there has been no action, but
for producers, brokers and reps who depend greatly on supplying a massive trade client like Wal-Mart, the matter can be vital, even one of survival.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
U.S. Trade Journals Go Abroad for New Growth

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Following in the footsteps of American general-interest magazines, publishers of American trade and specialty journals are scrambling to expand abroad. Driven by the recession at home and the perception of greater opportunities overseas, they are pursuing different strategies.
The Cahners Publishing Company, the industry leader in the United States and a unit of Reed International P.L.C. of Britain, hopes to make global publications out of about 20 of its American journals. Terrence M. McDermott, president of Cahners, expects their circulation in Europe and Asia to exceed 550,000 within five years, up from about 200,000 now. By comparison, the Cahners trade journals now have an American circulation of about four million. 
 The journals are aimed at managers and professionals in industries that are becoming global in ownership or in the technology they use or sell, said Martin Fleming, a Cahners vice president. They include such journals as Variety, Control Engineering, Pollution Engineering, Datamation, EDN, Electronic Business and Design News.
In a telephone interview from Cahners headquarters in Newton, Mass, Mr. Fleming said the company expects to spend "tens of millions of dollars over the next five years" on this international expansion.
Mr. McDermott said the journals generally covered areas in which the United States was the leader and in which there were no similar journals from foreign publishers. Cahners plans to use its relationships with large American companies with interests in Asia and Europe to gain a foothold in these markets. Some journals are being offered in different languages. But with the exception of inserts for individual markets, all will have the same editorial content.
Another publisher, the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, is creating indigenous magazines in large foreign markets for users and buyers of personal computers. These magazines are modeled after some of its seven successful American magazines.
For example, PC Professionell, which Ziff-Davis began publishing in Germany in April, is modeled after PC Magazine in the United States. Because the computer products available vary from market to market, each magazine has its own laboratory to conduct its own product-performance comparisons.
 
Circulation Projections
 "Foreign competitors do not compare products as exhaustively and as profoundly as Ziff-Davis does," said Frank Kelcz, the company's vice president for Europe, in a telephone interview from Paris.
He predicted that the circulation of the Ziff-Davis magazines in Europe would total 580,000 by the end of this year. The company's journals have a circulation of about three million in the United States.
Mr. Kelcz said the company's 1991-92 budget was about $60 million for creating these and other magazines in Germany, France and Britain. "But don't expect us to come out with an Albanian magazine," he said.
On the other hand, International Data Group Inc., a pioneer in foreign markets, just might.
Of International Data's 170 information-technology journals, 145 are in 55 countries outside the United States, including Bulgaria, the former Soviet Union, Romania and China. "We probably started 25 publications overseas in the last 18 months and only a couple in the U.S.," said Kelly P. Conlin, president of the company's marketing services division, in a telephone interview from Boston. The company's journals have a circulation of 2.56 million in the United States and three million abroad.
About 40 percent of International Data's $620 million in revenues last year came from abroad. With markets like Eastern Europe and Latin America relatively undeveloped, Mr. Conlin expects the international portion of revenues to rise to 60 percent within five years. The company first went abroad in the early 1970's.
Mr. Conlin described four of International Data's journals -- Network World, PC World, Macworld and Computer World -- as "global product lines." Versions of them account for about 90 of the 145 foreign journals. But all 90 are very separate publications. While all of International Data's foreign journals have access to each other's information, local editors at each magazine decide which articles best suit its market.
Many American trade publishers think it will be some time before the community, with its different languages and product tastes, will be ready for a pan-European trade magazine.
Mr. McDermott of Cahners contends that another American publisher -- CMP Publications Inc. of Manhasset, L.I. -- is discovering this with Electronic World News, an English-language magazine aimed at managers and engineers in the electronics industry. Introduced in 1989, it has separate editions in Europe and Asia that share some articles. Mr. McDermott believes it is struggling to attract advertising.
But CMP's president, Michael Leeds, insisted that the journal was "doing very well" and was having no more difficulty than a new journal in a competitive American market. He declined to say if it was profitable.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press;
Libel Threat Is Increasing Even for Small Publications

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
ABOUT three times each semester, student editors at The Daily Pennsylvanian, the 14,000-circulation newspaper of the University of Pennsylvania, call their libel lawyer about how to get something prickly into print without risking economic ruin in a libel suit.
For Lee Levine, the lawyer they call at Ross, Dixon & Masback in Washington, the most galling aspect of counseling such clients is their tendency to view him with suspicion if not hostility. 
 "The hardest job I've got is to convince them that I'm on their side," said Mr. Levine, who worked at The Daily Pennsylvanian as an undergraduate. His firm also offers regular pre-publication advice to Jack Anderson, the columnist, and The Diamondback, the student newspaper at the University of Maryland. And the firm is on call for consultation by any of the 2,200 publications in the Newsletter Publishers Association.
Indeed, small news organizations of all types are under increasing pressure from worried owners and anxious libel insurers to consult more frequently with lawyers like Mr. Levine to blunt -- if not avoid -- the very real threat to their existence posed by libel suits.
Bruce Sanford, a First Amendment lawyer at Baker & Hostetler in Washington, estimated that the simplest libel action could cost about $20,000 to defend before the case ever came to trial. He said a tenacious plaintiff or an unsympathetic judge could easily increase pre-trial costs to $500,000.
James T. Borelli, legal counsel for Media/Professional Insurance Inc., which claims to be the largest provider of libel insurance to the news media, said the greatest concern was not litigation costs but the risk of a huge financial judgment by a jury. Last year, a record of $58 million was set in a Texas case.
Mr. Borelli said insurers, who have great say in whether libel suits are settled or fought, were increasingly settling, though he offered no specifics and noted that "the vast majority" of cases were not settled.
"It's not like opening a checkbook for libel plaintiffs," Mr. Borelli said.
Large news organizations and book publishers have long been in the habit of consulting lawyers about potential libel problems.
For instance, C. Thomas Dienes, a law professor at the National Law Center at George Washington University, spends several hours each week reading U.S. News & World Report before it is published. When he spots problems, Mr. Dienes said, "You still try to keep the punch in it, but cut down a little bit on the risk," by, for instance, not identifying a person whose reputation could be damaged in an article.
But libel plaintiffs seem increasingly to be aiming their litigation at smaller publications.
John J. Walsh, who has built a successful law practice at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft in New York representing libel plaintiffs, said newsletters and trade publications often became the target of libel suits not because they were more economically vulnerable, but because they were perceived as tip sheets for large media organizations.
"These smaller publications are the feeders," said Mr. Walsh, who added that stopping the publication of damaging information at newsletters often means "it is not going to be picked up by a larger publication."
The trend of bringing libel suits against newsletters and other small publications has seemed to parallel the growth of so-called Slapp suits, an acronym that stands for Strategic Lawsuits Against Public Participation. Mark Goldowitz, director of the California Anti-Slapp Project, said a Slapp suit could include a libel suit filed against an environmental group by a municipality.
"It is an effort by a plaintiff to change a policy or political issue into a litigation or judicial issue," Mr. Goldowitz said.
Slapp suits are most often filed against political groups rather than news organizations, but the intention is similar to libel suits against newsletters and other publications when the intent is to nip damaging information in the bud. In such situations, pre-publication review by a lawyer would rarely avoid a suit.
Mr. Sanford said one such suit was filed by the National Life Insurance Company against his client, Phillips Publishing Inc., the publisher of the newsletter Profitable Investing.
In 1989, Profitable Investing evaluated the nation's insurance companies in an article entitled "How Safe Is Your Insurance?" The article was among the first to note that one method for evaluating an insurer's strength was its rating by Standard & Poor's. On this basis, National Life was listed among the companies the newsletter characterized as "shaky" and recommended that it be avoided.
National Life filed suit for defamation. Theodore Sherbow, the company's lawyer from Weinberg & Green in Baltimore, said the article unfairly impaired National Life's reputation, integrity and financial strength.
Phillips Publishing has lost several court motions, including one seeking dismissal on the ground that the newsletter was exercising its right to fair comment. Another motion to dismiss is before the Federal District Court in Maryland.
Mr. Sanford said that had he reviewed the newsletter before publication, he would not have changed it. "We've said this is simple," he said.
Mr. Sherbow also views the situation as obvious, but to his mind, the newsletter's guilt is what is apparent.

HEADLINE: Why Economy Isn't Like a Warm Current

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire grasps the essential science in "The Current Event" (column, Jan. 16), on El Nino, the warm Pacific Ocean current, which is being blamed for floods in Texas. El Nino is a natural rhythm of the climate system, and it is not a calamity for everyone. In Florida and Georgia, for example, it reduces the likelihood of forest fires. 
 Mr. Safire's other inferences are specious. Like other natural and necessary cyclic phenomena -- earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, droughts, floods -- El Nino is a disaster for those unlucky enough to be in the wrong place. Perhaps economic cycles are also inevitable, but those who lose their livelihoods or homes cannot share Mr. Safire's benign view of the consequences.
He implies that acknowledging the rhythms of nature -- or the economy -- dictates passive acceptance. Shouldn't a humane society act on its knowledge to ameliorate negative effects? Contrary to Mr. Safire, we have come to understand the huge forces that determine which way the wind blows well enough to predict El Nino and many of its consequences.
The latest return of the warm current was predicted a year ago. El Nino can't be stopped, but such tropical countries as India and Peru have learned to reduce the harm it causes by acting on our expanding knowledge. Surely, our advanced society can do better than Mr. Safire's mystical fatalism. This is El Nino's most powerful lesson.
 
MARK A. CANE
Doherty Senior Scientist
Lamont-Doherty Geological
Observatory, Columbia University
Palisades, N.Y., Jan. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: We Need to Increase, Not Decrease, Savings

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Open Up the I.R.A.'s" by John D. Sicher (Op-Ed, Jan. 17), arguing that Americans should be allowed to tap into their individual retirement accounts, shows the same glaring myopia demonstrated by the debt architects of the 1980's. The way out of this recession is not to consume money saved for retirement in the future; it is to invest in and build that future. 
 Mr. Sicher would have you believe that I.R.A. funds are invested in mattresses. Instead they are invested in stocks, mutual funds, certificates of deposit and many other productive investments. This pool of money finances the growth and development of America's economy. The United States savings rate is already too low, thus granting a competitive advantage to the Japanese, who have always had a very high savings rate.
The large supply of savings contributes to the low cost of capital for Japanese companies, enabling them to invest in more modern and efficient equipment. Some may remember that the I.R.A. deduction was expanded under President Carter to increase savings and decrease interest rates. In the Reagan era of spend now, pay later, the incentives were removed for most Americans.
If we are to have long-term economic recovery and a future as the leading economic power, it will be through intelligent investment in the future.
 
KENNETH S. WAGNER
New Haven, Jan. 18, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Delays Paralyze Newark's Efforts to House Poor

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In a ramshackle area of wood-frame houses in the Central Ward here, officials held a ground breaking last April that they hailed as the start of a new era for Newark's poorest residents.
But there was more to it: The 100 town houses were to be a new start for the Newark Housing Authority, which had become notorious for failing to build or maintain housing even when it had money to do both. The ceremony would begin a $110 million construction program -- as ambitious as any in public housing -- that would replace 11 deteriorated high-rise buildings with scattered two- and three-story houses. 
 Today the lot where officials gathered with shovels and promises remains empty. The developer chosen for the project never secured financing, and construction schedules are still changing. Instead of a new beginning, the groundbreaking has become a vivid reminder -- along with two town houses under construction that blew down in a windstorm -- that the authority is unable to shelter the poor. Indeed, since the authority demolished four 13-story buildings in 1987, vowing to start construction of new town houses within 90 days, it has built one house.
 
A Last Resort Deteriorates
 To some degree, the failure of Newark's public housing is the story of the failure of public housing all over the country. Where projects became the housing of last resort, buildings were allowed to deteriorate. Peter Marcuse, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University who is writing a book on public housing, calls the pattern "a clear recipe for disaster."
"Wherever public housing has become the housing for the poorest," he said, "buildings have been similarly abandoned, torched."
But while replacing the failures of the past with better, more humane housing has not been an easy task anywhere, it has been especially tortuous in Newark. The Housing Authority's management has been hapless -- inept and riddled with unbridled patronage, some argue -- and its housing is far more unwieldy than most.
To many here, the situation is the shame of Newark. New market-rate housing and $6 billion worth of construction seem to have begun a revival in Newark's downtown, a state arts center is planned and there is even talk of building a convention center. But decent low-income housing is a crucial need in this city where the median income is $12,000, unemployment exceeds 12 percent and one-third of its 275,000 residents receive welfare.
In the Central Ward, filled with rundown houses, boarded-up buildings and homeless men warming themselves around trash-can fires, the need is obvious. The 10 buildings of the Hayes Homes, a Housing Authority complex, loom above bald dirt, shriveled trees and broken playground equipment. Shards of glass litter the central courtyard. Five of the buildings are vacant except for drug-addicted squatters.
 
'Reservations For the Poor'
 There is a consensus that both Newark's public housing and the authority are in desperate condition. Mayor Sharpe James, the city's most indefatigable booster, calls the public housing high-rises "shameful reservations for the poor."
No one disputes him, though many argue that even wretched public housing is better than nothing, especially when there are an estimated 5,000 to 10,000 homeless people, not including those who live doubled up or in substandard conditions. Hundreds of families stay in expensive welfare hotels, and community leaders say their numbers are growing.
Meanwhile, 22 housing authority high-rises stand empty and several others are only half full. Walls in empty apartments have been punched so full of holes that it is often hard to tell where the doorway was. Pipes have been pulled out, light fixtures and wiring removed and floor tiles ripped up, and the staircases are full of garbage and reek of urine. Dried blood is a common sight.
Residents keep their occupied apartments as tidy as anyone's. But 11 vacated buildings, including all 8 of those in Columbus Homes, have been declared too ravaged to fix and are destined for the wrecking ball. But that could be years away. As part of a 1989 settlement with a coalition of tenant and community groups that blocked plans to level 39 of the authority's 46 high-rises, the authority must begin to build replacements before it tears down any more units.
The alliance of community groups, the Newark Coalition for Low-Income Housing, charges that mismanagement and incompetence are behind the construction delays. Last month, the coalition asked the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which oversees public housing, to appoint a receiver to take over the construction program.
"It's the same story over and over," said J. Harris David, a lawyer for the coalition. Small projects have taken an average of 10 years to complete, Mr. David said, adding: "H.U.D. bears a special responsibility here. There is more than $110 million and 1,777 units of housing at stake."
Victor DeLuca, the coalition's chairman, says the demolition plan proves that the housing authority, with H.U.D.'s acquiescence, has abandoned its mission. "No one wants to build housing for the poor," he said. "Some of the land is becoming too valuable for poor people."
 
Red Tape And Recession
 Authority officials call such charges ridiculous and counter that construction has stalled because of the recession, which has made banks uneasy about backing projects that cost, on average, more than $10 million. And they cite bureaucracy that has hindered obtaining titles to land or site approvals.
"Each step along the way, not only do we get some problem, perhaps," said Robert Graham, the authority's interim assistant director, "we also get the entity using all the available time to give us their approval. And oftentimes it's not done concurrently, but consecutively." Burton Bloomberg, acting manager of the H.U.D. office in Newark, said, "It's a complex situation with a lot involved."
But stalled construction is not the authority's only problem. Its leadership is in disarray. In August, its board dismissed its executive director, Dr. Daniel W. Blue Jr., who has since joined the Chicago Housing Authority. In December, four top officials resigned. Mayor James, who opposes a Federal receiver for the authority, contends that new management is needed.
"For too long, the Newark Housing Authority has been a political pork barrel for patronage-giving contracts," he said in an interview at City Hall recently. "I'm looking forward to an independent board with a new N.H.A. director who puts shovels in the ground and builds housing." The Mayor won a court fight in 1990 for the right to appoint six of seven commissioners, five without City Council approval, where the Council previously appointed five and the Mayor one. The Governor appoints the seventh.
Most of the top administrative jobs at the authority, which has 1,000 employees, have changed hands at least once since 1988, said Frank Armour, an authority lawyer. And there was excitement in 1989 at the appointment of Dr. Blue, who had been Mayor Kenneth Gibson's chief of staff, and fanfare over a new board back in 1987. Both appointments were hailed as the beginning of a turnaround.
The Newark authority currently houses about 7,900 households. It has 10,700 units, not including those scheduled for demolition, a waiting list that hovers around 6,500 families, and one of the highest vacancy rates in the country for a public housing authority. In several projects, money is desperately needed for basic maintenance, though the authority receives subsidies for vacant apartments and though its operating reserves, the money used to spend on repairs as needed, are at 90 percent.
Michael B. Janis, deputy assistant secretary at H.U.D.'s Bureau of Public and Indian Housing, said the "very, very high" operating reserve was one reason the authority, the nation's eighth largest, was considered among the nation's most troubled. "If there are units in the housing agency that need some maintenance," he asked, "why isn't that money being utilized to improve the housing?"
But Ben Quattlebaum, the authority's former chief of staff and one of the four officials who recently resigned, said more than 1,600 apartments had been renovated over the last two years to comply with the settlement agreement. He added that the agency had increased its spending on maintenance and modernization and earmarked some reserves for capital improvement.
Some critics trace the authority's problems back to a source of many of the city's other enduring woes, the 1967 riots, which left 26 people dead and leveled entire neighborhoods, destroying more than 1,000 businesses. Residents who could afford to flee did so. Between 1970 and 1990, according to Census Bureau statistics, Newark lost 27 percent of its population. What remained were the projects.
Housing Authority officials say a plan embraced in the 1980's by public housing authorities all over the country sheds some light on their vacancies and maintenance problems. Authorities came to see demolition as the only way to put ravaged, crime-ridden high-rises out of their misery, a concept the N.H.A. wholeheartedly endorsed. It devised a plan that would have seen the most sweeping removal of public housing by any city in the country. More than 5,000 of its 13,133 units would have been eliminated, and thousands were warehoused in preparation for the demolition. No money was spent to either repair or maintain them.
But the authority's plans came to a halt in 1987, when Congress outlawed the demolition of public housing without a one-for-one replacement of the units destroyed. The Newark Coalition sued, and the authority was forced to reverse its course.
Now, said Mr. Graham, the authority is in a Catch-22. "We can't demolish the buildings and they were not maintained, so the cost of trying to fix them is too high," he said. 
 
Tenants Clean Up: 'This Is Our Home'
 But Pearl Cole, who has lived in Building No. 1 at Hayes Homes since it opened 37 years ago, cannot believe that it would cost $100 million to restore the project's former pride. Ms. Cole, co-chairwoman of the Hayes Homes Tenants Committee, said the tenants started a clean-up campaign in December that had made a world of difference. "We wanted to look good for Christmas," she said. "We bought some cleaner to get rid of the smell and the housing authority gave us the paint to do the walls."
Building No. 1 is now a clean, well-lighted place. The front door has no lock and the linoleum is worn, but there are no graffiti on the walls and no trash in the stairwells. Residents have been moved down to the lower 6 of its 12 floors, but there are no squatters in vacant apartments. "We chased them out," she said. "This is our home."
The tenants at Hayes Homes want the housing authority to unbolt sealed floors and buildings and make the project livable. That is unlikely. The housing authority plans to close two buildings and consolidate the tenants in the remaining three.
Stephen Finn, the director of the Newark Coalition's home project, which monitors the 1989 settlement, said that efforts to consolidate Hayes Homes tenants would be challenged in court. "We would hope the Mayor would become more involved," he said. "Instead of going around like Gorbachev trying to sell everybody on how great Newark is, he could be helping the residents of the city."
The Mayor bristles at the criticism. "My commissioners fired the executive director," he said, adding that "the James era" will start with the new executive director. Mr. James also added that his administration was the first of any city to build its own low-income housing, Victory Gardens. But others point out that Victory Gardens does not serve the most needy since its 100 units are for sale, not rent.

HEADLINE: Officers Go on Trial Today In Beating of Black Driver

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Nearly a year after they were caught on videotape clubbing and kicking a black motorist, four white police officers go on trial this week in a case that renews the painful question whether beatings and racial prejudice are common behavior within the Los Angeles Police Department.
The videotape shocked national television audiences, raised a political storm here and led to demands for reforms in the Los Angeles Police Department and to an examination of police misconduct in other cities around the country. 
 Eleven months after the March 3 beating, Los Angeles continues to wrestle with the difficulties of adapting its aggressive Police Department to the complicated needs of its ethnically diverse community.
Critics say brutality is common within the department, and the four officers will, in effect, be taking up the critics' banner by arguing that they were acting in accord with departmental procedures.
One year later, even the commander in charge of instituting reforms in the department concedes that while many changes have been made, officers on the beat are conducting themselves much as they always have.
 
Seeking to Control Chief
 An independent commission investigating the department reported last week that some progress had been made in instituting the changes it proposed in July. But its chairman, Warren Christopher, said lasting improvements would depend on passage in June of a ballot measure that would limit the city's police chief to two five-year terms and and bring him under closer political control by removing him from civil-service protection.
The current Chief, Daryl F. Gates, has resisted pressure to resign and continues to oppose changes, reacting to public criticisms of his department as personal challenges.
Chief Gates, 65 years old, had told the City Council last summer that he would retire in April but now says that he will stay on the job at least until after the vote on the measure, which he plans to campaign against.
But taking him at his earlier word, the city is searching for his successor and plans to announce its choice in April.
On the national level, John R. Dunne, Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, said the Justice Department had completed a much publicized review of 15,000 complaints of police misconduct nationwide filed over the past six years, but that he did not know when its results might be made public.
Although several national organizations monitor police practices, none keep complete statistics on complaints about the police in each city, so it is difficult to compare Los Angeles officers to their counterparts elsewhere. On average, about 600 complaints a year are filed against Los Angeles police officers, and the city in 1990 paid $8 million in jury awards and settlements for brutality complaints.
Now, as the trial officially opens Monday in the Los Angeles suburb of Simi Valley, public attention will again be drawn to the videotape that shows four officers swinging their nightsticks and kicking a prostrate Rodney G. King as nearly a score of their colleagues look on.
After analyzing the tape, prosecutors brought charges of assault last March against Sgt. Stacey C. Koon, now 41, and Officers Laurence M. Powell, 29, Theodore J. Briseno, 39, and Timothy E. Wind, 31.
Officer Wind, a rookie, was dropped from the force because he was still on probation. The three others were suspended without pay and face departmental administrative hearings. If convicted, the defendants could face prison sentences.
Once jury selection is completed and testimony gets under way, probably in early March, Mr. King, 27, an unemployed construction worker who has been convicted of robbery and at the time of the beating had recently been released from prison, is expected to testify after a nearly yearlong public silence about his beating.
His lawyer, Steven A. Lerman, said Mr. King continues to receive therapy for ailments that include memory losses, frequent nightmares, slurred speech, blurred vision, facial nerve damage that limits his feeling and taste, and a limp.
Mr. Lerman said Mr. King, who has filed a multimillion-dollar suit against the city, had suffered a broken leg, smashed teeth and almost a dozen fractures in his head. He underwent surgery to remove gravel that was embedded in his face when officers dragged him, hogtied, to the side of the road after the beating. Although the officers said he was speeding, Mr. King was not charged with anything in the incident.
In the trial, the prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney Terry White, is expected to show the tape repeatedly, as apparently unambiguous evidence to support his charges of assault.
But lawyers for the defendants say that what they call an "optical illusion" is involved because the videotape does not show the circumstances that surrounded the beating. They will admit that the officers struck Mr. King but will contend that their clients were pursuing the only prudent course.
They say they will focus on the minute or two after Mr. King was stopped at the end of a 15-minute chase and before an amateur cameraman named George Holliday began taping the incident from the window of his apartment.
"It is undoubtedly the case that the incident on the video is a reaction to what was going on before and at the very beginning of the video," said Paul R. DePasquale, who represents Mr. Wind.
Some officers who witnessed the incident told a grand jury that Mr. King behaved strangely when he was ordered from his car, joking and gesturing and resisting commands.
In sharp conflict with Chief Gates's contention that the beating was "an aberration," Mr. DePasquale said the defense would assert that the officers were acting in accordance with normal procedures during the beating.
"What happened out there was what these guys were taught, trained and expected to do by the L.A.P.D.," he said. "And the contention that the incident is somehow anomalous or an example of rogue behavior is hypocrisy. It's dishonest."
 
'Racist, Brutal Police'
 That argument echoes the views of a number of public figures in Los Angeles, like John Mack, the president of the Los Angeles Urban League, who said, "African-Americans are sometimes not sure who they are more afraid of, racist, brutal police on one side or gang bangers on the other."
In its initial report last July, the Christopher Commission found problems in several areas including training, the handling of citizen complaints, the use of excessive force and relations with the community.
In this week's diplomatically worded six-month update, it described a mixed picture of "important initial steps" by the department, along with resistance to structural changes.
Police Comdr. Rick Dinse, who is supervising reforms out of Chief Gates' office, said the department was taking to heart the commission's recommendations.
"Out of 163 individual recommendations, we either have in place or are in the process of putting in place 105 of them, and there are some that we are still opposed to," he said. But on the street, he conceded, "I don't think there is anything you can physically look at or that you can go out and say that is different."
Both the American Civil Liberties Union and lawyers specializing in police brutality cases said they continue to receive as many complaints about abuses as before.
"I think the response of the department has been deliberate, that it has been careful and orchestrated to create the appearance that they were doing all these reforms anyway," said Dan Garcia, the former chairman of the Police Commission, which oversees the 8,300-member department.

HEADLINE: New York's Haitians Share the Fear

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
In a smoky cafe in Brooklyn yesterday, Edner Desrosiers glanced over his shoulder, toward the Statue of Liberty which was visible four miles to the west in New York Harbor, and wondered what the grand symbol of freedom has come to mean.
A day after the United States Government resumed the forced return of Haitian exiles to their troubled country, Mr. Desrosiers trembled with anger and despair for the people of Haiti. 
 "I ask myself, the U.S. Constitution cannot allow Bush to do something like this," said Mr. Desrosiers, a 40-year-old math and French teacher who left Haiti 13 years ago during the brutal dictatorship of President Jean-Claude Duvalier.
"That's why the Statue of Liberty is there, right there in the Hudson River," he continued. "That's a symbol for any nation that seeks asylum."
 
Resentment, Loud or Quiet
 From cafes, street corners and offices of New York City, Haitians both angrily and quietly expressed resentment at the American policy. Many asked how the United States could recall its ambassador, citing growing political violence, and yet send hundreds of Haitian exiles back to a land with such a climate of fear.
The Haitians expressed resentment at what seemed to them a double standard in American policy. But they also spoke of dread, about a nation stoked with political and economic turmoil since the military coup that overthrew the elected civilian Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in September.
 
A Step Ahead of Secret Police
 At a tiny restaurant in Prospect Heights, Chez l'Ami Tiotio, Mr. Desrosiers explained that he had beat a hasty path out of Haiti, a step ahead of the Tontons Macoute, the Caribbean country's secret police. If he were to return, he said, brandishing an imaginary weapon, he would be dead.
"If you go there, they're going to kill you," he said. "The Haitian people who are in America now, we know what freedom means. We know what democracy means."
Aluption Cadet, who came to New York from Haiti in 1969, saw a grim future.
"It's a disaster to send them back," Mr. Cadet, a porter, said. "It's a shame. We don't do anything to nobody. We like everybody. Why someone hurt us?"
 
'The Dream is Gone'
 Raymond Guillaume, an accountant for Citibank, felt a similar sadness. "The whole dream of America is gone," Mr. Guillaume said wearily. He spent yesterday preparing income tax returns for Haitian immigrants, a second job at his brother-in-law's office in Brooklyn. Photographs of Father Aristide, the ousted President, lined the walls.
Mr. Guillaume said he learned of the forced repatriation on the Saturday evening news. As he watched, he said he grew angry at the excuses put forth by the Bush Administration.
"When the army people are harassing you and trying to kill you, it's really hard," said the accountant, a soft-spoken man who left Haiti 25 years ago. "The poor people are dying by mass. They are the ones who are fleeing the country. It's not economics. It is political. There is a part of racism to this."
Many Haitians interviewed yesterday said they did not know how to come to the aid of the exiles. Then they found a voice.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, at a news conference yesterday in Washington, called the forced repatriation "an immoral act of genocide" and urged houses of worship to ring their bells in protest. He said he was also getting in touch with all the presidential candidates to ask them to speak out.
"It's clearly a double standard fueled by race," Mr. Jackson said in an interview. "The extreme right wing, the David Dukes, the Pat Buchanans, have drawn the line of locking the Haitians out."
He added that Eastern Europeans and other immigrants had not been returned. Haitians too, he said, deserve a chance in the new world order.
For Alan Cave, the repercussions of returning to Haiti seemed too grim to ponder yesterday. Mr. Cave, a 25-year-old musician who plays at a night club in Brooklyn, said he calls his family in Haiti every weekend. "You don't know what could happen," he said. "There is always worry."
For the first time in a long time, Mr. Cave said, he could feel no hope. "We are desperate in a sense," he said. "We hardly know what to do."

He was in a restaurant yesterday in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, with Vital Yvon, right, and Fritz Simon, rear. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HAITI GETS DELAY IN EXILES' RETURN

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Plans to begin sending thousands of Haitian boat people home from the crowded refugee camps at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, were delayed for 24 hours today, in what diplomats and relief experts said was an effort to give the Haitian authorities more time to prepare for the refugees' return.
The delay meant that two boats carrying the first 400 returnees would not be able to dock until Monday. The process began after unusual judicial and diplomatic maneuvers succeeded in ifting an injunction barring the repatriations. 
 Since the military coup on Sept. 30 that toppled Haiti's first democratically elected government, about 15,000 fleeing Haitians have been picked up at sea. Last week, the Administration increased pressure to expedite the case, arguing that a renewed surge of boat people was rapidly outstripping the country's capacity to handle them. Washington said that about 20,000 more Haitians were massing on their country's shores preparing to flee.
On Friday, a Federal appeals court in Atlanta said it had overruled a district court in Miami that was blocking repatriation. In an unusual move, the Atlanta court quickly rescinded its announcement, citing a "clerical error."
Later Friday, the Supreme Court voted 6-3 to lift the injunction. The court gave no reason for its decision, although it apparently agreed that the Administration was facing a refugee emergency. The action still allows the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta to deliberate the merits of the case.
 
Embargo Constricts Island
 Lawyers for the refugees say the Haitians should not be forced to return while violence persists. The Government says most of the refugees have no right to asylum because they are fleeing for economic reasons.
In addition to the violence, an embargo has devastated the economy and malnutrition and disease are multiplying in rural areas, relief experts say.
"We are still alive, but we have been badly wounded," said Cheryl Little, the supervising attorney for the Haitian refugee center in Miami which sought court action to slow repatriation. "By the time a decision comes down on the merits, how many Haitians will have already been returned?"
Ms. Little called Government reports of 20,000 new refugees "unfounded," and said the Supreme Court had let itself be influenced by "politics, scare tactics and disinformation."
She said the court left her less than half a day on Friday to present arguments against lifting the injunction.
A Justice Department official said that each side had repeatedly been caught with little time to prepare arguments. The official denied that the issue had become politicized.
Ms. Little's complaints were echoed by human rights and church leaders in Haiti, however, who warned that the violence is far from subsiding.
"This is a slap in the face of the Haitian people who are being denied due process," said the Rev. Hugo Triest, a Roman Catholic priest involved in human rights monitoring here. "No one believes this story about 20,000 people, and if it is even partly true, it is because of the extreme repression that is going on here against anyone who wants change."
Offering evidence of the climate of fear, Father Triest said that earlier today he had seen the police round up people in the capital for supposedly supporting the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, issued a statement tonight saying she "regrets" the American decision, given the violence in Haiti.
Officials here and in Washington could not say where the figure of 20,000 people originated. One, who defended the estimate as "maybe even a little conservative," however, alluded to satellite data, which he said showed that enough small boats were available to carry 150,000 Haitians.
Diplomats and relief officials said that the repatriation would begin Monday with the boatload of 150 refugees who left Guantanamo late Saturday and have been cruising between Cuba and Haiti while Haitian authorities prepared to receive them. A second boatload of 250 left today.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
President Bush plans to finance his health insurance proposal, aimed at helping 90 million Americans buy coverage with new tax credits and tax deductions, mainly by slowing the growth of health programs like Medicare and Medicaid, Administration officials and members of Congress said. The plan is to be introduced in a speech in Cleveland on Thursday. [Page A1.]
Economists say that if the $50 billion in military spending cuts Bush proposed is used to increase growth, the short-term pain would be outweighed by long-term gain. [D3.] 
 It may be premature to write the obituary of the department store. Those eager to relegate the stores to a retailing museum can cite a long list of failed emporiums, yet the traditional department store's share of the general merchandise market has declined less than bankruptcies would seem to indicate. [A1.]
After years of talk, New York City is expected to announce a program today to sell tax-exempt bonds to small investors at prices as low as $1,200 for a $5,000 bond due in 20 years. [B1.]
Dozens of corporate giants collected money to promote brand-name products under an Agriculture Department program. [D7.]
 
Companies
New York legislators are expected to approve changes in credit card laws that would encourage banks to keep more jobs in the state but would raise the cost of credit cards to consumers. [D1.]
Drug marketers have found a new promise of comfort for Americans with drippy noses and aching bodies, but the active ingredients in many new flu medicines are the same as those in regular cold medicines. [D3.]
 
International
Unless American auto parts suppliers swiftly adjust to the vastly different priorities set by Japanese car companies, President Bush has shaken hands on an agreement that may hasten the decline of the American industry, experts say. [D1.]
Representatives of about 160 governments are trying to agree on how to make room for new radio technologies. [D1.]
Germany and the U.S. called for drastic steps to insure liberalization of world trade as the best means to guarantee growth and encourage market economies in the former Soviet Union. [D2.]
German steelworkers voted to strike, and union officials said work stoppages could begin this week. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
CBS desperately needs its Winter Olympics coverage to be an unquestioned success in the ratings. [D1.]
Is ambush marketing about to become an Olympic event? The spoilsport strategy, in which an advertiser tries to disrupt a competitor's plan, seems to be growing, with companies seeking to become associated with events like the Olympics for which a rival has paid for an official affiliation. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]
Small news organizations are under increasing pressure from worried owners and anxious libel insurers to consult more frequently with libel lawyers. Alex S. Jones: Press. [D8.]
Publishers of U.S. trade and specialty journals are scrambling to expand abroad, driven by the recession at home and the perception of greater opportunities overseas. [D8.]
Mademoiselle is giving up fiction for fashion, after being known for its short stories for 57 years. [D8.]
 
Today's Columns
After three months of guesswork over the size of the Treasury's next sale of 30-year bonds, the immediate question may be answered this week, but the debate on the subject will no doubt continue. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D5.]
Stock prices of property-and-casualty insurers jumped in the fourth quarter, but analysts remain skeptical. Some think insurers will benefit from lower interest rates, but others say weak prices will continue to plague the companies. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Hoping Freedom Will Ring, U.S. Relaxes Cuba Embargo

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Making a rare exception to its economic blockade of the Communist Government of President Fidel Castro, the Bush Administration has granted permission to A.T.&T. to expand telephone service between Cuba and the United States.
But Administration officials say that far from recasting their policy of isolating the Communist Government, they instead intend the move to help stir popular unrest by increasing exposure between Cubans and their more affluent relatives in the United States. 
 Despite Washington's motivation, Havana would apparently like to believe that telephone diplomacy, like the Ping-Pong diplomacy that improved American relations with China, could loosen the embargo.
"It could be a good sign," said Ariel Ricardo, spokesman of the Cuban Interests Section in Washington, "but you always have doubts about what is the intention."
The Administration's decision in late December to allow the company to pay Havana $620,000 in fees for operation of a cable line to Cuba reflects a new, more flexible approach to the island nation at a time when the Castro Government faces a serious threat from the collapse of Soviet Communism and the loss of Moscow's crucial aid.
Even as it has tightened regulations on Cubans who wish to immigrate, the Administration initiated new immigration negotiations with Havana in December. And in a move that would have been unthinkable a few years ago, the Administration shared intelligence information with Havana to thwart a reported terrorist plot to plant a bomb at the recent Pan American Games.
The Administration's willingness to promote A.T.&T.'s business in Cuba comes at a time when there has been a shift in the thinking of some Cuban-Americans who are influential in the Republican Party. Once opposed to any accommodations with Havana, they and the Administration have come to believe that increased communications can spur popular opposition to the Castro Government.
"We believe the more information that flows into Cuba the better," said a senior State Department official.
A break with past practice was signified by the Treasury Department's long-delayed approval of A.T.&.T.'s three-year-old request for permission to pay the Castro Government annual maintenance and capital improvement fees for a telephone cable. While a handful of American companies have received licenses to deal with the Cuban Government in the last several years, all were involved in educational, artistic or charitable endeavors, not commercial transactions.
About 60 million attempts to place telephone calls are made annually between the countries, but only about 500,000 get through the antiquated short-wave radio system. Many people spend hours dialing in vain. With the copper underwater cable connecting West Palm Beach, Fla., and Cojimar, Cuba, an estimated 250,000 more calls should be completed annually.
Officials predict the cable could be operational by the spring. Treasury Department approval is required for the deal on the payment of tolls, by which Cuba would eventually earn between $1 million and $2 million a year.
The Cuban Government is not expected to net money from the transaction, and may even lose some currency, because it receives what callers consider exorbitant fees for some calls between the United States that are now patched through from Canada.

HEADLINE: Credit Card Legislation Up for Vote

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
New York legislators are expected today to approve changes in the state's credit card laws that would encourage New York banks to keep more jobs in the state but would raise the cost of credit cards to consumers who pay their bills late.
The legislation would eliminate the 10-day delay period before banks can charge a penalty fee on past-due card payments and would make it easier for New York banks to offer cards with a variable interest rate. 
 Opposed by the state Consumer Protection Board, the bill is an example of how lawmakers sometimes balance competing interests to keep jobs from moving to other states.
"We want to create a climate that tells banks they can do business in New York, and at the same time protect the consumer," said Herman D. Farrell Jr., a Democratic Assemblyman representing parts of Harlem and Washington Heights. Mr. Farrell is chairman of the Assembly banking committee and sponsor of the Assembly version of the bill.
 
Same Powers as in Delaware
 The bill would give New York banks the same powers as banks that operate their credit card businesses in Delaware, South Dakota or other states where banks are given greater leeway in running their credit card operations.
Chase Manhattan and the Bank of New York have large credit card businesses in Delaware. Citicorp, which has more than 30 million credit card accounts and is by far the largest in the field, runs its card business through banks it owns in South Dakota, Nevada and Maryland.
The proposed changes are closely related to the Dec. 31 merger of Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Bank, which is expected to result in the loss of 6,200 jobs, most of them in the metropolitan New York City region. The Chemical Banking Corporation moved its credit card business to Delaware from New York in the early 1980's. Manufacturers Hanover currently employs about 1,400 people in a computer center in Hicksville, L.I., that handles credit cards and other consumer transactions.
As those two companies merge their operations under the Chemical name, they have wanted to combine the card operations in New York -- but they have also sought to make the state's laws as favorable as those in Delaware.
Officials from Chemical visited Albany in September to meet with legislators. "We certainly expressed our opinion that the existing laws were unworkable," said Judy Walsh, a Chemical spokeswoman.
In November, bank officials were optimistic enough that they would get their way that they announced plans to combine the Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover credit card businesses in Hicksville.
Manufacturers Hanover is the largest New York bank to have kept its card business in the state, and it has not been shy in the past about asking the state for help. In 1989 it sought and obtained laws that allow New York banks to charge fees to consumers who pay late or exceed their pre-approved credit lines.
 
Responding to Competition
 The chairman of the Senate banking committee, Hugh T. Farley, Republican of Schenectady, said the importance of preserving the 1,400 jobs in Hicksville and attracting new jobs from the credit card business of Chemical's subsidiary bank in Texas, was more important than the extra costs to consumers. Chemical employs 150 people in Delaware and several dozen in Texas.
"It's very competitive business," he said, referring to credit cards. He noted that New Yorkers who used cards issued by banks from outside the state were already accepting terms similar to those in the proposed bill.
While many banks still charge interest rates of 18 to 19.8 percent on credit card balances, many other banks have been cutting rates in recent months.
People's Bank in Bridgeport, Conn., for example, cut its rate to 11.5 percent from 13.9 percent late last month. And Chemical has said it plans to cut rates to 17.8 percent from 19.8 percent on its ordinary fixed-rate cards in March and to 16.8 from 17.8 percent on its gold cards. Chemical's floating-rate cards, offered through its Delaware bank, charge 15.5 percent.
Mr. Farrell and Mr. Farley expect the bills to pass today's vote, despite the opposition of the Consumer Protection Board. Senator Franz S. Leichter, Democrat of Manhattan, said he planned to offer an amendment that would forbid any bank, whether based in New York or elsewhere, from charging late-payment fees to New York consumers. A similar law in Massachusetts is now being challenged in court by the Greenwood Trust Company, a Delaware bank that handles Sears, Roebuck & Company's Discover card.
 
Consumer Board's Criticism
 In a memorandum sent to legislators on Jan. 24, the New York State Consumer Protection Board called the late-payment charges, about $10 at most banks, a "nuisance fee" that consumers did not notice when doing comparison shopping for credit cards.
The board also objected to provisions of the bill intended to help New York banks offer credit cards with variable interest rates. For variable-rate cards, the bill would eliminate the requirement of 30 days' notice for interest rate changes and would rescind consumers' rights to cancel their credit card and pay off their debt at the old interest rate.
The consumer board said that offering customers a chance to cancel their card at the old interest rate would not prohibit banks from charging higher rates to other customers.
 
Removing Rate Caps
 The bill would also eliminate an existing requirement for New York banks that the maximum and minimum interest rate on cards be equidistant from the initial interest rate charged the consumer.
The consumer board said this requirement should be continued because it discouraged lenders from setting very high maximum interest rates. To get a high maximum rate, the lender must also allow for the possibility of a low minimum rate.
Ms. Walsh of Chemical Bank said it would be cumbersome to keep track of all the maximum and minimum rates for consumers because the initial rates would vary, depending on when their accounts were opened.
