HEADLINE: While Fear of Big War Fades, Military Plans for Little Ones

SERIES: After the Cold War -- Second of six articles.

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT KNOX, Ky.

 BODY:
On a bleak, cold hillside one January afternoon, a class of future Army tank commanders huddled on a set of bleachers as Col. John Sylvester, one of the heroes of the Persian Gulf war, explained why the breakup of the Soviet Union would have no effect on their careers.
A towering Daniel Boone figure with muddy boots and a booming voice, Colonel Sylvester led the Tiger Brigade of the Second Armored Division of M1-A1 tanks against Kuwait International Airport a year ago. Now, as warrior-teacher, he was telling these young captains and lieutenants that even with the cold war's end they might still find themselves in a war someday. 
 And in war, Colonel Sylvester told them, the enemy will always try to put obstacles on the battlefield "to make you vulnerable so he can kill you." Simple as that.
But what the Colonel didn't say was who that enemy might be. The fact was, he didn't know.
With the cold war ended, the future is sweeping over the United States military. Nowhere is frustration as intense as here at the Army's tank school, where virtually every tank driver since World War II has trained with a Soviet enemy in mind.
 
An Old Fear, Now Gone
 That vision of an enemy that could point 90 or more divisions at Western Europe and still wage global war with the United States was implanted in multiple generations of Americans in uniform. But now it has evaporated, leaving the United States military without the old certainties about its role in the world, its deployment overseas, its need for futuristic weapons and battlefield scenarios.
At no time since the end of World War II has America's two-million-member military establishment faced as much fundamental change and uncertainty as in 1992, the first full year that will unfold without a unified Soviet military and the industrial complex that supported it.
Significant military threats to American security are greatly diminished, but they have not disappeared altogether: Saddam Hussein reminded the world that sizable military challenges might arise in the undefinable era ahead, but these potential adversaries are vaporous shapes.
"This transition period is potentially dangerous," argued Maj. Gen. Thomas C. Foley, who commands the armor school at Fort Knox. "I don't want to say there is a bogey man behind every tree, but you have to admit when the American people say, 'Our interests are being threatened, let's do something about it,' we have got to be ready to go, on a much reduced scale maybe, but ready to go."
 
A Game With Only One Team
 For other officers, the loss of certainty is more distressing.
Col. Dennis H. Long is the director of "total armor force readiness" at Fort Knox. His job is to look 15 to 20 years into the future and recommend to the Army what kind of tanks and other armored vehicles the service should design.
"For 50 years, we equipped our football team, practiced five days a week and never played a game," he said. "We had a clear enemy with demonstrable qualities, and we had scouted them out."
Now, he continued, "We will have to practice day in and day out without knowing anything about the other team. We won't have his playbook, we won't know where the stadium is, or how many guys he will have on the field. That is very distressing to the military establishment, especially when you are trying to justify the existence of your organization and your systems."
 
The Questions
How to Learn From Small Wars
 The final collapse of the Soviet empire has caused millions of Americans and many of their representatives in Congress to call for dramatic reductions in the American military. And it has led the Bush Administration to retreat, though in small steps, from the large military budgets that characterized the Korean War era, the Vietnam War era, the late Carter Administration, the Reagan era and even the first days of the Bush Administrastion.
"For all of my lifetime," said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, "the driving force for everything has been the Soviet threat." Now that it has gone away, he continued in an interview, "we are cut loose from a lot of our certainties, and we must ask ourselves first-principles questions which haven't been asked in 40 to 50 years."
What are those questions?
Former Defense Secretary Harold Brown said the first question Americans must answer is what kind of military power they want the nation to be.
"Is it really America's job to fight in North and South Korea?" he asked. "Apparently it is America's job to fight in the Persian Gulf. What about southern Africa and Latin America?"
"My own guess is that the American public wouldn't see the same motivation" in those regions that it did during the cold war, Mr. Brown said, when global military competition with the Soviet Union led to American intervention in Europe, Central America, the Caribbean, the Middle East and Asia.
"The end of the cold war should mean the end of the cold-war method of judging defense requirements," former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger wrote recently in Foreign Policy.
In an interview, Mr. Schlesinger said American society must recast its definition of power to include such elements as economic competitiveness, productivity and investment in industry. These other priorities, he suggests, will move to more commanding positions as the need for massive military strength disappears.
 
Loaded Words in the Budget
 This transition holds practical problems, however, and most of them are in Washington, where the annual budget cycle requires the Pentagon and the Congress to define "threats" to national security and then to state the "requirements" for weapons and forces needed to meet them. From this process emerges an annual Pentagon budget and five-year spending plan to "acquire" the forces and weapons needed.
But without a big threat, there is little agreement on how to proceed.
Representative Aspin recently suggested that the Persian Gulf war should be the model for future wars. The Iraq experience would be transplanted around the globe to measure the relative strength of other troublesome regional powers as a means to plan forces to defeat them. Mr. Aspin has dubbed this method "Iraq equivalents."
In August 1990, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, defined a strategy that would shrink worldwide American forces by 25 percent from cold-war levels while increasing spending for a new generation of high-technology weapons to outfit the American military of the future.
 
Military's New Tasks
 This transitional strategy foresaw the threat of regional wars in the Persian Gulf or Korea. It focused on the spreading ballistic missile threat, nuclear proliferation, terrorism, drug trafficking and the possible re-emergence of a Soviet threat in Europe.
The collapse of the Soviet Union quickly undermined this strategy and highlighted the fact that Mr. Cheney and General Powell were building so many new weapons that future defense budgets, after a period of shrinkage, would actually begin growing again by tens of billions of dollars a year later in the decade.
But Mr. Cheney and General Powell have now retrenched further.
Oppressed by the new reality that it must justify itself in a relative vacuum of "threats," the military's leaders are clinging to the truisms of military philosophy, admonishing political leaders in the way Machiavelli might have instructed his prince or Clauswitz his king.
The advice is simple and blunt: any nation that disarms invites attack; wars, when they come, are seldom the wars expected; being as good as a potential adversary is not enough; winning means not only exceeding the strengths of the opponent, but dominating him so completely that the conflict is ended early with favorable results and minimal casualties.
 
The Background
A Strategy Built On Years of Fear
 On Aug. 25, 1989, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., General Powell's predecessor as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, distributed his last "national military strategy," a classified guide to waging global conflict with the Soviet Union. He did not know that in just 76 days the Berlin wall would fall, bringing the end of the cold war clearly into view.
"Should deterrence fail and war come," he wrote to Secretary Cheney, "the United States must be prepared for an extended conflict involving the survival of the nation." The document, which was sent to top military commanders, spoke of "total mobilization at home" to build the nation's wartime combat power.
"United States forces will seek out and destroy Soviet naval forces, project power ashore and be prepared to conduct attacks against the Soviet homeland," Admiral Crowe wrote. Should the war go nuclear, the document says, "our forces will hold at risk those assets that the Soviet leadership would need to prevail in a nuclear conflict and to dominate a postnuclear world."
It was a military catechism that epitomized an era -- an era in which NATO developed strategies to offset the numerical superiority of the Warsaw Pact; an era in which the United States Navy focused on resupplying Europe in wartime, on dominating the oceans and on building a maritime strategy using aircraft carriers and marines to strike on the Soviet flanks.
 
Harking Back to Their Coming of Age
 For most senior general officers in the American military today, coming to adulthood coincided with the onset of prospective East-West conflict.
General Foley, now the commander at Ft. Knox, recalled that when he arrived in West Germany in 1961 as a young second lieutenant and watched the Berlin wall going up, "I think all of us took very seriously the fact that we could go to war at any time.
"There was a fear," he said, a recognition that those officers who had brought their families to Europe might not get the opportunity to warn them in the event that war broke out with nuclear weapons.
When his wife, Sandy, and two young children arrived by transport ship in Bremerhaven and traveled by train to Bavaria in June 1962, the Foleys had been separated for a year by the Berlin crisis. Their family reunion lasted only three days before Lieutenant Foley had to be back with his unit in a high state of readiness for war.
When there was spare time, the Foleys reconnoitered the escape routes through Germany that Mrs. Foley and the children would use if war broke out.
"That's how serious it was taken," he said.
This seminal cold war experience shaped General Foley's lifetime view, leaving him with the opinion today that the United States should strive to remain a potent military power to deter threats, even if the threats were not readily apparent.
 
The Analysis
Threat Is Diverse Rather Than Deep
 For the military, and the nervous Foleys, the cold war was a time of great building and transition. The first bomber designed to carry nuclear weapons, the B-52 Stratofortress, went on 24-hour alert in 1957. The Air Force's Strategic Air Command became the first among equals of all military commands; its mission was to annihilate Soviet targets with nuclear fire.
In June 1962, the same month that Mrs. Foley followed her husband to Europe, Roy Alcala graduated from West Point and reported to tank school at Fort Knox.
The commencement speaker for Lieutenant Alcala's graduating class at West Point had been President John F. Kennedy, who admonished the cadets that the global competition between the Soviet Union and United States might send them into the third world as cold warriors against the spread of Marxist revolutions.
"I know that many of you feel, and many of our citizens may feel, that in these days of the nuclear age, when war may last in its final form a day or two or three days before much of the world is burned up, that your service to your country will be only standing and waiting," Mr. Kennedy said.
"Nothing, of course, could be further from the truth."
Five Soviet leaders and several wars later, Mikhail S. Gorbachev began the process of turning the world on its end. And after two tours in Vietnam and three years of graduate school at Yale University, Colonel Alcala and many of his contemporaries saw the decline of the Soviet Union long before the Pentagon officially acknowledged it.
"We began to see it in 1986 and the spring of 1987," he said. By this time, Colonel Alcala was running a small research group for Gen. Carl E. Vuono, the Army Chief of Staff.
Sensing the future, General Vuono mobilized his staff to formulate what he called a "successor strategy" that would allow the Army to shrink in size, while maintaining its lethalness and mobility for any crisis.
 
Change in Risk Ratio
 "Changing from the containment of the Soviet Union," Colonel Alcala said, meant that "we were preparing our forces so they could act in areas other than mainland Europe while not knowing precisely what kind of threat they would face."
"Our conclusion was that while the risk to national existence was way down, the probability of having to engage was way up.
"It took the exercise against Iraq to shed much of the old language and to demonstrate what we had done," Colonel Alcala said.
General Vuono and Colonel Alcala also understood that the service would have to shrink substantially because no set of hypothetical threats could ever measure up to the demands the Soviet military had put on American military preparedness.
 
The Outlook
The Dead Past Shapes the Future
 Veterans of the Pentagon's planning process say the military has spent most of its time for the last two years justifying a slimmed-down version of the cold-war military structure, rather than trying to design a force for the 21st century.
The notion of throwing out a decades-old system is a powerful bureaucratic threat. It rankles veterans.
"It can't be a clean sheet of paper," said Mr. Brown, the former Defense Secretary. "You have an immense capital investment, and you can't throw it away."
Planning for the future need not waste the investments of the past, some experts say. Without a clear and identifiable military threat, why not design a smaller, highly mobile and lethal military that could respond to a crisis anywhere in the world, seize territory, control the air over the battlefield and provide support from the sea, but at half the cost of the military that existed when the Berlin wall fell?
New ideas about so-called all-purpose forces are being offered. Some argue that the military has only begun to explore the possibilities offered by cost-effective combinations of computers, radars and high-technology munitions that can bring more firepower to bear on targets than at any time in history.
Mr. Aspin, head of the House Armed Services Committee, has advocated new procurement strategies to slow the development of new weapons: "rolling over" research and "skipping generations" of weapons instead of rushing into production with every new model.
It appears that the Pentagon is moving in that direction.
 
The Doubts
Inertia Hobbles A Vast Military
 Just retired from the Army that he joined in the era of Dr. Strangelove, Colonel Alcala is proud of the imprint his generation left on his service. But he has also begun to believe that the United States can remain the strongest global military power while also shedding much of the "dishonesty, pork and near-term economic gain" that impels the Pentagon's budget.
He says he would be willing to scrap the Army's tank factories and deactivate divisions that have lost their purpose. He would experiment with so-called cadre divisions that would maintain a skeletal core and fill out with reservists in a crisis.
"The right answer is probably unachievable," he said, "because it requires traumatic change and the amputation of useless limbs if we do it right. You have to cut the money, change the strategy and make the force fit the strategy. And you'll never get that on Capitol Hill."
Next: Sweeping changes proposed for the nation's intelligence agencies.

Chart: "New Weapons for an Old War"
Some weapon systems designed for cold war applications.
 
Weapon: B-2 Stealth Bomber
 Original Mission: To penetrate Soviet airspace undetected carrying nuclear weapons during wartime Development by Northrop began in 1978; first flight was in July 1989.
 Status: The Pentagon wanted 75 planes at a cost of $65 billion, but President Bush's budget proposal for fiscal 1993 calls for halting production at 20 planes. The program has already cost $34 billion.
 
Weapon: F-22 Advanced Tactical Stealth Fighter
 Original Mission: To replace the F-15 Eagle and F-16 Falcon fighters and maintain air supremacy over any improved Soviet fighters. The search for this new generation or aircraft that could at supersonic speeds without detection began in 1981; Lockheed won the design competition in April 1991.
 Status: Full-scale production to begin this year at an expected cost of $95 billion for 650 planes. In the fiscal 1993 budget, the Pentagon is requesting $2.2 billion for the program.
 
Weapon: SSN-21 Seawolf -- named for the first submarine in this class
 Original Mission: To succeed the Los Angeles-class submarine with the mission of preventing the Soviet Navy from seizing the oceans during wartime. The first boat, ordered in January 1989, is under construction.
 Status: The Navy wanted 30 boats for a total cost of $65 billion. President Bush's fiscal 1993 budget proposal calls for ending the program after only one submarine is built.
 
Weapon: M1 Tank
 Original Mission: To counter heavy armored Soviet tank divisions in Europe.
 Status: Congress instructed the Pentagon to proceed with the M1-A2, an upgrade of the M1-A1, even though the Defense Department says it already has more tanks than it needs. Current proposals call for $315 million next year.
 
Weapon: Aircraft carrier battle groups
 Original Mission: To maintain "deep attach" capabilitites against the Soviet Union, and to provide forward air attack abilities around the world.
 Status: Three new carriers are under construction, and the Navy wants to build another. The 15 carrier battle groups already deployed cost more than $20 billion a year to operate. Each carrier along with its battle group costs about $45 billion over its 30-year life cycle. HEADLINE: Plan Expected To Widen Sale Of City Bonds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
When security guards assigned to the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, asked her last year how they could buy the city's bonds, it served as a reminder that the banks and Wall Street firms that sell the bonds were not reaching multitudes of small investors. Today, after years of talk, the city is expected to announce a new program to sell tax-exempt bonds at prices as low as $1,200 for a $5,000 bond due in 20 years, far less than the $25,000 minimum purchase at most securities firms.
About $50 million of the city's $750 million bond sale in early March will be earmarked for small investors and sold through a special group of firms that have agreed not to charge fees to those buyers. 
 "We are giving smaller investors the same opportunity that rich investors have had to take advantage of high yields on tax-free municipal bonds," Ms. Holtzman said in an interview on Friday. "There is a tremendous pool of money in New York among city pensioners and others who live and work here and who have a lot of confidence in the city."
At a time when many investors are suffering sticker shock at interest rates of less than 5 percent posted on bank windows, the city hopes for a good response to its bonds, which are expected to yield more than 6 percent.
 
Ads in Subway System
 To reach potential investors, monthly pension checks mailed on Thursday to more than 240,000 retired city workers included notices of the new bond program. By 11 A.M. on Friday, more than 150 calls had been received through a special telephone number (1-800-874-3645) for those wanting more information.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has donated space for advertisements in the subway system, and half a million brochures have been printed for distribution to city employees and at elementary and junior high schools, for teachers and administrators and for children to take home to their parents.
 
Prospective Buyers
 The advance publicity is intended to help a group of eight securities dealers, led by Prudential Securities, to gather prospective buyers before the March bond sale. At that sale, the eight firms have promised to fill the smallest orders before they sell to wealthier investors, whose larger orders are more profitable to handle. The firms will not charge account fees or handling charges to customers who buy only the New York City bonds, but customers who do not want to open brokerage accounts may keep accounts at the Chase Manhattan Bank, which would act as custodian and whose $2 annual fee per account would be paid by the city.
Although it wants to reach smaller investors, the city chose not to make the bonds available in amounts as low as $250, as some other cities have done and as was suggested last year by James Lebenthal, chairman of Lebenthal & Company, one of the securities firms handling the new bonds. Mr. Lebenthal's plan, which was not accepted, was similar to the United States Series E Savings Bond program, in which investors can choose when to cash in their investment.
By requiring investors to have more than $1,000 of ready money and by selling the bonds through securities dealers that are supposed to ascertain that the bonds will be a suitable investment for individual customers, the city hopes to avoid drawing money from people who should avoid investing in bonds before accumulating a financial cushion in savings.
 
'Zero Coupon' Bonds
 The new bonds allow investors to avoid the fees and charges of bond mutual funds. These funds, which offer investors a diversified mix of bonds, can often be bought in minimum amounts of $1,000 or less.
The initial purchase price of the city bonds is far below the $5,000 value at maturity because these are "zero coupon" bonds, meaning that they do not pay interest every six months, like traditional city bonds.
Because prices of zero-coupon bonds can fluctuate widely before maturity, financial advisers recommend them primarily to investors who will not need to sell early and want to build a nest egg for an anticipated expense, like buying a home or paying for a child's education.
With zero-coupon bonds, the interest for investors is the difference between the purchase price and the $5,000 that the city promises to pay when the bonds reach maturity.
If a bond is sold before it matures, the amount received will be less than $5,000, with the amount of the discount depending on the length of time before the bond matures, the level of interest rates and investors' confidence in the city's ability to pay the bonds. For the first issue of the bonds, the city does not plan to buy insurance, which would protect investors in the event of a default.
The city's bond rating slipped last year and both major credit rating agencies have warned that the trend in the city's financial condition is negative. But although the city's well-publicized financial problems and heavy borrowing needs force it to pay much higher interest rates than most local governments, the possibility of a default is considered remote.
 
Long-Term Savers
 Darcy Bradbury, the city's deputy comptroller for finance, said the bonds were intended "for people who are long-term savers." The city will issue special notices, she said, warning potential buyers that if they sell the bonds before maturity, there is a risk of loss.
The city plans to raise about $50 million in March from the sale to small investors of securities with maturities of from 5 to 20 years.
Although the $100 million a year the city hopes to raise from small investors is small compared with the more than $3 billion of bonds it sells annually, it does help keep interest rates down by reducing the amount of bonds the city must sell to the mutual funds, wealthy people and insurance companies that have been buying 75 percent of recent city bond issues.

HEADLINE: Governments to Begin Talks On Uses of Radio Spectrum

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Representatives from about 160 governments begin a monthlong meeting in Spain Monday in an attempt to reach an international agreement on how to make room for new technologies on the crowded radio spectrum.
At stake are radio frequencies for a broad family of new mobile communication services for individual consumers, from low-cost wireless telephones that can be used anywhere on the globe to laptop computers that can send and receive data using satellites. Also at stake is "digital" radio broadcasting from satellites that promises sound as crisp and clean as that from a compact disk. 
 Advances in technology over the last four years have made many such services economically feasible, and companies around the world are clamoring for a chance to offer them. Because virtually all of the radio frequencies that can be easily used are already assigned for other purposes, governments are under pressure to decide which older services should be displaced to make room for the new.
 
Ambitious List of Proposals
 As representatives from around the world assemble for the 1992 World Administrative Radio Conference in Torremolinos, Spain, they will take up an ambitious list of proposals. The conference is held approximately every four years by the International Telecommunications Union, a Geneva-based organization that establishes the rules for international radio frequencies.
Individual countries are free to write their own rules for uses of the radio spectrum within their borders. But many signals are hard to contain within national boundaries, and for commercial purposes, common standards also make it easier to cut costs through economies of scale.
Delegates from the United States, Europe and Japan say the agenda this year has made the stakes unusually high. "In the past, we'd go to these conferences hoping we wouldn't get raped and pillaged," said Jan W. Baran, the United States Ambassador to the conference. "This time, we're going into it with a whole list of futuristic proposals."
 
Agreement Far From Certain
 It is far from certain that the negotiators will reach a broad agreement. Underlying this year's conference is a basic conflict between the United States on one hand and Europe and Japan on the other about the best way to establish personal communication networks.
With its vast land mass and many sparsely populated areas, the United States wants to set aside frequencies for fleets of low-orbit satellites that can broadcast wireless telephone and data communications to large areas, an aspect especially valuable for rural outposts too remote for land-based networks. The American stance has been set in large part because Motorola Inc. and several other American companies have already proposed launching fleets of small satellites that would orbit several hundred miles above the earth.
Leaders in Europe and Japan are betting more heavily on land-based radio networks for what would resemble the next generation of cellular telephones. These systems would link pocket telephones, laptop computers and other devices through antennas scattered through urban areas.
 
Japanese Government's Position
 "To be honest, the Japanese Government is not all that interested in low-earth-orbit satellites," said Yasuo Suzuki, a counselor at the Japanese Embassy in Washington for the Telecommunications Ministry. "The main purpose of low-earth satellites is for rural areas, and Japan doesn't have many."
European and Japanese officials contend that, without common global standards, the new generation of low-cost pocket telephones will not be usable in different countries and will probably cost more to make.
"I would admit that the number of customers who want to take phones from Europe to the United States is relatively small," said John Carrington, director of mobile and new business at Cable and Wireless P.L.C. in London. "But the larger the number of addressable customers that can be provided with equipment to a common standard, the lower the cost of that equipment will be."
American officials respond that the United States already has plans to allocate domestic frequencies for cordless telephone technologies and finds no compelling need for a common global standard because manufacturers can easily modify their equipment for different markets.
A satellite system would function as well in urban as in rural areas and would thus allow for economies of scale if the Europeans and Japanese agreed to it. But if the satellites cannot be used worldwide they would not be as economically viable.
Another top issue will be setting aside frequencies for "digital audio broadcasting," a technology for broadcasting radio in the ones and zeroes of computer code that proponents say will offer a striking improvement over current FM technology. In the United States, many existing broadcasters fear that digital radio threatens their very survival.
In a blow to the broadcasters, the Bush Administration decided several months ago that it would propose reserving frequencies for digital radio in a part of the spectrum that is useful only for satellite services. Broadcasters had hoped the Government would press for frequencies in a lower frequency range easier for them to use.
The Europeans and the Japanese share an interest in digital radio programming but have proposed frequencies different from those proposed by the United States. The United States proposal is for frequencies the Europeans and the Japanese want to use for land-based telecommunications.
The role of developing countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America is also a matter of debate. In many such nations, the biggest issues are the preservation of frequencies for old-fashioned short-wave radio. But because any new rules require unanimous consent, some countries could emerge as political allies of one side or another in the debate.
"I don't want to minimize the problems, because there are a lot of differences, but there is a lot of good will," Mr. Carrington of Cable and Wireless said.

HEADLINE: Economists Cite Benefits Of Arms Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The military spending cuts that President Bush proposed last week would certainly hurt workers who make submarines in Connecticut and fighter aircraft in California. But, economists say, if the $50 billion is used instead to increase growth by, say, increasing investment, the short-term pain would be outweighed by the long-term gain.
Lawrence R. Klein, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania and recipient of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, says this new "peace dividend" can, if not frittered away, raise economic output in the long term in two ways. One would be to move resources into the civilian sector, making it more competitive. Another would be to reduce the Federal budget deficit, which would help push down interest rates and spur investment in the private sector. 
 Professor Klein said his studies of Pentagon spending cuts after the Vietnam War showed that if a cutback eliminated 100,000 jobs in the short run, the redirection of the money saved would ultimately create more than 100,000 permanent jobs to replace them.
Substituting civilian spending for military spending would expand the nation's production potential, Professor Klein said, because "a weapon doesn't produce goods for the next 20 years, but a new building or piece of equipment produces output for the length of its life."
 
Deeper Cuts Sought
 Many Democrats in Congress are eager to cut even more deeply into the military budget than the $50 billion over five years proposed by the President. That push, combined with the more than $100 billion in cuts already in the pipeline, has led many economists to fear a drastic drain from the Government's pool of research and development money. They were heartened that the Administration would increase spending for civilian research and development by 7 percent. Supercomputers would get $803 million, a 23 percent increase.
"If we can turn our research capacities and scientific talent to something other than weapons, then what's the big problem about defense cuts?" said Herbert Stein, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute who was a chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford.
Certainly, there will be a big problem for the workers at the General Dynamics Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn., who were shocked to learn that the Pentagon would like to reduce its orders for the Seawolf submarine to one, down from three, if Congress, in election years particularly sensitive to job losses, permits it to. Similarly, workers at the Hughes Aircraft Company in Southern California were unhappy to learn that the Pentagon proposed ordering 20 B-2 bombers instead of 75. No one is sure how many layoffs will result from the newest round of cuts in the Pentagon budgets, but many economists say it will reach the tens of thousands.
"In terms of macroeconomics, it is not the national level but the local level we have to worry about regarding these cuts," said John Tepper Marlin, director of the conversion information center at the Council of Economic Priorities, a public policy institute in New York.
 
Retraining Is Needed
 The trauma can be reduced if local and state governments aggressively plan to help such workers adapt to a nonmilitary future, economic development officials say. Economists point to success stories like St. Louis, where St. Louis Community College worked with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to retrain and find jobs for laid-off workers.
David Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc., an economics consulting group, said his research team had done studies showing that if military spending cuts were used to reduce the ballooning budget deficit, "in the long term it helps you because it will allow interest rates to drop, investment to recover and more stimulus long term."
Mr. Wyss said every dollar spent on military production generated $2.30 extra in gross national product from auxiliary industries, but public investment, like building roads or bridges, would generate a larger kick: an extra $2.50 in gross national product.
The multiplier effect was greater for public investment because in pothole-filling or bridge-building, Mr. Wyss said, little money goes overseas to buy raw materials or components. Other economist noted that such spending would also help increase productivity by reducing transportation delays and costs.
For some economists, the Pentagon's heavy research and development spending was good for the overall economy because it helped develop important technologies, like semiconductors and light aircraft frames, that were spun off to help civilian industry. These economists worried that reducing the Pentagon's budget would hurt the nation's research and development efforts.
In its proposed budget, the Administration took pains to say it was increasing outlays for the nonmilitary research budget even as it cut military spending.
Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, a public policy institute in Washington, said the proposed military spending cuts would be far smaller proportionally than those after World War II and the Vietnam War. After Vietnam, military spending was cut from slightly under 10 percent of G.N.P. to just under 5 percent. President Bush's proposals would reduce military spending by 1.8 percent of G.N.P., to 3.4 percent from 5.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Easing of Trade Barriers Is Urged

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Germany and the United States today called for drastic steps to insure a liberalization of world trade as the best means to guarantee growth and encourage market economies in the former Soviet Union.
At an annual gathering here of political and business leaders, known as the World Economic Forum, Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann of Germany said a summit conference of the Group of Seven industrialized nations should be called next month or in April if the five-year-old world trade talks remain deadlocked. 
 Those talks, conducted under the auspices of the 105-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, have stalled over the demand by the United States, Canada and other food-exporting nations for lower farm subsidies, which they contend curtail their exports.
Without an accord from the GATT talks, Mr. Mollemann said, the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe will suffer enormously because important Western markets will be inaccessible to them.
"We can't leave it to negotiators of the second rank," Mr. Mollemann said. "It's too important."
 
Mandela Speaks
 Later in the session, Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, said South Africa under black majority rule would need a market economy to pull millions of blacks out of poverty, the Reuters news agency reported.
Mr. Mandela urged business executives to invest in South Africa but repeated his demand that economic sanctions not be lifted until an interim, broad-based government is brought in, ending apartheid, Reuters said. He also stressed that wealth and income must be redistributed.
President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa also urged the executives to invest in South Africa as it moved out of international isolation to a democratic future, Reuters said.
Mr. Mandela said the African National Congress was still discussing with business leaders whether a future government would nationalize some industries, according to Reuters.
The general feeling here was that there was little money available to stimulate the world economy or provide aid to Eastern Europe and that increased global trade is the best means to economic growth.
Summing up the feeling at the meeting of more than 2,000 officials, Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said: "Keeping markets open does not cost money, it just needs political energy. And nobody feels they have much money to spare." He predicted a sluggish growth of "not more than 2 to 3 percent" in Western economies next year.
The impasse in the GATT talks, while centered on agriculture, affects every aspect of the world's $4.3 trillion in annual trade. The European Community, led by France, is resisting calls for sharp cuts in farm subsidies, and Japan is reluctant to abandon its curbs on rice imports.
At the same time, Germany made it clear that while it was prepared to make great efforts to resolve the GATT impasse, it was not ready to spur economic growth by lowering its interest rates, which are at their highest levels in many years.
Concerned about inflation that is just above 4 percent, Germany raised its rates by a half-point in December. That angered some countries that saw the move as an unnecessary dampener on attempts to revive the world economy. High interest rates make borrowing money more expensive and tend to slow economic activity.
 
Criticism From Lithuania
 But Hans Tietenmeyer, deputy governor of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, said that controlling inflation remained a priority for Germany and that international economic coordination did not mean all the countries could follow the same policies. American interest rates have dropped steadily in the last year.
The German stand reflects a general mood among Western powers that domestic problems will not allow significant short-term initiatives to spur growth.
"The sense is that because of budgetary constraints, there's not much to be done in the short term beyond trying to keep markets open," said Mr. Volcker, who led the session on encouraging international growth. "There's some feeling of exhaustion in the West as the needs of so many countries are contemplated." He said the success of the GATT talks was vital, adding "the stakes are so big the odds must be good -- but by no means certain."
Vytautas Landsbergis, President of Lithuania, criticized the United States for not being forthcoming with aid. "Denmark has given the Baltic states $52 million, which is more than the United States," he said. "Is that not a little strange?"
He said his country needed $200 million as a stabilization fund for its planned currency, noting that this was a lot less than the roughly $6 billion sought by Russia. But Lithuania is getting little assistance, he said.
Andrei Fedorov, a prominent Russian economist, said chaos threatened the Commonwealth of Independent States if the West did not quickly provide substantial aid. "We should perhaps be thinking already of the second Commonwealth because this one is not working," he said. "I believe the Ukraine will soon defect."
Faced with such appeals, Wayne D. Angell, a Federal Reserve governor, said there was no point in providing stabilization funds before currencies actually operated as units of account. In Russia, the ruble has lost virtually all its value and been replaced by barter.
"Until Russia and other republics have a unit of value there is no point talking about a stabilization fund," he told a news conference.

HEADLINE: Battling Poverty's Ills Each Day, They Also Give to Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Donors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund supply the ammunition needed by seven charities to battle poverty and illness. But the nurses, teachers and social workers fighting that war have also sent donations, along with dispatches from the front lines describing the increasing needs of New York's poor, sick and disabled.
"In 17 years of working in public-funded employment and training projects, I have never witnessed such a severe need for basic social support, not to mention economic assistance," wrote Beverly O'Donnell of Brooklyn, who gave $50. 
 The staff at the Mount St. Ursula Speech Center for Communication and Learning in the Bronx wrote that they "work with children from poor homes -- in many cases, foster homes -- who come to us as an oasis." The note attached to their $25 contribution continued: "We know how important a helping hand can be in desperate circumstances, in these desperate times. We would like the money used wherever it's needed and hope it provides some measure of support to those who are struggling."
 
'We Feel Grateful'
 Although they spend their days helping others, these workers have turned to the Neediest Cases to cast a wider net of assistance. "I see people suffer every day but until I volunteered at the Manhattan State Psychiatric Center I had never seen first-hand the consequences of drug and family abuse," wrote Nancy M. Brozain, a nursing supervisor who works with cancer patients, who gave $200. "The neediest of this city deserve a chance and should know that people care."
Like many other contributors, they have given in thanks for their own good fortune and health. "For all the suffering and tragedy that we see at work and around us," began a letter from the night nursing supervisors, clinical instructors and secretaries at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, who gave $100, "we feel grateful for our health, our jobs and to God, who helps us through each night."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled. So far more than $4.6 million has been raised from almost 15,000 donations during the 80th annual appeal, which continues through Feb. 29.
The Times covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed on directly to seven charities. The money finances programs for people with AIDS, provides financial assistance for poor people who cannot afford necessary operations and supports neighborhood centers that provide children with places where they can study and play after school.
Some who work with the poor and the ill contributed to help those who never make it to their offices for help. "Everyday at least one panhandler approaches me on the subway or street asking for money," wrote Emil Chynn, a resident at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital who gave $24. "But one can never be sure such money will go to food rather than drink. My 'solution' has been to volunteer at the homeless shelter on West 168th Street and to donate to your fund each year. That way I know my efforts will go to the right things, the necessities of life to provide hope for these poor people in the cold without any money."

HEADLINE: Parts Pact With Japan May Backfire

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Since agreeing that Japanese auto makers would sharply increase their purchases of American auto parts, diplomats on both sides of the Pacific have only heightened the confusion over precisely what obligations the auto makers have undertaken. But automotive executives, economists and other experts are certain of this: Unless American suppliers swiftly adjust to the vastly different priorities set by Japanese car companies, President Bush has shaken hands on an agreement that may hasten the decline of the American parts industry.
"The agreement is going to backfire on the Big Three and the parts manufacturers in a big and dramatic way," predicted Robert B. Reich, the Harvard economist. He compared the latest measure with Japan's voluntary agreement in 1981 to limit the number of cars it shipped to the United States for a few years. 
 The goal then was to restrain sales of Japanese vehicles and give Detroit time to produce cars that were more competitive. Instead, it led to the establishment of Japanese assembly plants in the United States that only increased sales of Japanese cars.
"The fastest way to reduce the trade surplus will be to transfer suppliers here," Mr. Reich said. "Japanese auto makers have been working to develop American companies as suppliers, but with the additional pressure of time to comply with the agreement, that's going to take too long."
Earlier this month, Japanese auto makers told American negotiators they would nearly double their purchases of American-made parts, to $19 billion by 1994, up from about $10 billion in 1990.
The Japanese also pledged to raise the content of American parts for all Japanese models assembled in North America to 70 percent, from 50 percent currently. About 25 percent of the $41 billion American trade deficit with Japan stems from the huge volume of parts imported to the United States.
Less than two weeks after the trip, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan touched off a diplomatic storm by stating that the dollar figures were only "goals."
That statement prompted an angry "I told you so" from Lee A. Iacocca, chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, who harbors chronic suspicions of Japan's intentions.
Yutaka Kume, president of the Nissan Motor Company, criticized American executives for "anti-Japanese emotions." By the end of last week, Mr. Miyazawa tried to patch things up by saying in New York, "We will deliver all we promised you."
Beyond the posturing, however, remains the reality that politicians in both countries lack the authority to enforce what parts will be purchased from whom. Executives of American suppliers are left to wonder how the agreement will play out.
"The Japanese commitment was a step in the right direction," said Jack Reilly, chairman of Tenneco Automotive, the Tenneco Inc. subsidiary that makes mufflers and shock absorbers. But it "falls short of what is needed to insure a healthy U.S. automotive supply base."
 
Unclear Aspect of Agreement
 Executives of American parts suppliers who accompanied President Bush on his trip to Japan say Japanese auto makers promised "special consideration" with regard to America's 4,000 makers of auto parts. But it is not clear just how much new revenue will flow to the American parts makers, whose sales are about $100 billion annually; to the nearly 300 Japanese suppliers now operating in the United States, or to joint parts-making ventures of American and Japanese companies.
In any case, some of the revenue will supplant the value of parts imported from Japan and take a slice -- albeit a tiny one -- from the trade deficit.
The Honda Motor Company, for instance, said its goal was to buy $4.38 billion a year in American-made parts by 1995 for its assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, up from $2.5 billion bought in America last year. It also said that in the same time span, it would aim to double, to $560 million a year, its imports of American parts for its operations in Japan. Thus, the impact on the trade deficit would be slight.
"The agreement was nothing substantive," said Candace Howes, who teaches economics at the University of Notre Dame. "Japanese suppliers will get most of it, and it reflects decisions that were made three or four years ago to increase production of Japanese cars in American plants." Ms. Howes has contended that suppliers to Japan's auto assembly plants in the United States are wiping out the jobs of two Americans for every job they provide, based on the rising market share of Japanese cars, compared with American makes.
Heinz Prechter, president of the ASC Corporation of Southfield, Mich., which makes sunroofs and convertible tops for several auto makers, agreed that Japanese auto makers prefer Japanese suppliers "because they would rather deal with a known quantity than an unknown quantity." But he said the President's agreement "is very positive because it will encourage U.S. suppliers to become more active in Japan."
He added, "The Japanese business leaders are very smart." Because they understand the potential for a backlash against Japanese products by Americans, he continued, "they will do whatever has to be done to make the agreement work."
 
Enormous Misunderstanding
 Still, the uncertainty over how the agreement will play out speaks to the enormous cross-cultural misunderstanding that has grown up between the automotive industries of the two countries. The American side wants more business, but the Americans say they have been burned in the past when Japanese promises did not turn out as hoped.
The Japanese feel stung, too; they do not wish to be blamed for political tension between the countries, but they also resent having to alter their practices to accommodate less successful competitors. Privately, managers of Japanese auto makers are worried that they may be pressured to accept parts of less than top quality in the name of trade harmony, a notion scoffed at by the American parts makers.
But it is not easy for American suppliers to get purchase orders from Japanese auto makers. "I visited Toyota for 10 years before I got my first order," Mr. Prechter said. The Japanese value a long-term relationship between the car maker and the parts maker, based on mutual trust and disclosure of one another's plans. By contrast, he continued, Detroit cares mostly about which supplier can make the right part for the least amount of money.
 
A Relationship With Toyota
 Fred Hay, president of the automotive group of the United Technologies Corporation, which makes interior trim like instrument panels, described the company's relationship with the Toyota Motor Corporation, which began in 1984, as "tough, demanding and time-consuming." Toyota demanded top quality, buried United Technologies with technical requirements and demanded proprietary information about the company's costs.
Frequent, intensive meetings were held with Toyota engineers in Japan and Ann Arbor, Mich., where Toyota has a technical center. But the reward was a contract to supply the center consoles for the 1992 Toyota Camry, which is built in Georgetown, Ky. "Making that early commitment to Toyota's stringent requirements was difficult at first," Mr. Hay said. "I'm glad we had the foresight to stick with it."
A typical vehicle is assembled from more than 10,000 parts. Traditionally, as long as the price remained rock bottom and the quality was acceptable, a supplier could keep the business. But as sales of American cars fell in the 1980's, the sales of most suppliers declined, too.
 
Different Ways of Doing Business
 American parts makers tried to pick up new business by courting the Japanese. But Japanese auto makers conduct business differently. First and foremost, Japanese auto makers expect parts makers to provide their own designs, and many American suppliers lack engineering expertise. Secondly, Japanese auto makers require intricate and detailed planning that may begin years before the model goes into production.
"Many American suppliers have never had to undertake that kind of long-term thinking or show that amount of patience," said James Olson, senior vice president for public affairs for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. in Torrance, Calif.
Nevertheless, some American suppliers have adapted to Japanese rules. Tenneco, which makes Monroe shock absorbers and Walker mufflers, for example, began meeting with Nissan engineers in the late 1970's. Monroe failed to win a contract to supply shocks for the Nissan pickup truck built in Smyrna, Tenn., but a decade later got an order for shock absorbers for the Nissan Sentra compact car, also assembled in Smyrna.
"A lot of U.S. suppliers have gotten a little bit of business," said Mr. Reilly, chairman of Tenneco's automotive subsidiary. "The real test is to get more meaningful volumes. We have the capacity to ship a million shock absorbers to Japan; we ship 5,000."
 
Incentive to Buy American
 Financially, Japanese auto makers have every incentive to buy American, since the dollar is weak and the yen is strong. Indeed, Toyota, Nissan, Honda and others have opened technical centers in the United States, which are supposed to work with prospective American suppliers. The staffs at the centers are mostly English-speaking, American-trained engineers and designers.
If a supplier has trouble with a design, Toyota engineers are ready to assist. The auto maker is also exploring the possibility of engaging independent engineering companies, which are not found in Japan, to help suppliers, he said.
But some wonder about Japanese good faith.
"You heard some serious Detroit-bashing in Japan," said Michael Flynn, assistant director of the University of Michigan's transportation study project. "If we take the pressure off, we won't see much serious action."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Anger, Assumptions and the Rush to Limit Welfare

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
"WHEN a lot of people are out of work," President Warren Harding opined in 1921, "unemployment results."
Not until a quarter-century later, though, did the Federal Government begin a meaningful measurement of joblessness. Last week, more than a half-century after the Social Security Act was signed, the Senate passed Daniel Patrick Moynihan's bill to belatedly apply the same scrutiny to welfare dependency. 
 Today, Senator Moynihan's subcommittee on family policy will examine welfare rules imposed recently by New Jersey and other states desperately seeking to balance middle-class demands for fairness with the unmet needs of people for whom welfare is a way of life. New figures raise questions about the fundamental assumptions in some political solutions proposed so far.
In 1990, one of four New Yorkers was living in poverty -- the highest proportion ever recorded by city welfare officials. The poverty rate jumped to 25.2 percent from 20.7 percent the year before -- about twice the national rate and more than three times the rate for the rest of the state.
Who was poor? Nearly one in four families (their incomes were below the Federal Government's arbitrary poverty level, which is $10,560 for a family of three). Two-thirds of female-headed households with children -- up from about half the year before. And 4 in 10 children under the age of 18 -- meaning that nearly half of New York City's poor are youngsters.
The Human Resources Administration derived those numbers from the 1991 Current Population Survey, a small sample that nonetheless suggests troubling trends, the burden imposed on the city's taxpayers and why Mr. Moynihan fears the national consensus embodied three years ago in his Family Support Act may be evaporating.
Nine states cut basic benefits in 1991. Another 31 froze them. California proposes to slice grants by up to 25 percent. Two weeks ago, Gov. Jim Florio signed a comprehensive legislative package that makes New Jersey the only state to deny an additional subsidy -- $2.12 a day was standard -- for welfare mothers who have more children.
"In the 50 years since the Social Security Act was signed," Mr. Moynihan said, "we've never had a time that slowly but suddenly, with much greater force, the country is deciding that we're spending too much money on children.
"New Jersey is saying, 'Let's show that little 6-week-old to shape up or starve,' " the New York Democrat said. "It's happening all over the country. It all begins with David Duke and his talk about the threat of the welfare culture. It's because we're in a recession, because this is much larger issue, because welfare is a code word.
"You could also say, 'You want more abortions?' " the Senator said, which might be one consequence of the New Jersey law that could place some conservatives in an ideological bind. "This is a very ugly turn and it's what comes of denial."
Also of resentment and of ignorance. Which is why one goal of Mr. Moynihan's hearings is to answer New Jersey's $64 question: Were the revised welfare provisions grounded in mean-spirited anger or in constructive disincentives to enlarging the dependent population?
New Jersey's law conforms to the Family Support Act by encouraging education and job training -- indeed, by requiring it. But do welfare mothers bear more children merely to collect another $64 a month for each addition to a three-person household?
The law includes other anomalies, too. Wages are ordinarily deducted from welfare checks, but if a woman has a baby, she can keep her welfare grant and about $200 in monthly earnings. If she marries the child's natural father, his earnings are deducted from the mother's welfare grant, but if she marries someone else, he can earn up to $21,000 a year without affecting the family's grant. So much for family preservation.
New Jersey officials offer rationales for these provisions; critics are unconvinced. "You can go to Calcutta and see people living on the street and having another mouth to feed and they're not motivated by more money," said Cesar A. Perales, Deputy Mayor in New York and a former State Social Services Commissioner.
Despite President Bush's endorsement, it is arguable whether the New Jersey law will get needed Federal waivers or survive court challenges when it, in effect, reduces benefits for a new baby and its siblings.
"Sinking more innocent children deeper into poverty will not help solve a bigger problem: producing productive adults," said Richard P. Nathan, director of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany.
"Yes, we should require the heads of welfare families to work and help them to do so," Professor Nathan said. "The $64 question is whether we should penalize babies once they are born for having mothers at whom the legislature is angry."
If President Harding were alive today, he might conclude that when a lot of people are poor, poverty results. Officials today may not be much better informed. When society spells relief on the basis of frustration, not facts, its judgment may be just as poor as its population.

HEADLINE: Signs of Hope for Broadway: 22 Marquees Light Up Again

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The season of the darkened marquee is suddenly becoming the season of the booking bonanza. In the next three months, 22 shows -- nearly as many as opened in the entire 1990-91 season -- will open on Broadway, and producers have been eagerly seeking theaters to accommodate this burst of activity.
The spring lineup is also unusual in that it will bring to Broadway the largest contingent of Hollywood stars to act on the New York stage in years. Producers are counting on marquee names to attract investors -- and, they fervently hope, audiences -- to salvage a Broadway season that, until now, has been deeply disappointing to producers and plagued by a severe post-holiday audience slump that has been worsening by the week. At the same time, Off Broadway theaters are cutting back on productions and other programs, a new study has found. [Page C11.] 
 The incoming shows are "a huge number when you realize that there were 28 shows during the entire 1990-91 season," said George Wachtel, director of research for the League of American Theaters and Producers. So far this season, 15 new productions have opened.
The roster includes new plays by August Wilson, Lanford Wilson, Neil Simon and John Guare; revivals of three classic American musicals, "Guys and Dolls," "The Most Happy Fella" and "Man of La Mancha," and a London hit produced by Cameron Mackintosh, "Five Guys Named Moe." But there will be none of the extravagantly produced new musical spectacles that have been a staple of Broadway in the last decade, possibly reflecting the declining public taste for such shows, and certainly demonstrating the difficulty of raising the huge investments they require.
But the heavy pace of activity on Broadway does not reflect a complete turnaround for the commercial theater. Seven new shows are sponsored, in full or in part, by nonprofit, institutional theaters like the Lincoln Center Theater or the Manhattan Theater Club, which are renting Broadway theaters to accommodate their expanding activities. While these presentations will be eligible for Tony Awards, they do not spring from the creative efforts of commercial producers, and their revenues will not primarily enrich investors.
So glum has been the Broadway picture this season that even when all the new shows now planned open, a handful of theaters will remain dark unless other producers suddenly rush in with last-minute productions.
 
So Many Stars, So Little Space
 Nevertheless, few seasons on Broadway have been greeted with as much anticipation as this spring. If this derives partly from the contrast with the dismal state of the season so far, the enthusiasm is also linked to the Tinseltown factor: it has been a long time since so many names with Hollywood sheen have planned to illuminate the Great White Way. The stars coming soon to Broadway include Alan Alda, Alec Baldwin, Ellen Burstyn, Glenn Close, Joan Collins, Richard Dreyfuss, Gene Hackman, Gregory Hines, Judd Hirsch, Raul Julia, Jessica Lange and Al Pacino.
The fact that so many stars are available may be in part a consequence of the recession: cutbacks in Hollywood salaries and production schedules have made it impossible for many West Coast names to find quality vehicles at their "prices," according to several producers who spoke on condition of anonymity. A limited run on Broadway, with the prospect of an award or two, may be a career-enhancing way to ride out the recession.
So tight is the crush of new bookings that many of the new shows had difficulty finding their tentative theater homes. Some producers are actively rooting for the speedy demise of planned or current shows so that more desirable theaters will be freed for new productions.
The traditional post-holiday decline in audiences and ticket sales seems to have been worsened by a recession-plagued winter, and more and more Broadway shows have empty seats. A week ago, only two shows, "The Phantom of the Opera" and "Miss Saigon," were complete or near-complete sellouts, and sales were generally so low that even solid hits like "Dancing at Lughnasa" and "The Will Rogers Follies" had seats available. Two shows, "Park Your Car in Harvard Yard" and "Two Shakespearean Actors," say in their advertising that they are in their final weeks.
"Right now there are more empty theaters than at any time I can remember, and the recession has definitely affected our industry," said Roger Berlind, a producer. Not only do theatergoers have less money to spend on entertainment, he said, "but investors have been more reluctant to risk capital in a time when everything is marked down, and their house or their art is worth less than they thought."
Although the recession has not dried up venture capital on Broadway -- the spring lineup is evidence that substantial investment money is available -- angels are clearly more cautious. Not only are they not putting money in mega-musicals, but the emphasis now is also on straight plays, which account for 13 of the new productions and cost considerably less to produce than musicals. Among the nine musicals scheduled to open soon, most are revivals of proven hits rather than riskier original works.
Since awards generate publicity and sell tickets -- a Tony-winning show is usually assured of a run through July -- producers are exercising still more caution by bunching their opening nights shortly before the Tony deadline, April 29. They fear that Tony voters, like Oscar voters, have a limited attention span.
 
Broadway and the Economy
 Despite the impact of the economic climate on investment and ticket sales, some on Broadway say the recession has been kinder to the theater than to other sectors of New York City's economy. "At a time when investment in many other businesses is at the bottom, Broadway is doing very well indeed, given the number of new shows that are planned," said Harvey Sabinson, executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers.
"I don't believe that the recession has had all that much effect," said Bernard Jacobs, president of the Shubert Organization. "The retailing business in New York is terrible, but we haven't really seen that same negative downturn in the theater."
Investment money is available on Broadway. No organization keeps year-by-year comparisons of total investments in shows, and such figures could well be misleading anyway, since recent years have seen larger investments in individual shows but fewer shows opening.
But with straight plays costing up to $1.3 million to mount, and musicals generally from $4 million to $7 million, it is clear that this spring season involves an investment of at least $40 million.
What is also clear, however, is that productions from the institutional, nonprofit theater are more essential to Broadway than ever before, and the phenomenon of their role as tenants of Broadway real estate has every prospect of growing.
On average, plays and musicals are about 10 percent more expensive this year. Investors cite the increased costs of production, notably in stars' salaries, union wages and marketing expenses. Producers are diversifying their newspaper and television advertising and adding the expense of sophisticated direct-mail campaigns.
 
Some Limited Runs
 Star-studded shows like "Death and the Maiden," to be directed by Mike Nichols and featuring Mr. Hackman, Ms. Close and Mr. Dreyfuss, will need near-capacity audiences to make money in their limited runs. The producers of "Death and the Maiden" have said that the show, which is to open at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on March 17, will cost $1.3 million to mount for 26 weeks, the time the stars are available, and that Mr. Nichols's contract guarantees him about $13,000 a week, even before the show makes back its money.
The high hopes for spring contrast sharply with the sad statistical trail of what has been an abysmal season for hit plays and musicals to this point. For the 1991-92 season, which began after the Tony Awards on June 2, Broadway ticket receipts are down $1 million, and attendance is off by nearly half a million compared with a season ago, according to last week's Variety.
Even Broadway's powerhouses, the Cameron Mackintosh mega-musicals, have been buffeted by recessionary gales. Although "Miss Saigon" and "The Phantom of the Opera" are nearly sold out every night, Mr. Mackintosh said advance ticket purchases have fallen off.
"On both sides of the Atlantic, the trend toward gigantic advances has come to a halt, due to the recession," he said. "I have five shows running in London, and all of them have 20 percent less in advance bookings than a year ago. The same is becoming true of the advance here."
 
Some Price Cuts
 Mr. Mackintosh said the economy was also the reason he established a new $15 price for hundreds of seats at "Miss Saigon," "Phantom" and "Les Miserables," starting March 9. The lowest prices have previously been $35 at "Phantom" and $30 at "Saigon" and "Les Miz."
Noting that "Miss Saigon" recouped its $10.9 million investment in 39 weeks, Mr. Mackintosh said that in deciding to lower the top price for 248 front-mezzanine seats from $100 to $65 on March 9, "the economy certainly was a factor," he said. "But also, we didn't want it to be perceived that all the seats to the show were $100."
On Jan. 24, the producers of "The Will Rogers Follies" lowered the cost of the last two rows of mezzanine seats from $50 to $20 on Mondays through Thursdays. And some tickets for "Grand Hotel" have been reduced to $7.50, the price of a movie admission in Manhattan.
The question of whether things are looking up or down in the commercial theater cannot be answered until the returns are in on the star-filled spring. In the matter of success, Broadway has a very short memory; if "Nick and Nora" had been a triumph, even the dismal fall might be more fondly remembered than the sad statistics could justify. If the incoming shows produce a fair number of hits, "the first half of the season will be forgotten quickly," Mr. Sabinson said.

HEADLINE: Recession Affecting Theaters Off Broadway

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
A new study of the recession's effects on theater Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway indicates that companies have been forced to cut back on productions, curtail audience-building educational programs, reduce staff and slash outreach programs in hospitals, community centers and homes for the elderly.
Nevertheless, while budgets have been cut and the number of productions is down, attendance and ticket sales have risen, according to experts on Off Broadway. And a significant number of productions by Off Broadway companies in the last year have achieved major success with critics and audiences, underscoring the continuing strength of Off Broadway as a creative center of theater in New York City. 
 The study by the Alliance of Resident Theaters of New York, a service group for 136 nonprofit theater organizations in the five boroughs, shows that budgets have dropped 19 percent since 1989 and that a further 16 percent decline is projected for the remainder of the season.
 
A Continuing Toll
 On Friday, Mayor David N. Dinkins released a preliminary four-year financial plan for New York City. It does not call for any new cuts in the culture budget, which aids many of the nonprofit companies that make up the alliance's membership. Nevertheless, the toll of previous budget reductions "is very sobering," said Ginny Louloudes, executive director of the alliance.
The organization counts among its members the Circle Repertory Company, the Ensemble Studio Theater, the Intar Hispanic American Theater, Lincoln Center Theater, the Manhattan Theater Club, the New York Shakespeare Festival, Pan Asian Repertory Theater, Playwrights Horizons, Second Stage Theater and Theater for the New City.
Twenty-six alliance members participated in the study and gave information to the alliance on condition that they not be named. Four organizations reported annual budgets of more than $1 million, four had budgets between $600,000 and $999,000, six between $300,000 and $599,000, four between $101,000 and $299,000 and eight less than $100,000. "We believe that the findings reflect an accurate picture of the current situation of nonprofit theaters," Ms. Louloudes said.
The study found that financing from the New York State Council on the Arts had decreased in recent years by an average of 66 percent for the alliance members studied. Support from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs has dropped by an average of 46 percent.
Decline in financial support has been so devastating that 77 percent of the theaters studied have lost corporate financing. Donations from individual contributors declined an average of $73,718. Staff size at the alliance theaters has plummeted by an average of 30 percent since 1989, and more than half of the organizations said they would have to lay off more staff members by the end of the current season.
More visibly for those in the theater, companies participating in the alliance study will produce 29 percent fewer shows than they did two years ago and hire 25 percent fewer actors than in the 1989-90 season.
 
A Growing Audience
 Paradoxically, even while they have lost private and Government money, audiences and ticket revenues have grown for many shows Off and Off Off Broadway. This season has already produced successes including "Lips Together, Teeth Apart," "Marvin's Room," "Return to the Forbidden Planet," "Tubes" by the Blue Man Group, "Beau Jest" and "From the Mississippi Delta."
Since no totals are tallied for Off Broadway attendance or ticket receipts, exact comparisons between this and previous years cannot be made. "I'm on the phone all the time with theater owners and producers, and I can tell you that audiences are up," said George Elmer, secretary-treasurer of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers. The group, a trade association for commercial and nonprofit organizations in New York City, represents 87 theaters, producers and general managers.
"If upscale folks used to think that Off Broadway was merely some out-of-left-field people mumbling poetry, they think so no more," Mr. Elmer said. "They are coming in greater numbers than ever before, thanks to the success of 'Driving Miss Daisy,' 'Steel Magnolias' and 'Other People's Money.' "
"Grosses are up, too, because ticket prices are up," he said. "The average Off Broadway show is up $2 over what it was two years ago." Currently, Off Broadway ticket prices range from a high of $38.50 to a low of $5 or even less at some Off Off Broadway venues, compared to a top of $100 for the musical "Miss Saigon" and $45 for the play "Lost in Yonkers" on Broadway.
 
Broadway's Loss Is Their Gain
 Off Broadway shows may also have benefited from the dearth of new productions on Broadway in the first half of this season. "As the number of dramas on Broadway has dwindled, more and more people are looking to Off Broadway for the experience of live theater," Mr. Elmer said.
Audiences have ballooned for some membership theaters, too. "Subscriptions are up to nearly 15,000, an all-time high for us," said Barry Grove, general manager of the Manhattan Theater Club, which has produced such hits as this season's "Lips Together, Teeth Apart." Seeking to explain the reason for growing audiences, he said, "People need theater more than ever in a time of economic hardship."
Even for a company like the Manhattan Theater Club, blessed with comparatively large, diverse financing, the cuts in Government support will directly affect audiences. Not only has city financing for the group been reduced, but the one-third reduction in the budget of City Center, the theater's home, also means that fewer visiting companies will perform there, thus reducing the number of organizations sharing City Center's operating expenses. Thus, more than $50,000 has been added to the Manhattan Theater Club's operating costs this season.
Because of the red ink, Mr. Grove said, Manhattan Theater Club will produce one less play this year than originally scheduled, offering its subscribers an eight-play season instead of a nine-play season.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE THAW;
'The Residual Role for the Military'

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
"The opportunity for the Western democracies at present is to establish a vision of a new world order. It's thefirst opportunity of conceiving of such a vision and moving toward it since Roosevelt and Churchill put forth their vfision of a post-World War II world. They were looking to a world in which relations among nations were based on a rule of law and a form of collective security founded on the United Nations. That is possible now.
 "I'm not so naive as to believe this post-cold-war world would be without conflict. There have been 125 wars leading to 40 million deaths, largely in the third world, after World War II and before the Gulf War. These were not a function of ideological differences between East and West. They were a function of the age-old causes of war -- boundary disputes, economic conflicts, ethnic tensions. 
 "The danger is not that some group of nations will engage in conflict that will endagner the military structure of the great powers. The danger is that the great powers will fail to follow through on the vision. If the United States will give leadership in that direction and the other great powers will follows, than I believe it should be possible to cut military expenditures in the world roughly in half.
 "The residual role for the military is to deal with the conflicts that can't be deterred -- such as the Gulf. We have many, many problems in the world, such as the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. We've got all kinds of common enemies and challenges, such as the sustainability of development in broadest sense around the world. Population stability and environmental stability are going to be increasingly serious problems."
