HEADLINE: American Express Plan To Get Cash

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Hoping to build up its financial cushion, the American Express Company announced yesterday that it planned to sell to the public a minority stake in its profitable information-services company.
American Express said it would sell up to 45 percent of its Information Services Corporation in an initial public offering. The company did not say how much the offering would raise, although analysts estimated it could be up to $800 million. 
 Analysts said the offering was intended to raise capital to funnel to American Express's travel-related services division. Profits were down sharply last year in the travel unit primarily because of recession-related losses from the Optima credit card operation. The company set aside $265 million in October to deal with defaults on Optima accounts.
 
Concentrating Resources
 "They want to concentrate their resources and capital on getting the problems squared away in the travel area," said Charles M. Vincent, an analyst wih Provident National Bank in Philadelphia. In 1991, profits in the travel division, the company's largest, dropped 59 percent, to $396 million, from $956 million in 1990.
The Information Services unit will be renamed the First Data Corporation. The unit processes Mastercard and Visa card transactions in the United States and Britain. In 1991, it handled more than 1.7 billion transactions for 700 financial institutions.
The unit earned $118 million last year, an increase of 15 percent from 1990. Its 1991 revenues were $995 million, a 20 percent increase from 1990.
James D. Robinson 3d, chairman and chief executive of American Express, said, "The public offering will raise substantial funds for American Express that will be available for general corporate purposes at a time when a strong capital base is especially important for financial services companies."
American Express stock rose $1.625 yesterday to close at $22.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"This is selling the silverware," said John Keefe, an analyst at Lipper Analytical Services. "They are not really starving for capital at this point, but they are probably getting a little hungry."
Mr. Keefe said the move would ease concern about American Express in the credit markets. In the fall, Moody's Investors Service downgraded its rating on American Express debt to A1, from Aa2.
"This is not a major portion of their business but it is growing rapidly," said Mr. Vincent, the analyst.
Last month, American Express executives said the company was exploring the sale of a stake in its Lehman Brothers investment banking arm.
 
Estimating a Price
 Analysts estimated that an information-processing company would sell for about 15 times earnings, which would value First Data at $1.77 billion. Based on that, selling a 45 percent stake would raise $800 million for American Express.
Most of the offering will be shares currently held by American Express. A small portion will be new shares issued by First Data.
Richard Schmidt, an analyst with the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said that in addition to providing more potential reserves for Optima, the proceeds could provide a cushion if more reserves were needed to cover bad real estate investments made by the company's Balcor unit.
"There are any number of areas where they may be called on to belly up to the bar with more resources," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
McGraw-Hill Profit Off 12%

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
McGraw-Hill Inc. yesterday reported lower earnings for the fourth quarter and year, largely because of a loss of advertising stemming from the weak economy.
 The company said net income in the fourth quarter fell 12 percent, to $45.4 million, or 93 cents a share, from $51.4 million, or $1.05 a share, a year earlier. Revenues edged up 1.8 percent, to $568.1 million from $558.1 million. 
 The New York-based company said continued weakness in advertising, construction and computer markets led to a 33.2 percent drop in profits before taxes and interest in the quarter in its information and publication services group, which includes Business Week magazine.
 In financial services, which includes the Standard & Poor's Corporation, operating profits jumped 13.3 percent in the quarter, in part because of expansion overseas and record issuance of new debt. S.& P. is one of the country's leading debt-rating agencies.
 Profits in educational and professional publishing slipped 24.2 percent. Broadcasting profits fell 38.1 percent in the quarter, the company said.
 For the year, McGraw-Hill's net slipped 14 percent, to $148.0 million, or $3.03 a share, from $172.5 million, or $3.53 a share. Revenues were essentially flat at $1.94 billion.

HEADLINE: An Introduction to the Joys of Biblio-Browsing

BYLINE: By ELEANOR BLAU

 BODY:
Exploring the shelves of a library with her fingers the other day, Karen Eisenstadt, who is blind, found a book in Braille that she had not known existed and that may help her in her work in an unemployment office.
The book was on a shelf of the new Andrew Heiskell Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped at 40 West 20th Street, and Ms. Eisenstadt was surprised not only at her find but also at the very act of discovery -- for she had never browsed before. Accustomed since childhood to the help of librarians, she had not experienced serendipity. 
 "I never thought of using the library that way," said Ms. Eisenstadt, who heads a citizens' committee that advised planners of the library.
The six-floor library, which opened in December, is the first public library in the country to offer a wide range of Braille, large-print and recorded books accessible to patrons on open shelves.
Braille and large-print signs guide readers through the stacks, and lighting is glare-free. The information desk is near the entrance, but is off to the left, so users can walk freely along the right, using the wall for guidance if necessary.
There are lounge chairs, tables and study carrels wired for audio playback equipment and for closed-circuit television magnifiers that enlarge print. A children's room has a stuffed lion, bear and panda, and a meeting room features a piano.
"It sort of puts you on a level with a sighted person," said Virginia Bass, who is blind and also a member of the citizens' advisory panel.
Louis Berkel, an assistant branch librarian, said that was the intention. "The idea is to make this function as closely as possible to a regular library," he said.
The library is open for walk-in use from 1 to 5 P.M. weekdays.
The library is so new, however, that walk-in use has not yet made a dent in statistics. About 85 percent of its material is still circulated by mail order, as it was at the site it replaces: a dilapidated library on Spring Street that never was envisioned as a place people could visit and use.
 
An Intricate Mail System
 To handle that volume -- mailing out 2,500 recorded and Braille books each day and processing incoming material -- the library has a complex, high-tech system adapted from industrial use and guided by computers. It is believed to be the most fully automated system in use by any library for the blind.
All six floors are joined by pneumatic vertical lifts and conveyors resembling airport baggage carriers. Tow lines recessed in the loading dock floor haul heavy bulk mail to a sorting desk. The mail is then placed in totes that go up spiral tracks to the third floor.
Revolving storage carousels -- like clothes racks in drycleaning establishments -- hold returned books, most of which have already been requested by other patrons. The computer compares requests with returns and then generates mailing labels for items to be reshipped.
The Andrew Heiskell Library, named for the former board chairman and current trustee of the New York Public Library, occupies the bottom half of a 12-story former warehouse built in 1910.
Renovated with $16 million appropriated by New York State, it is a sort of hybrid -- managed by the New York Public Library, yet part of a Library of Congress network of 53 regional libraries for the blind and physically handicapped. The library serves all of New York City and Long Island and gets most of its books and recordings from the Library of Congress.
 
A Fraction of Potential
 It also received private money, for an outdoor reading terrace on the second floor, for instance, and for some equipment and material.
The library has areas for volunteers to record books not available from the Library of Congress.
And there is a room for repairing the special listening machines that play cassettes and flexible disks for the blind. The library repairs not only its own machines but also those that are loaned to all eligible patrons for home use. The recordings are on non-commercial speeds to prevent their recreational use by people who do not need them.
The second floor is not yet open to the public, because of a lack of staff members.
Envisioning more staff members and longer hours in some happier economic time, Tara M. Phethean, a library spokeswoman, said the library now has 14,000 active patrons. The estimated potential number, she said, is 140,000.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKET;
Dollar Ends Session Mixed As Germans Reach Pay Pact

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against European currencies yesterday but rose against the Japanese yen as the market appeared to worry about the potential inflationary impact of a German wage settlement.
Gold prices rose overseas but fell in United States trading. Gold closed at $356.70 an ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange, down from $357.00 on Friday. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $355.75, off $1.00. 
 Traders said the dollar had initially fallen on a report suggesting that the United States manufacturing economy continued to fall in January, but then the currency recovered.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of business activity was unchanged at 47.4 percent. When the index registers under 50 percent, it indicates the manufacturing economy is declining.
Of more concern was the settlement of a German steelworkers contract that offered higher wages. The dollar initially rose against the mark on news a strike had been averted, but then fell as some traders grew concerned that the settlement could be inflationary if it set a pattern for other industries.
Inflationary concern could prompt the German central bank to keep interest rates at their current high levels, said Paul Yarden, a corporate currency dealer at Credit Suisse in New York. That could hurt the dollar since it makes investments in the mark more attractive.
In Europe, the dollar fetched 1.5975 German marks, down from 1.6070 late Friday. In New York, the dollar traded at 1.6000 marks, down from 1.6110 late Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.13 yen, to a closing 125.65 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 125.60 yen. But in New York, the dollar closed at 126.20 yen, up from 125.75 late Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7995, from $1.7905 late Friday. The pound cost $1.7961 in New York, more expensive than $1.7870 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.4265 Swiss francs, down from 1.4333; 5.4525 French francs, down from 5.4870; 1202.00 Italian lire, down from 1,211.00, and 1.1753 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17475.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Dividend News Gets Better; Often Bad News for Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Notwithstanding highly publicized actions by Bethlehem Steel and Westinghouse, the number of companies providing bad dividend news to shareholders is rapidly falling, an indication that the worst of the recession may be over.
At the same time, the number of companies announcing higher dividends is on the rise. Oddly, in the past, such increases in good news have often been followed by bad news on stock prices. 
 Figures released yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation showed that only 11 companies stopped paying dividends in January, among them the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. That figure was down from 28 a year earlier and from 18 in December and was the lowest for any month since August 1989, well before the recession began.
There was also a drop in the number of companies cutting payouts to shareholders. There were just 11 such announcements, less than half the 24 companies that announced such moves in January 1990 and down from 16 in December. One of the January announcements was made by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which cut its dividend by almost half last week, citing losses from its financial services operation.
Similarly, the report showed that 124 companies announced dividend increases during the month, up from 112 a year earlier and 102 in December. That figure was the highest of any month since April 1990, also before the start of the recession, which officially began in July of that year.
It was the fourth month of the last five in which more companies raised dividends than in the month a year earlier, but those increases are coming off a depressed base, the period between the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the allied victory over Iraq. It was during that period that pessimism, among corporate managements as well as consumers, reached a peak.
While the number of companies providing good news is up, the overall level of dividends for the Standard & Poor's 500 has just began to budge. The current indicated level of dividends for the index, assuming an investor bought a portfolio of fractional shares for $408.79, the index level at the end of January, and assuming that all 500 companies make no changes in dividends, would be $12.16, the same as a month earlier but up 5 cents from the end of November. That would mean a dividend yield of 2.97 percent, a figure that is near the low end of the historical range.
That fact has been cited by some as a warning that the stock market could be vulnerable. But the market sometimes moves up rapidly for a time, even after reaching such a level. In 1987, the dividend return fell below 3 percent as early as February, but prices kept rising until August, by which time the return was down to 2.6 percent, the lowest in recent history.
Another indicator that could warn of trouble for stock prices is the dividend-dip indicator, which is based on comparisons of the number of companies raising payouts over a six-month period, compared with the period a year earlier. Historically, the stock market has tended to decline after the number of companies raising payouts begins to rise, and to rise when the number of companies increasing dividends is on the decline. Presumably, that reflects the fact that the stock market often moves as a leading indicator of economic conditions, while dividend actions are lagging indicators.
Over the last six months, 568 companies announced higher dividends, 12 more than in the period a year earlier. It was the first time the six-month comparison was positive since June 1989. A month later, the figure turned negative, providing a buy signal for stocks when the Dow Jones industrial average was at 2,660.66. That index ended January at 3,223.39, an increase of 21 percent.
The dividend-dip indicator has sometimes provided early sell signals. It turned negative in 1987 at the end of February, when the Dow was well below the peak it would eventually reach before the market crashed in October. For that reason, back-tracking the index indicates better performance for an investor who followed it only twice a year, at the end of June and December. But an investor who followed every move would also have substantially outperformed the market since the mid-1950's, the longest period for which comparable data are available.
Excluding dividend income, and excluding the interest that would be gained from investing in cash during the periods when an investor was out of the stock market, an investor who bought the stocks in the Dow industrials when the first buy signal was given at the end of August 1956, and followed each sign thereafter, would have seen a profit of 805 percent through the end of last month, compared with 541 percent for a buy-and-hold investor.
Using only the semiannual signals, and begining at the end of 1956, the comparable figures would be 1,081 percent for the dividend-dip follower, and 545 percent for the buy-and-hold investor.

HEADLINE: Pratt & Whitney's Comeback Bid

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HARTFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
After losing much of the aircraft engine business to General Electric during the 1980's, Pratt & Whitney appears to be making a comeback.
Lackadaisical customer service, with erratic parts supplies, are only bad memories. Now, a leaner company has a head start in the contest to supply a new generation of wide-body aircraft with the most powerful airline engines ever built. 
 Sales to airlines are critical to Pratt & Whitney and to its corporate parent, the United Technologies Corporation, the nation's second-largest aerospace concern after the Boeing Company.
As military orders decline with the end of the cold war, and President Bush lays plans for further cuts, Pratt is expecting to lay off thousands of workers in central Connecticut. The jobs of thousands more depend on winning civilian orders.
Pratt's strategy is to match the General Electric Company's lower production costs through internal efficiencies and international alliances.
Pratt and G.E., with Rolls-Royce P.L.C. a distant third, are vying to power the large two-engine airliners that are emerging as the dominant type. Some analysts estimate that engine sales could total $20 billion over the decade.
Officials of Pratt & Whitney, the largest single division of United Technologies, are hoping that the new PW4000 series will become the best-selling high-powered engines.
United Airlines, the initial customer for the new Boeing 777 wide body, chose them over the offerings of G.E. and Rolls-Royce to power a fleet of planes scheduled to fly in 1995. All Nippon Airways, formerly a G.E. customer, also chose the PW4000 for its fleet of 777's.
Last year, Pratt officials said they won 39 percent of the firm orders for engines on wide-body aircraft, compared with 49 percent for G.E. and 12 percent for Rolls-Royce. G.E. said that Pratt's accounting was close to its own.
Layoffs and plant closings, Pratt says, are part of an effort to become as efficient as G.E. "We estimate that G.E. has had a 5 to 10 percent cost advantage over Pratt," Arthur E. Wegner, an executive vice president of United Technologies, told analysts last month. He said the company's goal was to become the low-cost producer by 1994.
 
Forging International Alliances
 Pratt & Whitney is also emulating G.E. by forging international alliances to spread the cost and risk of developing new engines. G.E. has parceled out 45 percent of its new engine project to French and Japanese companies.
United Technologies' chairman, Robert F. Daniell, said that last year's deal to develop jet engines jointly with a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany exemplified Pratt's direction. Since airplane and engine sales are politically influenced in many parts of the world, links to local companies give a supplier insider status and also help reduce outlays.
The new engines -- capable of developing more than 90,000 pounds of thrust, compared with about 40,000 for engines on a 757 -- reflect changes in the airline business.
Although the recession has reduced air travel, airlines and aircraft suppliers are optimistic about the longer-term trend. Because few new airports are being built, airlines are buying bigger airplanes, to put more passengers on each available flight.
The Boeing 777 embodies the airlines' thinking. In an all-economy configuration, it can carry more than 400 passengers, second only to the huge 747 in capacity. Both Boeing and Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, are discussing the possibility of building even larger planes, carrying 600 passengers or more, to fly early in the next century.
Meanwhile, the number of engines per airplane is shrinking. The Boeing 747 has four, the McDonnell Douglas MD-11 has three, but the 777 will have only two, despite being designed with enough range to cross oceans.
 
A Future for Twin Engines
 "The future is with twins," said Selwyn D. Berson, president of Pratt & Whitney's commercial engine business. Twin-engine airplanes consume less fuel and require less maintenance than those with three or four engines. These are important cost considerations for airlines in an era of deregulation.
The airlines are also confident that the big twin engines are highly reliable, since they will be seeking certification from the Federal Aviation Administration to fly over oceans, with a safe landing place up to three hours away.
Boeing's most recent models, the 757 and 767, also have only two engines, as does the forthcoming Airbus A330.
Since airlines like to use just one brand of engine, so as to reduce parts inventories and the complexity of maintenance, winning an airline's initial order on new airplanes like the 777 assures an engine maker of orders for more engines when new airplanes are purchased.
 
Pratt's Lead Over Rivals
 G.E. has won only one 777 order, with British Airways P.L.C. G.E. has faced criticism for paying a high price to buy the airline's maintenance operation at about the same time that the order was placed, to take the order away from Rolls-Royce, British Air's traditional supplier.
Rolls has won only one 777 competition, a small order from Thai Airways. Over all, Pratt officials say they have won 55 percent of the competitions for large engines since the PW4000 first went into service in 1987.
Pratt & Whitney and General Electric are using sharply different strategies for the big new engines. Pratt is increasing the power of its existing PW4000 line, while G.E. is developing an entirely new engine it calls the GE90. Each is the most powerful civilian engine its company has ever produced.
Pratt officials say their new engine is based on a design that has proved itself by flying millions of miles, assuring its reliability. "We are the lowest-risk engine," Mr. Berson said.
General Electric says it is looking to the future with its new design, which will be capable of greater power than Pratt's. Boeing already has plans for stretch and extended-range versions of the 777 that will require more thrust. The proposed superjets -- Boeing has been showing Asian airlines a 747 with a full upper deck -- would probably require greater power, as well.
"We are designing the engine for up to 95,000 pounds of thrust," said Ronald E. Welsch, general manager of the GE90 project. The company plans to win F.A.A. certification to operate the engine at 87,400 pounds, then tune it down to 75,000 pounds for early versions of the 777. He added that the ability easily to increase power gave airlines more flexibility in choosing aircraft.
Analysts said the Pratt & Whitney engine might be better suited to smaller aircraft flying shorter routes, and the GE90 for larger aircraft on longer routes.
 
New Fans Have Huge Diameter
 "When you get 90,000 pounds of thrust and beyond, G.E. will probably have the advantage" in efficiency, said Paul H. Nisbet, an analyst with Prudential Research.
More power means bigger in the jet engine business. The fan in front of the PW4000 for the 777 will have a diameter of 112 inches. The GE90 fan will measure 123 inches, more than 10 feet, in diameter. Boeing officials say the cylindrical housings holding the engines on the 777's wings will be wider than the entire body of the 727.
More powerful versions of the Pratt & Whitney engine would use a fan more than 140 inches in diameter, and G.E. also plans to use wider fans in the enhanced version of its engine.
 
Strategies for Cutting Weight
 The enormous size of the fans has forced both companies to push their technology to hold down weight. Pratt & Whitney is sticking with metal but is hollowing out its titanium blades 60 percent. G.E. has decided to switch to a composite of graphite fiber and epoxy plastic.
Rolls-Royce's experiments with a composite fan almost put the company out of business in the early 1970's, when the blades failed to survive hits by birds. Mr. Welsch said that materials had improved strikingly in the last 20 years and that computer technology now enabled more precise analysis than was possible 20 years ago.
But Marnix A. J. Hoogewerff, an engineering manager at Pratt & Whitney, said his company had chosen a more sensible course. "We do not think there is enough weight advantage with composite fan to overcome the risk," he said. "We can come within a hair of the weight using metal."

HEADLINE: Careers;
Insecurities In the Ranks Of Managers

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THESE days middle managers with jobs worry about how secure their positions are. Those without jobs wonder not only how long they must search for new ones but also how much security they will have once they find a new one.
Jerome M. Rosow, who heads the Work In America Institute Inc., a research organization, based in Scarsdale, N.Y., thinks such managers may not have to worry much in the future. He says the pendulum that has swung away from job security for middle managers will swing back again. 
 "It will take a while longer, perhaps until the year 2000," he said in an interview last week. He noted that a few leading companies like Pfizer, Merck and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing had kept the idea of job security for managers as a principle.
Mr. Rosow deplored the trend of layoffs of managers, pointing to the effect on morale and productivity at a time when global competition demands more of both. As a result, he said that even now he was urging companies to reconsider their approach and to instill a sense of more job security among their work force, especially among the managers.
His institute regularly holds productivity forums for leading companies in the industrial and service areas, like General Electric, Miller Brewing and American Express; for big labor unions, like the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, and for governmental units like the Department of Defense, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York City and New York State's Department of Labor. Until the mid-1980's these companies and institutions tended to be committed to not reducing staffs through layoffs -- an unwritten social contract understood by the managers of those days.
"Then it all fell apart starting in 1984," Mr. Rosow said. "It's amazing how fast the situation changes. I think it was poor management. American managers must take a harder look in the mirror and not look for scapegoats. It was a matter of a long-term social contract with workers and managers collapsing."
"The loss of the social contract has profound effects on more than two million managers and professionals who lost jobs during the 1970's and 1980's." Mr. Rossow said, stressing that the threat diminishes both the financial and emotional security of the managers and their familes.
He calls for a resumption of the practice of providing assistance for managers who do a good job but are involuntarily displaced through no fault of their own. Such corporate help might involve placement in another part of the company, or outplacement services paid for by the company -- the help of a professional firm dedicated to assisting the displaced manager with resume writing, psychological support, office space with secretaries and telephones.
There should also be adequate bridging money, which Mr. Rosow describes as "maintenance of income and benefits, and dignity during the transition to the next job." A few companies like Polaroid have maintained this policy despite its large numbers of layoffs in recent years, but many others that once had generous policies have changed or eliminated them as the number of managers dismissed increased sharply.
But there has recently been some good news for middle managers and top managers. The Association of Executive Search Consultants Inc. reports that "maybe the end is in sight" for the recession and poor hiring opportunities. It said last week that statistics compiled for the fourth quarter of 1991 indicated a 15 percent gain over the third quarter of 1991 and a 10 percent gain in searches for managers compared with the final quarter of 1990.
This appears to indicate "the beginning of the long-awaited economic turnaround," the association said. Its members include more than 100 management recruiting firms that specialize in finding managers for jobs paying more than $60,000 yearly.

HEADLINE: RJR Reports Profits for Quarter and Year

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it earned $161 million, or 14 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1991, compared with a loss of $13 million for the comparable period in 1990. It also reported a profit for 1991, its first full-year profit since the company was acquired in a leveraged buyout in 1987.
For the year, the company earned $368 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with a $429 million loss in 1990. That difference was largely the result of lower interest payments. It paid $2.1 billion in interest in 1991, compared with $3 billion a year earlier. 
 During the year, the company paid off $4.3 billion, leaving a still-hefty debt of $14.4 billion from the buyout, the largest in United States history, which left it $29.1 billion in debt.
For the fourth quarter, RJR's sales were $3.98 billion, up 7.9 percent from $3.69 billion a year earlier.
For the year, sales were up 7.9 percent, to $14.99 billion, from $13.88 billion in 1990. Operating income rose 3.9 percent, to $2.93 billion from $2.82 billion.
Saying 1991 "really was a milestone year" for the company, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., RJR's chairman and chief executive, declared, "We put the LBO behind us several years ahead of schedule."
The company's share price rose 25 cents, to $10.50, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Two of RJR's three main businesses performed well during the fourth quarter, food and international tobacco, while the third main business, United States tobacco, declined.
Overseas, sales of tobacco rose 12 percent in the quarter, and operating profits were up 10 percent, because of gains in Europe and the Middle East. Operating profits of the domestic tobacco business fell 11 percent.
Over all, tobacco sales were up 6.8 percent for the quarter, to $2.20 billion from $2.06 billion.
 
Declines for Winston and Salem
 "Winston and Salem have been losing a lot of market share" to bargain brands, said Ronald B. Morrow, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. In addition, Philip Morris's Marlboro brand gained share last year.
Food sales in the fourth quarter were $1.78 billion, up 9.2 percent, from $1.63 billion for the quarter in 1990. Operating profits rose 11 percent in the quarter for the food group.
The company also took advantage of lower interest rates to refinance some of its debt in 1991.

HEADLINE: Neanderthals: Dead End or Ancestor?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
EVER since Neanderthals were discovered nearly a century and a half ago, they have been seen as something less than fully human. Their bones suggest that they were beetle-browed, squat, thick-boned, heavily muscled and incredibly strong, with short forearms and shinbones, a face pulled so far forward that the chin disappears, a side-to-side gait and a grip that might break a person's fingers.
But anthropologists now believe that Neanderthals closely approached the earliest modern humans in intellect and level of culture, and in some regions may even have equaled them.
Were Neanderthals our ancestors or an evolutionary dead end? 
 Debate is flaring once more over the relationship between modern humans and Neanderthals in the period between 200,000 and 35,000 years ago, when the Neanderthals lived. One school of thought, led by Dr. Christopher B. Stringer of the Natural History Museum in London, holds that Neanderthals were driven to extinction and replaced by modern humans who originated in Africa about 200,000 years ago. Another school, led by Dr. Milford Wolpoff of the University of Michigan, argues that modern humans evolved from Neanderthals in Europe and from other archaic species of Homo sapiens in other parts of the Old World.
Everyone agrees that the earliest ancestors of both Neanderthals and modern humans appeared in Africa at least 5 million years ago. Eventually they evolved into a pre-human creature called Homo erectus, which migrated out of Africa into the rest of the Old World. Separate populations of Homo erectus then evolved in different places into the various archaic versions of Homo sapiens, including the Neanderthals of Europe. The argument over Neanderthals' relationship to modern humans is about what happened after that.
Some of the latest evidence bearing on the debate is to be examined at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Chicago this Saturday.
In Dr. Stringer's view, anatomically modern humans evolved from an archaic form of Homo sapiens in Africa and then, about 100,000 years ago, swept out of Africa to colonize Europe, Asia and eventually the rest of the world. There was little or no interbreeding between the moderns and archaic forms of Homo sapiens like the Neanderthals, in his view.
But the takeover by the modern humans was probably not a conquest or genocide. "There was no holocaust," said Dr. Stringer."It would have been an economic competition" for food and other resources, "one in which the Neanderthals gradually lost out." The replacement took thousands of years, he says, because the Neanderthals and moderns were so closely matched intellectually and culturally; otherwise, it would have happened much more rapidly.
Dr. Wolpoff, on the other hand, says Neanderthals were ancestors of modern Europeans, although the evolving Europeans of that era may have interbred with their counterparts in other regions. Dr. Wolpoff and those who support him cite archeological evidence from central Europe that, they say, shows that the earliest modern humans there had some clearly Neanderthal features.
Furthermore, says the Wolpoff school, the evolution of modern humans was more complicated than Dr. Stringer would have it, taking different paths and twists in different parts of the Old World. In Israel, they say, where Neanderthals overlapped with early moderns for about 50,000 years, the two populations were intellectual and cultural equals. "Their behavior was the same," said Dr. Wolpoff. "If you saw this any other time you'd say these were two races in contact" rather than separate species.
Scientists have been arguing about Neanderthals since the discovery of a partial skull in a cave in the Neander Valley of Germany in 1856. The latest phase of the debate began in the mid-1980's, when genetic analysis suggested that modern humans first appeared in Africa and then spread out from there.
The genetic findings were based on an analysis of DNA contained in the mitochondria, tiny structures that generate energy for body cells and which are inherited, via the ovum, only through the female line. Using this technique to draw up a family tree of modern human populations, scientists at the University of California at Berkeley calculated that the earliest modern humans emerged from Africa about 200,000 years ago.
Dr. Stringer and others who believe Neanderthals were an evolutionary dead end say that the modern humans spread from Africa into the Near East, and thence to the rest of the world. The remains of early modern humans found in both Africa and Israel, about 100,000 years old, are "what I consider to be genuine modern humans," Dr. Stringer said. "If you look for modern humans in other parts of the world, there is no evidence until 40,000 years ago or less."
Last June, French scientists reported that a Neanderthal skeleton discovered near the village of Saint-Cesaire, north of Bordeaux, was about 36,000 years old. Dr. Stringer interprets this to mean that modern humans and Neanderthals must have coexisted in Europe for thousands of years.
 
Contribution Called 'Negligible'
 If there was any interbreeding between moderns and European Neanderthals, he says, it was insignificant. "The Neanderthal contribution to the evolution of modern people is negligible," he said.
Dr. Stringer says modern humans did not supplant Neanderthals by conquering or killing them, just that they had an edge in technological or demographic competition, even though the tools found at Saint-Cesaire suggest that later Neanderthals were almost as accomplished as moderns. "I believe the Neanderthals did lose out because they were inferior, but I don't see them as being massively inferior," said Dr. Stringer. "Otherwise, they would have lost out much sooner."
Ezra Zubrow, an anthropologist at the State University of New York at Buffalo, has calculated that a rise of even 2 percent in the mortality rate of Neanderthals, caused by disease, perhaps, or lack of food, could have led to their extinction in only 1,000 years, or 30 generations. The shape of the Neanderthals' upper respiratory tract, which evolved to aid nasal breathing in a cold, dry climate, may have predisposed them to serious respiratory infections, putting them at further disadvantage, says Dr. Jeffrey T. Laitman, an anthropologist at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York. The Neanderthal larynx was higher than that of modern humans, Dr. Laitman believes, limiting the Neanderthals' ability to speak.
Dr. Stringer has written that Neanderthals were gradually displaced to environments where food supplies were less reliable and "where their dwindling numbers would have suffered greater attrition from the vagaries of fluctuating climates and food supplies, as well as disease," adding, "The Neanderthals probably went out with a whimper, not a bang."
 
Using Fossil Records
 Dr. Wolpoff and his colleagues argue that Dr. Stringer's ideas, however elegant, are contradicted by the fossil record. Abundant evidence from central Europe, they say, establishes that early modern humans still displayed many traits that are clearly Neanderthal in character, and therefore evolved from them. Many early modern skulls, for example, display a tell-tale bone near the place where the mandibular nerve enters the jaw. The bone is a well-established characteristic of Neanderthal skulls, says Dr. David Frayer, a physical anthropologist at the University of Kansas. Another marker seen in both is the space between the third molar and the jaw.
In addition, says Dr. Fred H. Smith of Northern Illinois University, the backs of most Neanderthal skulls look "as if a little bun were stuck there." Skulls of early modern humans found in Czechoslovakia also display this feature. But it is found in neither the Neanderthals nor the early moderns in Israel. "How did the earliest modern humans in Eastern Europe get it unless they got it from Neanderthals?" Dr. Smith said.
In the past, said Dr. Frayer, scientists have compared Neanderthals with modern skeletons no older than 100 to 300 years, concluding that there was a huge anatomical gap between Neanderthals and all modern humans. "We're going to be showing at the Chicago meeting that the gap isn't that great," he said.
Neanderthals and early moderns who coexisted in Israel, 50,000 to 100,000 years ago, are said to display an especially striking cultural similarity. "Their archeology is so identical, it's shocking," said Dr. Wolpoff. They made the same kinds of tools, using the same techniques. They hunted and butchered the same animals in the same way. They buried their dead in the same manner, with the same artifacts.
As for the European Neanderthals, Dr. Wolpoff suggests that they followed a separate evolutionary course from those of the Near East. They might have differed as, for instance, a modern Swede and a modern Iranian differ. And in fact, their skeletons, while clearly of the Neanderthal type, differ in some details from those of their European counterparts.
Dr. Wolpoff and his allies question the reliability of the mitochondrial DNA studies that bolster Dr. Stringer's ideas. Some critics say that the DNA analysis assumes that evolution takes place in the minumum number of steps possible, but that there is no reason to believe it actually operates so tidily and efficiently. The exodus of modern humans from Africa may have occurred far earlier, in their view, than the DNA analysis implies.
A number of anthropologists believe the truth may lie somewhere between the two schools of thought. Dr. Smith, for one, believes that although modern Europeans evolved in large measure from Neanderthals, other early moderns from elsewhere, including Africa, probably moved into Europe and interbred with the evolving Europeans.
Why were the Neanderthals in Europe for so long, only to fade out? Dr. Smith proposes what he calls "a possible scenario."
Neanderthals' physical characteristics, he suggests, enabled them to adapt well to the cold of ice-age Europe. The most recent ice age lasted from about 120,000 to about 18,000 years ago, when the ice sheets began a gradual withdrawal. The Neanderthals had large babies, and size helps babies survive cold better. From an adaptation standpoint, the other physical characteristics of Neanderthals may have been secondary.
During a warm interlude in the last Ice Age, Dr. Smith's scenario continues, early modern people from elsewere, lacking the Neanderthals' physical adaptation to cold, drifted into Europe and interbred with its Neanderthal population. The Ice Age reasserted itself for a time, but by then the surviving popluation had developed better clothing, more efficient fires and better houses to withstand the cold.
A robust body adapted to cold became less important and even a liability because it required more energy. As the generations passed, the human population lost its Neanderthal features under the culling of natural selection.
But while the Neanderthal physical type disappeared, Dr. Smith says, the breed "did not go extinct in the classical sense." Rather, he said, Neanderthal genes live on today in Europeans and those who, like most Americans, trace their lineage to Europe.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Vincent Facing a Week of Critical Decisions

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
The furies have continued without a let-up through Fay Vincent's tenure as the commissioner of major league baseball. Debates have extended long after his decisions about whether to resume the 1989 World Series after an earthquake, whether to ban the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, and what role to play in the 1990 player lockout.
But never before has Vincent faced a week like this one, in which he returns from a 10-day vacation to confront the dramas of the potential sale of the Seattle Mariners to Japanese interests, of the Yankees and Steinbrenner and Daniel McCarthy, and of baseball's never-ending economic angst. 
 Many of his fellow players on baseball's turbulent stage have labeled the week ahead for Vincent and baseball very important, very sensitive and crucial.
"I think it's all piling up at once. Maybe that's the reason Fay took a vacation, to get prepared for it," Haywood Sullivan, general partner of the Boston Red Sox, said with a wry laugh. "Seriously, though, even though it's the business of baseball, it's not the normal business of baseball. And it is going to be one heck of a busy week."
No one knows that better than Vincent. Asked whether he feels beseiged and beleaguered as he returns from a vacation in Jamaica, Vincent concedes that he's closer to that point than what he would like.
"There's a lot going on -- Seattle, some other difficult issues, not all of them visible," Vincent said. "It's a full-time job. But I have no complaints. I think that it's just more difficult and intense than even I thought."
Today, Vincent will make his first official appearance since Jan. 23, when he restated what he said was baseball's policy against selling franchises to off-shore interests in response to the news that a group primarily financed by Nintendo of Japan wanted to buy the Mariners.
Vincent is scheduled to meet with the Governor of Washington, the Mayor of Seattle, plus civic and business leaders from the Pacific Northwest who are concerned about keeping the Mariners in Seattle. Sure to be addressed is that group's concern about a baseball policy that could harpoon the one offer put forth that could prevent the flight of the Mariners to Florida or elsewhere.
On Wednesday, Vincent will meet with the owners' executive committee, an advisory group. "Economic issues are a top priority," said Bud Selig, president of the Milwaukee Brewers and a member of both the ownership and the executive committees. "But Seattle will be discussed, too."
On Thursday, Vincent will settle back into an issue that grips New Yorkers as he meets with McCarthy, the man trying to secure from both Vincent and the major league owners approval of his appointment as the Yankees' general partner. Then it's on to the ownership committee and back to the Seattle conundrum that same day.
Seattle will dominate as the ownership committee, which consists of the two league presidents and four owners from each league, wrestles with what is now a formal bid of $100 million placed on the table by Nintendo and its Seattle partners.
"There are going to be a myriad of questions," said an American League owner who sits on the committee and declined to be identified. "And the issues are real, the local ownership question is real. I have always believed that the more local ownership you have, the better off you're going to be. Does this group fit the bill? Give us time to see."
"No prior transfer that I can think of has attracted so much attention," said Jerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Chicago White Sox and a member of the committee.
Why? The Seattle issue comes with all kinds of baggage, including charges of xenophobia to not-so-subtle threats that baseball could risk losing its Federal antitrust exemptions if it causes the Mariners to seek buyers in other states.
 
'Difficult Issue'
 "Seattle has been a very difficult issue for the better part of a year, but now it's interlaced with the international issue," Vincent said. "I saw it coming. That's why about a year ago I asked Eli Jacobs and Walter Haas, owners who knew something about international business, who had international dealings, to look at it."
Jacobs is the owner of the Orioles and Haas is the owner of the Athletics.
"I wanted the ownership to have a clear point of view," Vincent said. "And they did develop a clear point of view, which was that they didn't want any participation outside of North America. That was their point of view and it still is as far as I know."
Could Vincent have reacted differently? He could have vetoed the bid, remained silent or blessed the Japanese for their interest. He said, however, that the whole issue would have to be more thoroughly discussed by owners.
"What he said was a reaction and I believe he got out in front too fast," said a lawyer familiar with the commissioner and baseball operations.
Vincent said he doesn't have second thoughts. "I don't think that you can manage these things," he said. "I mean, when the question comes up, there is a policy, there is a point of view that is never going to be 100 percent popular. On this issue, I think it was a no-win proposition for baseball. We were going to be killed one way or another."
 
Controversial Statements
 So Vincent spoke out on Jan. 23, having what he considered a consensus already. His statement set off the controversy and baseball has been labeled racist and exclusionary, not to mention a prime example of growing anti-Japan movement in America.
"I guess the timing couldn't have been worse, but I really don't know if the response could have been different," Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner, said. "Fay was not stating his personal view, but that of ownership based on where the owners were the last time they looked at the issue in the abstract."
Dealing in the abstract is history now, in light of the fact that Nintendo is willing to guarantee 60 percent of the $100 million bid.
Also, baseball's antitrust exemption is being called into question as is usually the case whenever baseball crosses swords with politicians. And there are politicians in this mix, mainly Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, and Tom Foley, the speaker of the House of Representatives, who hails from Washington.
 
Danger Points
 So Vincent must determine the danger points not only in the state of Washington, but also in the nation's capital. Just as important, Vincent must determine if owners, and their views, are different from what they previously stated. And the silence emanating from that group has been all but deafening.
"I think that once Fay came out with his statement, a lot of owners said, 'I don't have to say anything,' " the lawyer added. "Then, once they saw the flack start to develop, they chose not to say anything."
"I have my own views, but it's our position to let Fred Kuhlmann, chairman of the ownership committee, speak for us," said an American League owner, referring to the president of the St. Louis Cardinals. Kuhlmann will say only that he promises to reveal the final decision on Seattle.
Sullivan understands the reluctance of owners to speak. He also understands the nature of Vincent's job.
"And regardless of who sits in that office, whether it be Ueberrothh or Kuhn or Fay or Giammati, that is one tough position," Sullivan said. "It's just like being George Bush; somebody had got to have a finger pointed at him and most of the time it's none too complimentary. So I think it takes a real person, someone fortunately like Fay to say 'This is what I think should be done,' and be capable of standing up and letting people know that this is what he thinks is right. I think that's what is foremost on his mind right now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fay Vincent, baseball commissioner, has a full plate of problems that require his attention this week. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Campaign's New Phase: Impress Voters, or Die

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 3

 BODY:
The Democrats are entering the Hobbesian phase of the New Hampshire primary campaign: It will be nasty, brutish and short. Then New Hampshire's voters begin their "winnowing" -- a bucolic word that fails to capture the rough process of deciding which campaigns will die here and which will roll on to warmer climes.
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts enters this phase in the happy position of doing better than expected. He has stubbornly held on to second place in the New Hampshire polls, behind Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, and has made subtle political capital out of the obvious fact that with his mumbling, professorial presentation he will never be a slick media candidate. 
 Already, one can sense incipient guilt pangs in the press and pundit class, the nervous little twinge of fear that they overlooked the virtues of the unglamorous tortoise, once again.
Mr. Tsongas was at a breakfast with reporters in Washington today, busily trying to stoke those feelings. But as he gets his political moment, his second look, he still faces a basic question: Where does his campaign go after New Hampshire? Would a second-place finish here generate enough money and attention to carry him through the harrowing round of primaries that follows, particularly on March 10, Super Tuesday?
His campaign advisers say, with the stolid patience of the persistently underestimated, that he might just win New Hampshire. That may be what it takes. The contests that follow New Hampshire demand media, money and organization -- and perhaps favor the hares.
For weeks now, the designated hare in this race was Governor Clinton, who has the most money, the edge in the early polls, a cheering section among the commentators and the benefit of a primary calendar that gives heavy influence to his native South. He has clung to his position in the polls despite a two-week struggle with charges from a supermarket tabloid that he conducted a 12-year affair with a former cabaret singer.
Last weekend, he campaigned in Nashua and Manchester with the gusto of a man who believes he has dodged a bullet and now considers himself bulletproof.
Still, not everyone shares Mr. Clinton's euphoria about his political stock, post-Gennifer Flowers. The plain fact is he faces a critical test in New Hampshire. Only a strong showing is likely to allay the fear in his party of producing a wounded frontrunner. With a big win in New Hampshire, Mr. Clinton might scare off any late entries by big-name candidates who would have run if they had known the field would look this weak and scattered at the start of the February sweepstakes.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska is still trying to present himself as a Clinton alternative, but he has yet to take off in the polls; in fact, he may be wondering what he gained from his campaign shakeup of a month ago.
If any candidate could have profited by a longer campaign, it was Mr. Kerrey, who has yet to find a way to match his idiosyncratic but often compelling political style to the demands of a presidential campaign.
"He is a hard person to try to fit into the usual categories," said Harrison Hickman, his poll taker. "He is who he is, and he's trying to communicate that." The clock, however, can be brutal on a candidate still trying to connect at this stage of the game.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa is now running neck and neck with Mr. Kerrey in some recent polls here, after taking his economic populism, including images of closed and empty plants, onto television in campaign ads. Mr. Harkin is expected to handily win the Iowa caucuses next Monday. The Iowa bounce has created Presidential front-runners in the past, but since Mr. Harkin comes from Iowa, his bounce is likely to be minimal.
"Nobody's going to give us a break out of that," concedes his adviser, Donald R. Sweitzer.
Rather, the Harkin campaign is hoping for a good enough finish in New Hampshire to position the Iowa Senator as the Clinton alternative in the states to come, with the "underpinning," as Mr. Sweitzer put it, of supporters in organized labor.
The subtext: Mr. Harkin and Mr. Kerrey are vying for the same role coming out of New Hampshire.
That leaves former Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who is last in the New Hampshire polls but continues to mix it up in the debates, where he often torments his rivals. On Friday night, for example, he was the one who mentioned the allegations against Mr. Clinton in the closing minutes of the debate.
Mr. Brown, rarely accused of being a conventional politician, seems motivated by calculations other than the usual Presidential strategy.
All of these candidates will have their fates decided by an electorate that is angry, anxious and unpredictable. The next 14 days will be rough.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
Buchanan's Run Exposes Fissures in the Right

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 3

 BODY:
Whatever the outcome of the fight over the Republican nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan is exposing fault lines in the conservative movement at a time when the twin epoxies that bound conservatives -- Ronald Reagan and international communism -- have melted away.
As he campaigns in New Hampshire, Mr. Buchanan, a former White House speechwriter who is at times to the right of the two Presidents he served, has made clear that his goal is not only to unhorse President Bush as the titular head of the Republican Party, but also to change the direction of the conservative movement. 
 At a recent campaign stop in Littleton, N.H., Mr. Buchanan acknowleged the ideological fracturing among conservatives and argued that his campaign had become its focal point. "There is tremendous ferment in America, politically and ideologically," he told a gathering at the Littleton Elks Club. "The old conservative movement is breaking apart. Some of my friends are barely on speaking terms with each other; some aren't on speaking terms with me."
There is little doubt that many in the right wing of the Republican Party, especially those outside government, and not beholden to the Administration, yearned for a conservative besides David Duke, a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan and Nazi sympathizer, to challenge Mr. Bush. These conservatives view Mr. Bush as nothing short of a Judas who sold them out when he reneged on his pledge not to raise taxes and when he signed the civil rights bill.
 
Some Balk at Buchanan
 But by espousing positions on trade, immigration and the role of the United States in the world, views tinged with a kind of isolationism and protectionism that are anathema to many free-market and globalist conservatives, Mr. Buchanan is seen by some as an imperfect spear with which to impale the President.
"One has this almost irresistible urge to leap out of your chair and say, 'Pat, this guy deserves to be socked. Do it!' " said David Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union. "But Pat's mission is not just to sock the President, but to change conservatism in a way I don't like."
For some conservatives, supporting Mr. Buchanan therefore seems like a Faustian bargain. Their long-shot hope is for the challenger to bloody Mr. Bush in New Hampshire so that the President withdraws from the fray or a more acceptable conservative like Pete DuPont, the former Delaware Governor or William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary, is enticed to enter the race.
But if Mr. Buchanan embarrasses the President and no other conservative takes up the challenge, "then conservatives are stuck with either Buchanan or Bush," said Burton Yale Pines, vice president and director of research for the Heritage Foundation. "It is not a pleasant choice."
 
Worries on the Right
 Equally worrying to some conservatives is that a strong showing by Mr. Buchanan, while felling the President, also gives impetus to Mr. Buchanan's style of conservatism.
Mr. Keene said a debate had raged for a time in the Buchanan camp with some advisers urging the candidate to tone down some of his language to avoid being tagged as an isolationist or a protectionist. But Mr. Buchanan rejected that strategy, Mr. Keene said, saying voters should see the "whole package."
Officials with the Buchanan campaign deny there was an internal debate. But they say the candidate decided early that he would not modulate his views to increase his appeal to some conservatives.
At stops throughout New Hampshire Mr. Buchanan has bashed the Japanese for conducting what he terms "predatory trade policies," railed against the free-trade agreement being negotiated with Mexico, advocated possible United States withdrawal from multinational agencies like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, criticized the invasion of Panama and the economic blockade of Haiti and said he was against extending $10 billion in housing loan guarantees to Israel.
 
Not Cowed by Labels
 He has refused to be cowed by the neo-isolationist or protectionist labels some have tried to pin on him and has asserted that the tough economic times and voter discontent will force conservatives who disagree with him to adopt similar positions.
The core of Mr. Buchanan's message is that with the end of the cold war the prevalent force in the world today is nationalism. He argues that with countries like Japan centering their policies on their own national economic interests, the United States would be foolish to adopt purely free-trade practices or surrender authority to multinational agencies.
Such themes are reminiscent of the conservative isolationism advocated in the 1940's and 1950's by Robert A. Taft, the Ohio Senator who fought Wendell Willkie and Dwight D. Eisenhower for leadership of the Republican Party. The rise of the Soviet Empire, however, caused Mr. Taft's brand of conservatism to be subordinated to the goal of defeating Communism.
 
Some See Anti-Semitism
 "With the decline of the cold war, the underlying strain of isolationism among conservatives is now feeling more freedom to express itself," said A. James Reichley, a former researcher at the Brookings Institution who wrote "Conservatives in an Age of Change.".
Some conservatives, especially neo-conservatives like Norman Podhoretz, editor of Commentary Magazine, are also troubled by what they see as anti-Semitism in some of Mr. Buchanan's statements about Israel and what he calls Jewish influence on United States policy in the Middle East. These conservatives see in Mr. Buchanan a re-emergence of the type of anti-Jewish attitudes that haunted much of the conservative movement for years and that figures like William F. Buckley have since the mid-1950's sought to expel from American conservatism.
Last month in a long essay on anti-Semitism that appeared in National Review, Mr. Buckley after reviewing remarks Mr. Buchanan made on television talk shows, in interviews and in his columns, wrote, "I find it impossible to defend Pat Buchanan against the charge that what he did and said during the period under examination amounted to anti-Semitism."
Still, Mr. Buckley said, Mr. Buchanan's alleged anti-Semitic outbursts were probably motivated by "an iconoclastic temperament," rather than bigotry. And in a recent issue of Human Events, a conservative weekly newspaper, Mr. Buckley said that if he lived in New Hampshire he would probably vote for the challenger.
But polls show that Mr. Buchanan's campaign has so far failed to ignite voters in New Hampshire despite the state's sorry economic condition. And the ambivalence of the right wing of the Republican Party toward Mr. Buchanan's insurgency is a marked contrast to support in 1976 for Mr. Reagan's challenge to Gerald Ford.
"This is not a division among Republicans like Taft versus Eisenhower or Dewey," Mr. Reichley said. "It's not a battle royal like it was in 1948 or 1952. Buchanan would like it to be, but what he has is a splinter group, rather than a large wing of the party."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Banking Troubleshooter Gets a Healthy Change

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Lawrence K. Fish, who presided over the death throes of the Bank of New England, is back in banking, this time as head of the Citizens Financial Group of Providence, R.I., one of the region's strongest banking companies.
"It will be quite a change," Mr. Fish said, noting that the old Bank of New England had "single troubled credits that were larger than all the bad loans at Citizens." Mr. Fish, 47, came to the Bank of New England in early 1990 as part of a rescue mission after losses on commercial real estate had brought the bank to its knees. 
 Mr. Fish spent 15 months at the Bank of New England selling assets and cutting staff in a futile effort to keep it in business before regulators forced its sale to the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group of Providence, R.I., last summer. Mr. Fish said his move to Citizens on April 1 would be "a chance for growing rather than shrinking and for making money rather than losing money."
The opportunity for Mr. Fish comes with the departure of Citizen's 60-year-old chief executive, George Graboys. Mr. Fish will join the bank as president and then take on Mr. Graboys's job when he leaves on Sept. 30 to start a new career as an educator and lawyer.
Mr. Graboys, who joined Citizens in 1969, avoided the pitfall of excessive lending for real estate, which felled many other New England banks, and guided Citizens through a series of acquisitions and internal growth that resulted in a company with $4 billion of assets, up from $800 million in 1981. He also managed the sale of Citizens in 1986 to the Royal Bank of Scotland for $440 million.
"I love my job, but now that I am 60, it is time to do other things while I am still healthy," Mr. Graboys said in an interview yesterday. At the top of his list of new ventures is an seminar on economics he is developing for high schools in the region. "There are students now who go through college without ever learning how to apply the theories of classical economics to practical situations," he said.
While Citizens is operating profitably and earned $8.9 million last year, Mr. Graboys said the New England economy remained depressed. "Consumers have still not regained confidence in the economy and the region," he said.
For banks burdened with large amounts of bad loans, the weak economy is a severe blow that makes it hard for them to outgrow their problems. Mr. Fish said he expected to take advantage of the situation by acquiring weaker or failed banks in Connecticut and Massachusetts to expand Citizens' existing network of 47 offices in Rhode Island and 4 in Massachusetts. Last year, Citizens bought the Rhode Island subsidiary of the Bank of New England.
Although Mr. Fish spent his career at larger financial institutions, and once ran the Tokyo office of the Bank of Boston, he is no stranger to managing branch networks specializing in consumer and small business accounts. He ran the branch system at the Bank of Boston in 1988 before briefly heading Columbia Savings and Loan in California.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
New Magazine Spurns Gloom

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
As the nation's economic woes linger, more marketers are pegging their advertising to financial and recession themes. In at least one instance, the potentially dolorous message is being leavened with humor.
Worth, a personal-finance magazine being introduced this week, is running a series of humorous television and radio commercials in large markets around the country. One spoofs consumers who think the best way to cope with economic dislocations is to clip cents-off coupons. Another mocks an old-fashioned financial expert who mouths platitudes like "Real estate is always your best investment." 
 W. Randall Jones, chief executive of Worth and its parent, Capital Publishing said the tongue-in-cheek approach "is not to make light of the fact that money, and protecting money, is a very serious subject." But, he added, "I want people to read the magazine, and people are tired of doom and gloom."
Welch & Nehlen Advertising Inc. in Garden City, L.I., created the radio spots. The television spots were created by the Sterling Partnership in Boston and Drury Design Dynamics in New York. Welch & Nehlen also created a trade advertising print campaign, which began this week.

HEADLINE: The Ideological War Over Health Care;
Conservatives Ignore History

BYLINE: By Paul Starr; Paul Starr is professor of sociology at Princeton and co-editor of The American Prospect, a quarterly.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
The response of conservatives to rising health care costs and the unraveling of private insurance has been a triumph of ideology over experience.
President Bush's new proposals for tax credits still ask Americans to fend for themselves in a health insurance market with staggering administrative inefficiencies and little capacity to bring costs under control. 
 Historically, conservatives have upheld experience, prudence and tradition, while the left has been devoted to theory. Since the French Revolution, conservatives have cautioned against utopianism, social engineering and bloated bureaucracies; the left, until recent years, has presented a vision of a new, untried society.
Today, on health care the sides are reversed. The right upholds a theory, the free market, which is not applied to health insurance anywhere in the West. Conservative thinkers issue theoretical designs for free market reform and managed competition (related but distinct ideas); when confronted with the record of market failure in health insurance and the disappointing results of market-oriented reforms, they often respond that the true market has yet to be tried, much as some on the left still say true socialism has yet to be tried.
In contrast, liberal critics of our health insurance system are resolutely factual, emphasizing that the U.S. has higher costs, lower coverage and greater dissatisfaction than do countries with national health insurance.
Ordinarily, Americans expect conservatives to support lower-cost alternatives in social policy and liberals to be generous to a fault. But America's high-cost health system finds defenders on the right, which has a tender regard for the insurance and health care industries. It is the liberals who favor the reforms that have enabled Germany and other Western European countries to keep their per capita health spending at half the U.S. level.
Political conflict in the U.S. is commonly said to be more pragmatic than in Europe. But from the earliest campaigns for universal health insurance here, the issue has evoked much sharper ideological differences. European conservatives often introduced national health insurance programs that U.S. conservatives have denounced as socialized medicine.
The debate in the U.S. has been more inflammatory, as proposals for universal insurance have been accused of alien and subversive origins. Such proposals first died in 1918 when they were labeled an insidious German idea. They died again in the 1930's and 1940's amid charges that they were Soviet-inspired. Lately, conservatives have condemned Canada's system as socialism that individualistic Americans could never accept, even though Canadian health care providers are private and Canadians choose freely among them.
Yet while conservative rhetoric counterposing socialism and free choice has remained unchanged, conservative ideas have been transformed. Conservatives once saw the right to choose any doctor as essential to all health plans; now, with health maintenance organizations, they consider that right expendable.
More ironically, many Americans find that the health system restricts their economic liberty in another way: they cannot exchange jobs, for fear of losing coverage of pre-existing medical conditions.
What is puzzling is that in other Western countries with national health insurance, health care is still overwhelmingly private and capitalism is alive and well. A U.S. national health plan that provided universal coverage, squeezed administrative overhead and contained health prices would help employers control costs and broadly benefit the economy.
A public program with options for H.M.O.'s, which liberals generally support, would provide more choice and better managed competition than individual employers can provide.
It is a pity Marxists were wrong about our politics. If capitalism's interests really governed our political life, conservatives would have lost the health insurance battle long ago.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: February 5, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1027 words

HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS VOTE EXTRA ASSISTANCE FOR MANY JOBLESS

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Congress voted overwhelmingly today to extend unemployment benefits for two million jobless people for 13 more weeks, agreeing on an issue that inspired bitter debate much of last year. President Bush has promised to sign the bill quickly.
The quick and nearly simultaneous actions of the House and the Senate demonstrate that the White House and Congressional Republicans want to avoid being portrayed as insensitive to the needs of those who have been hard hit by the recession in an election year. 
 Last year Mr. Bush killed two versions of a similar bill, arguing that they would have unacceptably expanded the budget deficit. Under intense political pressure, Mr. Bush finally signed an extension of benefits in November.
For their part, the Democrats compromised by not pressing for a more costly, longer extension of benefits that Mr. Bush might have felt compelled to veto.
 
10 Republicans Vote No
 The House approved the measure by a vote of 404 to 8. The Senate followed suit, 94 to 2. All 10 negative votes were cast by Republicans.
By voting to spend an additional $2.7 billion on unemployment benefits, Congress added 13 weekly payments of $170 for workers in all states on top of the extended benefits enacted last November. That legislation provided payments of 13 or 20 weeks, depending on the unemployment rates of each state, but benefits in some states will begin to expire within the next two weeks.
The emergency payments will be available to people who have lost their jobs, cannot find work and have exhausted their 26 weeks of state-financed benefits by July 4. People exhausting those payments after July 4 would not be eligible for extra benefits.
 
At Least 52 Weeks' Benefits
 In all states, unemployed workers receive 26 weeks of state-financed jobless benefits. Last November Congress approved the 13 or 20 weeks of Federally financed payments. The vote today, another effort to help unemployed workers caught in the lingering recession, extends benefits for 13 more weeks.
Consequently, in most states, including New York, the jobless will be eligible for a the total of 52 weeks of benefits. In states where unemployment is highest, including Connecticut and New Jersey, the total will be 59 weeks of benefits -- longer than in any previous recession. The previous record was set in 1976, when some workers were paid up to 55 weeks.
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader, said during the House debate that passage of the bill showsed "Congress and the Administration can work together in a timely fashion to respond to the problems of the country." But he added that the extension of benefits was merely an aspirin that "eases the symptoms but doesn't cure the illness," and that Congress now needed to work on the far more difficult task of passing a comprehensive economic growth package.
During a floor debate in the Senate that was long on oratory though short on disagreement, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, said: "The reasons for acting now to pass this legislation are clear. The unemployed need it, the state of the economy demands it, the Congress strongly supports it, and the President says he will sign it."
Judy Smith, a White House spokeswoman, said today: "We are delighted Congress acted so quickly. We are anxious to get the bill so we can get the benefits to those in need."
 
A Dissenting Voice
 One of the few dissenting voices was that of Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, who said: "For many, a vote for this bill is an easy one to cast. It won't be so easy when members are called upon to pay the piper and raise taxes on employment a few short months from now."
Tens of thousands of workers are already running out of benefits extended last year. By July, that number of people who will be eligible for the extra benefits will reach 2 million. About 8.9 million people are unemployed.
The Administration released a statement last week saying it strongly supported the extension of benefits after Representative Dan Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, dropped a more generous proposal that would have cost $4.5 billion and not expired until October. Senate leaders last week did not commit themselves to the plan immediately, but Mr. Bentsen predicted that the measure would be approved.
 Like November's legislation, the new measure will be financed with accounting devices and not by new taxes or spending cuts. It is not clear where all the money will be found, although part of it would come from $500 million raised by obliging some companies to pay higher estimated tax payments sooner than originally scheduled.
The remaining $2.2 billion would come from savings that the Office of Management and Budget says were made by Congress last year by extending taxes in future years and by other financial devices.
The bill adopted in November was paid for by accelerated payment of unpaid student loans and faster payments of estimated tax by some high income taxpayers.
Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Long Island Democrat who was a leading sponsor of the legislation extending benefits last year, announced today he would soon propose a new bill to change the extended benefits program permanently by expanding eligibility and bolstering the financing of the unemployment benefits. "We need to act quickly to insure that jobless Americans have the safety net they deserve," he said on the floor.
 
Reflection on Suffering
 In the debates on the bill, members reflected on the suffering the unemployed. Not surprisingly, Democrats voiced the more pessimistic economic prognoses, and argued that more ambitious Federal programs were needed.
"The recovery seems as far away as ever," said Senator Bentsen. "Consumer purchases, corporate investment and industrial production are dropping. The Index of Leading Economic Indicators has just fallen for the second month in a row. Consumer confidence has declined steadily this winter to the lowest level in 12 years."

Total weeks of unemployment benefits that would be available in each state under the bill passed by Congress yesterday. Included are the standard 26 weeks, plus the extension of either 13 or 20 weeks adopted in November, plus 13 weeks added by the new bill. To be eligible, an unemployed worker must file a claim by July 4. (Source: Democratic Study Group) (pg. A18)
