HEADLINE: Dinkins Seeking to Stem Dispute Over Proposals for the Homeless

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins moved yesterday to quiet feuding between members of his administration and of a mayoral commission on the homeless that has called for sweeping changes in New York City's shelter system.
In his first public comment on the commission's recommendations, the Mayor said he was open to all of its proposals, including rent subsidies for the homeless and creation of a new agency to manage programs for the homeless. 
 The Mayor called those ideas "intriguing" but made no promise to support them in a letter to the chairman of the commission, Andrew Cuomo, that was released yesterday. The Mayor seemed more enthusiastic about encouraging the use of nonprofit groups, rather than the city, to develop sites for shelters, saying this route "may well, as you suggest, make for a more effective approach."
 
Stakes Are High
 The spectacle of the Mayor's staff's bickering with the Mayor's commission over the last few days had threatened to detract from Mr. Dinkins's efforts to seize the initiative on homelessness. Several municipal officials, including Deputy Mayor Cesar A. Perales, greeted the commission's proposals last week with skepticism, a stance that incensed Mr. Cuomo and raised the possibility that efforts to reform the system would come to nothing.
The stakes in the debate are high. The intensity of the dispute reflects a struggle for power and money between the vast public bureaucracy and the private agencies that would benefit enormously if the Cuomo recommendations were adopted. The outcome will determine who controls the city's homeless system and the more than 20,000 homeless people who live in it, as well as more than $400 million that the city spends each year on the problem.
This comes at a time when the city's fiscal problems have prompted much discussion about scaling back the size of the city government and turning a variety of services over to private groups.
So far, Mr. Dinkins's attempts to reform the city's homeless system -- a promise in his election campaign -- have been largely frustrated. He wanted to close dangerous, drug-ridden armory shelters, but his plan for the city to build 24 small shelters providing intensive social services in middle-income neighborhoods led to a firestorm of opposition from residents. The commission agreed with the Mayor's contention that small shelters are better but advocated that nonprofit groups pick the sites. Communities that mistrust the city government are likelier to accept shelters run by nonprofit groups with good track records, the commission said. And drug treatment centers would probably not be in residential communities at all, but in commercial or mixed-use areas, or outside the city limits entirely, the report said.
A switch from city to private development of shelters might help break the political logjam that has paralyzed city leaders' stated preference for small shelters over big ones. City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who promised to kill the Mayor's plan because it would "destroy neighborhoods," has praised the Cuomo commission's alternative.
 
'Mayor Is Very Open-Minded'
 While the Mayor made no promises to support the commission's recommendations, he said he would study the panel's full report when it is completed.
"The Mayor is very open minded and wants to heed the criticism and move in a constructive direction," said the First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel.
The brouhaha over the recommendations comes even before the 14-member commission has finished its full report, which was originally due on Jan. 31. The commission sent a synopsis of its recommendations to the Mayor on Friday. Mr. Dinkins extended the deadline for the full report to Feb. 28.
The report, which has not yet been released, criticized the policies of the last decade, saying they had cost "a remarkable $2 billion in government funds" and failed to address the problems of homelessness.
"There must be a recognition that radical, structural change of the system is necessary," the report stated. That can be accomplished, the report said, "without significantly increased spending."
Despite Mr. Dinkins's apparent efforts to rein in the criticism of the proposals within his own administration, some members of the Cuomo commission continued on the offensive. Mr. Cuomo and George McDonald, two of the four commission members who are drafting the final report, said yesterday that the city's Human Resources Administration bears much of the blame for the city's failed policies on the homeless.
A new city agency or public authority should take over the task, they said. It would be responsible for the shelter system now run by the Human Resources Administration, as well as for permanent housing for the homeless now provided through the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the commission report said.
 
Criticism of H.R.A.
 "The city is spending close to $20,000 a year for a cot in a miserable armory," said Mr. Cuomo, the son of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. "It's absurd. H.R.A. is responsible for the system. We're saying that has to change." Mr. Cuomo runs a nonprofit agency, HELP, that operates shelters for families.
Mr. McDonald, president of the Doe Fund, a nonprofit group that works with the homeless, described H.R.A. as a wasteful bureaucracy. "It doesn't help people," he said. "Just ask any homeless person."
Another commission member, Victor Kovner, who recently resigned as the city's corporation counsel and who frequently advises the Mayor on homeless issues, disputed the notion that the Human Resources Administration is to blame, though he said creation of a new agency merited study.
"This is a system Mayor Dinkins inherited," said Mr. Kovner, who is one of the four people drafting the commission's report. "It was not well designed from the beginning. That's not H.R.A.'s fault."
A spokeswoman for the agency, Sheila Jack, said agency officials would have no comment on the report until it is made public. The head of the agency, Barbara J. Sabol, served on the commission and opposed the creation of a new agency, commission members said.
Last week, Dinkins administration officials, including Mr. Perales, questioned whether the city should "create more bureaucracy" by setting up a new agency on homelessness, as well as proposals for rental vouchers and greater reliance on nonprofit groups.
Mr. Perales did not return calls yesterday. But Mr. Steisel pointedly noted that Mr. Perales had not read the commission's report when he commented on its recommendations. Mr. Steisel said the proposal for a new agency or authority to manage the homeless system should surprise no one.
"Despite some successes we've had, we need to take an overall look at the system," Mr. Steisel said.

HEADLINE: Bush Encounters the Supermarket, Amazed

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 4

 BODY:
As President Bush travels the country in search of re-election, he seems unable to escape a central problem: This career politician, who has lived the cloistered life of a top Washington bureaucrat for decades, is having trouble presenting himself to the electorate as a man in touch with middle-class life.
Today, for instance, he emerged from 11 years in Washington's choicest executive mansions to confront the modern supermarket. 
 Visiting the exhibition hall of the National Grocers Association convention here, Mr. Bush lingered at the mock-up of a checkout lane. He signed his name on an electronic pad used to detect check forgeries.
"If some guy came in and spelled George Bush differently, could you catch it?" the President asked. "Yes," he was told, and he shook his head in wonder.
Then he grabbed a quart of milk, a light bulb and a bag of candy and ran them over an electronic scanner. The look of wonder flickered across his face again as he saw the item and price registered on the cash register screen.
"This is for checking out?" asked Mr. Bush. "I just took a tour through the exhibits here," he told the grocers later. "Amazed by some of the technology."
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, assured reporters that he had seen the President in a grocery store. A year or so ago. In Kennebunkport.
Some grocery stores began using electornic scanners as early as 1976, and the devices have been in general use in American supermarkets for a decade.
Having sampled the ways of the American shopper, Mr. Bush tried to identify with the American bad mood.
He pounded a lectern and raised his voice. He accused "professional pessimists" in Congress of conducting class warfare by criticizing some of his programs as favoring the wealthy. He talked sarcastically about advisers who urged him to get "the right political ring" into his oratory and his policy proposals. And he told jokes.
Reminding the audience of his "love for sports," Mr. Bush added: "And this being an election year, my competitive juices are flowing more than ever. And so today I'm making an announcement that many of you have been expecting for a long time. I am officially declaring my entry into your best-bagger contest. Just one question -- paper or plastic?"
It was a clearly improved version of the promotional speeches the President has been making for his economic proposals, and it drew a wildly enthusiastic response from the grocers in Orlando.
But Mr. Bush could not seem to escape the impression that, with the Democratic field still in disarray and the economy still in recession, he was still running against himself.
 
Mom and Apple Pie
 Mr. Bush can raise cheers from his audience, as he did today, by attacking government regulators with a late 20th-century version of an old American saw. "Regulations may have stated aims as wholesome as Mom and the apple pie," he said. "But you know better than anyone that when regulators carry that regulation too far, there won't be any apple pie for Mom to buy."
And the President could also note with a tone of satisfaction that the grocers' convention included a seminar entitled "The Regulators Are Back." But he had to leave it there and not go into more detail, since the "regulators" mentioned are in his Administration, which resumed issuing regulations at an energetic pace after the deregulation frenzy of the Reagan years.
After drawing a distinctly unenthusiastic response from a crowd in Philadelphia last week, when he gave a professorial recitation of his economic proposals, Mr. Bush seemed determined to rouse his audience with exhortations today.
He urged his listeners to pepper their Congressional representatives during the Feb. 8-17 Congressional recess with demands that they pass his economic proposals by March 20, the deadline he set in his State of the Union Message last Tuesday.
Mr. Bush acknowledged that the nation had "run into some hard times," but told the grocers not to listen to "professional pessimists" who he said "tell us America has become weak and disabled -- that our economy has fallen and it can't get up."
"Well, that's plain bunk!"the President said, his voice rising and his fist pounding the lectern.
 
Focus on the Economy
 Mr. Bush focused his remarks almost entirely on the economy and other domestic issues, part of a campaign tactic of avoiding talk of foreign policy to avoid criticism that he spends too much time on diplomacy.
He did mention foreign affairs, drawing applause for his leadership in the Persian Gulf war. He also talked about his meeting with world leaders.
"I had a fascinating visit with Boris Yeltsin up at Camp David on Saturday," Mr. Bush said. "This man's got some tough reforms here. Got to stay with him. Got to help him make them work."
But the President quickly brought the talk back to politics, suggesting that Congressional Democrats are lagging behind even the Russians in moving into the new world. "Isn't it ironic that at the exact moment the world is turning to our values of more economic freedom and competition, some in the United States want to go just the opposite way," he said.

HEADLINE: Defining the New Plowshares Those Old Swords Will Make

SERIES: After the Cold War -- Fourth of six articles

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M.

 BODY:
On a narrow street near art galleries and boutiques, next door to an acupuncturist who trades in Chinese herbs, is an encouraging sign of how the nation's scientific best and brightest might redirect themselves now that the cold war is over.
It is the Prediction Company, a private spinoff of the Los Alamos laboratory, the birthplace of the atomic bomb high in the mountains near here. Computers and young men with ponytails dot the office. Company scientists, once on the Federal payroll, are now private entrepreneurs using world-class skills in chaos theory to predict the rise and fall of stocks and bonds.
 
Some Win, Some Hunker Down
 "We have something that wins," J. Doyne Farmer, 39 years old, a company founder and theoretical physicist, said with an easy smile, his computer screen alive with numbers. 
 But for every adventurer like Mr. Farmer, thousands of scientists and engineers in the military-industrial complex are hunkered down in their old jobs, fearful that shrinking budgets will cripple or end their careers. Others struggle to find constructive new roles for Federal research, like healing the environment or helping American industry compete with foreign rivals. Still others dream of turning back the clock to days of glory.
These wizards of the cold war are the greatest force of scientific and engineering talent ever assembled. Over the decades this army of government, academic and industry experts made the breakthroughs that gave the West its dazzling military edge.
Now, these experts suddenly have no clear mission. Thousands are already out of jobs. If these individuals cannot be redirected, if they can find no place to utilize their skills, some experts believe the country might be lost.
"They're critical to the country's fate," said Edward A. Knapp, a former director of the National Science Foundation who now heads the Santa Fe Institute, which backs interdisciplinary research.
"Being on the leading edge of technical change will continue to be essential to our well-being," he said. "These people can help keep us there. They're very important for meeting the new challenges to our security that are sure to arise in the future, be they military or commercial or intellectual."
Up the road, Colorado Springs is working hard to redirect its focus. The city is home to hundreds of high-technology companies that thrived on military contracts in the 1980's when billions of Pentagon dollars flowed into exotic research. Today, amid an economic slump and contractor layoffs, the city has received commitments for thousands of new civilian jobs from high-tech pioneers like Apple Computer and MCI Telecommunications.
But even specialists eager to meet the future can find themselves left behind as the effects of defense cuts are compounded by general economic malaise.
"It's going to get worse before it gets better," said Richard A. Ellis, director of manpower studies at the American Association of Engineering Societies. He said that about 100,000 engineers lost their jobs last year -- most perhaps because of military budget cuts -- and that the number of unemployed engineers was likely to rise.
"The real serious cuts," he noted, "are still coming down the pike."
 
Military Thesis
40 Years of Bombs And Missiles
 By some measures, the cold war was the best thing that ever happened to research. The explosion of money, talent and tools far exceeded anything in previous eras. Early in the century the Government cared little for science. But the Manhattan Project in World War II changed all that. Buoyed, some would say blinded, by nuclear success, the Government quickly grew into the largest patron of scientific research of all time, pouring money into any field that promised hope of gain over the Soviets.
Since 1955, the Government has spent more than $1 trillion on research and development of nuclear arms and other weaponry. According to the National Science Foundation, that represented 62 percent of all Federal research expenditures. In addition, untold dollars went into related efforts, like the civilian space program's $90 billion race with the Soviet Union to land men on the Moon.
An incalculable part of the price was that military research was often cut off from American society and many of its democratic values. The right of free speech was routinely waived in exchange for a security clearance. The secrecy was meant to bar the transfer of any possible advantage to the Soviets, and those accused of doing so could get the ultimate penalty: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were executed in 1953 after being convicted of conspiracy to deliver secrets of the atomic bomb to Moscow.
 
From Stealth Bombers to Teflon
 Out of all this came the hydrogen bomb, laser weapons, spy satellites, intercontinental rockets, nuclear-powered ships and submarines, the neutron bomb, stealth warplanes and the precision armaments that helped win the Persian Gulf war.
So did Teflon, modern television, passenger jets, weather satellites, computer chips, microwave ovens -- the whole industries of aerospace, communications and electronics, now pillars of the economy.
Some of the innovative edge has already shifted to civilian areas. Starting in 1980, American industry surpassed the Federal Government as the nation's prime patron of science research and has kept that lead ever since.
Finally, with the end of the cold war, budgets for military research began to fall, killing some programs, curtailing others and creating a general sense of forboding in the military-industrial complex.
 
Civilian Antithesis
Setting New Goals In the Labs
 Today, the brightest lights in the military-industrial complex are often tempted to leave for challenges in commerce and industry, sometimes taking unclassified skills and technologies with them. Los Alamos veterans founded the Prediction Company here in Santa Fe in July. It now has nine employees.
While at Los Alamos, Mr. Farmer, the company's vice president for research, pioneered ways to predict chaotic phenomena like ice ages, sunspots and fluid turbulence. Now, he says, he and his colleagues are forecasting the moves of financial markets. Each day computer predictions are matched against market performance. No trades have yet been made, he said; the company hopes to do its first trading this spring.
Down the road in Albuquerque is another team of Los Alamos refugees, their tidy offices packed with complex electronic gear. Cell Robotics Inc. is pioneering "laser tweezers" that use beams of concentrated light to move tiny bits of biological material with great precision and near-perfect hygiene.
"Now we're flying," said Tudor N. Buican, inventor of the "tweezers" and the company's chief scientist, as he directed a light beam to lift a tiny particle one-fiftieth the diameter of a human hair.
With such control, he said, a sperm showing good vitality could be picked out to fertilize an egg. Or a natural killer cell could be set next to a tumor cell to fight cancer. The seven-person company, prototype unit in hand, expects to sell its first machine this year for about $25,000.
"It's been much more work than we've ever done before," Mr. Buican said. "But the independence, and the prospects opening in front of the company, are extremely attractive."
 
From Missiles to Satellites
 The shift to civilian work has been slower but still significant at aerospace companies.
The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company in Sunnyvale, Calif., built six generations of Navy missiles, including the Poseidon, the Trident 1 and the Trident 2, which can hurl aloft a dozen or more nuclear warheads.
Today, Lockheed is aiming at new civilian areas while nurturing its Pentagon ties. It has won more than $1 billion worth of work on NASA's space station, a laboratory in the sky for astronauts that is to fly in the late 1990's. It is also drawing up designs for Motorola's Iridium system of 77 satellites to relay signals from pocket phones around the globe.
Despite new business, Lockheed Missiles has had its share of layoffs and early retirements as military work has dwindled. Its cadre of engineers and scientists has shrunk steadily since 1987, going from 11,526 to 9,636 last year. The company expects to lose another 430 technical experts this year.
John N. McMahon, its president, recently told edgy employees that the company's past achievements and technical strengths readied it for projects "sufficiently diverse and numerous to provide a healthy future." But he gave no examples of new opportunities.
 
Shrinkage at M.I.T.
 On the opposite coast, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a bastion of arms research, is wrestling with the same kind of change. After years of explosive growth, Pentagon funds are shrinking, from $438 million in 1990 to $402 million in 1991.
Experts say the worst is yet to come for M.I.T., especially for its 2,700-person Lincoln Laboratory, created as a military brain bank in the late 1950's by both the university and the Air Force. Recently, the lab has perfected new kinds of space sensors and laser communicators. During the Persian Gulf war, its tiny experimental satellites eased congested communications for allied troops.
Today, Lincoln is eager to find new customers, including Government bodies other than the Pentagon. For the Federal Aviation Administration, for example, it is studying whether anti-collision systems on passenger jets create distractions for air traffic controllers.
Walter E. Morrow Jr., Lincoln's director, said the lab's survival strategy was to keep a core of military work while expanding its horizons as much as possible, including helping private companies eager to do battle with foreign competitors.
"Our work for others," he said, "is going up steadily."
 
Commercial Synthesis
New Partnerships For New Products
 The core of the military-industrial complex is a secretive maze of military research laboratories owned by the Federal Government, including such places as Los Alamos, which still has about 7,400 employees despite a slow exodus.
This maze is scattered across America, often hidden behind armed guards and barbed wire. And it is huge. The Defense Department has 66 labs that employ 60,000 and spend about $7 billion a year. The Energy Department has three labs for nuclear weapon design, including Los Alamos, that employ 24,000 and spend $4 billion a year.
In step with the times, Washington is pushing this complex to share its high-technology skills and tools with industry. The buzz words are technology transfer, and the means include liberalized patent licensing and new kinds of cooperative research with industry.
 
So Far, the Rewards Are Meager
 For instance, a metals consortium founded by the Energy Department has grown to include 13 companies trying to improve products like jet engines by incorporating new kinds of high-performance alloys. In all, the Energy Department has 44 agreements with industry for cooperative research and the Defense Department has 171.
Despite much hoopla, the Federal payoff from these programs has been slim. In 1990 the Government received only $9.4 million in royalties from all its commercial research ventures, a minuscule return on an investment of $70 billion. For 1991, preliminary estimates are that the return rose slightly, to between $10 million and $12 million. Federal officials vow that returns will rise farther, but the process can take years because royalties are often linked to sales volume.
But private experts voice doubts. Smart business executives, they say, shy away from substantial links to programs like these because the military complex has traditionally cared little about low cost, looking for high performance instead. The upshot, analysts say, is that military experts often have a loose attitude about cost control.
"It's hard to retool engineers who have been taught to be sloppy and wasteful," said Eric Arnett, an arms expert at the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Washington.
 
Making It Work
The New Scene Still Out of Focus
 Even with Government contracts diminishing in number and size, the end of the cold war has in no way lessened calls for military readiness through advanced research. In some cases it has increased them. Some military experts see a host of potential new dangers on the horizon.
"Ominous threats are growing steadily in the third world," John S. Foster Jr., chairman of the Pentagon's Defense Science Board and a former director of the Lawrence Livermore weapons lab in California, said in a recent speech. Worry over the spread of ballistic missiles, fanned by Iraqi Scuds during the Persian Gulf war, has already increased Congressional interest in ground-based defenses similar to the Patriot interceptor.
Jacques S. Gansler, a former Pentagon procurement official, has long argued that in peacetime the Pentagon must expand research, not shrink it. "In time of reduced tensions," he said, "you need to increase your intelligence gathering so there are no surprises and increase your long-term investment so that if tensions rise, you're in a position to move."
 
Urging Break With the Past
 But an increasingly vocal group of analysts argues just the opposite, saying the military-industrial era is essentially over. Military threats, they say, have been eclipsed by economic ones. Besides, they add, any needed innovations for national defense should now come from the civilian sector, which has pulled ahead of the Pentagon.
They argue that most attempts to adapt cold-war research to the new era are doomed. What is needed, they say, is a clean break with the past and new Federal mechanisms to lower the price of peace.
These analysts applaud the growing displacement of scientists and engineers, saying the traumatic shift is planting seeds for whole new industries. But the Prediction Company and Cell Robotics notwithstanding, relatively few refugees from the arms complex have taken the entrepreneurial route.
Many analysts are less than sanguine about the odds of transforming the giant aerospace companies, saying most have been spoiled by big Pentagon budgets and are now unfit for the harsh world of free markets.
"The situation can be cured only by cutting defense budgets and redirecting national resources into broad industrial reinvigoration," Ann Markusen and Joel Yudken argue in "Dismantling the Cold War Economy," to be published in April by Basic Books.
Critics say the nation no longer needs three big centers for nuclear weapon design, or 66 Defense Department research labs, where endless red tape in hiring and procurement are often a recipe for poor performance.
But Congress, sensitive to pressure from millions of constituents and business leaders in the military complex, often fights shrinkage like this. One solution, experts say, is to cut wherever possible and throw open the rest of the cold-war complex to industry.
"These are critical resources," said Erich Bloch, past director of the National Science Foundation and a former executive at International Business Machines who now lobbies for Federal policies to enhance industrial vigor. "We're spending two-thirds of the Federal budget for research and development in this area. We have to get more out of it."
NEXT: The first post-cold-war Presidential campaign, and the new political balance.

HEADLINE: Job Losses Were Undercounted

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The declining economy in 1991 may have eliminated nearly twice as many jobs as previously estimated, a Labor Department official said today.
The department's widely tracked survey of employers showed non-farm payroll jobs totaled 108.8 million in December, 782,000 fewer than a year earlier. But, Martin Zeigler, an assistant commissioner in the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said revisions that would be incorporated into the survey by June would probably subtract an additional 650,000, for a total loss of 1.4 million jobs. 
 The expected revision of 650,000, first disclosed three months ago in Labor Department testimony to Congress's Joint Economic Committee, is roughly twice the size of the typical annual revision, he said.
Economists said the revision, would not change their view that the economy will recover this year. They noted that the changes were concentrated in the first three months of 1991, when the economy was at its weakest.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Revamping Takes a Toll On Kodak

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company today reported a loss for the fourth quarter of 1991 and full-year earnings of only $17 million because of close to $1 billion in restructuring charges.
Even without the charges, earnings slumped sharply, as the recession continued to slow film sales. Kodak announced the results after the close of the stock market; its shares rose 87.5 cents today, closing at $50.75 on the Big Board. 
 Kodak said it lost $400 million in the quarter, compared with a profit of $326 million, or $1.01 a share, in the 1990 quarter. The full-year profit, which was equal to 5 cents a share, was down 97.6 percent from earnings of $703 million, or $2.17 a share, in 1990.
Sales for the quarter were $5.16 billion, down slightly from $5.2 billion in the comparable 1990 period. For the year, sales were up 2.6 percent, to $19.65 billion from $19.15 billion.
 
More Retired Than Expected
 On Dec. 20, Kodak said it would take a $495 million charge primarily because more than twice as many employees as expected had enrolled in an early retirement program and to cover expenses for streamlining overseas film production and sell some businesses. The December announcement brought to $930 million the after-tax total of special charges the company took against 1991 earnings to reduce overhead and focus on its core photography business.
Without the restructuring charge, fourth-quarter earnings would have been $197 million, or 61 cents a share, down 40 percent from the similar period a year earlier. Earnings for 1991 would have been $1.05 billion, or $3.23 a share.
The 1990 results were reduced by a litigation judgment against Kodak in favor of the Polaroid Corporation. Without the judgment, Kodak's earnings for that year would have been $1.27 billion, or $3.91 a share.
Kodak's chief executive, Kay R. Whitmore, blamed the weak economy for the company's poor performance.
 
Recession Is Blamed
 "As if recession in the U.S. economy and a lackluster background for business in most of Europe were not enough to overcome, depression in the travel industry induced by the Mideast war continued throughout the year," Mr. Whitmore said.
"The fourth quarter was particularly difficult," he added, "as consumers restrained their spending and businesses put off purchases of office equipment."
Sales in Kodak's core imaging business -- which provides more than half the company's profits -- were down for the quarter and the year. Mr. Whitmore said sales in the company's information and chemical segments also fell short of targets in 1991.
Robert Maney, an industry analyst with Prudential Securities, said he did not believe that the film operations would be affected to such a degree. "Film used to be impervious to recession," he said. "It's just proven that it's not."
Mr. Whitmore said he did not expect to see significant improvements in the United States economy or in major European markets until the second half of 1992. Still, he said, the company expected to see higher sales and better earnings as a result of last year's restructuring.

HEADLINE: Aid Is Good, but Job Would Be Better

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 4

 BODY:
To people who have been out of work a long time, Congress's approval of 13 more weeks of unemployment benefits today was good news, but not nearly as good as a job.
"I think it's a good idea; it's needed," Ray Bradley, a computer salesman from Fairfield, said as he left the State Employment Security Division office here, where he had come to straighten out his eligibility for an initial 20 weeks of emergency benefits that Congress approved in November. 
 "But," he added, "I think the biggest thing we could do is take the income tax off unemployment. I've been out for a year, and I had to pay taxes."
If unemployment offices are rarely happy places, the mood in Connecticut's offices has soured badly in the last year, as people have taken longer and longer to find new jobs, whether blue-collar or white-collar.
"The whole tenor has changed in the last six to eight months," said Diane Krevolin, assistant manager of the unemployment compensation office here. "There's a pall over everyone."
Statewide, unemployment in November, the last month for which figures are available, was 6.9 percent, up from 2.5 percent in April 1988.
For the two-week period that ended Jan. 18, the Connecticut Labor Department reported 99,528 claims for unemployment benefits across the state. Of those people, 35,925, or 36 percent, had been out of work more than 26 weeks and so were eligible for the emergency benefits approved in November.
In Bridgeport, which had 9,352 claims during that period, 3,933, or 42 percent, were for the emergency extended benefits.
The numbers of claims are also up sharply, at their highest level since 1977, according to the Labor Department. Even though office hours have been extended, Ms. Krevolin said, on most days as many as 200 people are waiting in line outside when the doors open at 7:30 A.M.
Statewide, unemployment in November, the last month for which figures are available, was 6.9 percent, up from 2.5 percent in April 1988.
Those first emergency benefits will start expiring later this month, and so the additional 13 weeks approved today will carry people into May. While Mr. Bradley and others are glad to have the assistance, several people said that the benefits are only a help, not nearly a substitute for their former incomes, and that they are not encouraged about finding work soon.
"Basically, I've been overqualified for every job I've applied for," Mr. Bradley said, noting that he could not win even an interview until he deleted all dates from his resume, so as not to give away his age. He is 47 years old.
Frank Pope, who recently moved to Bridgeport from New Haven, has looked up and down southern Connecticut for work since the tire company where he worked shut down in October. He, too, is now receiving emergency benefits.
"To go out and try to find work in an economy like this is like trying to find a needle in a haystack," he said.
David Taft, a welder from Bridgeport who lost his job as a maintenance man at a private school in Southport in November 1990, said he had taken a train to Hartford on Monday to look for work. Like Mr. Bradley, he spent several months on his own, without benefits, before Congress extended the standard 26-week period.
Last November, with no income, he took a part-time job cleaning up for a welding shop, at $5 an hour. After a few weeks he quit.
"The thing is," Mr. Pope said, "you can find work, but you can't find work worth working for." On top of longer benefits, he said, "They could give us access to better jobs."

Next to him at left was David Taft, an unemployed welder, as they signed up for extended unemployment benefits in Bridgeport, Conn. (David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans to Sharpen Focus Of Its Sanctions Against Haiti

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that it would modify its embargo against Haiti's military Government to punish anti-democratic forces and ease the plight of workers who lost jobs because of the ban on trade.
As the State Department announced that the Administration would be "fine tuning" its economic sanctions, efforts in Congress to grant "temporary protected status" to more than 10,000 Haitian exiles in custody at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba, were running into serious problems in both the House and the Senate. This status would freeze the return of refugees until the end of the Haitian crisis. 
 Members of Congress, sharply divided on the issue of how to deal with an influx of refugees, cite bad economic times, an election year and, occasionally, fears of reported high rates of infection with the virus that causes AIDS among Haitian exiles for opposition to Congressional action.
 
'Time Is Just Not Right'
 "The time is just not right," said Arthur C. Helton, director of the refugee project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, one of many rights organizations, religious groups and prominent individuals protesting the resumption of forced return of Haitians on Saturday. Several hundred would-be refugees are being returned daily.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the Senate subcommittee on immigration and refugee affairs, said today that he would introduce a bill to suspend forced returns for two weeks, until President Bush can certify that conditions in Haiti are safe. In the House, Representative Charles Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, has been leading the call for temporary protected status for Haitians.
The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said today that the Administration would be collecting evidence on alleged financiers of the Sept. 30 coup or backers of army and police violence so that any assets they held in the United States could be frozen. The deposed Haitian President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has been advocating this, asserting that while poor Haitians are suffering, rich and influential ones are drawing on American bank accounts.
Miss Tutwiler said today that Washington could also deny visas to these Haitians.
The Treasury Department would also grant licenses to American companies to resume assembling goods in Haiti for re-export, the State Department said. More than 40,000 Haitians have lost jobs in the assembly sector because of the embargo.
The State Department spokeswoman said she did not know when these new measures would be put into effect.
At the same time, new diplomatic initiatives are being taken by Washington and other nations in the region to persuade the wavering democratic forces in Haiti's Parliament and some cooperative officers in a split military hierarchy to unite as a matter of urgency behind a new Prime Minister, Rene Theodore, whose nomination is stalled in the legislature.
The decision to modify the United States embargo is the latest in a series of Administration moves that have been alternately tough or concessionary as Washington tries to stem the flow of Haitian refugees while looking for more effective ways to hasten the collapse what the Administration calls an illegal Government in Haiti. The Organization of American States enacted a similar embargo in October, freezing Haitian Government assets, but not those of individuals, and barring trade except for humanitarian aid.
For more than two months, the Administration sought to overturn injunctions against forced returns, and finally were successful in both the Supreme Court and a Federal district appeals court in Atlanta. Refugee and human rights groups as well as some members of Congress called this approach inhumane.
"It was not our finest hour," said Dennis Gallagher, executive director of the private Refugee Policy Group in Washington, after the return of refugees resumed on Saturday, hours after a Supreme Court decision in the Administration's favor.
 
Administration Hard-Liners
 Support for a tough line against would-be refugees came from the National Security Council and President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, according to human rights and refugee groups who are in touch with Administration officials.
But a few days earlier, the Administration announced that Haitians fearing persecution could apply in Haiti for refugee resettlement in the United States, bypassing a risky boat trip and an asylum hearing in Miami. People granted refugee status abroad arrive in the United States with legal status.
In addition, in recent weeks the Immigration and Naturalization Service interviewers at Guantanamo have allowed 3,445 people to proceed to the United States to lodge formal requests for asylum -- about a third of the 9,937 Haitians interviewed.
International and national rights organizations and some members of Congress believe that the United States is violating the 1951 United Nations Refugee Convention and a subsequent 1967 protocol that prohibits sending home refugees with fears of persecution.
Other members of Congress take the Administration's view that the expanded immigration interviewing, with its high rates of asylum candidates, indicates that the United States is going out of its way to take in people with good reasons not to return to Haiti.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
MCI Profits Up 13%, to $144 Million

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 13 percent.
In light of the lingering recession, the gains at the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier were strong compared with the profit decline recently posted by A.T.& T., the industry leader. Earnings growth at U S Sprint, the No. 3 carrier, which is scheduled to report later this week, is also expected to be weak. 
 MCI reported that its fourth-quarter earnings rose to $144 million, or 52 cents a share, from $127 million, or 47 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Last month A.T.& T. said earnings in the fourth quarter had dropped more than 20 percent, to $635 million, or 48 cents a share. Quarterly revenue totaled $11.95 billion, up less than 1 percent. A.T.& T. cited the recession, growing competition and the sluggish performance of its new computer acquisition, the NCR Corporation.
 
Discount Plan Helped
 O. Gene Gabbard, MCI's chief financial officer, acknowledged that MCI, too, was being hurt by the recession but the damage was largely limited to small-business customers. MCI was helped mainly by additional customers attracted to the company by a new discount-calling plan.
But analysts said changes in bookkeeping also helped, such as a shift in depreciation policy that decreased quarterly operating expenses. "They basically decided that their plant and equipment was going to last longer than they had previously accounted for, thus reducing their costs by $5 million," said Robert B. Morris 3d, a telecommunications analyst for Goldman, Sachs.
Fourth-quarter revenue rose 8 percent, to $2.16 billion, from $2 billion in the fourth quarter of 1990.
MCI shares rose $1.625 each to close at $33.50 in over-the-counter trading yesterday.
For the full year, net income totaled $551 million, or $2.01 a share, up more than 84 percent from $299 million, or $1.06 a share, a year earlier. Annual revenue totaled $8.43 billion, up 9.8 percent from $7.68 billion.
MCI benefited somewhat from sharply lower interest costs as well as a full year of profitable revenue from its acquisition of Telecom USA, which had 1989 revenue of $713 million and was the nation's fourth-largest long-distance carrier when MCI acquired it in August 1990.
In the fourth quarter alone, a better basis for comparison because Telecom USA revenue was included in both the 1990 and 1991 periods, revenue growth was only 8 percent, slightly off the full-year pace for 1991.
 
Building Market Share
 MCI said its "Friends & Family" discount calling program had increased its business substantially, with five million customers enrolled -- about two million of them joining in the fourth quarter alone. MCI says that about half of these customers were new. Under the program, customers are given 20 percent discounts, in effect for recruiting relatives and friends to become MCI customers, who in turn qualify for discounts.
But there are limits to how long MCI can afford to build market share this way, since each subscriber to the plan reduces the company's profitability. A.T.& T., with a majority of the residential market, could not duplicate the plan without cannibalizing its own profits.
MCI said it had gained nearly 1 percent of market share in 1991, but did not specify whether it was share of revenue or of the minutes-of-use measurement by which actual telephone traffic is counted. Goldman, Sachs estimates that MCI traffic grew only four-tenths of 1 percent. Mr. Morris said MCI's minutes of use totaled 56.1 billion, or 17 percent of the market, up from 51 billion minutes, or 16.6 percent, in 1990.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
After Bad Start, Bush Seems To Have Steadied Support

BYLINE: By R.(TM)W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Feb. 4

 BODY:
President Bush's political standing in New Hampshire has finally begun to stabilize, Republican leaders here say, but some of them describe the electoral situation as highly volatile and suggest that he could still be seriously damaged by Patrick J. Buchanan's insurgent candidacy in the state's Presidential primary two weeks from today.
Former State Attorney General Tom Rath, who is considered one of New Hampshire's ablest Republican strategists, said that "the bleeding has been stopped" after a dangerously slow start by Mr. Bush. But he warned, "The electorate is not as settled as it should be at this stage from the President's point of view." 
 Having emphasized most of last month that the President cared about the recession in New Hampshire, the Bush campaign's current tactic is to blame higher taxes and other economic woes on the Democrats in Congress. Mr. Buchanan attributes the state's problems in considerable part to Mr. Bush.
A television commercial that went on the air last Friday shows the President in the Oval Office, promoting the economic recovery plan outlined in his State of the Union address, and telling New Hampshire voters: "I need your help now to send a real message to Congress to get this job done."
Mr. Buchanan, the conservative columnist and commentator, replied in an advertisement that went on the air this morning with an invitation to the state to "send Bush a message." The commercial ends with voters here chanting, "Read our lips!" -- a taunting reprise of the President's "No new taxes" pledge, which he broke in 1990 in a deficit-reduction deal with Congress.
But a poll taken for television station WMUR of Manchester by the University of New Hampshire suggests in a number of ways that Mr. Bush is winning the argument.
Conducted by telephone from last Thursday to Sunday, the poll showed that 62 percent of the respondents thought Mr. Bush had been "forced by Congress" to raise taxes, while only 19 percent thought the President had "betrayed voters' trust." The rest said they remained unsure.
Of 499 respondents in the survey, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4.4 percent, 60 percent said they supported Mr. Bush, with 23 percent backing Mr. Buchanan and 17 percent still undecided. That was one of the President's strongest showings since the campaign got under way, although the figures showed some undecided voters shifting to Mr. Buchanan.
"There is great discontent in the state among Republican voters," said Prof. David W. Moore, director of the university's survey center. "They are not satisfied with the economy, but they are nonetheless remaining quite loyal to the Republican President. For the most part they do not blame Bush for the poor conditions but rather the Democratic Congress."
Many seasoned Republican politicians in the Bush camp, some of whom expressed concern two weeks ago about his prospects, now say they expect him to get 65 percent or more of the vote. State Senator Susan McLane, who plans to write in the name of Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts rather than vote for Mr. Bush, said that "in the end, the undecideds will slide into the Presidential fold, because when they listen to Buchanan, they know he isn't the answer."
Gov. Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, who is managing Mr. Bush's campaign, put the situation this way: "I think there's no question we've taken the offensive. We have a message and we're delivering it aggressively. What worries me is that a lot of furious, frustrated people think they can vote however they want in the primary without having any effect on who lives in the White House next year.
"We have to convince the doubters that their vote has consequences. A vote for Pat Buchanan is a vote for Ted Kennedy and the Democrats, I keep saying, because it weakens George Bush in his fight against Congress."
But Paul Nagy, Mr. Buchanan's state manager, said the challenger was "on target as far as organization goes," and he contended that Mr. Buchanan was still "in a good position to get 20, 25, 30 percent of the vote." That would be enough "to hurt George Bush," Mr. Nagy said, even though well short of Mr. Buchanan's own recent statements that he hoped to win here. Other Buchanan aides said they had sensed a certain loss of momentum in recent days, but Mr. Nagy said he had noticed no slackening of pace.
One thing that could hurt the Bush effort would be a reopening of the old wounds in the state Republican heirarchy -- especially a revival of the long-standing enmity between Mr. Gregg and his father, Hugh, a former governor, and another onetime New Hampshire governor, John H. Sununu, the former White House chief of staff dismissed by Mr. Bush.
Until recently, the Greggs and Mr. Sununu had submerged their past differences to make common cause in behalf of the President. But the Governor and his father were reportedly infuriated by a column by Rowland Evans and Robert Novak this week that they believed to have been inspired by Mr. Sununu. The column suggested that Mr. Sununu had been dispatched to the state "to save Bush from embarrassment or worse."
Bush strategists deny that any such change of strategy happened and said Mr. Sununu had always been part of the campaign plan for New Hampshire. Governor Gregg said tersely and with evident displeasure, "As long as we win, we don't care what he does."
 
Bush Plans a Return
 Mr. Bush is to return to the state next week. In the meantime, a succession of surrogates have been carrying the fight to Mr. Buchanan, including Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who was in New Hampshire on Monday. A whole group of conservatives who are supporting Mr. Bush will be at a local group's fund-raising dinner in Manchester on Saturday, including Mr. Sununu, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, and Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Buchanan plans to be there, too.
Mr. Rath, the Attorney General, said the next step for the Bush campaign would come in a third wave of commercials later this week. For the first time the President will have ads that focus on his foreign-policy record, especially the American victory in the Persian Gulf.

HEADLINE: Dow Surges 38.69 in Hopes of Lower Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Fueled by renewed hopes of lower interest rates and a firm bond market, stocks rose yesterday in active trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average and some other indexes hitting record levels. By gaining 38.69, to close at 3,272.81, the Dow inched 0.67 point past the record it set on Jan. 28.
Investor sentiment was divided between those encouraged by the Congressional testimony of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and those focusing on economic uncertainty. The mixed feelings led to choppy trading, with the strength in bonds the decisive upward force. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 233.7 million shares, up from 185.3 million on Monday, with gaining issues easily outpacing losers by 1,116 to 620. The Big Board composite rose 2.18, to 228.79.
 
S.& P. 500 Rises
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.32, to 413.85, while the American Stock Exchange composite rose 2.36, to 413.68.
Trading was just as as heavy on the Nasdaq, as the composite hit a new high of 613.00, up 7.57, 0.18 over its Jan. 15 level. The Russell 2,000, another market barometer, reached a new high of 207.82, up 1.95.
Ricky Harrington, director of equity investment for Marion Bass Securities, said the tone of the market was essentially set by the bond market, which was responding to Mr. Greenspan's remarks that the Fed had not ruled out further interest-rate cuts.
Mr. Harrington said the bond market rally carried over into the stock market, outweighing any possible disappointment that might come as a result of today's announcement by the Treasury on the size of the Government's quarterly refunding and by the employment report due out on Friday.
"Conditions in the market are still not set for a correction and as long as interest rates are stable or fall it will be difficult for the equity market to move lower," Mr. Harrington said. "But a correction is still out there."
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said it tracked a number of programs that when combined lifted the Dow 13.19 points.
Philip H. Smyth, an analyst with Birinyi, noted that among the Dow's big movers yesterday were Merck, up 4 1/2, to 158 7/8, on news that the Food and Drug Administration was expected to recommend approval for Proscar, a new prostate drug. Goodyear Tire was up 2 3/4, to 64 3/4, and Du Pont was up 2, to 48.
Kemper shares were sent tumbling, after the Chicago-based insurance group announced lower earnings and an addition to reserves against possible decline in its real estate investment portfolio. Analysts said the announcement reflected a reversal of earlier comments on the portfolio's status and took Wall Street by surprise. The stock fell 4, to 36 3/4, as investor concern was noted in other insurance stocks as well, Aetna Life and Casualty was down 1, to 42 1/2, and Cigna, slipped 1/8, to 55 1/8.
Amid speculation that it will report a smaller-than-expected loss sometime this week, Chrysler stock rose to its highest level in a year, 16 3/8, up 1 3/8 in active trading.
Better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings by Amgen Inc. lifted the biopharmaceutical company's standing with several analysts who raised their earnings estimates. Amgen rose 1 1/4, to 71.
Advanced Micro Devices said it could only speculate about the rise in its stock price to 20 5/8, up 1 1/8, in active trading, guessing that it may be a technical rebound from last week's decline.
Cummins Engine, rose 2 3/8, to 58 7/8, after the diesel engine maker reported higher profit margins and a smaller-than-expected loss in its fourth-quarter earnings.
Jill Krutick, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, rated Mattel, Hasbro and Fisher-Price stocks "buys," noting that an analysis of how toy stocks traded over the last six years show that they rise an average 20 percent in the weeks before and after the American International Toy Fair, which takes place next week. Mattel, was up 1 1/8, to 33 1/2; Hasbro rose 1 3/4, to 41, and Fisher-Price was up 1/4, to 37 1/2

HEADLINE: Loss Is Reported by Goodrich

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The B. F. Goodrich Company reported today that it lost money in the fourth quarter and all of 1991, partly because of one-time charges totaling $90 million.
John Ong, the chairman, said the company was also hurt by the recession. 
 The specialty chemicals, vinyls and aerospace company said it lost $106.7 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to earnings of $14.1 million, or 47 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1990. Sales rose 5.2 percent, to $607.4 million, from $575.8 million.
The company said the special charges in the fourth quarter included $77.4 million, or $3.05 a share, for the phasing out of high-cost vinyl operations at three locations, and $3.7 million, or 14 cents a share, for a voluntary retirement program.
Without the one-time items, the net loss for the fourth quarter would have been $16.9 million, the company said.
Quarterly operating income rose to $22 million at the aerospace business, from $12 million a year earlier. But the specialty chemicals division had an operating loss of $3.4 million, while the vinyl products business lost $141 million.
For all of 1991, the company lost $80.6 million, in contrast to net income of $136.3 million, or $5.04 a share, in 1990. Sales increased 1.6 percent last year, to $2.47 billion, from $2.43 billion in 1990.
Shares of Goodrich were down 75 cents today, closing at $41.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Doesn't Bar Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
In unusually direct language, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the central bank had not ruled out further interest rate cuts as insurance to push the economy out of its doldrums.
In testifying before the House Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan, the nation's most influential economic policy maker, seemed to aim his remarks at the nation's financial markets, which had tumbled last week after he testified before the Senate Banking Committee. 
 Today stock and bond prices surged, with the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average climbing 38.69 points to a new record of 3,272.81. [Pages D10 and D16.]
 
Markets Fell Last Time
 Mr. Greenspan said today, as he had last Wednesday, that he believed the rate cuts already ordered by the Federal Reserve would be enough to lift the economy out of recession. But when he had said the same thing before the Senate panel, stock and bond prices dropped sharply because many investors concluded that monetary easing was over.
Today Mr. Greenspan said: "We expect that the amount of monetary ease in the pipeline is adequate to turn the economy onto the path of sustained recovery. But assessing the economic outlook at the present time is extraordinarily difficult."
Expressing surprise that investors had taken his comments last week to mean that interest rates had bottomed, Mr. Greenspan added that the Fed was "of course continuing to evaluate whether some additional insurance in the way of further monetary ease would be appropriate."
In the view of some analysts, Mr. Greenspan's comments took on added importance because the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, held its first meeting of the year today as soon as the Fed chairman finished testifying.
 
Increasing the Chances
 The report of the deliberations at the closed two-day meeting is not scheduled to be released until early April, and Fed watchers have been saying the central bank would probably not reduce rates until March or April, if at all, after assessing the economy's progress. But Mr. Greenspan's testimony appeared to some both to increase the chances of a rate cut and to move up the date.
With the economy continuing to stall and the Federal Reserve facing pressure from the Bush Administration, the central bank cut short-term interest rates a full percentage point on Dec. 20. It reduced its discount rate, the rate at which it lends money to banks, to 3 1/2 percent, and the Federal funds rate, the rate that banks lend money to each other, to 4 percent.
The cuts the Fed has engineered over the last several months have brought interest rates to their lowest point in 27 years.
Long-term rates, however, have edged up slightly in recent weeks, and when asked why today, Mr. Greenspan pointed to two possible causes: a belief among some investors that the economy has bottomed out, and the heavy borrowing to finance the Federal deficit. He said he doubted such a rise resulted from increased inflationary expectations because he said inflationary pressures continued to ease.
Mr. Greenspan said the economy's performance had been "disappointing," adding that "some strong forces have been working against a typical cyclical revival in economic activity."
In this recession, he noted, households and business had unusually high debt ratios, which have been keeping them from increasing expenditures. But he said lower interest rates were helping to ease debt burdens as consumers refinanced mortages and companies replaced debt with equity.
 
Cites Consumer Confidence
 "We thus have already made considerable progress in the balance sheet adjustment process, and this unusual restraint on economic activity should begin to dissipate, hopefully in the reasonably near future," he said.
He added that stubbornly low consumer confidence was also holding back recovery. Consumer confidence, he noted, is far lower than during the 1974-75 recession, when unemployment and the loss of output were greater. In his view, consumer confidence continued to stay low because of a concern that American living standards were growing more slowly -- or even declining.
Mr. Greenspan's other main message to the House committee today was that Congress and the President had to do more to bring down the mushrooming budget deficit, which he said was an "insidious" force that sapped the nation's savings, investment and, ultimately, living standards. He said the Government's deficit spending reduced the amount of money available for the business investment needed to improve productivity and living standards.
Mr. Greenspan was called before the House committee to give his views on budget proposals and the state of the economy. As he did last week before the Senate committee, Mr. Greenspan said he opposed Congressional and Administration plans to spur the economy by lowering taxes or spending more -- although he noted that many eminent economists disagreed with him.
He voiced fears that these competing stimulus proposals could produce "bidding wars," which were "to be avoided at all costs. Mr. Greenspan said, "It would be extremely detrimental to our longer-term outlook if this budget process hemorrhaged in an endeavor to come to grips with the admittedly very difficult short-term economic problems that currently confront us."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. PROPOSES CURB ON LAWSUITS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Bush Administration and Congressional Republicans proposed legislation today to change the rules of litigation in Federal courts, continuing a campaign that has positioned Vice President Dan Quayle as a scourge of the legal profession.
The main proposals of the legislation, which is intended to reduce the number of frivolous or otherwise unnecessary lawsuits and to speed the civil-trial process, are carefully limited in scope. 
 But they have provided a highly visible and, his aides say, a broadly popular campaign theme for Mr. Quayle, who heads a White House regulatory council that endorsed them last year.
"Non-lawyers support our proposals 100 to 1," Mr. Quayle said at a news conference on the legislation today. "More importantly, lawyers support our reform package 4 to 1. That ought to be a message to the leadership of the American Bar Association."
 
An Unflattering Light
 The association has been critical of the Administration's proposed litigation rules, in part because it disagrees with some of the particulars, but mainly because of how Mr. Quayle has presented them -- in a light that is distinctly unflattering to lawyers.
Officials of the bar association offered little objection today to the bill itself, which was introduced on the Administration's behalf by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., a Republican of upstate New York, and Senator Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa. Some of the proposals conform to the A.B.A.'s own suggestions.
Even the central and most widely debated provision, which would in some civil cases require that litigants who bring unsuccessful lawsuits pay some of the legal costs of the defendants, was shrugged off by Talbot S. D'Alemberte, the president of the bar association.
"It seems to me that is a modest proposal, and I don't have any personal great objection to it," he said in a phone conversation from Dallas, where the association's House of Delegates is meeting.
 
Some Important Exceptions
 The "loser pays" provision would apply only to cases that were brought before Federal courts instead of state courts at the choice of the claimant. Cases that were moved to Federal courts because a defendant wanted it that way would not be affected.
There would be two limits on the costs of defense to be paid by an unsuccessful claimant. First, these costs could not exceed the amount spent by the claimant in pressing the lawsuit. Second, a judge would have discretion to reduce or eliminate the payment simply by deciding that doing so would serve justice.
Mr. D'Alemberte welcomed another facet of the Administration proposal, which would encourage litigants to settle their cases through mediation. During a three-year experiment, each Federal judicial circuit would designate a courthouse where mediators would attempt to settle cases out of court. Mr. D'Alemberte cautioned, though, that funds would have to be provided to make this idea work.
He criticized a third proposal, which would require claimants to give written notice of their claims and set forth the damages before bringing suit. Here, too, the idea is to encourage out-of-court settlements, but Mr. D'Alemberte argued that the result might be simply another layer of procedure.
 
Not Meant as 'Attack'
 The bar association is to unveil soon its own proposals for litigation changes, which will include expanding legal aid for poor and middle-class people, he said. The Administration plan includes no such provisions.
Representative Fish, who like Mr. Quayle is a lawyer, said the legislation "is not intended as an attack on our nation's legal system or the legal profession." But he added:
"The fact is that the American people sense that something is wrong with our legal system. They believe there are too many lawsuits, too many excessive damage awards. They believe that there is too much litigation, and this is hurting the American economy."
Mr. Quayle himself, as he has done in a series of appearances for the last six months, lashed out at the bar association in a way reminiscent of the 1988 Bush-Quayle campaign's frequent criticisms of the American Civil Liberties Union. The Vice President said:
"The American Bar Association's position is this: They want to increase taxpayer financing for litigation, they want to increase a new bureaucracy in the Justice Department to hire more lawyers, and they want more grants for lawyers.
"Well, that may be the reform package of the American Bar Association, but that is not the reform package of the American people. I'm telling you the American people are on my side on this issue."
In response, Mr. D'Alemberte said sarcastically that he was "absolutely delighted" by the title the Administration had chosen for its bill: the Access to Justice Act of 1992.
"I hope that they really do mean to increase access to justice," he said. But he said the version introduced today offered "nothing for the Legal Services Corporation," the Federal agency that provides free legal assistance to the poor, "and nothing to make justice more accessible to the poor and middle class."

HEADLINE: Haven for Haitians Backed in Miami

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 4

 BODY:
After months of indecision and a complicated legal battle, the Bush Administration has begun forcing 15,000 Haitian refugees to return to their homeland. But here in the city that was the main destination of those boat people, Mayor Xavier Suarez has been handing out bumper stickers that read "Interdict Drugs, Not Haitians."
Like hundreds of thousands of other people in the Miami area, Mr. Suarez, a 42-year-old lawyer born in Cuba, came here as a refugee from a dictatorship that repressed and impoverished its people. For those immigrants, as for many of those who were born here, Washington's decision to classify most Haitians as "economic refugees" ineligible for political asylum, a policy that The Miami Herald on Sunday called "Operation Racist Shield," smacks of hypocrisy and a double standard. 
 "In my case, how could I not be in their favor if I was accepted here 31 years ago and and the whole world extended a hand to me and my family," Mr. Suarez said, expressing a sentiment that is being echoed in call-in programs broadcast on Spanish-language radio stations here.
"I think the old distinction between political and economic refugees just doesn't wash any more. The Haitians come here with a lot of good strong societal values and just want an opportunity. We should give it to them."
 
Election-Year Policy
 Florida officials and refugee advocates say the Bush Administration's forced repatriation of Haitians from Guantanamo Bay Naval Base is motivated at least in part by a desire not to alienate voters here. The President's advisers are said to harbor fears that a new flood of immigration into Florida could cost Mr. Bush and the Republican Party support in the nation's fourth largest state in an election year.
"Many senior-level officials have emphasized that this President is not Jimmy Carter," who lost Florida in 1980 to Ronald Reagan amid an influx of Cuban refugees, said Arthur Helton, who as director of the Refugee Project of the Lawyers' Committee on Human Rights has had many conversations in Washington. "That fear was animating discussion in the Government last fall when this issue was unfolding."
But most public officials here, regardless of party, regard that line of reasoning as inherently flawed. According to a poll conducted for The Miami Herald and a Miami television station in December, 57 percent of Florida residents believe that Haitians should be allowed to remain in the United States until it is safe for them to return to their homeland.
"People are ambivalent, but they do want to give a break to folks who will be in danger if forced to go back to their countries," said Robert Joffee of Mason-Dixon Opinion Research, which conducted the survey. "They don't seem to view these immigrants as a serious threat to their own well-being, and they don't make a distinction between political and economic refugees."
 
Backing for Refugees
 Mr. Joffee said 813 people were interviewed in the telephone poll in a four-day period. The margin of sampling error was 3.5 percent, and the results showed that "so far as immigration attitudes are concerned" there is no distinction "between those who are in trouble because of the recession and those who aren't," he said.
According to the poll, 51 percent of all whites were in favor of allowing the Haitians to take refuge in the United States. Support was even stronger among Hispanic residents, who are the largest single ethnic group in the Miami area, making up half of the population of Dade County, and blacks, 80 percent of whom wanted the Haitians to be granted refuge.
Support for granting refugee status to the Haitians appears to cut not only across racial and ethnic divisions, but partisan lines as well. Indeed, Florida's Republican Senator, Connie Mack, has been one of the most outspoken critics of the refusal to grant refugee status to Haitians, calling the Administration's policy "morally wrong" and "a disgrace" and introducing legislation that would grant Haitians who arrive here temporary protected status.
"He has taken a strong position, and is definitely an ally and friend," said Jacques Despinosse, president of the Haitian-American Democratic Club here. "We are Democrats, but if the election were held today, we would tell all Haitian people to vote for Connie Mack because he believes in human rights."
 
2 Waves of Immigrants
 The prospect of an influx of Haitians has awakened some hard feelings in Florida, political and community leaders here agree. But most of that resentment seems to be directed at the Federal Government, which has done little to help the state defray the costs of absorbing two large waves of immigration in recent years.
As a result of the Mariel boatlift in 1980, some 125,000 Cuban refugees came to the United States, most of whom eventually settled in Miami. Then, in the late 1980's, at the height of the Reagan Administration's efforts to unseat the Sandinista Government, more than 100,000 Nicaraguans came here hoping to escape civil war and political repression in their homeland.
In a letter to Attorney General William P. Barr last month, Gov. Lawton Chiles complained of "the federal Government's inaction on this issue since 1982." He urged the Bush Administration to make it possible for Florida to apply for $35 million included in an Immigration Emergency Fund, noting that his position had the support of all 21 members of the state's Congressional delegation.
In the letter, Mr. Chiles, a Democrat, noted that Mr. Barr has stated that "immigration and foreign policies are the exclusive province of the President and Congress" and added that "I could not agree with you more."
Florida officials have said they are still awaiting reimbursement for more than $100 million spent to resettle Cubans and Nicaraguans and want Washington to bear the expense of accommodating Haitians, 85 percent of whom have expressed a desire to settle in Florida.
"People agree that we should give them refuge," said Daryl L. Jones, a state representative whose district has large white, black and Hispanic populations. "It's just a question of cost. The common person doesn't make the distinctions the President does. They see a country in turmoil, they remember Baby Doc. On this issue, it's hard to tell Republicans from Democrats."

HEADLINE: Kentucky Trying to Find Money to Better Schools

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
The five-year plan for Kentucky school reform, the broadest education overhaul ever undertaken by a state, faces a stern test in its second year as legislators grapple with how to finance the plan in a recession.
The plan, which went into effect in the 1990-91 school year, cost nearly $600 million in its first year alone for changes in 176 districts, including offering early childhood education, instituting school-based management and raising the compulsory school age to 18 years old from 16. It also gives state education officials the authority to remove boards and superintendents and take over districts for not complying. 
 Like New Jersey and Texas, Kentucky was forced by the State Supreme Court to revamp its school-financing system after 66 districts charged that it was inequitable because it was based primarily on property taxes, enabling rich districts to spend more. The high court also told the state to overhaul the very structure of its education system, calling it unconstitutional.
"Even though people disagree with this piece of the legislation or that piece, there is no other effort that comes close to what Kentucky is doing," said David Hornbeck, a school-restructuring expert who helped to design the state's package.
But after the plan's first year, which was supported entirely by increases in taxes and the creation of new ones, lawmakers face tough decisions on how to finance the second year. State revenue is off because of the recession.
Gov. Brereton C. Jones, a Democrat who took office last year, is expected to unveil his budget tomorrow to the legislature, now in session in Frankfort. The Governor and key lawmakers said they support the plan, so some education officials said they expect financing for other departments and services to be cut.
One pressing need is additional money to award districts under a local tax-incentive plan. Under that plan, school districts can receive extra state aid if they raise their local tax rate above 35 cents for every $100 in property value. The state allocated $25 million last year and this year for the program, but more districts than the state expected raised their taxes beyond that threshold. As a result, the state now owes school districts $75 million for the first year alone, according to the State Education Department.
Each district has received about a third of what it is entitled to under the plan. Bill Griffith, a spokesman for Governor Jones, said, "The Governor's priority is to keep the reform package alive and going."
