HEADLINE: In Space, and in East-West Politics, It's a Very Long Voyage to Mars

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
As the nation's civilian space program drifts aimlessly, undone by the cold war's demise, calls are rising for the United States to join its former Russian foes in history's most ambitious voyage -- sending humans across many millions of miles of space to explore Mars.
The undertaking would tap skills of East and West and give both sides needed new direction, experts say. They note that NASA's $14 billion-a-year budget is under fire and that Moscow's space program is cracking under political and economic problems. 
 "There's a reservoir of skills, facilities and capabilities in the former Soviet Union that ought to be used for common objectives," says John M. Logsdon, a space-policy expert at George Washington University. "It makes no sense to throw it away."
Last month, Russian scientists called for a Mars mission, echoing earlier proposals by private American groups like the Planetary Society, the National Space Society and the Federation of American Scientists.
 
Just Talk, for Now
 The White House is said to be actively interested, if uncommitted. In 1990 President Bush announced an "exploratory dialogue" with the Soviet Union about joint ventures in space, including a manned trip to Mars. So far, however, East-West action on this issue has gone no farther than polite discussions.
Originally, the space programs of both East and West were anything but aimless. Both were cold-war creations, weapons in a costly race for technical superiority and global intimidation: The Soviet Union launched the first satellite in 1957 and the first man into space in 1961, then America forged ahead by landing men on the moon in 1969. The United States pressed onward in 1981 to launch the world's first reusable spaceship, the winged shuttle.
But this extraordinary feat of engineering initially had no mission aside from getting to the Moon before the Russians did. "The cold war turned our space program into a propaganda program, always in search of spectacular, high-profile stunts," said Walter A. McDougall, a historian at the University of Pennsylvania.
The Russians concentrated on heft -- bigger rockets, longer missions, more frequent launchings. Beginning in 1971, the Soviet Union put into orbit a series of manned space stations that have kept Moscow's astronauts circling Earth for increasingly long periods.
 
What Each Could Contribute
 Space experts say this experience in long-duration space flights would be of great value on Mars voyages. The Russians could also help in rocketry. Recently, scientists from Moscow described their efforts to perfect nuclear engines and proposed collaboration on an atom-powered trip to the red planet.
For its part, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has much technology critical for a Mars venture and has sent astronauts to a planetary body and returned them safely. But NASA is leery of a joint expedition. Among other things, it worries that political discord in the former Soviet Union would rule out the kind of long-term cooperation needed for the endeavor.
Advocates of a joint Mars voyage say that it would foster the kind of political stability Moscow now wants, bolstering the Russian Government's legitimacy and helping to stem the growing exodus of Russian scientists and engineers to arms factories in foreign lands, a gnawing Western worry in the post-cold-war world.

HEADLINE: Montreal Journal;
The Proud City of 'Great Events' Has a Great Fall

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
When a 55-ton chunk of concrete fell from the outer wall of the Olympic Stadium here last summer, the immediate casualty was the rest of the home season for the Montreal Expos, the city's baseball team. But because the stadium is a landmark, the crumbling of its wall was taken by many here as a symbol of the economic and social problems that have gnawed away at the city's self-confidence.
Stylish and innovative, the stadium seemed like an ideal talisman for French-speaking Canada when it was commissioned for the 1976 Summer Olympic Games. But because the structure and its retractable roof were plagued with technical problems, it ended up costing the province of Quebec more than $2 billion, some of it still being paid off by Montrealers with a special property tax. 
 Many Montrealers say their city, like the stadium, has become a monument to broken ambitions, a place where spectacles and illusions overwhelmed reality. In the 1960's there was Expo '67, a shimmering world's fair. In the 1970's there were the Olympics, and a new airport.
In the 1980's Montreal's leaders boasted that the city was becoming the most international on the continent, a Paris of North America that would add the charm of its French culture and 18th-century architecture to inflows of capital and technology from Asia, Europe and the United States.
 
The Bubble Has Burst
 But in the 1990's the city is in the grip of bitter self-reproach, centering on a realization that the billions of dollars spent on the "great events" of recent decades created a bubble that has burst.
"There is a lot of morosite right now," Jean Dore, the city's 47-year-old Mayor, said in an interview, using a French word for gloominess.
In 1986 Mr. Dore led a reform movement that took over city hall from Jean Drapeau, the Mayor who ran Montreal as a personal fief for a quarter of a century. For those seeking a scapegoat for the current problems, Mr. Drapeau, now in retirement, is an easy mark. But Mr. Dore said Mr. Drapeau's era had to be seen in perspective.
"In the period from 1960 to 1985, those 'great events' put us on the map," he said. "But we paid a price, and that was that we did not adopt a strategy for basic economic renewal until the mid-1980's."
Much about Montreal, particularly the old town, with its snug cafes and theaters and art galleries, remains as alluring as ever. But elsewhere, the markers of the distress press in: rising rates of violent crime; heightening racial tensions between the police and immigrant communities; a 20 percent unemployment rate among the city's 1.3 million people; crowded soup kitchens and homeless shelters; vacant development lots and abandoned construction sites.
New hotels and office buildings begun in the 1980's struggle with crippling vacancy rates, while St. Catherine Street, heart of the central shopping district, is gap-toothed for a mile or more with stores that have been abandoned or are holding going-out-of-business sales.
For shelter from harsh winters and humid summers, many of the city's chic boutiques have moved into modern shopping atriums, but they too are often deserted at the height of the business day.
Along with these problems, common across Canada in the recession, there is a distinctive and painful one for a city that has been the energizing heart of French Canada since its founding 350 years ago: A flight of middle-class Quebecers to the suburbs, which has reduced the proportion of inner-city residents speaking French as a first language to barely half.
 
Immigrants Move In
 As native residents have moved out, immigrants, many unemployed, have moved in. About 25 percent of those on welfare are immigrants, and a rising proportion of these, many from Haiti, are black.
Marcel Cote, an influential economist, wrote in a report he delivered to the Quebec government last year on behalf of Groupe Secor, a Montreal consulting concern, that behind an "illusion of prosperity" the city had remained rooted in a rusting past of steel foundries, refineries and textile mills. As a result, he said, the city had declined not only relative to Toronto, its traditional rival, but to cities in the Northeastern United States, including Boston, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.
But while just about everybody agrees that Montreal is in trouble, comparing its problems with those of America's blighted cities may be overdrawn. Mr. Dore, for one, seemed chagrined at the comparison.
"We have 60,000 people living downtown, and our streets are safe," he said. "Even if our economy was slow for 10 years, we'd still not be in as big a mess in terms of social problems as Detroit or New York."
The Quebec government announced in December that it would spend $350 million on a new development plan for the city, one that will focus on efforts to foster "clusters" of smaller businesses around high-technology industries like aerospace, pharmaceuticals and telecommunications.
 
Language Laws Are Issue
 In what many here see as a more startling acknowledgment of the need for new approaches, some French-speaking politicians and commentators have begun urging a repeal, or at least an easing, of the French-only language laws adopted in the mid-1970's that did much to prompt an exodus of 200,000 English-speaking Montrealers to Toronto.
Others believe that the city's economic woes will have more far-reaching political consequences, perhaps even deciding the struggle over Quebec's future as part of Canada. A referendum on independence is scheduled for Oct. 26.
A parade of Montreal business leaders have argued in recent weeks that the economic costs of independence would be too great. Mr. Dore has not said how he will vote. But he acknowledged that Montreal's hopes for recovery were being damaged by the bitterness of the independence struggle.
"We want the situation resolved as quickly as possible," he said. "Uncertainty is always a killer in terms of economic development."

Many of the city's chic boutiques have moved into modern shopping atriums that are often deserted at peak business hours. Les Cours Mont Royal, a shopping mall, was nearly empty at 6 P.M. on a recent Friday. (Jonathan Wenk for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Key Congressmen Vow To Act Soon on Taxes

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Both the House and Senate tax-writing committees will vote this month on President Bush's tax and growth program and on competing Democratic proposals, their chairmen said today. Votes in both houses are expected before the March 20 deadline set by Mr. Bush last month.
Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, said his panel would act by the end of next week. And Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, said in a brief interview that he expected his group to act during the week of Feb. 24. 
 Mr. Rostenkowski said his committee would not follow Administration wishes and split its tax proposals into two bills, one for quick action and one for later. Dividing the bill, he said, "would start us down the slippery slope to a 1981-style bidding war."
The powerful chairman, who is often readier to deal with Mr. Bush than some of his Democratic colleagues would prefer, complained today that in a Presidential election year the Administration wanted a few popular tax cuts up front, with the difficult actions needed to pay for them to come later.
Quick Congressional action could have both political and economic consequences. Action before March 20 would make it much harder for President Bush to accuse the Democratic-controlled Congress of prolonging the recession. And fast action would enable business executives, home buyers and others to know what the tax rules were going to be, reducing any tendency to delay purchases because of uncertainty.
Mr. Rostenkowski made his comments as he sought to assert control of this year's tax-writing process at the beginning of three days of hearings on tax and growth measures. In today's session the Administration and Democrats exchanged ritualistic criticisms of each other's pet ideas.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, told Representative Beryl Anthony, Democrat of Arkansas, "I believe it would be very dangerous" to try to pay for some of the Administration's tax cuts by increasing tax rates on higher-income earners, a key Democratic objective.
Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, scorned the Administration's central proposal, a cut in capital gains taxes, as a "tax break for the rich." He told Nicholas F. Brady, Secretary of the Treasury, that his extravagant claims on the economic good such a cut would do amounted to a boast that "other than curing the common cold, it will do just about everything."
In recent years, advocates of a higher maximum tax and supporters of a capital gains cut have battled to stalemates with no change in the law.
The Administration witnesses and such Republican committee members as Representatives Bill Archer of Texas and Philip M. Crane of Illinois suggested that quick adoption of seven measures in Mr. Bush's program was all the committee needed to do right away.
But, acknowledging political reality, Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said the Administration would of course welcome consideration of more parts of Mr. Bush's package.
He said that if the committee wanted to add other proposals to the Administration's short list, which includes captal gains, accelerated depreciation of investments and a $5,000 tax credit for first-time home buyers, it could pay for them by picking and choosing among various proposals for spending cuts in the Administration's budget. He said the House leaders could direct other committees to make the spending cuts.
 
Trading Off on Taxes
 Mr. Rostenkowski rejected that proposal, saying the tax bill would have to be revenue neutral on its own, setting the stage for an almost certain Democratic attempt to impose some sort of surcharge on high-income taxpayers to pay for some sort of middle-class tax cut.
The shape of the committee proposal will probably not become clear until it starts voting on specific provisions next Wednesday. Mr. Rostenkowski said today that he would keep the committee in session to vote on the bill "through the weekend if necessary." There is no clear scheduling beyond that.
Under that timetable the whole House could be ready to act during the week of Feb. 24. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley today predicted "a very early vote." He said it would come well before the March 20 deadline Mr. Bush proclaimed in his State of the Union speech.
Mr. Boskin offered the most urgent call for adoption of the heart of Mr. Bush's program, which also includes modifications of the alternative minimum tax for business, the easing of passive-loss restrictions on real estate developers, the waiver of penalties on I.R.A. withdrawals by first-time home buyers, and several proposals to facilitate real estate investment by pension funds and others.
He told the committee that the Administration's forecast was that the economy would grow 2.2 percent in 1992 and 3 percent in 1993.
"The unemployment rate may rise slightly early in the year," he said, "but if the President's policies are enacted, should start to decline thereafter. Inflation and interest rates should remain relatively low. If the President's proposals are not enacted, the economy is less likely to improve and the improvement is likely to be slower and weaker."
Committee Democrats pressed the Administration witnesses over their failure to include on their quick action list Mr. Bush's proposal to increase the personal tax exemption for each child by $500. Mr. Brady said that "we did not conceive the personal exemption as a growth measure" requiring fast action.
Representative Marty Russo, Democrat from Illinois, also complained that an increased personal exemption for children would benefit high-income taxpayers more than low-income people. He said the proposal should be made into a tax credit.

Brady, left, before the House Ways and Means Committee. Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, listened at center. (Lisa Berg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
U.S. Securities Up in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell in thin trading yesterday, reversing the price declines recorded Monday.
Traders and analysts said market participants took some comfort from Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, who went out of his way to emphasize that the Fed stood ready to lower interest rates further if that was needed to promote a recovery. 
 In addition, a report on car sales for the last 10 days of January showed a pickup, which some analysts attributed to pent-up demand and lower interest rates, as well as depressed sales a year earlier because of the Persian Gulf war. But for the entire month, sales remained mired around 5.9 million units, analysts said, roughly the same level recorded for December.
"These numbers show that pent-up demand is still waiting to be unleashed," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at the Paine Webber Group. "Right now, the economy is still treading water."
Uncertainty about today's announcement from the Treasury about the size and makeup of the quarterly refunding auctions limited the size of the gains, and also served as a disincentive to trade.
"We are trying to build a little bit of a base," one government securities trader said. "But you can't get a good view of what the market is going to do until we get a look at the refunding package. Right now, most retail accounts that normally are in the market have moved to the sidelines."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10231/32 late yesterday, up 7/8 point, to yield 7.74 percent, compared with 7.81 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10121/32 , up 19/32 , to yield 7.25 percent. The 6.25 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 7/32 , up 10/32 , to yield 6.43 percent. And the 4.875 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 5/8, up 3/32 , to yield 5.07 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates, which should be most sensitive to a change in market sentiment about a coming shift in Fed policy, fell yesterday, but only modestly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.82 percent in late trading, down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.87 percent.
In other developments, an offering of $85 million worth of New York State general obligation bonds met with strong demand in the tax-exempt municipal bond market, particularly among retail investors.
But the effects of the recent downgrade of the state's bond rating pushed up borrowing costs by as much as 30 basis points from November, the last time the state sold general obligation debt.
The securities, which were sold at competitive bid, were won by an investor group led by Paine Webber.
 
New York State Bonds
 The bonds were reoffered to investors with yields ranging from 3.70 percent on securities maturing in 1993 to 6.10 percent in 1998, 6.60 percent in 2003, 6.95 percent in 2008 and a maximum yield of 7.10 percent on bonds maturing in 2012.
The last New York State issue in November, 1991, carried a maximum yield of 6.80 percent.
The securities are rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Investment bankers at Paine Webber said that as of late yesterday the issue had an unsold balance of $18.5 million.
In the high-yield junk bond market, demand was so strong for an offering of senior subordinated notes by the Stop and Shop Store Companies that the size of the issue was increased to $250 million, from $200 million.
The 9.75 percent noncallable notes were priced at $100, or par, 2.45 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
 
Strong Showing by Junk Issue
 It is the first time a security carrying a B rating has priced an issue at less than three percentage points above Treasuries, according to the BT Securities Corporation, which acted as lead manager for the underwriting.
The securities are rated B by Moody's and B-1 by Standard & Poor's.
New issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a two-part, $325 million offering of 10-year and 30-year first mortgage bonds by Texas Utilities Inc.
The $150 million worth of 10-year 8.125 percent noncallable bonds were priced at $99.759 to yield 8.16 percent, 88 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $175 million of 30-year bonds maturing Feb. 1, 2022, have a coupon of 8.875 percent and were priced at $99.65 to yield 8.908 percent, 1.15 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing. These securities are noncallable for 10 years.
Both parts of the issue are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues rose by about a quarter of a point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities said prices of most widely quoted issues had dipped by an eighth of a point in sluggish trading.

HEADLINE: Aquarium Raises Hopes for Camden's Waterfront

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 4

 BODY:
Along a stretch of Delaware River waterfront near where the Campbell Soup Company once produced 10 million cans of soup a day and helped nourish Camden into a thriving industrial town, officials are pinning their hopes for the city's revitalization on fish.
Nearly 10 years after the idea was born and just more than three years after building began, the New Jersey State Aquarium will open on Feb. 29 amid expectations that it will be an immediate tourist attraction and the anchor for a number of waterfront projects that will end Camden's long economic and social slide. 
 "We anticipate that this aquarium will generate enough revenue over the next five years to exceed the current $220 million tax base in Camden," Senator Walter Rand, a Democrat who represents the city in Trenton, said today.
The aquarium, which was begun during the administration of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean and will bear his name, is the lead project in a planned $500 million revitalization of the waterfront that is to include a hotel and marina, an international trade center, a performing arts center and office and commercial development.
 
Image Concerns
 "There's no question that this wouldn't have happened without this aquarium project being here," said Judith L. Wellington, the chief operating officer for the aquarium and the vice president of the New Jersey Academy for Aquatic Sciences, the state agency that will operate it.
At the heart of the project is an effort to save a city that Ms. Wellington and Camden's mayor, Aaron A. Thompson, say has unjustly become a state and national symbol for urban blight and crime.
Camden, New Jersey's eighth-largest city with nearly 88,000 people, ranks near the bottom in just about every category measured by the state. Camden County is 17th among 21 counties in per-capita income; only two counties in the state commit juveniles to jail at a higher rate, and only six have higher high school dropout rates.
Last month, Time magazine published an article that said, "only people with no alternatives choose to live in Camden."
The article -- under the headline "Who Could Live Here?" -- appeared just as aquarium officials were gearing up for a campaign to lure people to the Camden waterfront.
"Obviously we are concerned about the magazine article," Ms. Wellington said. "But we have a substantial security force, and we have made it as safe and enjoyable an atmosphere as you will find anywhere."
From its pristine grounds and building to the security force assembled to protect it and its visitors, the aquarium stands apart from the city it is meant to save.
The aquarium complex, built at a cost of $52 million, covers an acre on the Delaware within the shadows of downtown Philadelphia's skyscrapers to the west and bordered on three sides by some of the most squalid parts of Camden. Road signs guide visitors along a route that skirts the city's tougher neighborhoods.
Officials have been concerned about attracting visitors from Pennsylvania when ferry service is restored next month between Penn's Landing in Philadelphia and the aquarium, which is built on the site of a ferry terminal that closed 40 years ago.
On Monday, Attorney General Robert Del Tufo announced an agreement under which state, county and city law enforcement officers will police the aquarium and the area around it and a state police boat will patrol the Delaware. Mounted officers will patrol a parking lot, and security guards will be posted on every floor of a parking garage.
 
Regional Rivals
 The aquarium also will have private security guards and, according to the attorney general's office, a cadre of Camden youths known as community services representatives "will patrol the streets and public areas of the district."
First Assistant Attorney General Frederick P. DeVesa, who coordinated the plan, said that the security arrangement was unusual because of the jurisdictions involved. But he said the security force was not a comment on crime problems in Camden.
"The fact is whenever you are trying to have a complex where perhaps a million people will be visiting a year you need this level of security," Mr. DeVesa said. "That's true whether it is Camden or Short Hills."
Ms. Wellington and other aquarium officials say they expect a million visitors in their first year and offer immediate competition for aquariums in New York City, Boston and Baltimore.
The aquarium has 60 species of fish native to New Jersey and its coastal waters, including striped bass, clearnose skates, rays and sandbar and sand tiger sharks. Its 760,000-gallon open ocean tank is the second largest of its kind in the United States, after a 5.6 million-gallon tank at Epcot Center in Orlando, Fla.

HEADLINE: Money Spent On Buildings Surges Again

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Spending on school construction increased for the sixth straight year in 1990, as more school districts replaced aging buildings or modified crowded ones.
The construction boom, documented in an annual building survey by American School and University magazine, totaled nearly $9.7 billion in 1990 -- the last year for which information was available -- compared with $9.3 billion in 1989. Spending for new school construction was $4.1 billion in 1990; in 1989 it was $3.7 billion. 
 The magazine's survey was the second in recent months to show that many school buildings are in need of improvement. Last November, the American Association of School Administrators found that one in eight school buildings had deteriorated to the point that they provided a poor atmosphere for learning.
 
Problems of Aging Schools
 Half of the country's 110,000 school buildings were erected 30 to 40 years ago, the association survey said.
"The schools that were built in the 1950's and 1960's are not appropriate for today because of the increasing emphasis on technology," said Joe Agron, the editor of American School and University.
But aging school buildings are only part of the construction picture. In some regions of the country, robust growth has produced more students and a need for more schools. In addition, some school districts, particularly in the Northeast, have been harder hit by the recession than others, so that additions and modifications have had to substitute for construction of new buildings.
 
Southeast and West Boom
 New construction last year was strongest in the Southeast, at nearly $1.5 billion, with about the same amount spent on additions and modifications. The West also reported robust growth in both new construction and additions and modifications.
But in the Northeast, construction of new schools totaled $385 million, one of the smallest totals of any region. The costs of adding on to schools there or modifying them totaled nearly $1.1 billion, however, as many districts chose those less expensive alternatives.
In some cases, school construction was the result of legislative mandates. In Nevada and Kentucky, for example, lawmakers limited the number of students who can be in a single classroom, thus requiring many districts to expand.
In other states, school districts that were compelled by legislatures to offer computer training had to modernize the wiring in their old buildings.

HEADLINE: Albany Sells Bonds, but at a Higher Interest Rate

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 4

 BODY:
New York State sold $85 million worth of general-obligation bonds today, a move that will cost taxpayers an extra $1.5 million to $2 million in interest costs because of the state's recently lowered bond rating.
It is impossible to calculate what the lowered bond rating will ultimately cost taxpayers, officials say, when all the state's bonds for this quarter are sold. But they estimated that once the state sells an anticipated $3 billion in various types of bonds in the first quarter of 1992, taxpayers can expect to pay tens of millions dollars more than they would have before the ratings were lowered.
 
Rebuke Over Budget
 In January, in a severe rebuke to the state for the way it runs its budget, Standard & Poor's announced that it was lowering its rating on New York's general-obligation bonds from A to A-, the state's lowest level ever and the second lowest in the country, higher only than that of Massachusetts. 
 The lowered rating, affecting bonds that are backed by the full faith and credit of the government and are usually considered the state's safest investment, came just a week after Moody's Investors Service lowered the rating of the state's appropriation-backed debt from A to Baa1, the second-lowest of any state.
The two credit monitors recently reaffirmed New York's current ratings. But they made it clear that they were closely watching the state to see if it could improve its performance and maybe even pass a budget on time this year, something it has failed to do for the last seven years.
Today's bonds, to raise money for hazardous-waste cleanup, were sold for $85 million at an interest rate of 6.7196 percent, for a total interest cost of $60.8 million. The bonds are redeemable between 1 and 20 years.

HEADLINE: In Test of Kentucky Education Law, State Takes Over a Troubled District

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARLAN, Ky., Jan. 31

 BODY:
For as long as anyone here can remember, there have been reports that many Harlan County School Board members engaged in nepotism and cronyism, with a business-as-usual attitude. But only recently, after months of reviewing the board's practices, did state education officials move against the board.
In the first test of the punishment mechanism in Kentucky's pioneering legislation aimed at improving schools, State Education Commissioner Thomas C. Boysen charged the five board members with a variety of infractions, including awarding school contracts to relatives and obtaining kickbacks from businesses for school contracts. 
 After a hearing before a state education panel two weeks ago, Mr. Boysen dismissed three school board members, all of whom said they would appeal. A fourth board member was acquitted of similar charges, and charges were dropped against another board member and the school superintendent when they resigned.
The ousters and state takeover by education officials in Frankfort, the capital, have upset residents in this rural county of 36,000 people in Eastern Kentucky, where people still talk about the bloody fights over unionization of the coal mines in the 1920's and 1930's.
In a county where the unemployment rate is almost double the state figure of about 7 percent, the takeover is the main topic of discussion in the community. The resentment is not so much because of the charges but because of the loss of control.
 
Residents Want Control
 "People are unhappy with the loss of local control of their school system," said Ken Moody, a Harlan restaurant owner, whose children attended the schools and whose wife works for the district as a finance officer. "People want their government at home. They don't want to be dictated to from Frankfort."
By beginning to crack down on errant school boards, Kentucky is moving into one of the most sensitive areas in the drive for improved schools -- local management. And as the nation demands better performances from both students and schools, the boards in this and other states are feeling mounting pressure from state legislatures to improve their management skills or face ousters and state takeovers.
"There's more attention being paid to school boards and the people who serve on them," said Gordon Aumbach, executive director of the Council of Chief State School Officers, an organization representing the top education official in each state. "State legislatures have been looking at results of school districts in terms of student performance, and there's been a real shift to hold school boards more accountable."
 
16 States Act on Boards
 That is a task easier said than done, education analysts said. Seats on the nation's 15,000 school boards are elective offices typically pursued by private citizens whose skills may not be up to par in the increasingly demanding job of managing schools. But 16 states have tried to make school boards more responsive by passing laws in the last nine years giving education departments the authority to seize control of districts for managerial, fiscal or academic deficiencies.
New Jersey took over school systems in Jersey City in 1989 and in Paterson in 1991 because of academic and fiscal woes. The school boards in both districts were removed, a trend that continues in Harlan County, a system with 6,400 students and 16 schools.
The trouble in the school system began brewing a year ago when several residents anonymously called state education officials to complain about the school board's management. State officials declined to comment on details of the investigation because of the anticipated appeal by the ousted board members.
But based on those anonymous complaints, the Office of Education Accountability, a watchdog agency created by the State Education Reform Act that was passed two years ago, began investigating the district's affairs. Last October, the agency presented its findings to Mr. Boysen, who decided to press charges against all the board members and the superintendent.
At closed hearings, a panel of state education officials heard the charges of violating state law or state education policies, including accepting credit form a local store, awarding contracts to relatives and violating state competitive bidding laws.
Benny D. Coleman, the board chairman, was found guilty of four of five charges; Ron Ball, another board member, was found guilty of three of five charges, and David Lewis, the third member who was dismissed, was found guilty of two of three charges.
Similar charges against Robert Shepherd, the superintendent, and Garry Henson, a board member, were dropped when they resigned last fall. David Kennedy, the other board member, was acquitted of all charges and remains the lone member of the board.
The Harlan County Prosecutor, Ron Johnson, plans to review the education department's findings to determine whether criminal charges should be filed against any of the former school officials.
Mr. Ball said the three plan to appeal their removals to the Harlan County Circuit Court. Their ousters, he said, "haven't gone over well here."
 
'Stigma to Eastern Hills'
 In October, when the charges were filed against the board, about 400 school employees rallied in front of the school administration building in a show of support. Some were carrying signs that called the state's charges a "witch hunt," and this month, days before the hearings began, residents sent petitions with 2,000 signatures to state officials expressing confidence in their school board.
"There's a stigma attached to the Eastern hills of the state," said Patricia Baker, an elementary school teacher. "People in the state think we're hillbillies, that we need to be saved from ourselves. We're smart people. We don't need to be saved from ourselves. The school reform has just started, and people need a chance to get used to it. I really feel the school district has been wronged."
Despite the conflict, Harlan County's schools have been operating without any apparent glitches. The acting superintendent, Grace Ann Tolliver, and Stuart Pepper, a state-appointed trustee sent to Harlan County, will pay the district's bills and perform other tasks usually assumed by the board until a new board takes office, which is expected in mid-March. A Harlan County Citizen's Committee appointed by Mr. Boysen is selecting potential members, from which state education officials will pick four.
However pained by the notoriety of the board's dismissal, some residents believe it's time for change. "It isn't going to be business as it has been done in the past," said Sid Douglass, a Harlan lawyer who is a member of the citizens' committee. "School districts are going to have to be better managed."

HEADLINE: Mollen Is About to Resign From Deputy Mayor Post

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Deputy Mayor Milton Mollen, who for two years oversaw New York City's vast criminal-justice programs and coordinated the Dinkins administration's anti-crime policies, will resign tomorrow or Friday to accept a private job, city officials said yesterday.
As the Deputy Mayor for Public Safety, Mr. Mollen is the highest ranking official to leave the two-year-old administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins. Other high-ranking city officials who resigned recently are Correction Commissioner Allyn R. Sielaff, Sanitation Commissioner Steven M. Polan and Personnel Commissioner Douglas H. White. 
 Another of the city's five deputy mayors, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, who is in charge of finance and economic development, has told the Mayor she intends to step down soon.
 
A Former State Judge
 Mr. Mollen, who is 72 years old, was a high-ranking state judge when he joined the administration. He is leaving for personal reasons and has not had any policy disputes with Mayor Dinkins, aides to the Mayor and Mr. Mollen said.
The aides, who agreed to be interviewed only on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Mollen had told them that he would resign his $106,000-a-year City Hall post to accept a "law-related position." Asked yesterday if he was planning to resign, Mr. Mollen said: "I can't comment. There may be an announcement later this week."
Jennifer A. Kimball, a spokeswoman for Mayor Dinkins, said, "If and when the Mayor has an announcement to make regarding that decision, he will make it."
The Mayor entrusted Mr. Mollen to handle several of the administration's most sensitive issues, including the investigation of the crowd crush that killed nine people at a City College gymnasium in December.
 
'Safe Streets, Safe City'
 Mr. Mollen played a major role in expanding the Police Department's community-policing and anti-crime program, known as "Safe Streets, Safe City." He was the administration's chief negotiator last year when it obtained the authorization of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the State Legislature and the City Council for taxes and a lottery to pay for the $1.8 billion program over four years.
The administration has described the Safe Streets program as a major effort to reduce crime by assigning more officers to foot patrol and by funneling funds into crime prevention and education plans. The program also provides for jail space to handle an expected surge in arrests.
Mr. Mollen joined the administration in March 1990, two months after Mr. Dinkins became Mayor. Mr. Mollen had been presiding justice for 12 years of the State Appellate Division for the Second Judicial Department, the appeals court with jurisdiction for Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island. He had previously been a state and city judge for 13 years.
In appointing Mr. Mollen, the Mayor elevated the position to the rank of Deputy Mayor from the previous title of Criminal Justice Coordinator. Mr. Mollen was responsible for reviewing policies of the Police Department, the Fire Department, the Correction Department and the Probation Department. He also supervised plans to streamline the city's courts and reduce court congestion.
Aides to Mr. Dinkins said he viewed Mr. Mollen as a "troubleshooter" in many matters and in March assigned him to be in charge of contract negotiations with municipal unions after Eric J. Schmertz resigned as Labor Relations Commissioner.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Rise 11.1% In Period

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose 11.1 percent in late January, the auto makers reported today. The gain prompted many analysts to predict that the auto industry may be nearing a turning point.
Ronald A. Glantz, an automotive analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco, and other experts attributed the gain to several factors: the war with Iraq, which depressed sales a year earlier; pent-up demand for new vehicles; lower interest rates, and a slight improvement in consumer confidence. 
 "These results are the first concrete sign that consumer confidence is building," said Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association. Mr. Glantz predicted that "we've seen the low for the second dip in the recession."
 
 
Japan's Market Share Is Up
 Some analysts also speculated that the fallout from President Bush's trip to Japan had motivated Americans to buy cars. Despite widespread public relations pressure to "buy American," however, Japanese brands gained market share at the expense of the Big Three in the most recent 10-day period, as well as for the month.
The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for American-built cars was 6.1 million for late January, compared with 5.3 million for the period a year earlier. For the month, the selling rate was essentially unchanged at 5.9 million.
Despite the gains of Japanese brands -- spurred in part by an inexpensive lease special offered by Honda on its Accord model -- several multi-franchise dealers said the buy-American effort had resulted in improved sales of domestic brands and weaker sales of foreign makes.
Mel Farr, who owns four domestic and foreign dealerships in the Detroit and Cincinnati areas, said sales at his Toyota showroom declined about 25 percent in January from a year earlier, while sales at his Ford and Lincoln-Mercury dealerships showed no decline.
 
 
Patriotic Sentiments
 At Biener Pontiac-Nissan in Great Neck, L.I., sales of Pontiacs were double the dealership's projections in January, while Nissan sales dropped by half. The dealership's general manager, Jerry Kramer, said many Pontiac buyers were trading in imports. "People come in and say that this time they will buy only an American product," he said.
Mr. Kramer added that Pontiac dealers in the New York metropolitan area would release another round of buy-American advertisements this week in response to recent remarks by the Japanese Prime Minister about the work ethic of Americans.
Mr. Kramer said that he was skeptical of such ads -- fearing that they could backfire if consumers saw them as "childish retribution" -- and that he thought the ads should simply focus on American quality. Another dealer said he had heard more consumers say they were aware that some foreign models, like the Toyota Camry, were built by Americans.
 Ray Green, who owns five foreign and domestic dealerships in Illinois, said January was his best sales month since 1988. He also reported "excellent results" at both his import and domestic dealerships. He attributed the gains in part to consumers who had reduced the debt on their current vehicles and were now able to make a trade.
A spokesman for the General Motors Corporation said that the company's dealers were also seeing more shoppers in their showrooms and that prospective customers were taking more test drives.
For the 10 days that ended on Jan. 31, sales of cars built in North America, which are considered domestically made, totaled 197,991, a rise of 6.8 percent from a year earlier. Sales of light trucks rose to 116,603, up 19.4 percent. There were 10 selling days in the period in both 1992 and 1991.
 
Big 3's Share Drops
 During January, the Big Three auto makers' market share slipped to 69.8 percent, from 70.5 percent in January 1991. The share for Japanese brands rose to 24.7 percent last month, from 23.9 percent in January 1991. The market share of all other imports fell slightly to 5.5 percent, from 5.6 percent.
 For the entire month, sales of all cars and trucks, domestic and imported, rose 3.5 percent from a year earlier, to 854,447. G.M. sold 190,670 cars built in North America in January, a decline of 1.8 percent from a year earlier; the Ford Motor Company sold 112,138 cars, for a gain of 3.5 percent, and the Chrysler Corporation sold 43,412, down 24.6 percent.
G.M.'s total market share for all cars in January was 35.5 percent, compared with 36.6 percent in January 1991. Ford had a 21.1 percent share, compared with 20.3 percent a year earlier. Chrysler's total share of the car market was 8.5 percent, down from 11.2 percent.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's market share was 9.6 percent, up from 8.2 percent. The Honda Motor Company's share was 9.8 percent, up from 8.2 percent.

HEADLINE: East Meets West, Dollars Apart

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The new East met the old West here this week, but there was scant indication of a meeting of the minds.
While Russian ministers and economists pleaded for billions of dollars in Western support to stabilize the ruble and the reform movement, the voices of Western industry and officialdom huffed about recession, rising labor costs and other distractions from salvaging the former Soviet republics. 
 "Until we have a stable convertible ruble, we cannot do anything and we need perhaps $5 billion to $6 billion from the West to accomplish that," said Anatoly Chubais, the minister in charge of Russia's privatization program. He added that about another $5 billion would come in handy as balance-of-payment support to get foreign trade going again. Meanwhile, he would also welcome a few billion dollars in emergency and technical aid.
 
A Lukewarm Response
 But with elections looming this year in the United States and Britain, and recession or anemic growth afflicting industrialized economies, the response was less than enthusiastic. As Richard Pipes, a Harvard historian and expert on Soviet affairs, commented, "The Russians think we can produce $30 billion for them, but they do not yet understand the imperatives of democratic politics."
The setting for this ticklish encounter was the ski resort of Davos, where about 2,000 government officials, executives and academics met for an annual gathering of what is known as the World Economic Forum. With 120 Russians present -- their air fares paid by a Swiss foundation because each round-trip ticket amounted to several months' salary -- the get-together amounted to a wide-ranging opportunity for Europe to come to terms with its new incarnation.
On the basis of the meeting, which ran from Friday until today, that process will take a long time. Even Switzerland, once an island of certainty and prosperity in a divided Europe, offered little reassurance. There was much talk of a Swiss identity crisis and the difficulties of being neutral in a world without opponents.
Carl H. Hahn, chairman of Volkswagen, was blunt in underlining that the preoccupations of many West European industrialists were very close to home, where they also saw the need for some new thinking.
"Labor in Western Europe is thinking in terms of the first half of this century," he declared. "We have to shed the traces of a certain socialism that exists in the West even as it has gone under in the East."
He was speaking just after German steelworkers, represented by the powerful I.G. Metall union, obtained a 6.4 percent pay increase in wage negotiations. The probable inflationary effects of the increase make it unlikely that Germany will soon heed requests to lower its high interest rates as part of an effort to revive the world economy. Without more robust economic growth in the West, Eastern Europe will have to be patient about its requests for help.
Nonetheless, elaborate plans were not lacking on the Russian side. Mr. Chubais outlined the intention of President Boris N. Yeltsin's Government to privatize 20 percent of state property in Russia this year.
The priority, he said, would be the privatization of retail stores and wholesalers, of which 75 to 100 percent would be in private hands by the end of the year. The state expects to garner 92 billion rubles from the process this year, compared with 2 billion last year. Foreign investment in the privatization drive was, he stressed, welcome. But the value of the rubles he was talking about was far from clear -- a point not lost on Western businessmen.
 
Inflation and Unease
 President Yeltsin's abrupt liberalization of prices on Jan. 2, while industry and agriculture remain predominantly in state hands, has led to higher inflation and widespread uneasiness.
Marshall I. Goldman, a professor of Soviet economics at Wellesley College, suggested that the privatization of farms should have been the initial step on which the Russian program was based. But Anders Aslund, a Swedish economist who is a key adviser to the Yeltsin Government, insisted that the reform program was proceeding as it should and that the next step should be the privatization of stores. "In all countries, privatization starts with trade," he said. "The marketplace is the essence of the market."
The caution of Western officials was so widespread that clearly nothing on the scale of the Marshall Plan, the American reconstruction of Europe after World War II, will be forthcoming for the countries of the former Soviet bloc.
Wayne D. Angell of the Federal Reserve Board expressed reservations about a fund to back the ruble. Some Western analysts suggested there might be as much as $10 billion of Russian capital in foreign banks that could be brought home to support the economy. And whatever happened, one analyst asked, to Soviet gold?
This cautious mood was plainly reinforced by the spectacle of several prominent Russian economists arguing bitterly and predicting imminent disaster.
"The Yeltsin team is playing on the brink of catastrophe," said Boris G. Fedorov, the head of Soviet affairs at the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, charged with rebuilding East European economies.
Andrei Fedorov, an economic adviser to Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, the Russian Vice President, who has recently warned of growing disorder, added his own prediction: "There is too much theory and too little management in the running of our economy and this experiment may be shortlived."
Still, amid the pessimism and irritation, there did seem to be some consensus on one point: the best hope lies in steering Russia and other republics into the International Monetary Fund and World Bank as soon as possible, perhaps by July.

From left were Donald R. Keough of the Coca-Cola Company; Carl H. Hahn of Volkswagen A.G.; Akio Morita of the Sony Corporation and Mr. Brittan. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
GTE's Operating Earnings Rise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The GTE Corporation, the nation's second-largest telecommunications company, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter operating earnings rose more than 10 percent, to $481 million, or 53 cents a share, from $435 million, or 48 cents a share, a year earlier.
The results were within analysts' expectations, a surprise in itself. "This is the first time in nearly three years that I haven't had to revise earnings downward for GTE and the 'Baby Bells,' " said Gregory R. Sawers, a telecommunications analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "That may be an indication the economy is bottoming out." 
 On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., and one of the country's most widely held stocks, closed at $31.25, up 25 cents a share.
The operating results reflect GTE's planned sale of its Electrical Products Group, which sells Sylvania light bulbs as well as cutting tools and other products. The numbers also reflect payouts to preferred shareholders. Without these factors taken into account, final profit in the quarter rose 10.3 percent, to $515 million, or 57 cents a share, compared with $467 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier.
Earnings from discontinued operations, the Sylvania light bulb business, $34 million in the 1991 quarter and $32 million in the 1990 quarter, contributed to net income. But GTE said accounting practices required that income from a unit not yet sold or spun off to be treated as if it were already discontinued.
For the full year, GTE earned $1.58 billion, or $1.75 a share, down 8.1 percent from $1.72 billion, or $1.93 a share, for 1990. Full-year revenue totaled $19.62 billion, up 2.4 percent from $19.16 billion.
 
Growth in Cellular Phones
 GTE, which in addition to its vast local telephone company holdings is the second-largest cellular phone operator after McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., said customer growth continued robustly despite a lackluster economy. Some 84,000 new cellular customers were signed up in the fourth quarter, totaling 811,000 by the end of the year, slightly below the 820,000 expected by analysts. GTE's cellular subscribers increased by 37 percent from 594,000 a year earlier.
Cellular revenues reached $765 million in 1991, up 30 percent from $590 million a year earlier. GTE has about 52 million potential customers, the standard measure in the cellular industry, which includes adults, children and infants in the count.

HEADLINE: Bank Fund Yields Mixed

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were mixed for the week ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
"Major money center banks outside New York apparently believe that short-term certificate of deposit yields have touched bottom," Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday. "By contrast, the Big Apple institutions are still reducing their yields slightly. In any case, rates definitely are leveling off nationwide, with the prospect of investors seeing only modest changes over the next several weeks. After that, the direction will be dictated by economic conditions." 
 Among New York-area commercial banks, the average money market account yields dropped 11 basis points, to 3.58 percent from 3.69 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percent point.
Among the savings institutions in the New York area, yields on money market accounts averaged 4.16 percent, off 7 basis points from a week ago.
For money market accounts, the steepest cut among area banks was made by Manufacturers Hanover, which lowered its rate by 51 basis points. The Connecticut National Bank led the way in cutting rates on its three- and six-month certificates of deposit, dropping them 20 and 21 basis points, respectively.
The Bank Rate Monitor said the average yield at 20 large banks outside the New York area had declined slightly -- 2 basis points, to 3.68 percent for money market accounts, and a basis point, to 3.87 on six-month certificates.
By comparison, at the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, the average rate at auction was 3.86 and 3.93 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: U.N. Study Assails the Way B.C.C.I. Was Shut by Western Central Banks

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The swift seizure and shutdown of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International last year by Western central bankers has undermined trade from several third world countries and increased the risk that depositors will suffer large losses, according to a United Nations research group.
The group, the United Nations Center on Transnational Corporations, was highly critical of the country-by-country settlements pursued by some Western nations. 
 The largest of these was in the United States, where the bank had comparatively few customers but assets of $550 million, which the Government seized. Under an agreement announced last December, American authorities have promised to put some of those assets in a fund for the bank's depositors worldwide, but only after all claims and penalties in the United States have been settled.
 
More for Victims Urged
 With a more coordinated, international settlement process, "a lot of innocent victims could have recovered more than they will,"
Peter Hansen, executive director of the United Nations group, said.
"We are not living in a world where an ad hoc club of the West should be handling these transnational issues alone," he said.
In its 24-page report, the center said that by simply shutting down the 70-nation banking network that financed international trade of $18 billion a year, the economic damage fell hardest on countries like Nigeria, Bangladesh and Zambia, where B.C.C.I. was an important institution. With credit lines frozen in the shutdown, many companies in third world countries have been forced to cut back sharply or go out of business.
 
Dividing the Bank
 The report, though not a public document, has been sent to some 60 central bankers worldwide. And while its authors say it is not intended to be a solution, it will certainly contribute to the debate about how international bank failures, like B.C.C.I.'s, should be handled in the future.
Instead of closing the bank entirely, the group said the bad loans and fraud-tainted portions of the bank should be separated from the rest, which should be kept in operation under the supervision of an internationally appointed group of trustees. "The uncompromised portions of B.C.C.I. could be kept going to enhance North-South trade," Mr. Hansen said.
The preferred approach, according to Clive Russell, a London accountant and member of the study group, would amount to "an international Chapter 11," a reference to the American bankruptcy law under which insolvent companies are allowed to operate under court protection.
Under the current liquidation plan, expected to be approved soon by a London court, depositors and creditors outside the United States will receive from 10 to 40 cents for every dollar they had with B.C.C.I. Devised by B.C.C.I.'s liquidator, Touche Ross in London, the plan calls for the Government of Abu Dhabi, the bank's main shareholder, to make a contribution of up to $2.2 billion in return for creditors agreeing to make no further claims on the emirate.
 
Dissatisfied Depositors
 One group of B.C.C.I. depositors, dissatisfied with the Touche Ross plan, has hired Paine Webber Inc., the American investment bank, to fashion an alternative settlement that involves a larger payout to depositors. A confidential Paine Webber proposal has been sent to Abu Dhabi for consideration, but it seems an 11th-hour effort.
One depositors' representative, who asked not to be identified, estimated that assuming a substantial contribution from Abu Dhabi and removing claims of those suspected to have participated in the B.C.C.I. fraud, legitimate depositors and creditors could recover 80 percent of their funds placed with the bank.
The participants in the United Nations study group included representatives from some of the third world countries most affected by the B.C.C.I. shutdown, including Nigeria, Jamaica, Zambia and Bangladesh.

HEADLINE: Tax Proposals Can Backfire at First

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Like many medicines, the tax breaks proposed by the Administration to help nurse the economy back to health involve some temporary unpleasantness and annoying side effects. The President's advisers hope these will be minimal -- though one substantial impact has already emerged.
Almost inevitably, when it became clear in late autumn that the President would need to propose an economic rescue package, speculation mounted that it would probably include an incentive for corporate America to invest in modernization. And so Mr. Bush proposed last week a 15 percent investment tax allowance for new equipment bought between Feb. 1 and Dec. 31.
 
Expecting a Break
 
 The Government has repeatedly provided such a temporary spur; the latest version ended in 1986. So, business executives, expecting some kind of tax break this year, did the only rational thing. They deferred such plans, and orders for manufactured durable goods tumbled at a 5 percent annual pace in December, the biggest monthly decline in more than a year.
"Companies were well aware of the proposal for tax relief in 1992, and this clearly seems to have caused a 'wait and see' reaction by business," said Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank in New York. And orders for January, too, he suggested "probably will remain depressed."
Then there are the various incentives for real estate, including the widely hailed 10 percent tax credit, up to $5,000, to encourage people who have not owned a home within the last three years to buy one. To get the credit, a sales contract must be signed this year but the transaction may be completed as late as mid-1993.
Since the residential real estate market was slowly perking up for much of last year, aided by falling prices and interest rates, it is less clear that talk of an incentive has caused substantial deferrals.
Still, even though the plan would apply retroactively to home purchases, beginning last Saturday, some buyers will sit tight while Congress debates the President's proposal and while the real estate industry invents a way, in effect, to turn the credit into an immediate benefit. Such aid could help to meet a down payment, which for many first-time buyers is the biggest obstacle to a purchase.
Some real estate brokers say they fear a chilling effect on the market while people try to figure the financial possibilities.
One sign that home buyers are paying close attention to tax implications came in reports from real estate brokers of wild scrambles by buyers to defer until this week closings that had been scheduled for late January.
 
A Matter of Timing

 
 The investment allowance and the home-buyer credit would both expire at the end of the year, a feature intended to spur early action, and distortions in activity could prove to be mostly a matter of shifting the time at which transactions occur.
One specific proposal, to abolish the tax exemption for certain kinds of annuities, has inspired a frenzy of buying by people wanting to get such annuities before Congress can act.
But some economists contend that putting any major tax proposal on the table introduces such general uncertainty that the economy could suffer damage that would not necessarily be made up.
Until, say, June or July, when the final outlines of legislation become clear, said Sung Won Sohn, head of an advisory panel of the American Bankers Association, the proposals could delay economic revival. "It will actually depress economic conditions in the meantime," said Mr. Sohn, who is chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "It's doing the opposite of what's intended."
Many in Washington, however, believe it will not be as long as June or July before a clear view of the legislation emerges, but that it could come in March or even late this month.
But in Mr. Sohn's view, shared by other members of his panel, the Administration plan invites an election-year bidding war that could well balloon the budget deficit, thereby frightening the bond market.
Indeed, interest rates on high-quality securities have already climbed in recent weeks by two-fifths of a percentage point from their lows, while rates on conventional mortgages have bounced back to 9 percent from a low of 8.25.
To be sure, the lowest mortgage rates in two decades set off a stampede to refinance, but there is no doubt that the market is also factoring in the risk that the competition to lavish benefits on voters could get out of control, as it did in 1981.
Other economists, however, are not so worried as Mr. Sohn. Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for the Chemical Banking Corporation, acknowledges that while orders for durable goods were no doubt delayed in advance of the Bush plan, the economy should be little harmed either in coming weeks or over the balance of the year.
This is because business activity is weak and because of broad sympathy on Capitol Hill for many, perhaps most, of the President's proposals. "It's not all one-sided" politically, Mr. Kellner said. "There's probably enough for both parties to like," thereby keeping legislative uncertainty to a minimum.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Lower On Signs of More Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday, as signs increased that interest rates would drop further, lowering the attractiveness of the currency.
Gold prices were also lower, closing at $356.20 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, down 50 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $355.70, off 5 cents an ounce. 
 Traders said the dollar fell in part because of comments by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan. He told a Congressional committee that the central bank was considering further interest-rate cuts if needed as "additional insurance" to spur a sluggish economy.
Lower rates tend to make the dollar and dollar-denominated investments worth less relative to investments in other currencies.
The currency market is also concerned that the January unemployment figures, scheduled to be released on Friday, will provide a further impetus for a rate cut.
"People are expecting lower interest rates," said Urs Bernegger, the chief currency dealer at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York.
A further drag on the dollar was the growing strength of the German mark. The currency has risen on the belief that a wage settlement reached on Monday with German steelworkers could be inflationary, preventing the Bundesbank from lowering the high interest rates that have supported the mark.
In European trading, the dollar fell to 1.5920 marks, from 1.5975 on Monday. In New York, the dollar brought 1.5931 marks, down from 1.6000 late on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8010, from $1.7995 late on Monday. In New York, a pound cost $1.8015, more than $1.7961 late on Monday.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.60 yen to close at 126.25 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 126.10 yen. In New York, a dollar bought 126.15 yen, down from 126.20 late on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Friday, included: 1.4220 Swiss francs, down from 1.4265; 5.4270 French francs, down from 5.4525; 1,197 Italian lire, down from 1202.00, and 1.1814 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1753.
In London, gold fell to a late bid price of $356.35 an ounce, from $357.50 bid late on Monday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $356.05, from $356.85 late on Monday.
Markets in Hong Kong were closed yesterday for a national holiday. They will reopen on Friday.
On the Comex, silver bullion closed at $4.173 an ounce, up from $4.17 late on Monday. Silver rose in London to a late bid price of $4.18 an ounce, up from $4.16 on Monday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Saatchi Sets Network for Health Care

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
LIKE pediatricians who move their offices closer to nursery schools, Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. is changing the way it does business to exploit the rapid growth in health care.
Effective today, the London-based global advertising giant has formed Healthcom, a worldwide network of health-care agencies that previously operated as part of its two general international agency networks, Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide. 
 The consolidation, which establishes a single global brand name for the Saatchi agencies that focus on health care, creates the third-largest such international network, with billings of $214 million and income of $27 million. First is Medicus Intercon International Inc., owned by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, followed by Sudler & Hennessey, owned by Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York.
"We looked at our various holdings," Richard F. O'Brien, vice chairman of Saatchi Worldwide, said in an interview at the agency's office in downtown Manhattan, "and decided that we had in place good health care agencies in most of the economies of the world."
"But they never had been knitted together into a cohesive, global force," he added. "Perhaps that time has come."
The consolidation, in development for six months, responds to a boom in health care advertising, which has surged as health care has expanded around the world. For instance, global sales of over-the-counter drugs, now about $23 billion, are expected to exceed $50 billion by 2000.
Billings in health care advertising are growing at an annual rate of about 9 percent, said Gary D. Landis, who has been named managing director of Healthcom, while there has been little or no growth in general advertising billings.
The consolidation also responds to the needs of clients, which are merging, amalgamating and forming strategic alliances at a feverish pace as they seek to become worldwide forces in marketing prescription and over-the-counter drugs, herbal and homeopathic remedies and even healthier, better-for-you foods that are advertised as if they were drugs.
Among such companies are Pfizer, which Healthcom has as a client in France, Germany and Britain; Upjohn, a Healthcom client in Canada, Spain and the United States, and Glaxo, a Healthcom client in France, Italy and Britain.
"The concept is simple," said Mr. Landis, who is 51 years old, a longtime Saatchi executive who joined Mr. O'Brien for the interview, "to create a global health care communications capability to service a global health care industry."
The consolidation, which Saatchi calls a joint venture of the two networks, involves eight agencies in eight countries: Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Sweden and the United States. Five had been under Backer's aegis and three under Saatchi Worldwide. Two other agencies in Australia and Japan, one from each network, are scheduled to come aboard around April.
In each case, the agency adds the prosaic Healthcom name, a telescoping of the words Healthcare Communications, to its existing name. For instance, Klemtner Advertising Inc. in New York, a health care agency from the Saatchi Worldwide network, with billings of about $125 million, is being rechristened Klemtner/Healthcom.
This is Saatchi's second amalgamation of services under a single banner in two months, following consolidation of its direct-marketing operations under the network of Kobs & Draft, formerly a Backer unit.
"In some of these specialized services, it doesn't make sense to maintain two competitive resources around the world," Mr. O'Brien said.
"Why have two," he added, "when one will do?"

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Soaking Lawns, Not Taxpayers

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
FROM San Diego to Marin County, Californians are discovering the dubious pleasures of the drier life -- of 60-second showers, econo-flush toilets and gardening with waste water. Just punishment, one is told, for the hubris of building cities in the desert.
But economists and their sometime allies among savvy environmentalists see it differently: Even in the worst of droughts, argues Tom Graff, a lawyer at the Environmental Defense Fund, California should have enough water to go around. The real problem, he insists, is the failure to allow markets, rather than politicians and planners, to decide who gets what. 
 And happily for both parched urbanites and the wildlife that depends on runoff from mountain snows, Washington is listening. Congress is on the verge of overhauling the federally financed Central Valley Project, the source of one-quarter of California's total water supply. Farmers are likely to pay far more to get somewhat less Government water. But in return they will secure the right to sell their allotments to thirsty municipalities.
Uncle Sam has invested the equivalent of $3.77 billion in today's dollars to collect water from Northern California and deliver it to the central valleys. But according to a Senate staff analysis, the water has been priced so low that the Government has only managed to recoup a nickel for each dollar spent. Farmers typically fork over $20 to $30 for enough water to flood a football field a foot deep, while coastal communities scrounge in vain for new supplies at 10 times that price.
One obvious (though, arguably, inequitable) solution would be to create a market, permitting growers to sell their water rights to the highest urban bidders. Since agriculture now absorbs about 90 percent of all California water, just a modest fraction of rural supply would suffice to fill every bathtub and drench every lawn.
But the political web has proved too tangled to unravel in the obvious way. Some farmers see no reason to fix a system that from their perspective is not broken. Others would be delighted to take the money and run, but worry that the financial windfall would be challenged by both urban consumers and environmentalists who do not think the farmers appropriated the water fair and square.
That is where Congress fits in. Many of the original 40-year water contracts in the Central Valley Project are now expiring. And as chairman of a subcommittee on water, Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, is challenging the local authorities' right to renew on the old subsidized terms.
Mr. Bradley is not alone: He has a powerful ally in Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Energy and Water Committee. Legislation is thus likely to make it through the Senate this year. Once it does, it is expected to breeze through the House. The real question is what terms the growers can extract.
A best guess now is that roughly half the water will be guaranteed with subsidies-as-usual, with the rest going at sharply higher prices that are closer to the real cost of delivery. In return, irrigation districts would gain the clear legal right to sell water to urbanites.
Environmentalists may win a bonus in the form of a percentage set aside from each contract renewed, or a commitment to divert enough water to protect wildlife in periods of drought. Even if they do not, though, the environment will gain because pressures to tap environmentally fragile sources of new water would be relieved.
The right to sell water might induce some farmers to plant fewer acres -- a possible outcome that has led farm workers' unions to oppose water markets. A lot of water could be diverted, however, simply by planting less-thirsty crops. In 1988, some 215,000 acres were devoted to growing rice, a plant better suited to the monsoon-flooded fields of Thailand than the California desert. A lot more could be saved by reducing seepage from irrigation canals, and using more efficient irrigation techniques.
Paradoxically, analysts say the interests with the greatest potential for sabotaging the reform are probably those with the least tangible stake: the water bureaucrats.
Officials in the Interior Department, who have fought water-trading in the past, would presumably be forced to get with the program. But Federal contracts allocate water to irrigation districts, not individual farmers. And if some farmers oppose trades, water authorities may well balk at the initiative of the ones who prefer to green their bank accounts rather than their fields.
Planners, it seems, do not have to call each other comrade to share an aversion to free markets.
