HEADLINE: A Restaurant Family Thrives, Always Together

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
ASK the Sindonis anything about their family -- who is related to whom, how many restaurants in New York are owned by their cousins, what life was like in Sicily -- and an extended debate, partly in Italian, ensues. But ask them for the secret of their successful restaurant dynasty, which has spawned five restaurants in seven years, and there is no dispute: Hard, hard work, and family ties.
It all begins, not surprisingly, with the mother, Maddalena, whose life has been alternating periods of tragedy and triumph. When her mother died in 1930, 4-year-old Maddalena was sent off to be raised by nuns because her father was unable to cope with a total of nine children. 
 Maddalena married and settled in her hometown, Palermo, but when she was in her 40's her husband died, leaving her with four children. Believing that Sicily offered no opportunities for a woman on her own, she moved to New York in 1973.
After years of work in factories and restaurants, Mrs. Sindoni and three of her children, Marcello, Vittorio and Mariella, opened a restaurant, Azzurro, in 1985. Since then, they have started three more in New York and one in Miami. Their second Miami restaurant will open this spring. The recessionhas hurt the restaurant business, but they are surviving and prospering.
"What makes them a success has a lot to do with their energy level," said Tony Chi, a New York restaurant designer who has done work for the Sindonis as well as a variety of clients, ranging from large companies like Pizzeria Uno to small ones, like Zen Palate. Mr. Chi says their family ties help them survive the recession.
"Believe me," he said, "they've seen better days. But they're dealing much better than everyone else because they are family. We have many clients who are dealing with it alone."
The Sindonis work from 9 or 10 in the morning until 11 or 12 at night. Maddalena is behind the cash register at Azzurro, an elegant but comfortable restaurant on 84th Street near Second Avenue that attracts an older clientele. It is managed by Vittorio, who is 33. Mariella, the 26-year-old daughter, presides over Baci, a lively, crowded place on Amsterdam Avenue near 79th Street.
Marcello, 37, is in charge of Vucciria, an airy setting on West Broadway between Spring and Prince Streets in SoHo that draws a mix of artists, tourists and stockbrokers. He also oversees the newest Sindoni venture, Meatballs, a three-month-old family-style restaurant in Miami.
A cousin, Massimo Scoditti, runs Brio, a chic, cozy restaurant on Lexington Avenue near 61st Street, in partnership with the Sindonis.
But if the entire family is considered, the empire is larger. Two of Maddalena Sindoni's sisters emigrated to New York, and both run restaurants. One, Erminia Lattanzi, who came here in 1966, owns five with her family: Lattanzi, on West 46th Street near Ninth Avenue; Tevere, on East 84th Street near Lexington Avenue; Erminia, on East 83d Street near Second Avenue; Va Bene, on Second Avenue near 82d Street, and Trastevere, in San Diego.
Another sister, Maria Carino, who came here in 1946, owns two restaurants in New York: Carino, on Second Avenue near 88th Street, and Via Oreto, on First Avenue near 61st Street. A cousin, Marlo Gitto, just opened Vespa, on 84th Street near Second Avenue.
When the Sindonis opened Azzurro with $50,000 in 1985, they raised half the money from relatives and half from the landlord. They also learned the business partly by working in restaurants owned by their cousins. The influence of family is so strong that Marcello Sindoni looks puzzled when asked whether he would go into business with a nonrelative. "No," he finally answers. "I don't believe in that. I never was in a position to go into business with a stranger."
None of the family members can fully explain why they have gravitated to the restaurant business. Circumstance and necessity played a part. "As an immigrant," said Vittorio Sindoni, "you are trying to accommodate yourself to whatever a city might offer."
Everyone in the family, though, clearly has a talent for the business. Their customers feel that someone really does care if they live, die, or return. They have an exuberance and a warmth that is immediately engaging. Twirling around Azzurro late one afternoon, Marcello Sindoni introduced himself: "It's Marcello, like Mastroianni, but without the money."
Almost all their food in New York is made from recipes Mrs. Sindoni used when her children were growing up -- Sicilian dishes like pasta con sarde, a robust mixture of sardines and fennel, and rigatoni con cavolfiori, which is pasta with cauliflower. The preparation is consistently competent: fish is moist, pasta is al dente and sauces are flavorful. Meatballs, their Miami restaurant, is Italian-American, with dishes like, well, meatballs. With red sauce.
In Sicily, Mrs. Sindoni routinely prepared two large meals a day; breakfast, generally just bread, was the only quick and easy meal. Money was scarce, so every bit of food had to be used well. "I remember when we would eat leftover pasta from the night before," said Marcello. "Fried with a little sugar on top. In those days, we did it because of need. Now, I do it because of pleasure."
Their cousins also trace their inspiration to their mother, Erminia Lattanzi. Paolo Lattanzi, the head chef for his family's restaurants, said his mother had a genius for creating something from nothing. "She could make dessert from eggplant," he said.
The Lattanzis lived in Rome, near the Jewish section, and their food reflects their roots; two of their restaurants are kosher. The Sindonis grew up in Sicily; their food, too, reflects their roots.
Although few customers go to the Sindoni restaurants just because the food is Sicilian, those who do are taken home by the experience. "They come up to me and say, 'It reminds me of when my mother used to cook the same food,' " Mrs. Sindoni said.
Anna-Teresa Callen, a cooking teacher who leads tours to Sicily, said the Sindonis were cooking food both genuine and good. Before they came here, she said, "What passed for Sicilian food was something that was not Sicilian at all."
Mr. Chi, the designer, said the Sindonis operate in very old-style ways. "They really believe in trust," he said. "I have never had any paper work with them. I treasure that."
Watching over everything, he said, is Mrs. Sindoni. "I call her the insurance company," he said. "She's superconservative because of her hard life in Italy." Her role, he said, is to provide moral support and keep the family together.
Mariella Sindoni said: "We're all very close and very warm. When people come in, they feel that."
Keeping customers is tough in this recession, though, and lately the Sindonis have had to work harder for less. Business has dropped 30 to 40 percent over the last few years. To draw more people, they cut their prices at Azzurro by $3 a dish, which lowered the average check to about $30 a person. They save on expenses by using fewer employees and persuading landlords to lower rent bills.
At least twice a month, the three Sindoni siblings meet with their mother to talk about business. One can never really know what transpires at these meetings. "We get spanked," Vittorio said.
Marcello added, "We ask for the raise she doesn't give us."
Their affection for their mother is palpable. They remember how hard life was as new immigrants and how she struggled to keep them together in a new and hostile country. Vittorio Sindoni remembers how Queens looked to him at 14, when he arrived from Palermo: "It was very close, very ugly. No one understood me."
Their mother believed they would eventually be better off, but it was years before they felt comfortable. "For five years," Mariellasaid, "we always had the luggage down."
She remembers her mother going off to work each day in a shirt factory. "I would say, 'Mama, come back, I want to tell you something,' " she said. "I would just hug her and hug her, and finally, after 10 times of calling her back, I would let her go."
Now the Sindonis feel like Americans. Their homeland has become rich enough to keep its young people at home; these days, the immigrants who work in kitchens are primarily from Central and South America. And Marcello, passing on what he has learned, teaches them to cook the dishes of his childhood.

HEADLINE: Book Notes;
Heathcliff and Huck Going Way of Scarlett

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
Literary trespassers are out there this coming book season, sneaking back into works of fiction that the original authors had finished and closed off.
First, there was the enormously successful "Scarlett" (Warner Books), in which, with the consent of Margaret Mitchell's estate, Alexandra Ripley poached the characters from "Gone With the Wind" and took them to Ireland and back. Now, readers will find that Huck Finn has grown up and will learn what happened to Heathcliff when he left Wuthering Heights. 
 Is no literary legend safe? Will future authors borrow Oliver Twist and turn him into a successful banker, or have a surgeon perform a miraculous operation on Anna Karenina and have her enter a convent in penance?
Lin Haire-Sargeant, who has written "H.: The Story of Heathcliff's Journey Back to Wuthering Heights," to be published in the summer by Pocket Books, said she thought of her book as a homage to Emily Bronte's classic, not as a ripoff.
"Art often refers to other art," said Ms. Haire-Sargeant, who teaches English at the University of Massachusetts-Boston and says she has had a lifelong obsession with Emily Bronte and her sister Charlotte. "I think this kind of writing is fair as long as the author has something legitimate to add. I think Heathcliff has become a kind of literary myth, and I often found myself wondering what happened to him in the years he was gone."
Richard White, a high school teacher from Nashua, N.H., said he found himself similarly curious about the man Huckleberry Finn became and decided that the only way he would ever find out what happened to him "was to write it myself."
Which he did, in "Mister Grey, or the Further Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," due out this spring from the publisher Four Walls Eight Windows.
"I think of Huck Finn as America's child," Mr. White said. "And not to be tedious, but he is what we were, and I always wondered whether he made it to the territories ahead of everyone else."
But in Mr. White's hands, Huck is no more the mischievous eternal child. He is now, as the catalogue copy says, "a grown man, strapping two six-shooters, lording it over a cowboy town in Wyoming in the 1880's."
When Warner Books published "Scarlett" last fall, it made few pretenses that the venture was anything but commercial. Scarlett O'Hara was, in effect, a brand name on which Warner was capitalizing, and Margaret Mitchell's wishes that the "Gone With the Wind" saga end with her final period were blatantly ignored. The authors and publishers of "H." and "Mister Grey" say they are counting on readers' identification with established characters, but they take umbrage at the suggestion that they are coasting on an established literary success.
"These are figures who have entered into the American cultural vocabulary," said John Oakes, a co-publisher of Four Walls Eight Windows. "I don't think of it as lazy. I think of it as playful."
And in keeping with what has become a genre unto itself, it's not only literary characters whose lives are fictitiously fleshed out in new books. This spring, Hyperion plans to publish "Clairvoyant: The Imagined Life of Lucia Joyce," a novel by Alison Leslie Gold about James Joyce's schizophrenic daughter, and HarperCollins is planning "Queen of Desire," a novel by Sam Toperoff that imagines certain crises in the life of Marilyn Monroe.
 
Moving Forward at Viking
 Al Silverman has been publisher and editor in chief of Viking for less than a week. The letterhead still lists his previous title, vice president and contributing editor of Penguin U.S.A., and the Viking-Penguin switchboard operators still identify him the same way.
But Mr. Silverman said he and his staff had already thought about the new program on which Viking would focus under his leadership. The publishing house has firm credentials in literature, he said, naming two writers he inherited when he came to the company in 1989 as an editor: Robertson Davies and William Kennedy.
"What we are going to do now is focus more tightly on serious American nonfiction in history and current affairs," said Mr. Silverman, previously the chairman and chief executive of the Book-of-the-Month Club. "We don't think that Random House and Simon & Schuster should corner that market, and we are going to be more aggressive in forming ideas for nonfiction books and recruiting particular authors to write them."
Penguin U.S.A. has weathered difficult financial times in the last two years. Profits fell in 1990, and the company went through several executive changes and reorganizations that included layoffs, economizing and scaling back on the number of books published.
But in 1991 the company had the best fourth quarter in its history, said John F. Moore, president of Penguin U.S.A., and Mr. Silverman said he believes he has been given the editorial and financial support for his aggressive new mandate.
"We've come through the fire in the last six months," he said. "We're more than ready to move forward."
 
More Joyce and Sexton
 The "new" new edition of James Joyce's "Ulysses" is to be published by W. W. Norton. The book is part of a series, "The Dublin Edition of the Works of James Joyce," being edited by Dr. John Kidd, director of the James Joyce Research Center at Boston University. Dr. Kidd caused a literary scandal several years ago when he charged that a much-hailed new edition of "Ulysses" produced by a team of German scholars was riddled with errors. . . . Houghton Mifflin is trying to ride the coattails of the critical and commercial success of "Anne Sexton: A Biography" by Diane Wood Middlebrook by reissuing "Anne Sexton: A Self-Portrait in Letters," edited by Sexton's daughter, Linda Gray Sexton, and Lois Ames. The new edition contains a forward by Linda Sexton addressing some of the controversy created by the Middlebrook biography, which drew on confidential tapes of psychiatric sessions between the poet and her doctor.

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
City Opera Ensemble Does 'Tosca' in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH

 BODY:
For one Manhattanite, a trip to the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College on Saturday evening to hear the New York City Opera National Company perform "Tosca" was a sentimental journey. In the mid-1960's, a touring production of "Tosca" by the New York City Opera at the University of Wisconsin in Madison furnished this critic's first experience of live opera.
A quarter-century of subsequent performances have obliterated almost any memory of that original "Tosca" beyond the fact that the staging was, understandably, rudimentary. Such was the case here, too. In Dona D. Vaughn's economical and tightly unified production, the basic layout remained the same for all three acts, with a wall sloping down and back from the right side of the stage and a few props focusing the action to the left and center. 
 Still, for all its simplicity, the physical setting had a sophisticated look. Miguel Romero's scenery was richly evocative, right down to the splashes of color in Scarpia's study, blood-red yet not garish. Joseph A. Citarella's costumes were also attractive, and Mark W. Stanley's lighting imparted a subtle, haunting glow to the last act.
Musically, it must be inferred, that ancient "Tosca" cannot have been altogether discouraging for a neophyte. But for a more experienced listener, there was cause for disgruntlement on Saturday, mainly in the pit. Joseph Colaneri, the touring company's music director, conducted with scant regard for his young singers or for the problematic acoustics of Whitman Hall. His 31-member orchestra produced a loud and aggressively articulated curtain of sound that stifled the voices for entire phrases.
Under these circumstances, the lead singers, drawn from the company's rotating pool, fared reasonably well. Nina Warren was especially effective as Tosca despite an occasional hard edge to her soprano, or perhaps because of it, since it helped her carry over the orchestra with fair consistency. There was also an appropriately vulnerable side to both her characterization and her singing.
Kenneth Shaw was less fortunate vocally. His baritone was slightly recessed to begin with, and the constant challenges from the pit seemed to wear him down in the second act. Antonio Adame was uneven as Cavaradossi, producing a few raw, forced high notes and some tremulous vibrato but rising admirably to "E lucevan le stelle."
The rest of the cast sang passably and acted indifferently. Mr. Shaw's coiling and slithering Scarpia seemed to set the dramatic tone, and the action seldom rose above posing and caricature.
The production is sung in Italian with English supertitles. Currently in New England, it will continue to tour through March 28.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Seattle Group Displays Major Show of Support

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
The Governor of the state of Washington and the Mayor of Seattle met with major league baseball officials yesterday to try to persuade them that there is sufficient business and community support to keep the struggling Mariners in the city.
To that end, the Seattle contingent promised to supply major league baseball with details of a three-year, $39 million advertising and ticket-sale revenue package today. 
 The group did so after receiving assurances from Commissioner Fay Vincent that the Mariners would remain in Washington for the 1992 season, even though the present owner has put the team up for sale.
Not discussed in the meeting, however, was the other issue looming over the Seattle situation: how baseball will act upon a bid by a Japanese company to buy a controlling interest in the Mariners.
That issue will come up tomorrow when baseball's ownership committee meets to address the $100 million bid by a group backed by the Nintendo Company of Japan. Even though Vincent has several times repeated the owners' policy against ownership outside North America, he said in an interview Monday that the owners "may change it."
"They may revise it or interpret it in other ways," he added. "I think that the ownership is going to be interested in accommodating all interests."
The policy, Vincent indicated, is in fact a set of guiding principles based on what he thinks is an ownership concensus favoring hometown ownership and opposing sale to foreign interests.
 
Going to the Community
 As for yesterday's meeting, he noted that the Seattle officials arranged it about two months ago to report on their progress in raising enough money to assure that any owner, whether it is the current owner, Jeff Smulyan, or someone else, feels secure enough to leave the team where it is.
"This meeting was not held to discuss any ownership group, but rather to discuss what the community can do to retain baseball," Vincent said.
Smulyan put the team up for sale on Dec. 9 and gave local interests a deadline of March 27 before he would begin entertaining bids from outside the area. Potential owners from the Tampa-St. Petersburg area have expressed interest in the team. In all practicality, the deadline would not allow the team to be sold and moved before the 1992 season is under way.
The specifics of the revenue package were not disclosed yesterday, but Herman Sarkowsky, a Seattle businessman, said they would be made public today.
"We have finally been able to focus the attention of the Seattle business community on the Seattle Mariners," said Sarkowsky, a former owner of the Seattle Seahawks of the National Football League and the founder of the Portland Trail Blazers of the National Basketball Association. "The goal we had was to increase the revenue stream by $13 million a year. That has been accomplished."
Mayor Norman Rice said, "We're here to show that there is strong community support for the team in Seattle, that we have a package that's very strong and can be moved forward."
Before meeting with the Seattle group which included Governor Booth Gardner of Washington, Vincent talked at length about a situation that remains complex.
"It's a very difficult set of issues, but I think that people will work at it," Vincent said. "I continue to think that the best course is for the team to stay in Seattle. I just don't know if that's going to be possible. Seattle has been a very difficult issue for the better part of a year but now it's interlaced with the international issue."
That second set of concerns arose Jan. 23 when the Nintendo Company of Japan announced it would be the major stockholder in a group bidding for the Mariners.
 
Presentation Called Important
 Meanwhile, Vincent termed the Seattle presentation important because he said: "I have always thought that the only perfect answer from baseball's point of view would be for the team to stay there with proper community support locally. We have to look at that issue very carefully as well."
Gardner and other Seattle representatives obviously think that there are threats greater than those baseball feels are posed by offshore interests.
"The only foreign investor I'm concerned about is Tampa Bay," Gardner said at a recent news conference in Washington, referring to groups in Tampa and St. Petersburg, Fla., interested in buying the team should Seattle not meet the financial stipulations set by Smulyan by the owners imposed deadline of March 27.
On Monday, Gardner stated anew the arguments to save the Japanese bid as well as the Mariners. "My own gut feeling is that all the ingredients are there," Gardner told The Associated Press. "If the mix is wrong, if people are concerned about the percentage of ownership, I think that can be dealt with. We should be able to come up with a way to do it, a formula."
 
Sullivan Sums Up Position
 Few of the owners of the other 25 major league clubs have been willing to articulate the reasons for baseball's policy against investment outside North America or even state publicly what the policy is. Haywood Sullivan, general partner of the Boston Red Sox and a member of the owners' executive council, summed up what he believes to be the general reasoning behind the owners' decision on foreign investors.
"It's to try to control your own business within your own confines," Sullivan said. "This would have applied whether you had somebody from Germany or Mexico or Brazil or Japan involved in it."
But Sullivan, like other baseball executives, was not surprised that the first major overture came from Japan, or that it raised the resolve of those opposed to foreign interests. "Their economy is flourishing so fast and everything is going in such a rapid, rapid pace, that it might be conceived that maybe it would have overrun us in a lot of aspects," Sullivan said.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Vanbiesbrouck Hopes To Stay With Rangers

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RYE, N.Y., Feb. 4

 BODY:
No current Ranger wore the Blue Shirt before John Vanbiesbrouck, who played his first game with the team in 1981 at the age of 18. And if unrelenting trade speculation has any validity, no current Ranger could leave sooner than Vanbiesbrouck, who shares the lesser half of the goalie position with Mike Richter.
In the meantime, Vanbiesbrouck will probably guard the net again Wednesday night when the Rangers return home to protect their various peaks and streaks against the Penguins at Madison Square Garden. 
 Richter is still ailing with an injury first described as a deep thigh bruise and now called a pulled thigh muscle. The Rangers have four consecutive victories and have gone seven games without a defeat. They lead the Patrick Division and have the best overall record in the National Hockey League.
 
Vanbiesbrouck on a Roll
 And Vanbiesbrouck, the winning goalie in the last three games, is coming off what may have been the best game of his career. When the team finished a 4-0-1 road trip Saturday night with a 2-1 victory at Minnesota, Vanbiesbrouck stopped 40 shots. Some saves, like the diving glove grab on Brian Propp in the final minute, were the kind that cause fans to slap their foreheads with the palms of their hands.
"I'd like to think that it was one of my best games, that's for sure," Vanbiesbrouck said today after practice. Told that his save on Propp would probably make many highlight films, Vanbiesbrouck replied: "That's nice. I usually make the post-game reels as the goalie being scored upon."
While that is an exaggeration, there certainly have been such moments. The worst was last season, in a game at Pittsburgh in late March, when Vanbiesbrouck lost control of a soft shot by Kevin Stevens and let the puck squirt past him for the winning goal in overtime.
At the time, the Rangers were plunging from first place, en route to a first-round playoff elimination; the Penguins were on their way to a division title and a Stanley Cup. Vanbiesbrouck and Richter had been rotating until then, but, after that, Vanbiesbrouck clearly became No. 2.
 
Mutual Respect
 Richter has played in 31 games this season and Vanbiesbrouck 28. Richter is 18-7-2 with a 2.96 goals-against average. Vanbiesbrouck is 16-10-0 and 3.22. The trade rumors continue because few teams have such a good pair of goaltenders. The theory is that with their best shot at the Stanley Cup since they reached the finals in 1979, the Rangers could trade Vanbiesbrouck for one or two skaters to add the scoring and checking depth they will need in the later rounds.
Vanbiesbrouck remains on good terms with Richter and he is philosophical about his predicament.
 
'It's Strictly Business'
 "It's strictly business and you can't let your business relationship interfere with the personal side," he said. "I definitely do not want to leave. I don't think the grass is going to be greener on the other side. This team is very chemically balanced right now. I would hate to be the guy to lessen the chemistry."
Vanbiesbrouck is playing out the option year of his contract. He could move to another team next season on his own, depending on the free-agency rules of the collective bargaining agreement now being discussed.
"Economically, I have to do what is best for my family," he said. "They always come first."
 
 
SLAP SHOTS
 Coach ROGER NEILSON of the Rangers said MIKE RICHTER has "a little muscle pull" in his thigh and might practice Thursday for the first time in a week. He could play Friday in Washington, Neilson said. The backup at practice Tuesday was BORIS ROUSSON, up from Binghamton. . . . The team scrimmaged for the first time this season, with uniformed officials and a scoreboard clock. . . . MIKE GARTNER didn't skate because of a sore knee and Neilson said "we're not going to take any chances" by bringing him back too soon.
Defenseman PAUL COFFEY has pulled a hip muscle and will miss the Pittsburgh Penguins' game Wednesday night with the Rangers. Coffey joined MARIO LEMIEUX and JAROMIR JAGR on the sideline. Lemieux has a herniated back muscle and Jagr has been suspended for bumping a referee. "I pulled it about a week ago, and it's not getting any better," Coffey said Tuesday after missing practice in Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE THAW;
'We Have to Do It With Manufacturing'

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
"I think the U.S. has every reason to be extremely proud of what it's accomplished over the last 50 years. We've done tremendous things for the world. Now we have to think about ourselves a little, but not step totally away from the world issues. The unfortunate thing is that as we've been altruistic, other economic regions, particularly Europe and the Pacific rim, have been able to focus their energies on economic competitiveness, so we find ourselves disadvantaged.
 "The little corner of the world that I'm interested in changing is manufacturing capability. The United States has lost its ability to manufacture competitive products today. It's particularly true when we're talking of high-volume, low-cost manufacturing, the kind of thing that has made TV's and VCR's so popular today. 
 "We don't know how to design a product; We Don't know how to manufacture it once it's designed. This is our biggest technological problem. The answer is to get a group of ocmpanies together, involve the Government and cooperate in systemic and generic manufacturing. If we don't rebuild our industry, we can't remain a leading country. We can't do it with nuclear weapons now. We have to do it with manufacturing.
 "The big science projects we're thinking about are good ones. But they should be global projects. The human genome. The superconducting supercollider. The manned exploration of Mars is something we can't pass up. But those are things we ought to do as a planet. We don't have to be macho and do it ourselves any more."

HEADLINE: ALBERTVILLE '92;
Plan to Share Sites Seems a Long Stretch

BYLINE: By ALLAN GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COURCHEVEL, France, Feb. 4

 BODY:
To help offset the surging cost of staging the Olympics, future Games may be held in several regions of a country or in even more than one country, the president of the International Olympic Committee said today.
But one city would continue to have overall responsibility for an Olympics, said Juan Antonio Samaranch, in a speech at the opening ceremony of the committee's 98th session. 
 In the speech, Samaranch also said that the Olympic movement's primary concern in the future would be insuring that the environment is protected, attempting to defuse growing criticism of the way in which some Olympic sites are constructed.
Olympic Games cost host cities and countries hundreds of millions of dollars and it is a constant struggle to break even.
Several towns in the Savoy region here nearly went bankrupt by renovation expenses in preparation for the Albertville Winter Games, which begin Saturday and are stretched over an area of more than 600 square miles.
 
Questions Arise
 Samaranch's idea will to some extent be tested in these Games. But the possibility of an Olympics that extends beyond national borders with venues spread even farther apart raises questions about whether visitors will support Olympic Games where events could be hundreds of miles apart, and whether intraregion or international cooperation is even realistic.
Also reinforced is the idea that the huge worldwide television audience that Olympic Games attract is becoming more important than the convenience of people who come to watch the Games in person or the sense of community that evolves at Games where participants are close to one another.
Already, the possibility of spectator disenchantment has been raised in these Games.
"In choosing the Savoy town and the whole Tarentaise Valley behind it," Samaranch said, "the International Olympic Committee knew what it was letting itself, and the organizers, in for."
There are 13 Olympic venues sprawled over an area nearly twice the area of New York City. The Olympic sites include 53 miles from Albertville, the site of opening and closing ceremonies as well as skating events, to Val d'Isere, where most Alpine skiing competition will be held.
 
Catching a Lift
 Few people disagree that it is an unwieldy arrangement. Traffic can be a problem here in the best of weather, but it remains to be seen how smoothly the Games will proceed in conditions like today, when snow fell and the fastest way to get around was on a ski lift.
But Samaranch today applauded the Albertville organizing committee for overcoming obstacles posed by geography, economics and politics and said its work had "served us well by opening up new possibilities."
Addressing another issue of increasing importance to the Olympic Committee, Samaranch pledged that environmental concerns would be taken into account when cities were selected for Olympic Games. Committee reports on candidate cities will contain a section on ecological impact.
 
'Attached to Nature'
 "The Olympic movement has a very clear position on the subject: We are very deeply attached to nature," Samaranch said. "Our entire culture is rooted in it. It is and has always been in nature that sport can thrive most happily. This is especially true of snow and ice sports."
Samaranch noted that the committee had altered its construction plans for an Olympic museum in Lausanne, Switzerland, to save a hundred-year-old oak tree. Nonetheless, advocates for the environment would assert that the committee's position is rather late in coming.

HEADLINE: Toward a Policy That's No Longer Foreign

BYLINE: By Roger Morris; Roger Morris, author of "Richard Milhous Nixon: The Rise of an American Politician," was on the staff of the National Security Council under Presidents Johnson and Nixon.

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M.

 BODY:
As is the case with all triumphs, America's cold war victory brings with it new difficulties. None is more troubling than the gathering irrelevance of U.S. foreign policy.
Militarily, America has emerged unrivaled, yet much of our arsenal is destabilizing, unusable and irrelevant in new tasks of national security. Economically, the Soviet defeat is complete, yet the cold war era also devoured our own productivity, real income and competitiveness, leaving a malignant gap between rich and poor and disgraceful and dangerous social conditions. Politically, we led a successful anti-Soviet alliance, yet the victors now bicker, with no collective security against a threatening depletion of environment and resources. 
 Not least are the moral costs: abroad, a bitter legacy of our many interventions; at home, a democracy diminished by national security demagogy and extra-constitutional acts, still governed by garrison-state conformity and myopia. America is neither the power nor the ideal that began the cold war 45 years ago.
Ominously, the real global revolution of our epoch is only beginning. We now face simultaneous upheavals that are far more momentous than the Communist challenge: in technology, weapons proliferation, population growth and migration, economic and political aspiration, national disintegration, resource scarcity and environmental decay -- all culminations of the old imperial, industrial orders that symbolically climaxed in the fall of the Soviet Union. It is indeed a new world, yet without its own order -- or an American policy for living securely within it.
Our victory at least releases us from a Faustian choice between ideals and interests, principle and pragmatism. In the cold war, we often sacrificed what was right for what was expedient. A redeeming irony of this new era is that its realities make principles pragmatic and ideals not only affordable but essential. National security in the post-cold war period comes with policy that is no longer foreign.
In a properly enlightened Washington, that policy would rest on a new trinity of military, economic and political-scientific security.
Militarily, the U.S. would forge ahead of the post-Soviet commonwealth in reducing strategic and conventional arms. To hoard a vast nuclear advantage amid Russian decline would be a Versailles-like peace, provoking eventual revision. To prevent that tragedy, we would go well beyond current negotiations that leave America's preponderance unredressed. America would initiate sweeping cuts in strategic weapons, sponsor dismantling of superpower and allied arsenals and set a timetable for verified demilitarization of the cold war victor as well as vanquished.
We would spur a new coalition for similar elimination of the nuclear Saturday Night specials: the existing or would-be arsenals of South Africa, Syria, Israel, China, India, Pakistan, Argentina, Brazil, the two Koreas and Iran as well as Iraq. Nothing so threatens peace as these anachronistic, apocalyptic weapons, relics of a vanished era.
We would recognize that conventional arms also consume our common future. The U.S. would cease trafficking in 40 percent of the world's munitions, stop giving or loaning $100 billion for military purchases, press Russia to embargo its share of the two-thirds of the arms trade we conduct together. On a planet where poor nations squander $50 billion a year on weapons, we would shed old military clients and quarantine arms merchants as we once checked fascist and Communist aggressors. And with billions of dollars saved by that new containment, America would invest in equally essential commercial security.
Economically, we would respond to a multipolar world with international trade and domestic industrial policies as concerted as was our commitment in the cold war. Gauging the mercantilist policies of our partner-competitors, their discipline of capital and labor, we would mount a comprehensive public investment strategy, promoting a new preparedness economically, educationally and fiscally.
America would continue its devotion to free trade, yet would strategically manage domestic markets and international businesses, preventing the exploitation of people and the environment at home and abroad as a matter of national interest. We would understand that security depends not only on a dynamic domestic economy but on the well-being of all nations.
We would see clearly that we cannot live safely in a world where four billion to five billion people are excluded from economic opportunity, where there persists an immense transfer of wealth from poor countries to rich, where third world babies are grown on farms to provide organ transplants for first world customers, where 11 million children die every year and there are 200 new corpses each minute in what the World Health Organization calls a "silent genocide" of preventable famine and disease, where the smoking shantytowns of the forgotten surround shrinking enclaves of affluence.
Washington would promote worldwide reinvestment in human capital, in education, jobs and land reform in the poorer nations. Using the billions now spent on third world arms, it would be a bargain, high dividend purchase of new security: international economic justice and the resulting stability would create vast new markets for U.S. goods and services.
As a third principle, the U.S. would organize a collective body to oversee environmental action, with planetary management of resources and technology. This world alliance would mobilize scientific and managerial talent to confront crises of climate and conservation, population and pollution. It would address dangerous imbalances of technology and resources, mass population migrations and the spurting growth of sovereignties.
Like cold war alliances, such a collective would be integral to U.S. security. It would epitomize international cooperation amid exploding nationalism and open new avenues for U.S. science, technology and business.
World revolutions now surround a Washington that is paying lip service to change, yet mired in spent missions -- bureaucracies defying the death of their raison d'etre. A stagnant Foreign Service was crudely politicized in the Reagan-Bush years. Exposed by recent hearings, the C.I.A. stands derelict in insight and integrity. For senior officialdom, Republicans draw on stock-option bureaucrats revolving between public office and consulting for the highest bidder, and the Democrats from a similarly dubious if dogged regime-in-waiting.
Intellectually, our security needs in the 1990's are plain -- new sensibility to the cultural, demographic, economic and environmental waves breaking over us, a fresh conceptualization of diversity and globalism. That creativity makes obsolete a venal establishment. Above all, national security requires a more open, representative foreign policy, a new generation of thinkers and doers.
We may continue to have a divided, poisoned planet, to remain a debt- and caste-ridden America, for a while at least. Or we may choose an era of secure diversity, equitable endowment, true community.
Policy no longer foreign would fulfill that poignant promise of George Washington, of an America not safe or prosperous by what it possessed but in what it was -- "a nation," he hoped, "which would have a meliorating influence on all mankind."

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Evan's Two Moms

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Evan has two moms. This is no big thing. Evan has always had two moms -- in his school file, on his emergency forms, with his friends. "Ooooh, Evan, you're lucky," they sometimes say. "You have two moms." It sounds like a sitcom, but until last week it was emotional truth without legal bulwark. That was when a judge in New York approved the adoption of a 6-year-old boy by his biological mother's lesbian partner. Evan. Evan's mom. Evan's other mom. A kid, a psychologist, a pediatrician. A family.
The matter of Evan's two moms is one in a series of events over the last year that lead to certain conclusions. A Minnesota appeals court granted guardianship of a woman left a quadriplegic in a car accident to her lesbian lover, the culmination of a seven-year battle in which the injured woman's parents did everything possible to negate the partnership between the two. A lawyer in Georgia had her job offer withdrawn after the state Attorney General found out she and her lesbian lover were planning a marriage ceremony; she's brought suit. The computer company Lotus announced that the gay partners of employees would be eligible for the same benefits as spouses. 
 Add to these public events the private struggles, the couples who go from lawyer to lawyer to approximate legal protections their straight counterparts take for granted, the AIDS survivors who find themselves shut out of their partners' dying days by biological family members and shut out of their apartments by leases with a single name on the dotted line, and one solution is obvious.
Gay marriage is a radical notion for straight people and a conservative notion for gay ones. After years of being sledgehammered by society, some gay men and lesbian women are deeply suspicious of participating in an institution that seems to have "straight world" written all over it.
But the rads of 20 years ago, straight and gay alike, have other things on their minds today. Family is one, and the linchpin of family has commonly been a loving commitment between two adults. When same-sex couples set out to make that commitment, they discover that they are at a disadvantage.
No joint tax returns. No health insurance coverage for an uninsured partner. No survivor's benefits from Social Security. None of the automatic rights, privileges and responsibilities society attaches to a marriage contract. In Madison, Wis., a couple who applied at the Y with their kids for a family membership were turned down because both were women. It's one of those small things that can make you feel small.
Some took marriage statutes that refer to "two persons" at their word and applied for a license. The results were court decisions that quoted the Bible and embraced circular argument: marriage is by definition the union of a man and a woman because that is how we've defined it.
No religion should be forced to marry anyone in violation of its tenets, although ironically it is now only in religious ceremonies that gay people can marry, performed by clergy who find the blessing of two who love one another no sin. But there is no secular reason that we should take a patchwork approach of corporate, governmental and legal steps to guarantee what can be done simply, economically, conclusively and inclusively with the words "I do."
"Fran and I chose to get married for the same reasons that any two people do," said the lawyer who was fired in Georgia. "We fell in love; we wanted to spend our lives together." Pretty simple.
Consider the case of Loving v. Virginia, aptly named. At the time, 16 states had laws that barred interracial marriage, relying on natural law, that amorphous grab bag for justifying prejudice. Sounding a little like God throwing Adam and Eve out of paradise, the trial judge suspended the one-year sentence of Richard Loving, who was white, and his wife, Mildred, who was black, provided they got out of the state of Virginia.
In 1967 the Supreme Court found such laws to be unconstitutional. Only 25 years ago and it was a crime for a black woman to marry a white man. Perhaps 25 years from now we will find it just as incredible that two people of the same sex were not entitled to legally commit themselves to one another. Love and commitment are rare enough; it seems absurd to thwart them in any guise.

HEADLINE: Indonesia Acts on East Timor Killings

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Tiananmen in East Timor" (editorial, Jan. 21) leaves the erroneous impression that the response of the Indonesian Government to the tragic killings in Dili last Nov. 12 has been the same as that of Beijing: arrogant indifference and domestic cover-up. This is not the case, as you report Dec. 27 and Dec. 29, and as has been covered in, for instance, the Far Eastern Economic Review. 
 An independent, civilian-dominated investigating commission reported to President Suharto of Indonesia that the Army was culpable for the use of "excessive force" and lack of discipline in crowd control. The commission's version of the Dili killings was much more like that of the eyewitnesses and supported the conclusions of Gov. Mario Carrascalao of East Timor, who blamed the military.
Unlike the stony intransigence of China's masters, President Suharto, on receiving the report, instructed that it be released to the press. Within two days he had sacked the military commander in Timor and the Bali-based military commander of the military district under which the East Timor command falls. Furthermore, a separate commission has been set up to determine whether and what charges should be brought against individual military personnel before a military tribunal.
Perhaps the United States position on the killings at least partly reflects Indonesia's prompt investigation and assignment of ultimate responsibility to senior military officers, rather than, as you suggest, cold-war concerns about offending a large, friendly Asian country.
We can hope that the Indonesian self-examination of the Dili tragedy will prompt a broader review of development and integrationist policy in the province, as well as addressing the question of civil-military relations.
 
DONALD E. WEATHERBEE
Donald S. Russell Professor
of Contemporary Foreign Policy
University of South Carolina
Columbia, S.C., Jan. 22, 1992

HEADLINE: Theater in Review

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:

Chess
Masters Theater
310 Riverside Drive, at 103d Street
Manhattan
Through Feb. 23
 
Music by Benny Andersson and Bjorn Ulvaeus; book and lyrics by Tim Rice; directed by David Taylor; scenery by Tony Castrigno; lighting by John Hastings; costumes by Deborah Rooney; new arrangements and orchestrations by Phil Reno; sound by Creative Audio Design; production stage manager, Doug Fogel; assistant director and choreographer, Madeline Paul. Presented by the Artists' Perspective, in association with Chess Players Ltd.
WITH: Bob Frisch, Jan Horvath, Patrick Jude, Kathleen Rowe McAllen, J. Mark McVey and Ray Walker. 
 "Chess," the board-game musical, is working its way back to a record album. After previous elaborate incarnations in London and on Broadway, the show reopened Off Broadway in what is supposed to be the new, improved, definitive version. It is shorter, which is the most complimentary thing that can be said about this continually misfiring musical.
This is, as you may remember, a show by Tim Rice without Andrew Lloyd Webber, with music written by Benny Andersson and Bjorn Ulvaeus. When "Chess" was first done in London in 1986 it had a certain novelty, but it was already dated in its treatment of global politics. Today, after the breakup of the Soviet Union, it is a lukewarm leftover of the cold war.
Unless one has seen an earlier, more detailed production, it might be difficult to know what all the singing-shouting is about. Mr. Rice has jettisoned Richard Nelson's Broadway book and its top-heavy subplot in favor of a show that has more singing and less speaking. The simplification highlights the score, which is a pop pastiche that veers between the pleasant and the argumentative while evoking familiar strains. But because of the shorthand style of storytelling, the politics seems even more confusing.
While trying to be economical, David Taylor's production becomes reductive. In London, the set was an enormous hydraulic chessboard, which was raised and lowered to symbolize the tilt in the power struggle (obvious but eyecatching). On Broadway, the characters played hide and seek around monolithic towers. Now the stage is dominated by a bleacherlike staircase, which might be used for a touring company of "The Will Rogers Follies" but is pointless as a background for "Chess."
Ray Walker and J. Mark McVey, who play the two chessmen, are stronger at singing than at acting. Kathleen Rowe McAllen, as the woman involved with both men, gives the evening's sharpest performance. "I Know Him So Well," the duet she sings with Jan Horvath, is, as before, the most memorable number in the score.
Surrounding the musical is a mountain of portentousness. Anthems are sung about chess as if it were the French Revolution, which is more dramatic weight than the show can support. After repeated attempts, it should be time for Mr. Rice and his collaborators to resign from this match and move on to more rewarding musical territory.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: CHESS (PLAY)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: Market Place;
No Faults Allowed In This Business

BYLINE: By Glenn Rifkin

DATELINE: MARLBORO, Mass.

 BODY:
IN an industry where profit-killing competition and slumping business are the norm, Stratus Computer Inc. continues to defy the odds by stringing up quarter after quarter of solid profits.
Stratus has quietly and steadily built itself into the second-largest maker of "fault tolerant" computers. Such machines are designed with enough backup components that they are never supposed to fail, as most conventional computers occasionally do, and they have become a mainstay in businesses where uninterrupted computer service is essential. Automatic teller machines, electronic-funds transfers and Wall Street trading operations all rely on fault-tolerant machines.
For the fourth quarter ending Dec. 29, Stratus's earnings rose 30 percent, compared with the corresponding quarter in 1990. For the full year in 1991,profits jumped 34 percent, to $49.7 million, on revenues of $448.6 million. 
 Since going public in 1983, Stratus, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol SRA, has not had a single losing quarter. Analysts see no end soon to that run. "Stratus can grow 20 percent per year for the next four years," said David Wu, an analyst with S. G. Warburg & Company. "They survive recessions very well."
The company that created the first fault-tolerant computers, Tandem Computer in Cupertino, Calif., holds more than 70 percent of the $2.3 billion market, according to John B. Jones of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. But Stratus, founded in 1980, has steadily whittled away at Tandem's lead, growing from a 10 percent share in 1985 to 24 percent in 1991.
"Tandem was in the business for a good six years before Stratus ever shipped its first system," Mr. Jones said. "I expect them to continue to gain market share against Tandem."
Stratus's own sales force sells more than half the company's machines, but the company also has agreements with I.B.M., Olivetti, NEC and Ericsson, among others, to resell Stratus computers under their own labels.
Even as demand grows for fault-tolerant systems, companies are willing to pay a premium price for them, compared with conventional computers. "Any system where the computer has direct contact with the customer is a candidate for fault-tolerant computers," Mr. Jones said. "People are willing to pay 15 percent to 25 percent more for continuous availability."
Despite the premium, Mr. Wu said, the cost of fault-tolerant computers is falling, enticing more companies to take a look at the technology they once considered too expensive. The starting price for Stratus machines is $50,000, though high-end machines can cost $9 million or more.
The telecommunications market has become a major target for Stratus and Tandem in the last two years, as telephone companies are increasingly using the machines to provide call waiting, voice mail and other new network services. Stratus has made strong inroads into that market, which company executives see as a potential $4 billion to $8 billion market in the next four years.
But Stratus also faces increased competition from giants like Digital Equipment, Hewlett-Packard, Fujitsu and Hitachi, which have all entered the fault-tolerant market in recent years. To maintain its pace, Stratus has pushed its technology in the direction of "open systems," the computer industry trend to make different brands of computers work together.
Moreover, Stratus last year began shipping computers with more advanced components, based on the technology known as RISC, for reduced instruction set computing. As part of this move, Stratus is shifting its entire product line away from Motorola microprocessors to RISC chips made by Intel. Customers of Status's RISC-based systems will be able to use the same hardware to run either the company's VOS software operating system or the more widely used Unix operating system to control the computer's internal operations.
John Adams, an analyst with Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston, said Stratus's biggest challenge was a management concern: "how to fight 'creeping large company-itis.' "
To ward off corporate sprawl, William Foster, Stratus's founder, president and chief executive, has built a fiscally conservative corporate culture. The company has incurred little long-term debt, accrued $100 million in cash and has fought the uncontrolled growth that is now haunting larger competitors like the Digital Equipment Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation.
Gary E. Haroian, senior vice president and general manager of Stratus, said: "We want to avoid reducing employment like so many others have had to do. With our profits up 30 percent last year, we only added 100 people to the payroll."
Mr. Jones of Montgomery Securities rates Stratus a 'buy,' predicting that the stock will outperform the market, with the price rising 10 percent within six months. He estimates earnings per share at $2.70 for 1992, up 22 percent. Mr. Wu rates the stock a "hold," waiting for a small price correction. "It's trading at $47 now and should be at $60 in 12 months," he said. "But the rewards are not high enough to put out a 'buy' just yet."

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Despite Slump in Atlanta, Mall Plans Are Under Way

BYLINE: By Ford Risley

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
THE construction of a big new shopping mall and the expansion or renovation of five others are among the few bright spots in Atlanta's slumping retail construction market.
The Homart Development Company and the JMB Retail Properties Company have begun construction of North Point Mall, a 1.3-million-square-foot center in suburban Atlanta. The project, which is expected to be completed in mid-1993, will be anchored by Rich's, Sears and J. C. Penney. 
 Elsewhere, two of the city's best-known malls, Lenox Square and Phipps Plaza, are getting big face lifts. Three other suburban malls around Atlanta are also being expanded.
In general, however, retail construction in Atlanta has slowed drastically. Despite the city's continuing growth, overbuilding, tightening credit and continuing retailer failures have led to a prolonged slump in the construction of new shopping centers.
Only 14 new centers of varying sizes, with a total construction value of $52 million, were begun in metropolitan Atlanta in 1990. That was down for the third straight year and less than half the number of centers started in 1989, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers.
Figures are not yet available for 1991, but shopping center construction is known to have dropped again, said Terry Sullivan, vice president for retail services at Coldwell Banker Commercial in Atlanta. "New construction has come to a virtual standstill," he said.
North Point will be the first new mall to open in Atlanta since 1986. The mall is being built near the town of Alpharetta, one of the hottest growth areas in metropolitan Atlanta. The population of the mall's trade area doubled in the 1980's to about 240,000 and is expected to increase to 295,000 by 1995, said Jack Oliaro, head of Homart's Atlanta office.
Even with such growth, the mall could not begin construction until a bankruptcy court judge gave permission for Rich's to put a store in the mall. Rich's parent company, Federated Department Stores Inc. of Cincinnati, is expected to emerge from bankruptcy as early as this week.
Mr. Sullivan said malls like North Point were dependent on finding big retailers to anchor them, and the dwindling number of retailers is making the task more difficult. He cited, for example, R. H. Macy & Company, which filed for bankruptcy protection last week. There are Macy's stores in most of Atlanta's big malls, and in the past the retailer could have been counted on to move into a mall like North Point, Mr. Sullivan said.
The entry of a new retailer to the Atlanta market, Parisian Inc., a department store chain in the Southeast that is based in Birmingham, Ala., permitted the long-delayed expansion of Phipps Plaza to proceed.
Phipps, an affluent mall in the city's Buckhead area, is getting a $140 million expansion and renovation that will nearly double its size to 827,000 square feet, said Jeffery R. Jones, development manager for Compass Retail. The mall, which is anchored by Lord & Taylor and Saks Fifth Avenue, is getting a new three-level wing that will have a Parisian store and a 50,000-square-foot AMC Entertainment Inc. movie theater as its main tenants. The work is to be completed by fall.
Across the road from Phipps Plaza on Peachtree Street -- Atlanta's best-known thoroughfare -- Lenox Square is getting a $40 million renovation, although no new space is being added. Work on the 1.4-million-square-foot mall, the largest in Atlanta, will begin later this year and be completed in late 1993, said Jane Fortenberry, vice president of the New York-based Corporate Property Investors, owners of Lenox.
Ms. Fortenberry said it was a coincidence and not a response to Phipps Plaza's expansion that Lenox was now having a big renovation. "We've been working on this for several years," she said.
Three other suburban Atlanta malls owned either in whole or part by Corporate Property Investors are also expanding this year, Ms. Fortenberry said.
Gwinnett Place and Town Center malls are both getting 130,000-square-foot Parisian stores as well as 75,000 square feet of additional retail space. Work on Town Center is scheduled for completion in the fall of this year, while construction at Gwinnett Place will be finished in the fall of 1993.
Another Corporate Property Investors property, Northlake Mall, is getting a 10,000-square-foot food court. Completion is expected later this year.
The addition of so much new space to the market has developers scrambling to find tenants. Although the recession has hampered their efforts in some cases, mall officials expressed confidence that the space would be leased.
"There's been a lot of tenant interest in this mall," said Mr. Oliaro of Homart. "But if you asked me if I would rather be doing this when we are not in a recession, the answer would be yes."

HEADLINE: A Garland of Freeze-Dried Vegetables

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
DON'T eat those strawberries!
To the world of dried roses and stuffed owls, add freeze-dried strawberries, asparagus and bibb lettuce made into topiaries, nosegays and garlands. 
 Lois Muller, the owner of Juniper Farms, a floral design shop in Locust Valley, L.I., freeze-dries fruits, vegetables and flowers. She then treats them with chemicals so that they last at least a year, or, as Mrs. Muller said, "indefinitely, as long as they're kept out of direct sunlight and handled like any other fragile piece." Once the food is treated, Mrs. Muller arranges it into topiaries, wreaths and still lifes in baskets.
She introduced her designs at the Winter Antiques Show last month. Thomas K. Woodard and Blanche Greenstein, antiques dealers in New York, asked her to fill two 19th-century clay urns with mounds of strawberries topped with gardenias, all on a base of artichokes entwined with raffia. "It looked like an extraordinary dessert," Mr. Woodard said.
Mrs. Muller chooses strawberries that are bright red but "not too mature, not too ripe, because you want the least moisture." She puts 5,000 at a time in her freeze dryer, the same sort of machine used by taxidermists for preserving carcasses and by hospitals for saving tissue samples.
Within eight hours, the fruit is frozen at minus 20 degrees Fahrenheit; the machine also vacuums the moisture from the fruit so that it does not spoil. Then Mrs. Muller treats the fruit with chemicals. She will not say what chemicals she uses, other than to say, "some are glosses, but I don't use polyurethane."
She designs topiaries of strawberries topped with gardenias ($650) or cranberry beans resting in a basket of asparagus ($375). She has also made fireplace screens of roses and artichoke leaves and lined a platter with bibb lettuce and roses.
"Even if freeze-drying flowers has been done before, it hasn't been done with this great amount of taste," Mr. Woodard said. "Besides, in a recession, it's an answer to replacing fresh flowers, which are expensive."
Juniper Farms can be reached at (516) 674-6080.

HEADLINE: 23 Charged With Bribery At Javits Hall

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Twenty-three men, including two former state police officers, were accused yesterday of charges of union corruption, extortion, fraud, thefts and violence that authorities said inflated exhibition costs and discouraged business at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
Almost from the day the crystalline-enclosed center opened on Manhattan's West Side in 1986, exhibitors have complained of shakedowns by employees, thefts and excessive labor costs. The indictments unsealed yesterday are the first significant criminal charges brought against union officials and employees connected to the center. 
Prosecutors in the Manhattan District Attorney's Office who conducted the investigation said there were strong indications of the control of organized crime at the center.
Among the main allegations in the indictments brought by a state grand jury in Manhattan were that a theatrical union official got a $27,000 bribe from a show manager for a sweetheart contract to permit the employment of nonunion workers; that teamsters union members were paid $1,500 by a trucker after threatening to block deliveries and that a teamsters official extorted $1,000 to allow flowers to be delivered to a trade show display.
 
Information Leaks
 A former New York State Police lieutenant, James F. Tansey Sr., was charged with leaking information in 1990 to targets of the convention center investigation that wiretaps and listening devices had been installed in a teamsters union office in the convention center. Prosecutors in the Manhattan District Attorney's office said the premature disclosure of the secret eavesdropping devices might have compromised the investigation.
Another former state police officer, Vernon J. Smith, a senior investigator who in 1990 had been in charge of state police detectives assigned to the convention inquiry, was indicted on charges of using stolen state government credit cards to make personal telephone calls.
"These things happen," Lieut. Col. Michael J. Hulihan, a spokesman for the state police, said of the arrests of the two dismissed officers. "It never makes you feel good."
The 23 defendants pleaded not guilty at arraignments in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Ten were charged with using fictitious identities to evade income taxes or to hold "no-show" jobs at the center while obtaining unemployment or disability benefits.
In interviews last year, companies that organize trade shows said that some costs at the center were twice as high as in any other city.
One example often cited was an $80 charge to plug in a lamp and payments to carpenters and teamsters of a day's wages of $150 even if they only worked one hour.
At a news conference in District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau's office in lower Manhattan yesterday, the center's president and chief executive officer, Fabian G. Palomino, said that he was renegotiating contracts with five major unions to reduce costs by changing work rules on the number of employees that must be hired for different jobs and minimum wage scales.
To encourage more business at shows, Mr. Palomino said he had asked the unions to permit exhibitors to assemble by themselves small portable displays.
Mr. Palomino, who was appointed to the top post in January 1991, said the center recently instituted security measures, including undercover investigators, television surveillance and payroll audits to deter crime and corruption.
The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, in a civil-racketeering suit filed in 1990 against the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, the major union for carpenters in the city, described the center as a hiring hall for mobsters and former convicts.
"There is a strong indication of organized-crime involvement at the center and this investigation is not over," said Michael G. Cherkasky, who is the head of the Manhattan District Attorney's Investigations Division.

HEADLINE: NEWARK JOURNAL;
Meeting the Neighbors, Old and New

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Residents of the Central Ward were skeptical when police officers and state troopers moved into a dilapidated apartment in a small building there 13 months ago, saying they would work with tenants to drive out drug dealers.
But not any more. Now, some of those same skeptics have embraced their new neighbors. 
 "Before, we lived in fear for our lives," said Mikki Parker, a 23-year-old with a 5-year-old son, who grew up in the Central Ward of Newark. "Street shootings were part of our daily routine. Before, we didn't communicate, didn't know our neighbors. But once we began talking and working together, we were able to pull together and take back our community."
Working together and taking back the community were the goals when the officers and state troopers moved into the apartment as part of Operation Homestead, a program to rid neighborhoods of drugs. The program is part of Fighting Back, a $40 million national initiative covering 13 cities and financed mainly by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, based in Princeton. Fighting Back will also provide drug treatment and education, offer training in parenting skills and help develop long-range plans for economic improvements.
So far, Operation Homestead in Newark seems to be paying off, said Lieut. Thomas Brennan of the Newark Police Department. Police statistics show that assaults, thefts and vandalism are down and that drug arrests are up, although thieves did break into Operation Homestead's apartment last summer and steal bulletproof vests, video equipment and anti-auto-theft locks. Most of the stolen equipment was recovered because tenants identified the thieves.
Tenants measure progress by the changes in their everyday lives. Residents say they are no longer afraid to walk their dogs after dark, children ride their bicycles along the streets and there has not been a robbery attempt at the corner grocery store in a year.
"I look out the window, and I see kids playing because their parents are more comfortable these days letting them go out into the neighborhood," said Richard Grossklaus, a homeowner.
The police and state troopers occupy their apartment at 719 Martin Luther King Boulevard in eight-hour shifts for 16 hours a day. The officers say they now have a keener understanding of tenants' problems. When the police officers moved into their apartment, for example, they did not have lights. Things are not that much better now. The ceiling still sags, and the walls still need painting.
To help win acceptance, the police gave parties for the neighborhood children at Halloween and Christmas. They also helped clean up a debris-strewn lot and put up backboards for basketball. (Two were vandalized within 24 hours.)
Because parents were afraid to let children walk to a nearby recreation center to swim, the police marked out a safe route, which they patrol. They added bright outdoor lights in an alley to discourage drug dealers and users. But mainly they just made themselves available and highly visible.
Many small gestures helped form bonds between tenants and the police, said Sgt. Pat Ciccone, 45 years old, who used to teach sixth grade in the Newark schools.
"The way this community has come together is vital because eventually residents will have to depend on their own resources," he said. "We cannot afford to be a permanent crutch."
Tenants help tenants as never before. Ms. Parker, for one, persuaded an addicted mother to seek treatment; that woman then induced another neighbor to get treatment. Another resident, Lateefah Baskerville, works days caring for children at a local hospital but is also studying at Essex County College to become a drug-treatment counselor because she wants to help her neighbors.
"I celebrated my 34th birthday last week and my 5th anniversary free of drugs," she said. "I really have reason to celebrate."
Fighting Back builds on the support of such people, said Irene James, the program's director. "They are what I call natural helpers," she said.
The police role in "Fighting Back" was never conceived solely as a law-enforcement activity, said Barbara Wright Bell, chief executive of the Boys' and Girls' Clubs of Newark, which helped develop a network of more than 150 individuals, Government representatives, businesses and neighborhood groups to help forge a program qualifying for assistance from the Johnson Foundation.
"The police were going into the community to become partners," she said. "We gave them someone on the other side to partner with."
